fields.headline: Smith leads American revolution
fields.standfirst: English striker set to kick off women's league Stateside
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison: Football, or soccer, takes America by storm, part 93. But this time it could be different as English striker Kelly Smith prepares to kick off the women's league in the USA.
fields.body:
Kelly Smith cuts in from the right, works her way across the edge of the penalty area with her left foot and releases a half-hit drive that goes wide of the post.

A little later on this filthy, dank night somewhere in back-of-beyond Pennsylvania, the England international repeats the manoeuvre, crowning it this time with an unintentional floater that goes miles high and wide.

As the knots of spectators at the 0-0 draw between 22-year-old Smith's team, the Philadelphia Charge, and Penn State University can be only too keenly aware, this match does not matter. Why, there is little or no effing and blinding from the opposing dug-outs and less on the pitch.

But this is, none the less, a warm-up - if such it can be termed in these conditions - for a grand gamble: football, or soccer, takes America by storm, part 93. This time though it is different; it is an attempt to capitalise on success rather than the assumption that football is bound to become popular in the United States on the grounds that it is already just about everywhere else.

The men's game is still struggling to find a niche in an American sporting life where it overlaps with baseball, basketball, ice hockey and the indigenous version of football, most of them sports that people actually like.

Major League Soccer, the men's professional league, has lost $250m (£176m) since it started five years ago - this season was greeted last weekend by crowds slightly lower than last year - and Octavio Zambrano, the coach of the MetroStars who play in New Jersey, says it might be 15 years before the sport makes a real impact (though, to be fair, he was having to find a way to manage Lothar Matthäus at the time he formulated this judgment).

The women's game has a chance to do better, founded on the optimism engendered by the national team's victory nearly two years ago in the Women's World Cup. Americans pay attention when their people win and no one doubts that the new league is the best of its kind in the world.

Smith's Philadelphia Charge are one of eight teams in the nation's first professional women's soccer organisation, a $64m (£45m) enterprise that shows its hand tomorrow with its first game, between the Bay Area CyberRays and Washington Freedom.

All have blood-pumping names. The others are the Atlanta Beat, Carolina Courage, New York Power, Boston Breakers and San Diego Spirit. But the Women's United Soccer Association has more sanguine projections for what it will take to establish a presence.

It believes that it can break even with ticket prices of about $11.50 (£8) and average crowds of 7,500. Players, in the land where money is supposed to talk so loud that nothing else can be heard, will receive salaries of between $24,000 and $85,000 for a season that lasts from April to August - or, for the best paid, not much more than a third of the money Michael Jordan receives in endorsements each day, three years after he last fired a competitive basketball.

So what's a nice girl from Watford doing in a place like this? "Football," says Kelly Smith, who, if she is to become a celebrity, is unlikely to do so on the strength of expansive advocacy for her sport.

The only Englishwoman in the league does not care to reveal what the Charge are paying her to play at the Villanova stadium, about 30 minutes from downtown Philadelphia. She has no use for distractions such as boyfriends: "I'm concentrating on soccer and playing to the best of my ability."

As a matter of diplomacy, she calls the game soccer when she is in the United States and football when she is in Britain. Smith, who is an Arsenal fan, has never seen the men's professional game in the US and basketball is the only American sport in which she has any interest: "The others are too boring."

Given the chance, she would like to live in California. The striker with a deft first touch, who won the first of her 22 caps for England when she was 16 - "very young" - will return to her home country when she is in her early 30s if there is a professional women's league by then.

To Mia Hamm, the unrivalled star of American women's football, has fallen the role of the league's evangelist, pumping up the volume and the visibility on news and talk shows.

But Smith, who won almost as many college sporting honours as she scored goals - 76 in 51 matches - for Seton Hall university, New Jersey, is not taciturn on every subject. "I always liked playing football with boys because I was good at it," she says, her right ankle packed in ice after the game against Penn State, whom the Charge might reasonably have been expected to trounce. "Nobody really spotted me. I played for a local boys' team until I got kicked off for being too good, because parents didn't like me making the boys look bad."

webTitle: SA soccer officials blamed for stadium disaster

fields.headline: SA soccer officials blamed for stadium disaster
fields.trailText: The South African government and football fans are blaming soccer officials for the country's worst sporting disaster, the death of 43 people in a stampede at a Johannesburg stadium on Wednesday night.
fields.body:
The South African government and football fans are blaming soccer officials for the country's worst sporting disaster, the death of 43 people in a stampede at a Johannesburg stadium on Wednesday night.

The sports minister, Ngconde Balfour, announced a judicial inquiry into the tragedy after saying earlier that inadequate preparations by the match organisers were to blame.

"Those South Africans who died there would not have died if proper arrangements had been put in place," he said.

The disaster, during a match between South Africa's two fiercest soccer rivals, Kaiser Chiefs and Orlando Pirates, the premier soccer league leaders, has been attributed in part to the decision to sell tickets in advance as a means of avoiding last-minute crowds.

But a series of other factors, from the timing of the match to a decision not to show it live on television, also contributed.

It has also emerged that a former league chief had warned it would be "suicidal" to play a major football match at night at the Ellis Park stadium, because the facility could not handle the crowds.

Three boys, aged 11, 13 and 17, were among the first 13 of the dead to be named. The identities of 30 others have yet to be made public. About 160 people were injured.

After an emergency meeting yesterday, the soccer authorities announced that all games would be postponed until after Easter and a disaster relief fund had been set up. But club and league officials declined to discuss the causes of the tragedy in advance of the judicial inquiry.

The stampede began about midway through the first half as thousands of angry fans who had been shut out of the packed stadium surged into the ground after hearing the crowd roar at an Orlando Pirates goal.

But the first signs of trouble were seen before the match. An experiment to persuade fans to buy tickets in the days before the match meant that a large number of seats were already sold when other supporters arrived expecting to get in.

In addition, many fans arrived late because the 8pm kick-off gave them barely enough time after work to travel from Soweto to the heart of Johannesburg.

Others were under the impression that the game would be shown live on television. When they discovered it was a delayed broadcast, thousands more headed for Ellis Park.

League officials said that even then only 57,000 tickets had been sold for the 60,000-seat stadium. But fans said some turnstile attendants were taking bribes to admit those without tickets and the stadium was clearly overflowing when the match began.

The organisers estimate that by the time the stampede began there were an additional 15,000 fans trying to get into the stadium, some of them with tickets.

Among the critics of the venue and timing of the match was a member of Orlando Pirates executive, Oupa Mabaso. "Pirates and Chiefs are the biggest soccer clubs in this country and to stage this kind of fixture in the middle of the week at night is despicable," he said. "Many people who support these clubs are working class and it is not safe holding the event at this time."

But the single biggest failing was poor security. The police say they were at the stadium only to prevent crime, not to control the crowd. A private security firm appears to have been unable to contain the stampede and resorted to teargas at one point.

The league's chief executive, Robin Petersen, said the league had drawn on the lessons of the disasters at Bradford and Hillsborough.

South African football, long tainted by corruption and incompetence, has been cleaned up considerably in recent years, in part because the country badly wants to host the World Cup. Mr Balfour said he did not believe the disaster would jeopardise his country's prospects of staging the competition.

fields.headline: Semi tough for teenager
fields.trailText: Livingston may have to use an untried teenager in goal in their first ever Scottish Cup semi-final.
fields.body:
Livingston may have to use an untried teenager in goal in their first ever Scottish Cup semi-final. Two of their senior goalkeepers are injured, another is cup-tied and an attempt to sign Dmitri Kharine on loan from Celtic was thwarted yesterday when it was revealed that the Russian international has a leg injury.

David McEwan, just turned 19, will start against Hibernian at Hampden Park tomorrow if Ian McCaldon fails to recover from a knee ligament strain.

Though the Livingston general manager Jim Leishman said yesterday that he had "no problem" giving McEwan the game, he made several attempts to find a more experienced replacement.

"Martin O'Neill was going to let us have Kharine on loan for the day," Leishman explained. "But I think I may have jumped the gun a bit. He has a slight calf strain."

Fiji are fired up for their daunting task tomorrow, when they take on Australia, 31-0 winners over American Samoa, in a World Cup qualifier at Coffs Harbour. They are angry that Australia's manager Frank Farina has claimed that they would be "kicking, punching and brawling to get a draw" tomorrow.

"They should show some respect," Fiji's coach Billy Singh said. "He's comparing us to animals and the players are upset."

fields.headline: National Theatre's high-class school play
fields.standfirst:
The Ramayana
National Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Ramayana
National Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
The bare stage area of the Olivier is surrounded by bits of tacked-together cardboard. Old beer crates, office chairs and plastic children's stools also figure. You get the feeling that if there were crowns they'd probably have fruit gums stuck in them for jewels.

This is the studied naivety of the Birmingham Rep's joyously inventive retelling of the legend of Prince Rama and his wife Sita, who is stolen away by the evil demon Ravana. It feels like a school play, albeit one done unbelievably well.

It demands that you join in the fun, embrace its tackiness. One of the musicians welcomes the audience and tries to get a bit of audience participation going. "This is not a panto," he declares - but in fact the evening is very like one. There are demons dressed in long red satin with gold lamé gloves, and Charlotte Bicknell as an evil temptress with a Madonna-style conical bra. The apes, which help Rama and his brother defeat Ravena and save Sita, monkey about to good clownish effect.

How much you enjoy it will depend on your taste for this kind of self-conscious playfulness. Take the ocean: the cast doesn't quite wave bits of aquamarine material up and down to represent the sea - instead they do a variation with blue pompoms that my teacher companion fully intends to steal for her next school assembly. But even if the childlike approach is sometimes irritating, it beats spending another evening in the National watching nothing but talking heads.

Indhu Rubasingham's production mixes spectacle with a clever inventiveness. The best "ooh-ah" moments are always the simplest, such as the beauty of the colours (saffron yellow and sky blue against milky white), or a bridge constructed entirely from beer crates, which allows Rama and his army of monkeys to walk across the sea. This is very effective, even if the logistics of the beer crates do demand two intervals when otherwise the entire piece could have been played in a little under two hours.

All the women in this piece come off badly, and it wouldn't have gone amiss if the unbearably smug Rama was sent up just a little. But this is a good-looking evening for the entire family to enjoy.

 Until April 21. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

fields.headline: Equitable Life completes board revamp
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Equitable Life yesterday attempted to draw a line under its troubled past by appointing a heavyweight new board.
fields.body:
Equitable Life yesterday attempted to draw a line under its troubled past by appointing a heavyweight new board.

The six new non-executive directors include Sir Philip Otton, a former court of appeal judge, and Andrew Threadgold, a former head of financial supervision at the Bank of England.

Equitable now has a completely new team at the top, untainted by the criticism that followed the crisis over guaranteed annuities which forced it to put itself up for sale and then close its doors to new business.

The company lost a House of Lords test case last year over its stance on guaranteed annuities which were sold as part of pension plans and left it with liabilities of £1.5bn.

It now has to formulate a compromise deal involving payments to people holding these guarantees and win approval for it from a majority of policyholders.

The six new directors, picked from 200 candidates, will replace non-executives who an nounced in December they would be resigning. Earlier this year, Vanni Treves was appointed as the new chairman and Charles Thomson was named chief executive.

The other four new directors are: Michael Pickard, formerly chief executive of mutual life insurer Royal London and now chairman of Mirror Group Newspapers pension trustees; David Adams, who is a non-executive director of occupational pensions regulator Opra; Peter Smith, a former senior partner at accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers; and Jean Wood, former Irish and UK chief executive of insurer Irish Life.

Mr Treves said the five action groups representing policyholders could still put forward one or more candidates for a seat on the board.

The directors will be paid £10,000 a year, and in addition each will be eligible for a fee of up to £15,000 after 12 months.

fields.headline: David Byrne makes a comeback
fields.standfirst:
David Byrne
Hanover Grand, London
****
fields.trailText:
David Byrne
Hanover Grand, London
****
fields.body:
When Talking Heads withered away in the late 1980s, not only were the careers of three of David Byrne's colleagues ruined but Byrne himself embarked upon a solo career that never quite lived up to his past. Now, though, he has renewed impetus: while nobody would compare his forthcoming album, Look Into the Eyeball, to his group, it is an almighty step forward and, live at least, he seems finally to be coming to terms with his history, mixing a well-chosen selection of old songs with new material.

What is startling is his appearance. He is dressed as a petrol pump attendant with DAVE (and no David is less "Dave" than Byrne) emblazoned on his workshirt. He is still slender and bug-eyed, with a disturbingly beautiful face. His hair is now grey. It rather becomes him.

There is a strangeness to Byrne. To the audience he plays the bumbling geek, goofily introducing songs. But he undermines his soundman ("really double-check this stuff"), who is doing a fine job. This becomes him less.

But the music is superlative. The unfamiliar fare is unindulgent and bristling with melody. The heartbreakingly beautiful Revolution stands proudly alone and The Accident - "the house where we used to live is destroyed by witnesses" - is a quietly ominous slice of suburban Americana.

Of the Talking Heads revisits, Byrne confesses that the glorious And She Was details an LSD trip; he sings the oft-repeated "same as it ever was" in Once in a Lifetime differently each time and allows the crowd to holler its self-revealing "my God, what have I done?" line with all their might. Wisely, he retains the essential structure of these songs, adding the manic percussion of his Brazilian solo period and, for the closing half of his allotted 60 minutes, a flamboyant string section.

He saves a cheeky surprise for the encore, covering Whitney Houston's I Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me) with straight-faced gusto. Byrne's rousing, non-sneering version underlines what a wonderful song it is. While he is not yet quite so loose-limbed to allow it on to an album, maybe the Scottish-born king of New York has a sense of joy after all.

fields.headline: The Necks
fields.standfirst:
Ocean 2, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Ocean 2, London
*****
fields.body:
One way to describe the Necks would be to say they are a trio: keyboard, bass and drums. Chris Abrahams plays the Ocean 2's grand piano with a loving touch. When he trills on a single low-register note at the beginning of their second hour-long set, you can hear tiny changes in its harmonic content, modulating like the filter sweep in an old synth.

Lloyd Swanton plays double bass, an orchestral one with a low extension. Drummer Tony Buck plays a modest kit with a single floor tom and a couple of ride cymbals. When he starts a hypnotic pattern on his hi-hat you marvel that someone can play so gently. Yet halfway through the set, after 30 minutes of slowly evolving improvisation, you are amazed that he can play so loudly with such subtlety.

What is both entirely new and entirely now about the Necks is their way of performing an hour of music in which everything changes very slowly and entirely logically. The Australian musicians have been together since 1989, and it appears that audiences have finally begun to "get it". They produce a post-jazz, post-rock, post-everything sonic experience that has few parallels or rivals. Sure, there are some interesting antecedents, from Terry Riley through to late-1960s Miles Davis; from Steve Reich's Come Out to This Heat's 24 Track Loop; from dub to trance. But those examples largely drew upon technological or compositional imperatives. By comparison, the Necks are totally exposed, with no scores or theories to hide behind. They are just three musicians seizing the moment. They may be teaching us to listen in a new way, but they communicate a fierce energy and warmth at the same time.

Their music is a thrilling, emotional journey into unknown territory. Ten minutes elapse before Abrahams plays more than one note at a time; more time goes by before you realise that Buck is hitting the snare with a stick or that Swanton's deep syncopated riff has grown into an extravagant chord. At their most intense moments you can't tell who is playing what, but the quiet moments are equally beguiling because their music develops so slowly, so unpredictably. Like seeing a world in a grain of sand, the Necks permit us to hear a whole new world of music in a sliver of sound.

fields.headline: The Salvador Dali of sound
fields.standfirst:
GMYO/ Jansons
Barbican, London
*****
fields.trailText:
GMYO/ Jansons
Barbican, London
*****
fields.body:
Although it takes its name from the most introspective of composers, a whiff of politics has always hung over the Gustav Mahler Youth Orchestra. Founded in Vienna by Claudio Abbado in 1986, its initial aim was to bridge east/west divides by bringing young Austrian players together with musicians from Czechoslovakia and Hungary. Fifteen years on, it's become "the youth orchestra for the whole of Europe", drawing its performers, most of them in their early 20s, from colleges across the continent. It has also become a formidable ensemble. The UK leg of their Easter tour brought them to the Barbican as part of the Great Orchestras of the World series. There's no doubt that they belong there.

Given that the galvanic Mariss Jansons was at the helm, an exciting evening was inevitable. He chose Ravel's orchestration of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition as the closing work, turning in a radical re-evaluation of the piece. It is usually treated as an exercise in orchestral flamboyance. Jansons, aware of the tensions and contradictions within it, probes it more deeply than most.

Mussorgsky, it should be remembered, was a depressive and an alcoholic. Despite the self-confident opening and the upbeat finale, Pictures is more nightmare than fantasy. It pre-empts surrealism, as images of horrific supernatural entities, corpses in catacombs and peculiar, anthropomorphic creatures thread their way through it. Much of the music is savage. Mussorgsky wrote the work for solo piano in 1874. Ravel's orchestration dates, however, from 1922, when humanity's violence had become all too apparent and surrealism was a dominant art form. Jansons consequently unleashes a study of orchestral weirdness, of textures at once brilliant and slippery that have the glutinous brightness of one of Salvador Dali's paintings. He leaves you in little doubt that this is actually one composer's interpretation of another's music, separated from the original by time and history. Jazz was also very much around when Ravel worked on his orchestration - and Jansons gives both the trumpet's opening Promenade and the saxophone solo that dominates The Old Castle a languorous, bluesy poise. In short, this was powerhouse stuff and, a couple of fluffs apart, it was phenomenally played.

Jansons preceded this stunner with an ebullient, well-judged performance of Weber's Euryanthe overture and the Schumann Piano Concerto. Radu Lupu was the soloist, by turns restrained, fluidly rhapsodic and elegant. The most undemonstrative of artists, he sits at the piano radiating extraordinary calm. To hear him is always both a privilege and a reminder that great piano playing need not mean self-dramatisation.

fields.headline: Yuri Honing Trio
fields.standfirst:
The Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.trailText:
The Wardrobe, Leeds
***
fields.body:
The Yuri Honing trio have been delivering their brand of dead pan Dutch deconstructionism to bemused jazz audiences for a few years now. In Leeds they interspersed their own compositions with a variety of dismembered 1970s and 1980s pop hits, reinterpreted so utterly that most of the audience spent the gig in a state of mild infuriation. "Oh God, I know this," was the catchphrase of the evening. At one point the gents lavatory was full of unhappy people all trying to work out which Roberta Flack song Tony Overwater had abused to produce his esoteric double-bass solo.

The band's choice of pop material has remained largely unchanged since the last time they came to Britain, as has its presentation. Abba's Waterloo, introduced as "Sweden's national anthem", was distorted into a queasy and fractured musical nightmare, Honing using his saxophone to initiate a sickening modulation into the chorus. The Police's Walking on the Moon was likewise dismembered, with Overwater scoring extra points for illuminating its melodic relationship to the opening bass refrain of John Coltrane's A Love Supreme. The toughest nut to crack, however, was Blondie's Denis, which was revealed agonisingly slowly through a series of elusive musical clues - a snatch of a drumbeat here, a main riff inverted there. When Honing finally kicked in with the chorus melody the audience's relief was palpable.

Surprisingly, none of these japes were quite as much fun as they should have been. Honing was more clever than entertaining, his musical dissections delivered with a kind of languid solemnity that often bordered on the tedious. A lot of the pieces laboured under a kind of sprawling limpness, lacking both shape and swing.

The musicians were technically superb. Drummer Joost Lijbaart summoned an amazing variety of sounds from his kit, and he used the freer passages to showcase his own brand of mutated rock/jazz fusion. Overwater's bass playing was never less than intense, and Honing proved himself a worthy devotee of Coltrane. A shame, then, about the sense of seeping boredom. Perhaps it's time to throw out a few of those worn-out covers and start mangling the Spice Girls.

fields.headline: Giselle
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
*****
fields.body:
Giselle is one of ballet's most naive heroines; Albrecht one of its most duplicitous heroes. The opening minutes of any performance will usually tell us what kind of spin dancers are going to put on them. Will we hate the caddish count on sight? Will we want to slap Giselle out of her trusting, virginal trance? These lovers were antique back in 1841 when arch-Romantic Theophile Gaultier wrote them into the ballet canon, and 21st-century dancers can find it hard to make sympathetic sense of them.

On Wednesday night, however, Tamara Rojo and Johan Kobborg did much more than make sense of the tale. Without compromising a second of the ballet's fragile logic, they gave dramatic life to every beat of the performance. They did that special thing of losing themselves in ballet history while remaining passionately present in every gesture.

Kobborg's Albrecht is a man besotted with love - so juiced up with adoration and fantasy that he barely registers anyone other than Giselle on stage. He has wandered miles out of his aristocratic routine into a place of his own imagining, yet what stops him looking mawkish is the transparent beauty of his dancing. Kobborg's Danish training has honed in him an extraordinarily clean line and ardent jump. We believe in Albrecht because the facts of his dancing are simultaneously so honest and so seductive. That he is also a partner of musical elegance and selfless accuracy clinches his power. We are entranced by him, so of course Giselle has to be.

Rojo portrays her own character as a girl so painfully shy she can barely meet her lover's gaze. But she also plays literally and symbolically with Giselle's love of dancing - showing how eagerly she sheds her inhibitions as soon as she can move. In some performances Giselle's constant needling to show off her steps can make her seem like a spoilt child. With Rojo it carries the urgency of someone who can't express herself any other way. Again, what makes this work is the quality of Rojo's technique and her ability to make space within a single phrase for changes in emotional dynamic. When dancers reach this level they can make absolute sense of ballet's superficial limitations, charging up its simple plotlines with a subtext of visceral and musical feeling.

Rojo's second act didn't quite match her first, its ghostly transparency not quite in her range, though I loved the way she retained spectral threads of her character even beyond the grave. Wednesday's supporting cast was mixed, but the lovers were wonderfully complemented by Christopher Saunders's dark and complicated Hilarion and William Tuckett's bluff and cynical Duke.

 In rep until May 16. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Millwall's blazing Sadlier
fields.trailText: Millwall extended their lead at the top of the Second Division to five points with a win based more on defensive solidity than attacking flair. It was their fifth successive clean sheet but they found this match, against a side haunted by relegation for much of the season, much less simple than their demolition of Rotherham, then their closest championship challengers, at the weekend.
fields.byline: Simon Burnton  at the New Den
fields.body:
Millwall extended their lead at the top of the Second Division to five points with a win based more on defensive solidity than attacking flair. It was their fifth successive clean sheet but they found this match, against a side haunted by relegation for much of the season, much less simple than their demolition of Rotherham, then their closest championship challengers, at the weekend.

Then they scored four; this time they barely had four chances. Then Steve Claridge received the plaudits; this time the striker, who turned 35 the day before the game, was substituted in the second half and the heroes were Sean Dyche, whose domination in defence restricted Port Vale's two attackers to a single chance between them, and their goal keeper Tony Warner, who was on hand whenever Dyche was not.

Claridge could have scored in the first minute as Millwall started brightly, but once Port Vale settled down from their early troubles they appeared more than capable of leaving the Lions frustrated. At which point Millwall scored.

Richard Sadlier has been keeping Neil Harris, the home side's top scorer on 24 goals, out of the team of late and from a long, looping free-kick into the box he controlled the ball well before turning to fire low and not particularly hard past Mark Goodlad. The defending was more generous than one would expect of a team that had played 16 games since their last defeat.

Though Brian Horton's side are unlikely to trouble the promotion challengers this season they are not as poor as their league position suggests. Their number of games in hand is, well, getting out of hand -thanks largely to their qualifi cation for the LDV Vans Trophy final - and on form there is no team in the country harder to beat.

Port Vale's fixtures have been piling up but when they could find the energy they played the better football and three times towards the end of the first half they could have scored. But from three dangerous crosses they could muster just one attempt on target and that, from Tony Naylor, was well saved by Warner.

Just past the hour Warner excelled again to keep out Marc Bridge-Wilkinson's finessed effort. The resulting corner prompted three minutes of mayhem in which Millwall found it impossible to clear the ball, but somehow Port Vale failed to score. Perhaps the home side's defensive record, the best in the division, owes more than a little to luck.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Flo fells fragile Killie
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo's first-half double made the difference as Rangers continued to claw back confidence and tighten their grip on second place.
fields.body:
It was more than approval that streamed down from the legions of away fans, it was a musical accompaniment to the restoration of old values.

But for a couple of defensive lapses, Kilmarnock might well have emerged with greater glory, not least following Garry Hay's rasping shot from the edge of the box to give the Rangers manager Dick Advocaat a few anxious late moments.

But this was a game mostly about Rangers' continuing process of re-discovery. Though they could only convert their superiority to just a handful of compelling moments, against their recent lack of confidence these were flashes to be feasted upon, substitute Kenny Miller being repelled by Hay's goal-line clearance to prevent a return to a long-standing two-goal advantage.

The game offered Rangers the chance to tighten their grip on second place and Kilmarnock to lay claim more strongly to fourth. No-one, however, appeared to have reminded Chris Innes, Kilmarnock's right-sided defender, of the importance of squeezing out at least a point.

Barely had the game got going when he was caught cold by Tore Andre Flo, who was granted free passage by a non-descript tackle to steer an angled shot beyond Colin Meldrum and put Rangers ahead within the first minute. Already, Kilmarnock were playing gesture football.

Although Rangers may have exuded the greater authority, they lacked the magical pass, meaning Kilmarnock had every reason to play on in hope. But when Scott Wilson appeared to clamber all over Kevin McGowne in a congested Rangers goalmouth at a Kilmarnock free-kick from the right, they spurned the tastiest morsel of the lot. Ally McCoist fired too close to Stefan Klos. The miss looked all the worse when, on the cusp of half-time, Fernando Ricksen's cross from the right caught an under-manned Kilmarnock and Flo timed his run at the back post to tap in the ball for his second.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Samoans lose 31-0 - or was it 32-0?
fields.trailText: Take the worst football team in the world, ban 19 of their squad for having the wrong passports, stop under-20s from deputising because of school exams and watch the records tumble.
fields.body:
Take the worst football team in the world, ban 19 of their squad for having the wrong passports, stop under-20s from deputising because of school exams and watch the records tumble.

Australia's 31-0 defeat of American Samoa yesterday smashed their own world record for the most goals in an international, set only 48 hours earlier by the Socceroos in thumping Tonga 22-0.

Yesterday Archie Thompson, 22, a New Zealander with a Papua New Guinean mother, scored 13 goals for Australia - another world record.

Yet both Australia's and Thompson's tallies yesterday may be even greater. With the ball entering the Samoans' net roughly every three minutes, the scoreboard operator at Coffs Harbour is believed to have flashed up one extra goal by mistake in the dying minutes.

Some observers thought the Socceroos had won 32-0, with Thompson striking 14 goals. But in view of the scoreboard error, Fifa announced last night that it "will only confirm the final official score when the various reports from the referee and the match commissioner have been received and checked".

American Samoa, representing a United States territory of five volcanic islands and 65,000 people in the South Pacific, boast only one international win in their history and are officially the world's worst team, ranked 203rd by Fifa.

Their World Cup Oceania group campaign was doomed from the start when Fifa ruled that their players must have US passports. The only member of their first-team squad cleared was the goalkeeper Nicky Salapu, who has now conceded 52 goals in their past three qualifying matches.

A 16-strong squad of US passport holders was scraped together, including two 15-year-olds and with an average age of 19. Their coach Tunoa Lui revealed his team of evangelical Christians prayed for divine intervention before this week's qualifiers at Coffs Harbour, 350 miles north of Sydney.

"We are here to learn. We have had a lot of problems but we don't give up," he said before yesterday's defeat. "We are asking the Lord to help keep the score down."

Although they had lost 13-0 to Fiji and 8-0 to Samoa here, their youngsters had until yesterday avoided a repeat of their previous record defeat, 18-0 away to Tahiti last June.

At 29-0 down to Australia by the 86th minute, they rallied briefly when Pati Feagiai shot weakly at Australia's goalkeeper Michael Petkovic.

Australia were 16-0 up at half-time, despite not calling up up stars like Mark Viduka and Harry Kewell of Leeds, and resting Coventry's John Aloisi after his six goals against Tonga.

Thompson's goals - whether 13 or 14 - saw him surpass Denmark's Sofus Nielsen and Germany's Gottfried Fuchs, who had each scored 10 in a game, Nielsen in the 1908 Olympics against France and Fuchs against Russia at the 1912 games.

The Marconi Stallions striker knocked down his achievement. "Breaking the world record is a dream come true," said Thompson, "but you have to look at the teams we're playing and ask questions. We don't need to play these games. It's really a waste of time.

"Their players were laughing at the end. There wasn't much more they could do. I think their one attack consisted of getting over the halfway line."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

But in view of the scoreboard error, Fifa announced last night that it "will only confirm the final official score when the various reports from the referee and the match commissioner have been received and checked". American Samoa, representing a United States territory of five volcanic islands and 65,000 people in the South Pacific, boast only one international win in their history and are officially the world's worst team, ranked 203rd by Fifa. Their World Cup Oceania group campaign was doomed from the start when Fifa ruled that their players must have US passports. The only member of their first-team squad cleared was the goalkeeper Nicky Salapu, who has now conceded 52 goals in their past three qualifying matches. A 16-strong squad of US passport holders was scraped together, including two 15-year-olds and with an average age of 19. Their coach Tunoa Lui revealed his team of evangelical Christians prayed for divine intervention before this week's qualifiers at Coffs Harbour, 350 miles north of Sydney. "We are here to learn. We have had a lot of problems but we don't give up," he said before yesterday's defeat. "We are asking the Lord to help keep the score down." Although they had lost 13-0 to Fiji and 8-0 to Samoa here, their youngsters had until yesterday avoided a repeat of their previous record defeat, 18-0 away to Tahiti last June. At 29-0 down to Australia by the 86th minute, they rallied briefly when Pati Feagiai shot weakly at Australia's goalkeeper Michael Petkovic. Australia were 16-0 up at half-time, despite not calling up up stars like Mark Viduka and Harry Kewell of Leeds, and resting Coventry's John Aloisi after his six goals against Tonga. Thompson's goals - whether 13 or 14 - saw him surpass Denmark's Sofus Nielsen and Germany's Gottfried Fuchs, who had each scored 10 in a game, Nielsen in the 1908 Olympics against France and Fuchs against Russia at the 1912 games. The Marconi Stallions striker knocked down his achievement. "Breaking the world record is a dream come true," said Thompson, "but you have to look at the teams we're playing and ask questions. We don't need to play these games. It's really a waste of time. "Their players were laughing at the end. There wasn't much more they could do. I think their one attack consisted of getting over the halfway line."  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: Players reap rich rewards
fields.trailText: The Premiership is on the verge of becoming the world's first £1bn football league while its players get richer and, Deloitte & Touche revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The average Premiership player earns £400,000 a year and is about to get richer. Wages are expected to rise with the changes to the transfer system and lucrative future television deals.

A financial survey of Premiership clubs last season by the accountants Deloitte & Touche found that wages overall increased by 20% in England's top division compared with 1999.

Chelsea are the biggest payers with an annual wage bill of £47m, followed by Manchester United at £44.8m and Liverpool at £40.1m.

The survey also claims that the Premiership is on the verge of becoming the world's first £1bn football league after registering a total turnover of £772m last season, an increase of 15% on 1999.

The overall turnover is set to increase for the 2001-02 season once money from the new television deal kicks in.

Leeds experienced a 50% increase in their wage bill and Sunderland's more than doubled. The bulk of a club's expenditure is on wages and they are set to go even higher. The proposed changes to the transfer system are likely to lead to wage inflation as clubs attempt to hold on to their star players.

Gerry Boon, head of Deloitte & Touche Sport, said in the review: "In the year under review, there were signs that a few chairmen and managers were making a stand against some player wage demands but key developments over the last year suggest player salaries will continue to spiral.

"The effects of the new TV deal are already apparent, with players and their agents positioning themselves for contract negotiations.

"Likewise, the European Commission ruling on transfer fees, or Bosman II as it is known, will cause further upward pressure on wages, at least at the top end.

"It must feel like being on a treadmill, running ever faster just to keep up. But chairmen can control the speed - at least they should be able to for everyone but the star players."

Paying the highest wages does not guarantee success. Chelsea as the highest payers last season failed to qualify for the Champions League, and Wimbledon, with a wage bill of £15.77m, and Sheffield Wednesday, with a wage bill of £14.38m, were relegated. Bradford City, who stayed up, spent £6.01m on wages.

The average club turnover is £38.6m, but, despite the huge amounts being spent in an attempt to gain success, only seven clubs made a profit.

More worrying for the grass roots of the game and clubs in the lower divisions, the survey found that last season Premiership teams spent £250m on transfers, of which £150m went abroad.

Television is also accounting for a greater part of a club's revenue and broadcast rights are set to overtake gate receipts as the principal source of income.

webTitle: Francis may turn his back on Birmingham City

fields.headline: Francis may turn his back on Blues, hints Gold
fields.trailText:
Birmingham City's chairman David Gold yesterday stated that he would not be surprised if Trevor Francis resigns as manager at the end of the season.
A HREF="http://football.guardian.co.uk/Match_Report/0,1527,471664,00.html">Tranmere 1 - 0 Birmingham
fields.body:
Birmingham City's chairman David Gold yesterday stated that he would not be surprised if Trevor Francis resigns as manager at the end of the season, the more so if the club are promoted to the Premiership.

Even though Tuesday's defeat at lowly Tranmere means Birmingham are experiencing their worst league run since Francis became manager almost five years ago, they remain on course to reach the play-offs for the third successive season.

"It wouldn't surprise me if Trevor left in the summer," said Gold. "He's a wealthy man with a mind of his own. Obviously it's his decision and, funnily enough, I think he's more likely to resign if we reach the Premiership because that would mean mission accomplished.

"If we remain in Division One I suspect he would want to give it one more go to achieve his ambition of winning promotion for the club."

There have been signs that the relationship between David Sullivan, the chairman of Birmingham City plc, and Francis will end in tears. Another row between the two became public last month after Francis implied that the directors were too mean to spend £90,000 to re-lay the scorched pitch.

Sheffield United will defy an agreement with Gillingham and field Carl Asaba against his former club on Saturday. Neil Warnock, the United manager, said: "My directors feel Gillingham moved the goalposts on certain financial details. They believe they don't have to honour the agreement."

Gillingham have been fined £15,000 and Crystal Palace £5,000 after a 12-man melee between their players in the Boxing Day fixture.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week thirty-three

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week thirty-three
fields.standfirst: Blue Square gave us wad of cash in invited us to make our fortunes - read and learn from our mistakes
fields.trailText: Scott Murray: Manchester United v Coventry: number of goals scored 0 or 1 £5 @ 4/1
fields.body:
Scott Murray: Manchester United v Coventry: number of goals scored 0 or 1 £5 @ 4/1

Any game at Old Trafford normally shouts "goal glut". Which is fair enough, I suppose. So it's entirely possible that my punt will be totally jiggered come 12.01pm on Saturday.

But, then again, United may not fly out of the blocks. They're not playing too well at present, and they're up against a Coventry team desperate for points and beginning to regain a little confidence on the back of two victories.

On paper, United should walk it. But they're not going to bust a gut with a big game against Bayern coming up, and if Cov dig in, this one could be tighter than most people think.

The Prince of Punts: West Ham v Derby: Freddie Kanoute to outscore Malcolm Christie £5 @ 11/4

Oh, hallo. I'm afraid you've caught me with my pants down rather. I've just been administering some paternal advice to the stable girl and, well, I'm rather short on creative juices. So you'll just have to take my word for it (and my word is "victorious") when I say that Freddie Kanoute will outscore Malcolm Christie on Saturday.

The Hammers have recently been performing like a stoat in Othello (ie rather badly), but a creditable draw with the Villa last week should have come as a fillip. Kanoute is at the centre of all West Ham's attacking play, whereas Malcolm Christie has been missing lots of chances for some time now. Both players look set to play, and at nearly 3-1 Freddie is good value to outscore his opposite number.

Now, Gwendolyn, where was I?

Nobby Dogger of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: West ham v Derby, draw - £5 @ 9/4

With a name like mine you've go to have a sense of humour, so in the spirit of moniker madness it is a random punt on a dull draw that gets the collective fiver this week. Spunking the cash on Tottenham to win away at Sunderland almost got the nod but that value mantra runs deep.

I could rattle on about why I think this is a sound way to make money, but where would be the fun in that? Suffice it to say, I wouldn't fancy either team to get the full three when both are looking down the barrel of the Nationwide gun. A timely scrap with little reward has to be the best bet. Value it is I think.

Sean Ingle: Leicester v Manchester City: Man City to win @ 10/3

Oppose bad favourites, look for value. Hence this bet.

Leicester have lost their last five games. City are almost as bad - they've only won one point in five themselves. In truth, this match is wide open.

What's more, at this stage of the season the rules change; pitches are worn, players are tired, and relegation-threatened sides scramble untidy 1-0 wins. Leicester are a bad favourite; City at 10/3 might just prove it.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Simon
fields.trailText: If you get the chance in NZ, spend a couple of days (at-least) at Tryphena on Great Barrier Island. This is a two-hour ferry ride from downtown Auckland but takes you to one of the most remote, laid back, and beautiful parts of coast and forest in NZ.
fields.body:
Hey Milly,

If you get the chance in NZ, spend a couple of days (at-least) at Tryphena on Great Barrier Island. This is a two-hour ferry ride from downtown Auckland but takes you to one of the most remote, laid back, and beautiful parts of coast and forest in NZ.

The Barrier has awesome bush and beaches, is rugged in the north, but more sheltered in the south. It is kind of a mini NZ, with all kinds of coast from rugged, fjord-like harbours in the north to sheltered bays in the south and wide open surf on the east coast. Don't expect it to be bustling, though - only a few thousand people live out there and there are only a few kilometres of sealed road on the island. The locals are friendly, though, and there are a couple of pubs on the beaches. It is made special by the lack of possums and deer which means that the forest is in the condition that the rest of the NZ bush once was, but unfortunately isn't quite anymore. I would recommend staying at Stray Possum Backpackers in Trypehna. They have a bus to provide transport round and you lend you sports gear, snorkeling gear and all that.

Whatever you do, I hope you have a good time in NZ. It's an awesome country.

fields.headline: Sky highs
fields.standfirst: New Zealand brings adventure aplenty as Milly walks on glaciers, shoots up rivers and finally achieves a lofty ambition
fields.trailText: Week 19: Christchurch to Queenstown: New Zealand brings adventure aplenty as Milly walks on glaciers, shoots up rivers and finally achieves a lofty ambition.
fields.body:
This week began like the opening of Four Weddings and a Funeral: we were woken by our door being hammered and someone yelling that our bus was ready to leave. Miraculously we made it out in 5 minutes. That morning we were driving west from Christchurch to Arthur's Pass at the foothills of the Southern Alps. The drive took us away from dry plains and into lush foliage - and it was here that it started bucketing down with rain.

Arriving, we sprinted for the nearest hostel and grabbed our warmest clothes. The rain had set in for most of the day and though we attempted a short walk to a waterfall in the afternoon we came back absolutely soaked. We were very glad of the wood fire in the hostel lounge and settled in for the night with others from the hostel and a bottle of whisky. A small group of us did try to go to the sole bar - rumoured to stay open late - but at 8.30pm it was well and truly shut. Arthur's Pass village isn't a place you stay for the nightlife.

The next morning we awoke to blue skies so decided not to leave until the afternoon, giving us time to enjoy a day's walk through the mountains. We chose Avalanche Peak track, seven hours return on paper - if you're extremely fit. The walk was lovely, taking us beside a waterfall and eventually up to breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains, but all the way long-forgotten muscles were crying at me.

We took a bus the rest of the way to the west coast into Greymouth. Despite the winding, treacherous roads, we made it to our hostel safely. It was a Global Village backpackers - the same chain as my very first hostel in Canada, but why in Greymouth? It didn't take long to establish that this was a town that tried to draw in tourists simply as a convenient stopover before heading to more interesting places. Worked on us.

That evening we actually cooked, on Josh's insistence (OK, he cooked, I stirred things). On Saturday we rose early to make use of the hostels kayaks and had a punt around the lake. It was a nice way to get some mornings exercise - although I'd better warn you the flies in this country will have you for dinner as soon as you expose flesh. Later, we were at least impressed by the town's liquor store where you could fill your own plastic bottles with beer, sherry or port.

That night I had the largest meal in memory, at a restaurant called West of the Border which attracted us with its offer of free beer. I should have known it would be excessive when they produced an 11-page menu of Cowboy/Cowgirl's choice - including a 4.4lb steak. We both opted for baby back ribs, and between us probably gnawed our way through the three little pigs.

The next morning we caught an early bus to Fox glacier, one of two glacial towns down the west coast we'd chosen for its good name. We went on a half-day ice-walk with a group and two guides. Wearing 15lb boots, which are great for the legs, we trekked in the sun through temperate rainforest onto the glacier itself. The clear blue sky meant we had stunning views across the glacier and up to the mountains. The ice beneath our feet shone blue beneath the surface - I compared it to walking on a blueberry squishie and got laughed at. The streams running from the glacier were so fresh and clean that we drank directly from them. The whole afternoon was captivating - but these glaciers are currently in retreat, so if you want to experience the joy of ice-walking go now while it's still possible.

Next morning we were off again, bound for Queenstown in the South Island - probably the adrenaline capital of the world. I instantly fell in love with the town. It has all modern conveniences with shops and countless bars that open until late but still retains a charm and character with its lake and mountain setting. Every other shop seemed to be selling activities and tours - they really do want to keep you busy here. I was dying to try a few new things out, and one in particular?

We decided to ease our way in to Queenstown life by going for an afternoon's jet-boating. Our driver took us spinning and swerving across Lake Wakatipu and down the Shotover river. Although he'd said we shouldn't get too wet I think I'd chosen a bad seating place in the boat - I got soaked every time! It was definitely a fun way to get a tour of the area.

That evening Josh and I tried out the various bars of Queenstown, the town with the most thriving night-life I've seen yet in New Zealand. Happy hours abound: in one bar we had a Queenstown teapot - literally a teapot filled with dangerously tasty cocktail shots. That evening I was stood in a bar when two friends of mine from school walked past: it came as a shock to suddenly see them in a random bar in Queenstown, though I'd been told before I left I was bound to run into people I know.

Wednesday was the day when I finally got to fulfil my burning ambition and go skydiving! A small van-load of us were driven to a landing site just outside Queenstown, where we had to fill a 'we accept no responsibility for your death' style form, and then just had to wait until we were called up. Two and a half hours of anxiously watching the wind get up and the skies get darker and praying not to have the flight cancelled, my name was called.

In each plane-load there were 3 jumpers and the person we were tandemed with - I was with a Yugoslavian guy named Rob who was lovely and calming and told me if I gave him $500 he'd let me survive! We were put into jumpsuits and harnesses, taught the 'big banana' position (the way people curve backwards when they're skydiving) then we were off in the little plane, 12,000ft up into the air.

Before I knew it the green light was on, the door was open, and the first girl was plummeting into the sky with alarming speed. Then it was our turn. Rob pushed me to the door and the force of the wind was incredible. He did a short countdown which didn't even give me time to consider what I was doing then we dropped. For a minute the mountains and lakes came hurtling towards me with a force so powerful I couldn't even scream. Then I realised I didn't want to - this was the most awesome and literally breathtaking feeling imaginable.

After a while came the comforting but uncomfortable sensation of the parachute opening and we slowly twirled our way back to earth, objects on the ground changing from looking like toys to actually being solid and real. My hostel receptionist had warned me I'd be on a high for hours afterwards and he couldn't have been more right - I guess one reason people put themselves through these deadly activities is because you feel so incredibly alive afterwards.

So my week ends on an unbelievable high. My only problem: now I've fulfilled my ambition, what should I do next?

Until next week (I can't wait, I don't know about you)
Milly

We were put into jumpsuits and harnesses, taught the 'big banana' position (the way people curve backwards when they're skydiving) then we were off in the little plane, 12,000ft up into the air. Before I knew it the green light was on, the door was open, and the first girl was plummeting into the sky with alarming speed. Then it was our turn. Rob pushed me to the door and the force of the wind was incredible. He did a short countdown which didn't even give me time to consider what I was doing then we dropped. For a minute the mountains and lakes came hurtling towards me with a force so powerful I couldn't even scream. Then I realised I didn't want to - this was the most awesome and literally breathtaking feeling imaginable. After a while came the comforting but uncomfortable sensation of the parachute opening and we slowly twirled our way back to earth, objects on the ground changing from looking like toys to actually being solid and real. My hostel receptionist had warned me I'd be on a high for hours afterwards and he couldn't have been more right - I guess one reason people put themselves through these deadly activities is because you feel so incredibly alive afterwards. So my week ends on an unbelievable high. My only problem: now I've fulfilled my ambition, what should I do next? Until next week (I can't wait, I don't know about you) Milly

fields.headline: Civil servant may replace Campbell
fields.trailText:
6.30pm: Blair may hire a civil servant to dampen accusations of spin doctoring but a PR industry professional could still get a look in, write Jessica Hodgson and Julia Day
12.04.2001: Journalists lament Campbell's departure
12.04.2001: Private sector awaits Campbell's expertise
12.04.2001: Campbell to quit as PM's voice
12.04.2001: Government rethinks PR spend
fields.body:
Tony Blair may hire a civil servant to dampen accusations of spin doctoring but a PR industry professional could still get a look in.

John Sergeant, the ITN political editor, said: "I think it's clear the PM last year wanted Alastair to reduce his role. The publicity he gets means he has become too close to the story.

"Given Alastair's prominence, there's an argument for reverting to a civil service figure.

"Both Margaret Thatcher and John Major asked for the best press secretary in the civil service and these figures went on to become very sophisticated media managers," said Mr Sargeant.

Here are the runners and riders:

Godric Smith
Mr Campbell's trusted civil service deputy is already running day-to-day issues for Downing Street and handles the twice-daily Lobby briefings. He worked for the charity Sane. He moved to the department of health, switching to Downing Street under John Major, and became the prime minister's deputy press spokesman in 1998. He is very popular with Mr Blair's staff and the media. Balding, in his early 40s, he read classics at Oxford but supports Cambridge United Football Club, is married with two children and lives in north London.

Philip Bassett
Head of Downing Street strategic communications unit and former industrial editor of the Times. Known to be very ambitious and hard-working and has positioned himself perfectly as an internal candidate to take over from Mr Campbell. His is one half of a cosy Labour couple - his long-term partner is Baroness Symons of Vernham Dean, a defence minister.

Tom Kelly
Director of communications at the Northern Ireland office, he was Peter Mandelson's spokesman. A BBC man, he held several senior posts with the corporation in Belfast, both on and off camera, including political correspondent. Downing Street is known to have been impressed with his handling of the peace settlement negotiations.

David Bradshaw
Used to be Mr Campbell's deputy at the Mirror. He worked for Labour in the run-up to the 1997 election then went back to the Mirror before joining the government in 1998. Although he is a great writer and very witty, he is believed not to be ambitious enough to take Mr Campbell's mantle.

Bill Bush
Mr Blair's polling analyst and chief number cruncher. He's not too well known but his political knowledge has helped Mr Blair out at prime minister's question time. He used to work for Ken Livingstone.

Jim Godfrey
Deputy to Lance Price, the Labour party's director of communications. He worked as a researcher and press officer at the Institute of Public Policy Research and went on to work on Frank Dobson's leadership campaign. He moved to Millbank full time last year.

webTitle: Plane crew back on US soil

fields.headline: Plane crew back on US soil
fields.trailText: Leaving their damaged spy plane on a Chinese island, 24 US crew members landed in  Hawaii today to face two long days of debriefing before planned weekend reunions with families and friends.
fields.body:
Leaving their damaged spy plane on a Chinese island, 24 US crew members landed in Hawaii today to face two long days of debriefing before planned weekend reunions with families and friends.

"A proud Navy day," read a banner welcoming the crew freed 11 days after their surveillance plane collided with a Chinese jet over the South China sea.

Hawaii's four members of Congress and other officials welcomed the crew, along with local military families, after an overnight flight from Guam aboard a military transport jet.

The crew faced 12 hour debriefing sessions to go over their ordeal, with an additional 14 hours on Friday. They will return to their home base and a warmer welcoming celebration in Washington state on Saturday.

Their arrival in Hawaii came as the Bush administration began fresh diplomatic efforts to win back its crippled plane.

The stalemate ended yesterday after Washington said it was "very sorry" for the incident - twice - but refused to give the outright apology that Beijing had earlier demanded.

President George Bush said: "We can't wait for them to get home."

"I'm very pleased they are back on American soil," the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, said earlier today, after he heard that the crew had reached a planned stopover at a US base in Guam.

American and Chinese delegations were due to meet next Wednesday to weigh the future of the Navy aircraft.

"This is not over," Powell said amid meetings on the Balkans yesterday in Paris. "Some discussions will begin, and we still have our plane there. But this will all unfold in the days and weeks ahead."

Condoleezza Rice, the White House national security adviser, has emphasized that the incident will not end American surveillance flights near China, which she said are essential to the security of the US and its Asian allies.

"The responsibility for avoiding future accidents rests not just with the United States, it rests heavily with the Chinese and the way they respond to these flights," she said.

The Chinese, who have not relented in their insistence that the US plane operated illegally, are also not relenting in their insistence that such flights be discontinued.

But vice president Dick Cheney said the United States has a right to continue to operate aircraft in international airspace. "That is not a subject we would want to concede on," he said in a radio interview.

The dispute has given a boost to a bid to overturn last year's law paving the way for China to gain permanent normal trade relations with the US.

The EP-3E, crammed with surveillance equipment, collided with a Chinese fighter jet on April 1 and made on emergency landing on Hainan island in southern China.

Crew members worked to destroy top secret codes and intelligence before the Chinese came aboard.

China agreed to release the crew after the US wrote a letter saying it was "very sorry" that the Chinese pilot was lost, and its plane had not received permission to make an emergency landing.

fields.headline: Television, Terms and Tragedy
fields.trailText: HARD WORDS
fields.body:
HARD WORDS

For a man who could probably get by with a simple system of grunts and barks, Roy Keane does give good copy. The Manchester United skipper has, in the recent past, made prawn sandwiches synonymous with being a ponce, told his teammates to pull their fingers out, and addressed the IMF on globalisation. We'll check on that last one, by the way, and get back to you. Anyway, Keane has continued with his recent garrulous form today and, amongst other things, claims he could be off to Celtic soon enough.

"In two years' time, if United say I can go, then Celtic is the club I would like to play for," he told the mighty MUTV (tonight at 9pm, Jonathan Greening stars as a lovelorn priest in a heart-rending remake of The Thorn Birds). Keane, who claims that some of his teammates "are living off what happened two years ago", says he doesn't plan to outstay his welcome at Old Trafford. "At the end of this contract I will be 31 and maybe that will be time to say thank you for the memories because hopefully by then there will be new players coming through."

But while Keane went on to list players like "Figo" and "Rivaldo" as desirable replacements, we're sure he meant popular-only-cos-you-can-sell -loads-of-replica-shirts-to-tourists midfielder Hideotoshi Nakata. Nakata, who has been rotting on Roma's bench for the best part of a season (honestly, you should see the state of his rib cage), is likely to leave the club this summer. So what a surprise to hear him nattering about United today. "I know that I am loved by Manchester United and playing for them would be an ideal situation," he said. "They are a great team and I know that I can help them." By doing a weekend shift in the Megastore?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER IS SHUT

Before you say it, that's not a spelling mistake. Because of Easter and all that, you'll not hear a peep from us until Tuesday. However, if Tuesday comes and goes and there's still no Fiver, you'll know that the police got wind of Granny Fiver's Easter Sunday booze and drugs bash.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BIG BARRY OF BIRMINGHAM

Usually, Aston Villa manager John Gregory repels professional footballers in much the same way as Luke Chadwick's face repels Biactol. But, in a move which has turned the world's natural order upside down and given confused dermatologists in Greater Manchester hope, a player actually committed his future to Gregory today by signing a new four-year deal. The man in question is six-time England defender Gareth Barry, and the Fiver doffs its virtual cap to him, because he's either very brave or, well, you know.

"I'm delighted it has been sorted out," Gregory announced. "I know Gareth still had two years left of his contract but I wanted to reward him for his achievements with us and bring him onto financial parity with other players," the Villa manager went on, gamely holding the show together in the total absence of the player himself. Nobody would say exactly where the lucky recipient of such an attractive new contract was; but perhaps he was in the lav, crying.

"He has crammed an awful lot into his career already and is the kind of player we want to try and build the future around," concluded Gregory of the 20-year-old he signed from Brighton for about six quid. Gregory then allowed himself to drift away in a dream of the bright future in store at Villa Park. With youngsters like Barry, Lee Hendrie and Darius Vassell knocking around, what an exciting team he can now build! The world will be Villa's oyster! Or maybe whelk.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If you were confronted with a skinhead on a dark street on a Saturday night, wouldn't you fear the worst? Those haircuts do look aggressive. Human nature is such that refs may look at players and say: 'He looks like a hardman.' If you want to have a good disciplinary record, then you might as well use every option available to you. Growing your hair is just one idea!" - Former Premiership ref Kevin Lynch beseeches Olivier Dacourt to grow a Beatles bowl-cut.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TRAGEDY AT ELLIS PARK

Grieving families queued from dawn outside the Johannesburg mortuary today, following the death of 43 people at a match between the Kaizer Chiefs and the Orlando Pirates last night. Men, women and children were crushed to death when thousands of fans broke down gates and surged into an already packed Ellis Park stadium, swelling the 62,000 capacity to around 90,000. The stampede killed 43 people, 29 inside the stadium and 14 outside. Two of the dead were children. A further 89 people were injured, including nine who remain in critical condition. The disaster is South Africa's worst-ever sporting tragedy.

Today, the South African football association promised a full investigation. In a statement former President Nelson Mandela said the inquiry should find ways to ensure there is never a repeat of the disaster. "This incident should not divide us now but rather bring us even closer to ensure that this horror story does not repeat itself," he added. Meanwhile, football magazine editor Richard Maguire has blamed greed and poor organisation for the tragedy. "The soccer authorities never ensure proper organisation", he said. "This has been waiting to happen for years. The rich people running these things wring their hands and protest innocence while people die cheaply because of their ineptitude."

The South African Football Association (SAFA) has insisted that the disaster would not affect plans to bid for the World Cup finals in 2010. "This was a tragic incident that is not good for the image of our soccer, but we will be able to learn and make sure the mistakes never happen again," said SAFA chief executive, Danny Jordaan. South African officials are set to cancel all weekend league matches as a mark of respect. However, the Kaizer Chiefs will play an African Cup Winners Cup match at Ellis Park next Wednesday - just a week after the tragedy.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Parma, Barcelona and Real Madrid are all interested in Newcastle's £5m-rated winger Nolberto Solano. Solano's lawyer Juan Domingo Pinieri confirmed he had received "very good offers" from Italy and Spain for his client. "There is a pre-agreement with Newcastle to renew his contract," he said. "But there is interest from Parma, another Italian club, Barcelona and Real Madrid."

Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola wants to move to England at the end of the season. But he says will not be joining Bobby Robson at Newcastle - despite reportedly being offered a £50,000-a-week contract to move to Tyneside.

Lens defender Jose Pierre-Fanfan is being chased by West Ham, Everton and Liverpool.

Sunderland are preparing a £3m bid for 6ft 6ins QPR striker Peter Crouch, who they see as a perfect replacement for Niall Quinn.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

David O'Leary has confirmed that Michael Duberry will not be sold this summer. "Michael loves it here and the players love him here," the Leeds manager said. "They speak to him all the time, so why should we sell him? He is thought of very highly. Anybody who knows him knows he is a lovely, lovely fella."

Meanwhile, O'Leary has won the Carling manager of the month award for March.

Rangers legend Jim Baxter is in a "very serious" condition three months after being diagnosed with cancer, the Ibrox club said today.

Celtic goalkeeper Dmitri Kharine has a calf strain and won't be able to play for Livingston in the Scottish Cup semi-final against Hibernian on Saturday.

Stoke director of football John Rudge has signed a new two-year contract.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.10am)

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.10am)

Dutch Football (12.40am)

Argentine Football (2.20am)

Major League Soccer (4am)

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm)

Australian Soccer League (11pm)

Sky Sports 2: Non-league Football Review (6pm)

Fifa TV (6.30pm)

Spanish Football League (10pm)

British Eurosport: Football (10.15pm) Today's TV and Radio section is a washing machine on the set of Rapido being filled full of pure cotton shirts by a cast member of the Black and White Minstrel Show who has seen the error of his ways.

webTitle: Rough sleepers tsar sweeps ahead with targets

fields.headline: Rough sleepers tsar sweeps ahead with targets
fields.trailText: Homelessness tsar Louise Casey's rough sleepers unit (RSU) is on course to cut the number of people sleeping rough by two-thirds by clearing 1,200 people off the streets, almost a year ahead of target.
fields.body:
Homelessness tsar Louise Casey's rough sleepers unit (RSU) is on course to cut the number of people sleeping rough by two-thirds by clearing 1,200 people off the streets, almost a year ahead of target.

Ms Casey was set what many saw as an impossible task of cutting the number of rough sleepers in England from 1,850 in June 1998 to 617 by March 2002.

Officials from the RSU have boasted in private that the unit is on course to meet the target this summer.

The claim is backed by figures obtained by SocietyGuardian.co.uk, which show that in 14 towns and cities outside London, where the most recent count figures are available, a two-thirds reduction has already been achieved from 381 to 133 (click on table below).

The results will be portrayed by the government as a vindication of Ms Casey's "zero tolerance" approach to the problem, but charities warned it merely shifts the problems from the streets to hostels.

Rough sleeping in London is proving more difficult to prevent - the latest overall figures show a 41.5% cut from 650 to 380. But more recent street counts in so-called hot spots show bigger reductions.

The number of long-term rough sleepers in London is also showing a sharp decline. Previous efforts to house this group have largely failed.

St Botolph's project, one of three agencies responsible for counting the numbers sleeping rough in London, has already exceeded its target for a reduction in "entrenched" rough sleepers from 181 to just 40. This achievement included a reduction from 61 to 20 of so-called "famous face" rough sleepers known for sleeping rough locally for years.

St Botolph's director John Downie, said: "So far we are doing particularly well with the vulnerable entrenched rough sleepers."

He pointed out that reducing numbers for the new influx of rough sleepers was more difficult. But he added: "The target is achievable - the end of the summer is possible for London as a whole."

Ms Casey and her officials are hoping that new hostels, now nearing completion, will help further reduce the figures in London. It is understood the RSU is planning a high profile announcement this summer when the target is reached - which could even be before the likely election date of June 7.

The government is believed to be keen to hit the target early before an expected down-turn in the economy starts to lead to more people sleeping on the streets.

A spokesman for Ms Casey refused to say whether the unit was on course to hit the target early, but was cautiously optimistic: "It's certainly going in the right direction. There's a reduction across the board and in some areas very close to either eliminating rough sleeping or reducing it to single figures."

He added: "We are not talking about figures and targets we are talking about vulnerable people so if we can help them sooner rather than later we would be delighted."

Shaks Ghosh, director of the charity for single homeless people Crisis, who has been critical of the RSU in the past, said: "I'm really pleased - our mission is to end street homelessness. The voluntary agencies should be congratulated for their delivery."

But she added: "If it (the RSU) has done this by coercion and zero tolerance then all it has done is shifted the problem from the streets to hostels.

"Moving people off the streets is base camp one. If we are going to ensure the problem does not recur then the real rebuilding work needs to begin now. You have not reduced social exclusion by moving people off the streets into hostels."

Gary Lashko, director of the homelessness charity Providence Row, said: "The RSU has been very focused on the target and the people that need to be given the services. But what we don't know is what is happening to the hidden homeless who are drifting on and off the streets, but not long enough to be counted."

fields.headline: Yuri Gagarin
fields.standfirst: April 12 2001 is the fortieth anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's flight into space, the first time a human left the planet. Here's our guide to the best of Gagarin on the net.
fields.trailText: April 12 2001 is the fortieth anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's flight into space, the first time a human left the planet. Here's our guide to the best of Gagarin on the net.
fields.body:
1. Born on March 9, 1934, Yuri Alexeyevich Gagarin had a tough upbringing on a 'kolkhoz', or collective farm. After working his way through college he joined the Soviet Air Force.

2. Russia launched the world's first man-made satellite, Sputnik, in 1957, and its tinny bleeping terrified an already paranoid USA (their response was to create Nasa). Gagarin knew a human in space would be next.

3. Next, that is, after a Russian mutt called Laika became the first animal in space.

4. After two years of highly secret training, on April 12 1961 Gagarin climbed into his Vostok ('East') spacecraft. As the engines fired on the Baikonur launchpad in Kazakhstan, he shouted "Poyekhali!" - "Let's go!"

5. After his first words in space, Gagarin made a single orbit of earth in 108 minutes, travelling at 27,400 kph. Gagarin returned a hero of the Soviet Union, as well as the most famous person on earth. The Soviets showed him off around the world, and he was encouraged to describe his experiences.

6. Gagarin's safe return killed off worries that space flight would be fatal for humans; it also badly bruised American confidence.

7. The Russians went from strength to strength; soon they would boast the first woman in space (trained by Gagarin) and the first man to walk in space.

8. Banned from more space missions in case he was killed, Gagarin grew depressed and turned to alcohol, but did as he was told and helped train other cosmonauts at Moscow's Star City.

9. Gagarin and an instructor took off in a MiG-15 jet on March 27, 1968. The plane crashed in bad weather just outside Moscow and both were killed, some would say in suspicious circumstances.

10. Gagarin has a crater on the moon named after him; Picasso drew a picture for him; and on the fortieth anniversary of his earth orbit there will be parties around the world in his honour. One thing is certain - Yuri Gagarin will always be a hero in Russia.
