webTitle: Research shows grants affect university numbers

fields.headline: Research shows grants affect university numbers
fields.trailText: New research from Harvard University supports university claims that student welfare has been hit by the abolition of grants.
fields.body:
Grants do make a difference to university numbers, according to new research. These new findings from Harvard University give weight to university and student groups' claims and debunk the government's argument that student welfare has not been affected by the abolition of grants.

Harvard's assistant professor of public policy, Professor Susan Dynarski, found that every $1,000 of grant aid makes it 4% more likely a student will go to university. Each $1,000 will also increase students' average number of years of schooling by 0.16 years.

In other words, student grants affect both university attendance and completion.

Professor Dynarski told the Royal Economic Society's Annual Conference at Durham University that the key issue was getting students over the initial threshold of university entrance. The choice may be between a student entering university with government assistance and people not applying at all.

Although her research was carried out in the United States, she said last week that it applied equally to Britain. "It shows that cost matters," she said.

Theresa Blackstone, Minister for Education and Employment, has argued for years that student welfare and support has been maintained through student and hardship loans, despite the abolition of grants.

At the beginning of last year, she told the House of Lords, "The system of student support is working well. The system is fair and equitable to students, families and the taxpayer."

Such a blithe view of student funding is undermined by this week's research.

Teacher and student groups have argued for years that student hardships have increased since the abolition of the grant and that there has been a knock-on impact on university completion and application. But they have had no hard evidence before Professor Dynarski's announcement last week.

At this year's National Union of Students'(NUS) annual conference, speakers were forced to rely on belief rather than evidence, with the most common start to a speech being, "We know grants affect students".

The University and College Admissions Service's figures, released last Wednesday, actually showed the opposite trend to what Professor Dynarski's research suggests. There has been a modest increase in the number of applications.

But the increase in university applicants has not kept pace with the growth in university places, which has taken place as higher education institutions try to get more money by attracting more students. The shortfall is causing increased budget strictures.

fields.headline: Betty the Yeti replaces Hamlet
fields.trailText: Shakespeare has been declared 'racist and sexist', writes David Cohen in this week's student press roundup.
fields.body:
A professor of drama at the Arizona State University has been denied tenure because of his insistence on teaching the works of William Shakespeare, and at least one student newspaper in Canada is not amused. The head of the department had maintained that Shakespeare was "racist and sexist" and therefore not appropriate content for university students, and subsequently vowed to "kill off the classics". The university has replaced Hamlet with "Betty the Yeti: An Eco Fable", in which a feminist environmentalist leaves her husband to go live "in harmony with nature" and begins a sexual affair with a sasquatch.

A gruff editorial response published in The Varsity, a student newspaper at the University of Toronto, Canada, said that such "assaults on the honour and integrity of higher education" are part of the wider problem of diversity consciousness at universities, with its own institution being a prime example. "The focus of academia these days, it seems, is not reason, not the pursuit of knowledge, not the preparation for a career but rather something called 'multiculturalism'," the paper complained.

The paper cited another recent case, at the University of Wisconsin, where an information brochure sent to prospective students featured a large photograph of students cheering on the school football team. The photo made sure to maintain an "ethnic balance" and featured an equal number of white, black, Asian and Hispanic students. The photo was a fake, doctored from an original in which all the cheering students had been white. The university had found this offensive and super-imposed photographs of minority students into the picture. "Most people are quick to accept this new code and even applaud it," the article said. "After all, this is about tolerance and equality, right? No, it's not. 'Ethnic diversity' is merely racism in a politically correct disguise."

Well, sure. But at The Post student paper at Ohio University, there were bigger fish to fry this past week. An editorial weighed in on the issue of the proposed amendment before the US Congress that would prohibit the physical desecration of the American national flag. The initiative already has more than 100 co-sponsors in the country's House of Representatives and it needs "to be struck down," the paper said. "It would be a very hollow victory indeed if we preserved the symbol of our freedom by chipping away at those fundamental freedoms themselves."

At the University of Melbourne, in Australia, the student organ Farrago ran the colourful but possibly overstated headline, "Why Melbourne University Is Fucked". The article reported that the institution's vice-chancellor, Alan Gilbert, had been acting in "an increasingly ditzy manner" after a London newspaper revealed that the institution's sponsorship plans for a private university looked to be on very shaky financial ground. The paper also included news of a report tabled recently in the Australian parliament that examines the question of possible links between a $2m "donation" made recently to the university and the upgrading of an unidentified postgraduate student's marks.

Singapore's Quo Vadis Aspire, the official voice of the student union at the National University of Singapore, appeared to be tempting fate this week by running what it billed as being an independently minded article on one of the city-state's few opposition MPs, Chiam See Tong, who recently visited the national university to address a lunchtime meeting of 400 students. "I was never the type to attend any political rallies or worry too deeply about the political fate of Singapore," writer Kenneth Tan began. However, he added, a touch generously, "while I disagreed with many issues Mr Chiam raised and was generally unimpressed with his sometimes lame answers in the Q&A session, I managed to get something out of the lecture. I walked out with my thoughts provoked and though I most probably wouldn't stand in Hong Lim Square speaking for the Opposition, much less vote for them (at least not in the next elections), their alternative voice is one to be heard." So that's OK then. (A title of another unintentionally humorous article published in the same edition of the publication read, "Cell-phones - Friend Or Foe?")

And this just in at The Heights, the student newspaper at Boston College, "I've been itching to get this out for a while," wrote Annie Barrat, in an editorial page commentary on current affairs. "Mayonnaise is wonderful. It tastes great. It's a major asset to any sandwich, or to fries, if you're going for that pseudo-European or 'Matthew Perry in The Whole Nine Yards' look... So go out there, grab some packets, and go nuts. You too can 'show them' and 'live on the edge".

fields.headline: Mapmaking martyr
fields.standfirst:
Ian Thomas loves making maps. His talent won him respect and a US government job. So why was he fired for putting a chart of caribou calving areas on the internet? Julian Borger reports

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Ian Thomas loves making maps. His talent won him respect and a US government job. So why was he fired for putting a chart of caribou calving areas on the internet? Julian Borger reports.
fields.body:
For some people, maps are an obsession. They may be drawn in by the bright colours, or the vicarious sense of adventure, or the impression of order that maps impose on the world. Whatever it is, Ian Thomas is one of those people. He is fanatical. Thomas makes maps for a living and stays up until midnight making them in his spare time. He has a gift for it, no doubt inherited from his father, who analysed aerial photographs for the RAF nearly half a century ago, scrutinising Egyptian troop movements during the Suez conflict.

Now the son, Watford-born but a naturalised American, stares at the world through a computer screen, summoning up a satellite image of just about any corner of the globe he chooses. With a few more clicks and a bit of web browsing he can conjure up some relevant data, put it together with the image and make a picture that tells you something about the world. By his own estimate he has done this 20,000 times or more in his short career as a hi-tech cartographer.

It is a skill that has earned him a living and a good deal of respect from his colleagues at the US Geological Survey (USGS). But it has also taken him on to a particularly nasty political battlefield, and he has consequently been sacked and become a cause célèbre - mapmaking's first modern martyr. All this because of a single map the size of a postcard. He put it together on the evening of March 7 with some data he had collected about the calving habits of caribou - North America's oversize version of reindeer - in a remote corner of Alaska for a project that had failed to win funding.

It turned out that his map was far too clear for his own good. It charted, for all to see, where the Bush administration was going with its environmental policies - and the price it was willing to pay to get there. The map depicted, in brilliant red, the area of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge where caribou most often go in spring to have their calves. It was a narrow strip along the state's northern coast, adjacent to the Canadian border. It was also known as Area 1002, and it was precisely the strip of land that the new US government was proposing to open up for exploration and exploitation by the oil companies that had backed George Bush's election campaign.

Thomas now swears that when he put the map on the internet he had no idea where the administration wanted to drill for oil. Sitting in a Washington pub, looking back on the extraordinary chain of events of the past two weeks, he says: "If they had just told me, I would have taken it down. I didn't want to cause any trouble. I loved my job."

Unfortunately, it was too late for Thomas, whose timing could not have been worse. His map appeared on the internet just as the new secretary of the interior, Gale Norton, was being briefed on the Arctic refuge's ecology. Norton's job is to champion the cause of Arctic drilling. On the evidence of its environmental policies to date, this administration is not merely pro-business; it actually appears to hold a grudge against the natural world. It has rejected the Kyoto treaty on global warming, ruled out statutory limits on industrial carbon dioxide emissions, dropped a ban on building roads through indigenous forests, closed down wildlife research centres and even lifted federal limits on the permissible level of arsenic that mining companies are allowed to leave in the water table.

Throughout, it has maintained the same Orwellian tone of reassurance. The soothing message on the Arctic wildlife refuge was that oil prospecting would only affect one small part of it and that the animals would hardly notice the derricks.

Thomas's map showed that the supposedly small area under consideration was critical to the refuge's wildlife. All the experts briefing Norton knew this, but the map made the point in public, and its appearance triggered alarm bells at the higher reaches of USGS management, which was already worried about its future funding. The word went out that the people at the top were demanding the head of the mapmaker responsible.

When Thomas came to work the following Monday, there was a note on his door ordering him to see his supervisor. He had failed to see a warning from a colleague in Alaska telling him to take his map off the web. Two weeks on, the sense of shock remains.

"I'd never been in trouble before," he says. "No one had complained before about any of my maps. They way overreacted."

Thomas asked for the right to provide a written explanation and defence of his actions, but his employers refused to accept it. Thomas decided he would write it anyway, for his own satisfaction. So he stayed behind that night clearing his desk and working on his letter.

"I stayed to 5am on Tuesday morning, and I thought, 'I'll just send out the letter on the internet, just to explain what had happened.' By 5.15 am, I got my first email letter back. It was from someone in South Korea, saying, 'This is terrible and I'm going to send it to everyone I know.' And I thought, 'Oh shit.' "

Thus a green icon was born. The tale of Thomas's martyrdom spread around the world via internet chatrooms in a matter of hours, and he received 2,000 emails of support. His cause was taken up by Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility, Defenders of Wildlife and a host of other pressure groups. By his own admission, the mapmaker is an unlikely and an entirely accidental hero. Thomas would probably not even have come to the US had he not been in the University of London student union bar to see a band called The Telescopes one night in 1991.

He fell in love with an American girl doing temporary work for the union, and followed her back to the US the same year when he finished his engineering degree. By chance, the National Audubon Society, a private conservation group, was looking for someone with a knowledge of hydrology for a research project on Nebraska's Platte River, a route taken by many migratory birds.

That triggered his interest in wildlife, which in turn got him a job at the Nature Conservancy (the US version of the National Trust), where he learned to make maps. In 1998 he ended up at the USGS, where he found his niche at the migratory birds department at Patuxent, a set in 20 square miles of protected Maryland wetlands.

Since his dismissal, the interior department has portrayed Thomas as an ideological maverick operating beyond the control of his supervisors. "Mr Thomas was not doing the work he was paid to do and was instead doing what he chose to do," said Trudy Harlow, a USGS spokeswoman now working for Gale Norton. "He was counselled repeatedly to stick to what he was meant to be doing...This caribou map was just the straw that broke the camel's back."

Furthermore, Harlow said, the map was plain wrong, a gross simplification of out-of-date information. For that reason, his contract was terminated by local management, without any interference from above.

Throughout his three years at Patuxent, Thomas's skills were highly regarded. He was encouraged to put together maps for all departments. He was even given an USGS award for his far-reaching work. "I used my contract money to get him to do things for me on the things I was doing," says Sam Droege, a researcher on amphibians at Patuxent. "We are all of us working outside our job descriptions in our general mandate of promoting conservation. Ian was very highly regarded. He was a person who could do all sorts of novel and interesting things and he was really good at finding information."

It looks as if the order to get rid of Thomas came from outside Patuxent. The warning email he had failed to read the weekend before his dismissal came from a colleague who had taken part in the Alaska meeting with Norton. The charge which does stick, however, is that the map was inaccurate. It was based largely on 1999 data, but as Thomas points out, that was the latest information publicly available. Meanwhile, Brad Griffith, a caribou researcher on whose work the map was based, is annoyed that Thomas did not consult him and says the bright red "hot spot" area for caribou calving should really be much bigger. Thomas pleads guilty. "If only I had managed to find Griffith, I could have put it right," he says. "My map is actually good for the oil companies. That's the irony."

fields.bodyText: For some people, maps are an obsession. They may be drawn in by the bright colours, or the vicarious sense of adventure, or the impression of order that maps impose on the world. Whatever it is, Ian Thomas is one of those people. He is fanatical. Thomas makes maps for a living and stays up until midnight making them in his spare time. He has a gift for it, no doubt inherited from his father, who analysed aerial photographs for the RAF nearly half a century ago, scrutinising Egyptian troop movements during the Suez conflict. Now the son, Watford-born but a naturalised American, stares at the world through a computer screen, summoning up a satellite image of just about any corner of the globe he chooses. With a few more clicks and a bit of web browsing he can conjure up some relevant data, put it together with the image and make a picture that tells you something about the world. By his own estimate he has done this 20,000 times or more in his short career as a hi-tech cartographer. It is a skill that has earned him a living and a good deal of respect from his colleagues at the US Geological Survey (USGS). But it has also taken him on to a particularly nasty political battlefield, and he has consequently been sacked and become a cause célèbre - mapmaking's first modern martyr. All this because of a single map the size of a postcard. He put it together on the evening of March 7 with some data he had collected about the calving habits of caribou - North America's oversize version of reindeer - in a remote corner of Alaska for a project that had failed to win funding. It turned out that his map was far too clear for his own good. It charted, for all to see, where the Bush administration was going with its environmental policies - and the price it was willing to pay to get there. The map depicted, in brilliant red, the area of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge where caribou most often go in spring to have their calves. It was a narrow strip along the state's northern coast, adjacent to the Canadian border. It was also known as Area 1002, and it was precisely the strip of land that the new US government was proposing to open up for exploration and exploitation by the oil companies that had backed George Bush's election campaign. Thomas now swears that when he put the map on the internet he had no idea where the administration wanted to drill for oil. Sitting in a Washington pub, looking back on the extraordinary chain of events of the past two weeks, he says: "If they had just told me, I would have taken it down. I didn't want to cause any trouble. I loved my job." Unfortunately, it was too late for Thomas, whose timing could not have been worse. webTitle: Brahms cleared of serial cat slaying

fields.headline: Brahms cleared of serial cat slaying
fields.standfirst: Author's research reveals calumny that for 100 years defamed German composer was the malicious gossip of 'notoriously bitchy' Wagner
fields.trailText: Johannes Brahms, bewhiskered composer of four symphonies, has been cleared of one of the most serious charges ever levelled at a musical genius - the accusation that he was a serial cat slayer.
fields.body:
Johannes Brahms, bewhiskered composer of four symphonies, has been cleared of one of the most serious charges ever levelled at a musical genius - the accusation that he was a serial cat slayer.

For more than a century, cat lovers have accepted as true the allegation that Brahms slaughtered felines, transcribed the sounds of their dying moments and callously incorporated them in to his works.

But research proves that the foul calumny was almost certainly the work of Richard Wagner, a notoriously bitchy composer whose operas go on longer than one of the nine lives of an average mog.

Writing in the May issue of the BBC Music Magazine, Calum MacDonald, who is the author of a study of Brahms, dismisses the charge on empirical grounds. "In my own limited but miserable experience, dying cats don't tend to make much noise," he says.

In his review of the evidence, he notes that stories of Brahms killing cats surface mainly in books about cats rather than in books about music "which is suspicious in itself".

He finds one of the most recent accounts in Desmond Morris's Cat World, published in 1996, which claims that Brahms began cat bagging after the Czech composer Antonin Dvorak gave him a "Bohemian sparrow slaying bow".

Brahms used to take aim from his apartment window in Vienna, alleges Morris, who then quotes Wagner: "After spearing the poor brutes, he reeled them in to his room after the manner of a trout-fisher. Then he eagerly listened to the expiring groans of his victims and carefully jotted down in his notebook their ante mortem remarks."

Morris adds: "According to Wagner, who disliked Brahms, he worked these sounds into his chamber music."

MacDonald dismisses every detail of this account as suspect and reports that Morris cannot now find the source for Wagner's comments. He also explains that Wagner never visited Brahms's flat, so at best could only have been retailing gossip. Dvorak and Brahms met in 1880, only three years before Wagner died, leaving a very limited time for Brahms to become an expert with the Bohemian bow and for Wagner to get wind of the story, had it been true.

MacDonald adds: "Dvorak would presumably have to have given Brahms the bow in person but their collected correspondence contains no letter saying, 'Please, Honoured Master, accept this amusing artefact from my native land'."

He then asks: "Is there really such a thing as a 'Bohemian sparrow slaying bow'?

"Brahms's 'apartment' is presumably his flat in the Karlgasse, which was several floors up, so he'd need a long line to haul up any speared moggies. Did sparrow slaying bows have lines attached? It surely wouldn't be strong enough to haul in dying cats, especially if they were struggling."

After consulting Styra Avins, editor of Johannes Brahms: Life and Letters, MacDonald learned that in 1893 - when Brahms was still alive - a music critic for the New York Times, James Huneker, had cited the story of the composer's hatred of cats as an example of how biography could be contaminated by deliberate fiction. Huneker named Wagner as the guilty man.

"Brahms's supposed sadism is a malicious fabrication," MacDonald concludes. Which means the rest of us can listen to the clarinet quintet without fearing that some of its finest moments were inspired by a cat yowling its way to oblivion.

Catty genius

Richard Wagner (1818-1883)

The dramatic radical who took music into new realms of tonality and, with a godlike certainty of his genius, demanded universal applause. He built his own theatre in Bayreuth, Germany, in which to stage the music dramas on which his fame rests.

He proved irresistible to women, including Cosima, daughter of Franz Liszt and wife of the conductor Hans von Bulow, who apparently did not mind losing his partner to an intellectual superior.

Wagner wrote: "I am being used as the instrument for something higher than my own being warrants. I am in the hands of the immortal genius that I serve for the span of my life."

Trying to find something to say to Brahms after hearing one of his works, he commented: "The evil only starts when one attempts to compose better than one can."

Maligned maestro

Johannes Brahms (1833-1897)

A romantic who idolised Beethoven and was so intimidated by his predecessor's genius that he waited until he was 43 to produce his own first symphony. He wrote three more, plus two concertos for piano, one for violin, one for violin and cello and a series of chamber works.

Robert and Clara Schumann invited him to share their home. Brahms, who never had a lasting relationship with a woman, may have been in love with Clara. He supported her when Robert tried to kill himself.

In later life, he was known for his rudeness. Once, as he left a party in Vienna, he said: "If there is someone here whom I have not insulted, I apologise."

fields.headline: Discovery could take pain out of diabetes treatment
fields.standfirst: Hope of insulin inhaler replacing daily injections
fields.trailText: The pain and inconvenience of regular injections could become a thing of the past after a team of scientists stumbled on a means of administering some drugs with an inhaler.
fields.body:
The pain and inconvenience of regular injections could become a thing of the past after a team of scientists stumbled on a means of administering some drugs with an inhaler.

Researchers at the universities of Strathclyde and Glasgow have found a way of making drug particles so small they can pass through the lung wall and into the blood.

The technology, which could be available for public use within four years, could radically improve the quality of treatment for thousands of insulin-dependent diabetics who have to inject their medication.

Until now, drugs based on natural proteins, such as insulin, have had to be given by injection, because if they were taken in tablet form they would be broken down by acids in the stomach.

Researchers at the two universities have been working together on the project for the last two years after a team of chemists at Strathclyde stumbled across the process during an experiment on enzyme-based catalysts.

The newly-patented technology has been developed to allow the manufacture of protein-coated microcrystals, which can be absorbed into the bloodstream.

The particles are being tested using dry powder inhalers similar to those used by asthma sufferers. An artificial lung is being used to check that the particles are small enough to pass deep into the lung.

The technology could also be used to treat many other diseases such as cystic fibrosis, osteoporosis, emphysema and multiple sclerosis.

The project has received funding from Scottish Enterprise's Proof of Concept fund, which encourages technological innovations.

Barry Moore, of Strathclyde University's department of pure and applied chemistry, said that the breakthrough was significant and could revolutionise the treatment of countless people.

"Essentially we have found a way of making very fine protein particles - so fine that they are able to get to the base of the lung," he said.

"To do that they need to be 100th of the width of a human hair. The whole idea of being able to administer protein-based drugs without having an injection is enormously helpful. People who need to have injections regularly miss them because they don't feel up to it or can't face it."

Dr Moore said it could be up to four years before the process was completed and any product available for public use. Researchers in America are also working on similar projects.

Bill Hartnett of the support group Diabetes UK said the news was very encouraging.

"It could be a breakthrough for people with diabetes," he said. "It would remove the social stigma and the discomfort of having to inject up to four times a day.

"It is something we would be delighted to see. It is still in the trial stages but so far the results look encouraging."

webTitle: Woman's skull drilled during radical gene therapy to fight Alzheimer's

fields.headline: Woman's skull drilled during radical gene therapy to fight Alzheimer's
fields.trailText: An ex- teacher, aged 60, has become the first person to be given gene therapy to fight the effects of Alzheimer's, in a procedure which involved drilling a hole in her skull and injecting cells inside her brain.
fields.body:
An ex- teacher, aged 60, has become the first person to be given gene therapy to fight the effects of Alzheimer's, in a procedure which involved drilling a hole in her skull and injecting cells inside her brain.

The woman, who has not been named, underwent the 11-hour operation last week at a hospital attached to the University of San Diego in California. She was discharged two days later, but it will be at least a month before scientists know whether the procedure has been effective.

The operation was masterminded by neurologist Mark Tuszynski and carried out by neurosurgeon Hoi Sang U, leaders of a team which has been working toward trying the technique in humans for 12 years. There is likely to be scepticism in the wider Alzheimer's research community at the value of such a radical approach.

"This approach is not targeting the disease itself," warned Declan McLoughlin, a lecturer in old age psychiatry at King's College London.

"Although there is some scientific rationale for doing it, you could say a lot of current work has superseded it," he said.

The procedure targets a thumbnail-sized region of the brain called the nucleus basalis of Meynert, which produces a substance called acetylcholine, critical in modulating thought and memory.

The San Diego team's approach is to take a sample of skin cells from the patient months before surgery and insert a gene in them which expresses a chemical called nerve growth factor (NGF).

These cells are multiplied in culture, tested to see that they are producing the right amount of NGF, and then injected into the nucleus basalis with a fine needle put through a hole in the patient's skull.

Critics say drugs already exist which target the lack of acetylcholine in the brain of Alzheimer's patients.

 Birth defects in babies of women who take medicine for epilepsy while they are pregnant are caused by drugs and not by epilepsy, according to new research reported in the US, writes Sarah Boseley. The study, in the New England Journal of Medicine today, claims the idea that the genetic abnormalities which cause the epilepsy are then passed on to the foetus, is wrong.

fields.headline: Science uncovers secrets of past disasters
fields.standfirst: Superhot gas killed 300 people fleeing Herculaneum
fields.trailText: Superhot gas killed 300 people fleeing Herculaneum.
fields.body:
When the eruption of Vesuvius turned day into night over the Bay of Naples and buried the town of Pompeii in AD79, around 300 people from nearby Herculaneum thought they had escaped. They had raced to take cover in caves along the shore, hollowed out to house their boats, and they were still alive 12 hours after the first catastrophic blast.

And then came the fatal surge. A cloud of gas heated to around 500C burst from the collapsed mountainside, billowed through the empty town of Herculaneum without disturbing the most fragile heat-resistant object, raced on over the silent terrain, reached a 20 metre cliff, dropped down suddenly, and in a freak effect, funnelled into the boat chambers and killed the cowering fugitives instantly.

They had - according to a report from a British-Italian team in today's Nature - no chance at all. They had no time to gasp, or clutch at each other, or even writhe in a split second of torment. Alberto Incoronato of the University of Naples Federico II and colleagues studied 80 of the intact skeletons and after more than 1,920 years, produced a forensic report.

"These individuals," they write, "do not display any evidence of voluntary self-protective reaction or agony contortions, indicating that the activity of their vital organs must have stopped within a shorter time than the conscious reaction time, a state known as fulminant shock."

The Vesuvius eruption was pyroclastic: it sent a great wall of superheated gas and rock at hurricane speeds, followed by thousands of tons of ash. In the streets of Pompeii, the partly-fossilised victims overtaken by clouds of ash and flaming dust seem to writhe in the torment of suffocation.

The people of Herculaneum had more warning, and headed for rescue from the sea. In the boat sheds that became their tombs - first discovered only in the 1980s -there was no sign of suffering. The ash that arrived with the superheated gas suddenly cooled, became denser, and engulfed the bodies. Some of the skeletons had the kind of fractures seen in incinerated remains. The skull surfaces were blacked, the tooth enamel was cracked, indicating that the temperature had been at up to 500C. Some of the skeletons showed fists clenched in a pugilistic pose.

"When your muscles cook - from any cause, not just a volcanic cloud - they coagulate and they contract the arms and the legs, but the spine extends," said Peter Baxter, of the University of Cambridge clinical school, one of the team. "So you get a funny shape of somebody who looks as though they are trying to box with the head back, and their hands up, and the legs are flexed in a crouching position. This is within a very short time of death."

"But there are more sophisticated plans for evacuation."

webTitle: Scientists solve riddle of Assam quake

fields.headline: Geologists find fault to solve quake mystery
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Two science detectives have solved the riddle of the worst earthquake in modern history.
fields.body:
Two science detectives have solved the riddle of the worst earthquake in modern history.

Seismologists estimate that the Assam quake of June 12 1897 reached magnitude 8.8 on the Richter scale. During the shock, which left 1,542 dead, a plateau in the Shillong district of what is now Bangladesh rose by 15 metres (50ft) in three seconds.

Boulders, gravestones and even people were thrown into the air. In lower Assam, rice fields that had been flat before the quake were thrown into metre-high undulations, like a crumpled carpet. Buildings across an area the size of England were reduced to rubble.

Because the quake happened in the afternoon, most people were outside, but 600 died in landslides. A week later, on a tea estate in Assam, a glass of water left on a table was reported to have not stopped trembling since the quake.

In 1897, seismology was in its infancy and for more than 100 years scientists puzzled over the cause of the calamity. But today in the magazine Nature, Roger Bilham of the University of Colorado at Boulder and Philip England of Oxford University have the answer.

The lethal weapon was a blind thrust fault of the kind that killed 25,000 in Gujarat in January and triggered the Los Angeles earthquake of 1994. A blind thrust fault does not rupture the surface. There is no evidence for later settlers of a fault line, and thus no hint of future hazard.

The two geologists used theodolite measurements, made by the Survey of India more than a century ago, and computer models to calculate the existence of a lethal fault - 78 miles long - that dips between five and 20 miles under the surface of the Shillong Plateau south of Bhutan. They calculated that the fault slipped by about 15 metres (50ft) - one of the largest ever movements for an earthquake.

They called it the Oldham fault, after the geologist who studied the Assam disaster. Over the century, the hazard has crept further south, increasing the danger to Bangladesh, which has a population of 130m.

"Fortunately an earthquake as powerful as the Assam event only occurs about once every 3,000 years on the Oldham fault," said Professor Bilham. "They are very rare, but could be extremely devastating in this region, given the huge population now living in Bangladesh and the poor construction practices there."

webTitle: A day in the life of a teacher in Moscow

fields.headline: A day in the life of a teacher in Moscow
fields.trailText: "9am: Set off for work from our tiny, two-roomed Kryshchev flat". An EFL teacher finds living in Moscow a difficult experience.
fields.body:
6am : My body clock awakens me, as usual, a few minutes before my 20-month-old son opens his eyes. I am 52 years old and, unable to find work as a language teacher in the UK, in 1995 I completed a one-month CTEFL training course and set off for Russia. Here I not only found work, but also a wife. We now have two children.

9am: I set off for work. The children have been changed and fed and our tiny, two-roomed "Kryshchev" flat has been put back in order.

Moscow has an official population of about 10 million and an endemic shortage of accommodation. In the 60's, Nikita Kryshchev inaugurated a quick building programme of tiny flats which now bear his name and are slowly being replaced with more spacious accommodation. Living in a Kryshchev flat is like living in a small boat, where space is utilised to a maximum and everything has its place. Beds fold away and the walls are lined with cupboards and shelves.

I live in central Moscow, about a mile and a half from the walls of the Kremlin. I always travel by Metro. The Moscow Metro is justifiably the best in the world, not only because of its architectural grandeur; one rarely has to wait more than three minutes for the arrival of a train. The downside, however, is that the trains are often packed to capacity on weekdays and it is often unbearably stuffy during the hot Moscow summer. When I first arrived in the city as a student in the dying days of the Soviet Union, everything used to shut down at 9pm. One could then stroll through the quiet streets, only rarely seeing any privately owned vehicles. Now the streets are packed with cars, mostly imported Mercs and BMWs that would make a British road-worthiness inspector's hair stand on end. Driving in Moscow is a nightmare. Traffic lights are universally ignored; and "new Russians" in their brand-new American or Japanese jeeps regularly mount the pavements to beat the inevitable snarl-ups, treating pedestrians with less respect than they would farmyard chickens. Travelling by Metro is the only way to avoid this insanity.

9.40am: I arrive at the language school where for the past two years I have done most of my work. Since coming to Russia, I have worked as a freelance EFL teacher, having realised that I am clearly operating in a seller's market. I have taught in banks and schools, teaching adults and children, both in groups and individually. A native English speaker is worth his or her weight in gold here; academic qualifications are of secondary importance.

Russian language schools are usually more than willing to hire teachers with little or no experience, which is a problem. Russia is one of the few countries in the world where EFL teachers are not required to have, as a minimum, an education to a first-degree standard or any teaching experience. There is therefore a surfeit of inexperienced teachers, most of whom arrive not knowing what to expect. Most of them belong to the "anti-grammar" school of teaching methodology, either because they have been trained to teach that way or because they themselves have scant knowledge of English grammar. "Grammar translation" is the main foreign language teaching method in Russian schools. Russian students, be they young or old, expect a teacher to explain the grammatical whys and wherefores of the English language, and if such explanations are not immediately forthcoming, then they consider their instruction to be of dubious quality. It is partly for this reason that there is a large turnover rate of EFL teachers in Russia. I have many times witnessed students refusing to be taught by people who, in their opinion, are not teachers.

Personally, I tell my students that they will not learn to speak English by learning grammatical "rules". Nevertheless, I always keep in mind that I am selling them a product and if, for whatever reason, they question the quality of that product, I feel that I must modify it according to their demands.

The other main cause of the large turnover rate of EFL teachers in Russia is simply that Russia is not an easy country to live in. Many teachers spend their time here counting the days remaining until the end of their contract.

10am-12.15am: My first lesson: an adult group at upper-intermediate level. In Russia there are "astronomical hours" and "academic hours". The former are what are known worldwide as hours that last for 60 minutes and the latter are "teaching hours" that last for 45 minutes.

The average rate of pay in Moscow EFL schools is now US$12 an hour. Most schools pay in dollars and roubles, usually on a 50/50 basis. However, if the management appreciates your value, you can receive all your pay in dollars. I earn around $2,500 a month and live well. A skilled manual worker is lucky to earn $50 a month. Food is cheap - for a Westerner - and plentiful, but imported luxury goods are expensive. British Home Stores recently closed its Moscow outlet, which was hardly surprising since their products were marked up by at least 50% on their UK selling price. You can buy Guinness in Irish bars here for about £4.50 a pint, and you can buy a decent Russian beer for about 25p a pint.

Few people pay tax in Russia. I think I do, but I do not really know. There is a PAYE system, but I receive cash in hand and ask no questions. I just simply presume that the two companies with whom I have contracts make tax contributions on my behalf. To date, the tax police have not visited me.

I use the usual Oxford/Cambridge University Press course books provided by the schools. I do little lesson preparation, as I know these courses by heart. They are unsuitable for Russians, being either too eurocentric - the question, "Ask your partner where you went on holiday last year", gives rise to the almost universal response, "To my grandparents* in the country" - or downright boring. Therefore, over the years I have accumulated masses of my own material and often use the internet as a teaching source. I am also writing my own course book targeted at Russian speakers, which I hope to have published this year.

1pm-2.30pm: Second lesson, teaching two Russian teachers of English. I use a conversational English course book and my own materials. Russian teachers have little idea of correct register, hardly ever use phrasal verbs, avoid modals and make horrendous errors when attempting to express conditional sentences. They also have a major pronunciation problem as they believe that "correct" English is the RP of 70 years ago and usually sound like an American actor taking off Noel Coward.

3pm-4.30pm: Individual tuition, with a 14-year-old girl whose banker father wants her to study at Roedean. She has already studied for four years at a private school in Baden-Baden and her English is suffering a severe case of German grammar interference. I have negotiated a special rate for this work: $15 an hour. The banker is more than willing to pay this fee after having previously found out how much the British Council wanted for private tuition.

4.30pm-6pm: A back-to-back lesson, which is not really good policy, but I have a wife and two babies to feed. One to one tuition of a schoolgirl again, but this time for only $10 an hour. The girl knows and understands the basic grammatical structure of English - although she believes that there is an English future tense and therefore overuses "will" - but she cannot speak English. In other words, she is suffering the classic symptoms of grammar-translation tuition. She is only too happy doing grammar exercises, but speak she will not. It is like getting water out of a stone trying to get her to talk and very tiring. The lesson drags on to its close.

6pm-7pm: A welcome break. I can mark some homework and prepare the next lesson.

7pm-9.15pm: Last lesson, with an advanced group of adults. Two of the group of eight have lived and worked in the USA and are already fluent English speakers. The others still have major problems: modals, conditionals, pronunciation, wrong tenses, wrong register and limited vocabulary. By the end of the lesson I am fighting to keep awake.

I normally get home at around 10.15pm and get to bed at around 1am or even later.

On my way home I buy a beer at a kiosk, where beggars immediately pester me for money. It can often be dangerous for a westerner to talk to strangers at night. The other day a colleague of mine was severely beaten by a gang of youths for no other reason than that he is a foreigner.

Young Russians slavishly imitate western fashions. At night they watch uncensored American films and repeat and learn all the obscenities they can. Most Russians are fascinated by the west, but at the same time many of them are envious of westerners. This dislike of foreigners is especially noticeable among the uneducated, although many educated Russians also have this curious love-hate relationship. This, together with the cramped living conditions, can often make Moscow a frustrating and unfriendly city to live in.

 The author of this piece wishes to write under a pseudonym

fields.headline: Blair attempts to charm teachers
fields.trailText: Prime minister attempts to woo teachers at their annual conference, but gives no ground on the key area of pay.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair told teachers this morning they were "the most crucial profession in Britain today".

Speaking at the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' annual conference in Torbay, the prime minister sought to reassure universities that his government is committed to education. But he gave no ground on the key area of teacher pay.

"You stand for the values which bind Britain together - equal worth, community responsibility and the right of everyone to get on and develop their talents to the full," Mr Blair said.

In what was almost a return to Labour's redistributive roots, Mr Blair said that first class schools must make a cash sacrifice in order for everyone to have a first class education.

He also sent out a message that he wants unions to stop emphasising teacher shortages, and said there are now more qualified teachers in schools than at any time since 1985.

There are now 10,000 more teachers than in 1997, with seven in 10 of those working in secondary schools

In the first speech ever by a prime minister to a classroom union, Mr Blair was in election mode, detailing a "key choice facing the British people" between Tory policies and his commitment to increase spending on schools, as a proportion of gross domestic product, throughout the next parliament.

However, Mr Blair kept to the government line that an independent review of pay and conditions would be welcome, but only once any industrial action was called off.

webTitle: 'Abuse and neglect' at school for deaf

fields.headline: 'Abuse and neglect' at school for deaf
fields.standfirst:
NSPCC report means institution faces closure

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A school for deaf children has been severely criticised by the NSPCC for a catalogue of abuse and neglect and practices which undermine fundamental child protection procedures.
fields.body:
A school for deaf children has been severely criticised by the NSPCC for a catalogue of abuse and neglect and practices which undermine fundamental child protection procedures.

An investigation was launched last May at the Royal Schools for the Deaf in Cheadle Hulme, Greater Manchester, after social services heard complaints of unexplained injuries and poor care and practice at the school, which teaches 78 children, aged between six and 21. It faces closure unless practices are radically improved.

Three members of staff have been suspended by the school but criminal charges are unlikely to be brought against them as the children are regarded as unable to give evidence in court.

Jean Daintith, director of social services at Stockport council, said: "The school provides a valuable regional resource, but its future existence is likely to depend on the willingness of the trustees and staff to accept the need for change and translate it into action."

A spokesman for the National Deaf Children's Society, said it was appalled by the NSPCC report and was gravely concerned by the extent of abuse at the school.

Unless significant immediate action was taken by the school, the society would advise parents to move their children elsewhere.

Stockport council has made 21 recommendations which it says should be implemented straight away. All staff must be trained in suitable restraint procedures, all injuries should be reported contemporaneously, and a weekly report should be made to the social services' child protection unit on all injuries sustained and action taken.

Dominic Tinner, development manager at the school, said there had been deficiencies in management and practice, but insisted that the allegations of abuse had not been substantiated. "We have already implemented a raft of management changes and we now have a child protection family liaison officer," he said.

Mark Fisher, a former employee who was a support worker for nine years, resigned after he compiled a dossier detailing 142 alleged incidents of abuse.

fields.bodyText: A school for deaf children has been severely criticised by the NSPCC for a catalogue of abuse and neglect and practices which undermine fundamental child protection procedures. An investigation was launched last May at the Royal Schools for the Deaf in Cheadle Hulme, Greater Manchester, after social services heard complaints of unexplained injuries and poor care and practice at the school, which teaches 78 children, aged between six and 21. It faces closure unless practices are radically improved. Three members of staff have been suspended by the school but criminal charges are unlikely to be brought against them as the children are regarded as unable to give evidence in court. Jean Daintith, director of social services at Stockport council, said: "The school provides a valuable regional resource, but its future existence is likely to depend on the willingness of the trustees and staff to accept the need for change and translate it into action." A spokesman for the National Deaf Children's Society, said it was appalled by the NSPCC report and was gravely concerned by the extent of abuse at the school. Unless significant immediate action was taken by the school, the society would advise parents to move their children elsewhere. Stockport council has made 21 recommendations which it says should be implemented straight away. All staff must be trained in suitable restraint procedures, all injuries should be reported contemporaneously, and a weekly report should be made to the social services' child protection unit on all injuries sustained and action taken. Dominic Tinner, development manager at the school, said there had been deficiencies in management and practice, but insisted that the allegations of abuse had not been substantiated. "We have already implemented a raft of management changes and we now have a child protection family liaison officer," he said. Mark Fisher, a former employee who was a support worker for nine years, resigned after he compiled a dossier detailing 142 alleged incidents of abuse. The parents of a former pupil, now aged 19, are suing the school, claiming she was restrained in a buggy and lost teeth and sustained cuts as she attempted to escape. The school denies the allegations.

webTitle: Ofsted chief promises teachers less hostile regime

fields.headline: Ofsted chief promises teachers less hostile regime
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education

Special report: Ofsted
fields.trailText: The head of the government's schools watchdog delighted teachers last night by promising a less aggressive inspection regime after the general election.
fields.body:
The head of the government's schools watchdog delighted teachers last night by promising a less aggressive inspection regime after the general election.

Mike Tomlinson, the chief inspector of schools, told the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference in Torquay that he wanted inspections to be "done with you, rather than to you". The move confirms a decisive break with the era of Chris Woodhead, who resigned as Ofsted's head in November after six years of conflict with teachers.

The pledge to delegates came as Tony Blair prepared to woo teachers with an appeal to the unions to join in a new "partnership" with the government to raise standards.

Mr Tomlinson told reporters that after the election he would unveil a new consultation paper on the future of school inspections, in advance of the next round beginning in 2003. This is likely to involve a prominent role for self-evaluation by teachers.

"I think there is a need to look again at the inspection system, not to take any of the rigour or proper challenge out of that process but to ensure that it's done with schools, not to schools," he said. The new system would involve taking more account of data collected by schools on staff performance and management.

"Inspection has to ask itself how it fits into that different environment," he said, but added: "I don't support Ofsted pulling back entirely. There is a need for an external objective look at the performance of schools ... by those not involved deeply in any shape or form in running the school."

Peter Smith, general secretary of the ATL, said: "It is extremely good news. Ofsted is going to become a resource and support to schools."

Eddie Ferguson, president of the ATL, said: "Times they are a-changing. Who would have believed 12 months ago that we would have given such a warm reception to the chief inspector of schools."

Earlier, delegates had unanimously passed a resolution calling for a revamp of the inspectorate to "aid the positive development of each and every school in England".

But Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said last night: "There is scope for Ofsted to change the way it inspects schools, but for the sake of maintaining standards we need Ofsted to remain rigorous and independent."

Mr Blair will today urge delegates to join "a partnership founded on trust and honesty on both sides", as he hails teachers' "skill, dedication and sheer hard work".

"I am here because teaching is the most critical profession in Britain today," he will tell the delegates in Torquay. "You stand for the values which bind Britain together: equal worth, community, responsibility and the right of everyone to get on and develop their talents to the full."

He will insist education remains his priority, and pledge to increase again the share of national income spent on education in the next parliament.

On Monday, the ATL, the most moderate of the main associations, voted to join three other teacher unions in fighting for a 35-hour working week. Mr Smith, threatened "civil disobedience" in the classroom.

Mr Blair will present new figures showing that 10,000 more teachers have been employed since 1997, with half of them coming in the last year.

fields.headline: Leakey sued in Kenya court
fields.trailText: The distinguished palaeontologist Richard Leakey is being sued in a Kenyan court for allegedly intervening, when head of the Kenyan civil service, to halt a criminal case.
fields.body:
The distinguished palaeontologist Richard Leakey is being sued in a Kenyan court for allegedly intervening, when head of the Kenyan civil service, to halt a criminal case.

John Nottingham, the British-born owner of a failed flower-growing business, claims that Mr Leakey abused his office by halting the prosecution of four men accused of defrauding the company. Mr Leakey, former head of the Kenyan wildlife service, was a cabinet minister and head of the civil service from July 1999 until his resignation last month.

AP, Nairobi

webTitle: Take Easter break in countryside, urges PM

fields.headline: Take Easter break in countryside, urges PM
fields.standfirst:
 Blair and Prescott visit tourist attractions
 1.75m Britons to holiday abroad
 Epidemic 'flattening out', says chief scientist

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 Blair and Prescott visit tourist attractions
 1.75m Britons to holiday abroad
 Epidemic 'flattening out', says chief scientist
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
Tony Blair and John Prescott were today making further visits to countryside tourist attractions in an attempt to persuade Britons that foot and mouth should not stop them holidaying in the UK this Easter.

The deputy prime minister visited the Grand Union Canal in Tring, Hertfordshire, to announce the reopening to walkers of 1,000 miles of towpaths - two thirds of the national total.

The prime minister was set to make a trip to a seaside resort and country pub in Devon to drive home the point that, even in the areas worst hit by the disease, facilities were still open for visitors.

Their efforts come amid predictions that some 1.75m Britons will flee foot and mouth and the forecasted showers by taking an Easter break abroad. Many tourism businesses are expecting trade to be significantly below normal over the Easter period - traditionally the first busy weekend of the holiday year. The British Hospitality Association yesterday predicted foot-and-mouth would cost the industry around £5bn this spring and summer.

But crisis for farmers has begun showing signs of easing. The government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, announced yesterday that the numbers of outbreaks appeared to be "flattening out".

Although a firm date for eradicating the disease could not accurately be predicted, Prof King said latest figures showed there was now a steady decrease in the average number of new cases being recorded each day.

The average number for the week ending April 8 stood at 32 a day, compared with 43 for the previous week.

The reopening today of 1,000 miles of canal towpaths follows talks between Mr Prescott and British Waterways.

Mr Prescott said he was confident that reopening the towpaths posed no risk of exacerbating the problems caused by the disease.

He said: "We have done a risk analysis. British Waterways had a helicopter along all the waterways to ensure there was no risk."

"Our priority is to eradicate foot and mouth disease in the UK. However, we must strike a balance between tackling the disease and reducing its impact on the rural economy, not just farming but all kinds of business, including tourism."

Mr Blair was expected to stress that 60% of Easter tourism is made up of short trips by local people within their home region.

He will say that he was encouraged yesterday to be told by farmers' leaders that they recognised the need to boost tourism as a way of getting the rural economy back to normal.

Meanwhile, environment minister Beverley Hughes was due to announce a £4m grant from the countryside agency to help local authorities speed up their review of footpath closures. The cash will help councils carry out risk assessments on footpaths and, where necessary, carry out remedial work such as the erection of fences to make them safe for use during the outbreak.

In Cumbria, the county worst hit by foot and mouth, more than 100 footpaths will be open over Easter, and a further 60 are presently being assessed for reopening.

As foot and mouth cases reached 1,225 yesterday, Prof King said improved culling times had fuelled hopes that the virus was finally being brought under control.

Government targets to slaughter infected livestock within 24 hours and livestock on neighbouring farms within two days were increasingly being met, he said.

Meanwhile, preliminary test results on a suspected foot and mouth case in Northern Ireland have proved negative, it was announced today.

Northern Ireland has so far had only one confirmed case of foot and mouth at a farm in South Armagh.

The news will come as a massive relief to farmers who feared a ban on exports was going to be reintroduced.


 Maff today said no more figures about the numbers of animals condemned by foot and mouth will be released until they are satisfied that latest statistics are both "robust" and "accurate".

Shadow agriculture minister Tim Yeo described Maff's claim that there was no immediate need for fresh statistics as "ludicrous".

fields.headline: Refugee Council faces financial crisis
fields.trailText: The Refugee Council is facing a financial deficit of £700,000 and has had to cut 44 posts. The charity has recently launched a five-year plan and changed some of its priorities but in common with other charities, it is finding it difficult to attract funding for core activities.
fields.body:
The Refugee Council is facing a financial deficit of £700,000 and has had to cut 44 posts. The charity has recently launched a five-year plan and changed some of its priorities but in common with other charities, it is finding it difficult to attract funding for core activities.

The government's dispersal of asylum seekers is also causing financial problems for the charity. Communications director Fazil Kawani said: "There are not enough community services in the regions and asylum seekers are returning to London adding extra pressure on the resources of the charity."

Over 300 asylum seekers are turning up every day at the Refugee Council's centre in Brixton asking for advice. As asylum seekers who return to London are not eligible for benefits the centre is also providing food. "We are very worried that people are going to end up on the street," added Mr Kawani.

The Refugee Council has no objection to dispersal as long as asylum seekers are supported in local communities. Mr Kawani said: "Some asylum seekers want to settle outside of London but they need interpreters, community services and legal advice - in many cases this doesn't exist. The asylum seekers are also facing racial harassment."

He added: "It is very difficult for us to make long-term decisions to run services around the country as most asylum seekers will be refused entry by the Home Office."

The Refugee Council is one of the leading charities working to support refugees and asylum seekers. Last year it expanded its staff from 200 to 500 to cope with the increasing numbers of asylum seekers. It provides a range of services including language training, advocacy and support.

As well as services, the charity acts as a campaigning organisation to promote asylum seekers' and refugees' rights.

fields.headline: Kilshaws decide against appeal
fields.trailText: The British couple who adopted twins on the internet have decided not to appeal against a ruling to return the babies to the US.
fields.body:
The British couple who adopted twins on the internet have decided not to appeal against a ruling to return the babies to the US.

Their solicitor, Michael Charles, said Judith and Alan Kilshaw had made the decision because it was in the best interests of the children.

He said the Kilshaws had found the decision very difficult and that they still cared very much for the twins.

"Throughout the proceedings they have been only too aware of the impact this has had on both the twins and their own children.

"In particular they are concerned about the continuing effect of being under the media's spotlights, which at times has been unkind and unfair," he said.

Mrs Kilshaw and her husband Alan claim they paid a US baby broker £8,200 to adopt the twin girls. The babies were taken by social services in January from a hotel in north Wales where the couple were staying and were placed with foster parents.

On Wednesday, Mrs Kilshaw spoke of her desire to start a new life in the US following the court's decision to return Kimberley and Belinda, now nine months old, to the US.

The twins' natural mother, Tranda Wecker, is said to be relieved the girls were returning to Missouri.

A Californian couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, who claimed they too paid for the twins, are believed to have dropped out of the custody battle after Mr Allen was arrested on suspicion of molesting two teenage girls.

webTitle: Israel and the Palestinians: the war of words continues

fields.headline: Israel and the Palestinians: the war of words continues
fields.standfirst:
Earlier this week we published an article by the Guardian's Middle East editor, Brian Whitaker, analysing media coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It attracted a huge postbag; below we publish a selection of your responses, including a strongly worded riposte from the Israeli embassy in London

Read Brian Whitaker's article
fields.trailText:
Earlier this week we published an article by the Guardian's Middle East editor, Brian Whitaker, analysing media coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It attracted a huge postbag; below we publish a selection of your responses, including a strongly worded riposte from the Israeli embassy in London.
Read Brian Whitaker's article
fields.body:
I came across a similar phenomenon while working in the US. I noticed that (and it stuck out a mile!) CNN referred to the British Army in Northern Ireland as "the occupying British forces". The inclusion of the one word "occupying" entirely changed the tone of the report.

I've also noticed that despite the disproportionate number of Palestinians that have been killed over the last six or so months, Time magazine chose to print the pictures from the funeral of an Israeli victim.
Dave Boyle, UK

The article missed one important fact: some journalists refer to Camp David, and how it was designed to find a way to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and occupation, of course. Arguably, Israel offered the Palestinians the most she could, consistent with her spiritual and demographic survival. The Palestinians rejected this offer.

Palestinians have a legitimate right to fight occupation. But if they choose to do so after they have rejected Israeli offers to end the occupation, and after failing to make bridging proposals of their own, then the picture is somewhat more complicated. This is why many stories on the conflict state that the Palestinians rejected Israeli offers at Camp David, something I rarely find in Guardian reports.
Avi Weinreb, Financial Journalist, Globes Business Newspaper, Israel

A classic I have oft observed is the use of "gunman", always and only ever prefixed with the word - you know it already - "Palestinian". Never "settler gunmen" or even "Israeli gunmen", these don't even sound right together, but oh, "Palestinian gunmen" we've heard all about them.

I don't know where the blame lies. I feel much is owed to the conditioning of the 70s / 80s media, when political use of the word "terrorist" justified every ethnic atrocity be it against the Lebanese or Palestinians. The nomenclature in this conflict has become accepted, part of the "journalese" that is deployed, and churned out by the Israeli PR team.

Yet it is all part of the greater picture. I'm continually horrified by the psychological warfare that ordinary Palestinians experience even when their homes and 1000-year olive groves are not being bulldozed.
Simon D'Oyly, London

Let me point out a further example of sloppy journalism - the use of the term "target" to refer to Palestinian homes, villages, or cities subject to sniper or machine gun fire, artillery shelling, rockets, or bombing by the Israeli military (called, of course, "Israeli Defence Forces", as if "defence" were the name of the game). A target is there precisely to be shot at - a piece of paper with concentric rings on it - and shooting at targets evokes no terror.

Having worked with journalists in China, I am aware that articles are not necessarily printed as dispatched. How much of the "sloppy journalism" referred to in the article originates with correspondents on the spot and how much to editors at home?
M. Henri Day, Molde, Norway

To argue (in the Guardian, of all places!) that Israel is "winning" the war of words regarding media coverage of the Middle East, is laughable.

One only has to think about the complete absence of the word "terrorism" when the media describe the regular and wilful targeting by Palestinian bombers of Israeli civilians deep in the heart of sovereign Israeli territory, to see that the British media at least, has long since given up on telling the story as it is, preferring to regurgitate simplistic images - as Brian Whitaker has done himself - of the weak and just Palestinian underdog fighting off the aggressive, oppressive Israeli occupier.

Or the use of the word "intifada", or uprising. The Guardian has been reporting for months that mass Palestinian protests have been replaced by regular drive-by shootings and other forms of guerrilla warfare, including mortars, but the paper and others like it still choose to refer to this violence as an "intifada" rather than what it is - a calculated unleashing of violence in order to secure diplomatic gain.

Or the term "hardline". Is Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon the only Middle East leader worthy of such an appellation? Are none of the others also "hardline"? And if they are, why is that word not used for them too?

Perhaps one of the most commonplace but insidious uses of particular terminology amongst the British media in covering this conflict is the consistent tendency to strip the Palestinian side of any volition or rationality, choosing instead to describe all Palestinian actions and reactions solely in emotional terms. By focusing incessantly on Palestinian "anger", the Western media regularly indulges the worst excesses of Palestinian behaviour, including the pre-meditated targeting of non-combatants, as if these actions are somehow explicable, and therefore tolerable, because of the seething emotions of Palestinian existence.

How often do we hear and read of this Palestinian anger as the sole explanatory factor regarding the Palestinian side of events, as if, on the one hand, Israelis don't also have similar emotions, but worse, as if the Palestinians are somehow a nation apart, one whose members don't make choices like all other people? In fact, the choices made since Camp David by the Palestinian leadership are key to understanding how the violence erupted in September and has continued for every one of the 200 days since. But don't expect your liberal press to tell you that, because to portray the Palestinians as somehow culpable and responsible for their own actions would upset the pat template of innocent Palestinian victimhood.

Of course, it is clear to all reasonable observers that the continued Israeli presence in the West Bank and Gaza remains a source of immense Palestinian frustration and dissatisfaction. Israel recognises this. Israel also recognises that in order to achieve its own aspirations of peace and security it must meet the Palestinians' own legitimate needs and aspirations. To balance these competing legitimacies is what we had - and need - a peace process for.

But it seems not a little ironic that in an article which decries the lack of context in Middle East reporting, there is no mention whatsoever of the entire Oslo peace process, the immense progress that was made as part of that process along the road to full Palestinian empowerment and self-determination, the fact that it was the Palestinian side which rejected the compromises on the table but refused to suggest counter-proposals, and the fact that within that process - supported and sanctioned by Western governments and the overwhelming majority of the mainstream media - Yasser Arafat and his Palestinian Authority undertook to resolve all disputes - including the question of the settlements - through peaceful means.

Moreover, if its context we're looking for, then the blanket Arab rejection of Israel which preceded and precipitated the war of 1967 must also be factored in to the mix. When we hear that the Palestinians demand to this day not only their own state of Palestine but also an eternal claim on the State of Israel by dint of the co-called "right of return", then there is every reason to keep this historic and fundamental rejection of Israel's right to exist very much in one's mind when "contextualizing" current events.

Ultimately, no matter what the journalists write, it is up to the sides to resolve their differences. Focusing on securing favourable media coverage, as so many of the Palestinians' actions over the last six months have been, is to miss the point entirely. The people they need to convince are not the media or the citizens of the west, but the Israelis.

However, in light of the daily vitriol heaped upon Israel and Israelis in the Palestinian media, in their school textbooks, in summer camps where Palestinian children are taught to use rifles, in light of the continued failure of Yasser Arafat even once in the last six months to speak out against the resort to violence (there have been over 3,500 separate shooting incidents by Palestinians in that time), in light of the fact that the worst of the Palestinian terrorists continue to roam free in Palestinian cities and prepare their heinous attacks against ordinary Israelis (Arafat has a police force of 40,000 in case he should ever want to use it), there is serious cause for doubt as to whether the Palestinians are genuinely ready at this time to rejoin the process of historic reconciliation.

As for the journalists - absolutely, bring on the context and the accurate use of language. Then at least Israel would win the war of words for real.
DJ Schneeweiss, Press Secretary, Embassy of Israel, London

As one who lives in the Arab world and works in public relations, I have discussed this issue many times with Arab friends and acquaintances (especially those who work in the media) and have been frustrated at the shrug of the shoulders that usually greets such observations. Such defeatism is, I believe, a result of the fact that they are a subject people, with a feeble, disorganised and corrupt leadership who feel powerless to confront in any way the machine - military and political - that faces them. The expressions of support that they receive from their Arab brethren are just that - expressions which though reflecting a genuine anguish for the human tragedy are about as substantial as a snowball in the desert.

When asked how I would suggest they deal with this situation I have responded with a simple phrase - play the game. Get the vernacular agreed, ensure that your key journalists are identified and briefed regularly by people who don't look like they've just come from a building site, don't do interviews in front of chanting crowds, confront biased and unfair reporting, insist on equality of airspace. And so on and so on.

While the Arab media, in particular the satellite media, burn with discussions about how to deal with the situation the Palestinians' engagement with the rest of the world is lamentable. A Palestinian friend put it well: "This is a family embarrassment. If the neighbours knock at the door we'll just keep quiet until they go away again." This failure to engage means that the only hope for the Palestinian position is that journalists will go through the slick Israeli media machine and begin doing what they're paid to do - report.
James Mullan, Dubai, United Arab Emirates

Dave Boyle, UK The article missed one important fact: some journalists refer to Camp David, and how it was designed to find a way to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and occupation, of course.
