His immediate thought is to load a shotgun and seek violent retribution, but he is persuaded by Murphy that the best way to get back at rich people is to hit them where it hurts - in their wallets. Politicians in Europe have - metaphorically speaking - been looking for their shotguns since George Bush said that the United States would not abide by its commitments under the Kyoto agreement on global warming. The president's view is that cutting emissions of greenhouse gases would be bad for the US economy. And in the president's scheme of things, the US economy comes first, second and third. The big polluters of corporate America have received a quick payback for all that campaign funding. Bush's repudiation of the Kyoto protocols has caused outrage in other countries, not because the Americans under Clinton were cutting carbon dioxide emissions (they weren't) but because Bush made it abundantly clear that he thought the US's economic might meant that it could blow a raspberry at the rest of the world. A European Union mission was sent to Washington but, predictably enough, returned empty-handed. But all is not lost. There is a way the rest of the world could respond effectively to American selfishness because it is the rest of the world that is bankrolling the excessive consumption that, in part, is the reason for the US's high CO<->2 emissions. As can be seen from the first chart, US greenhouse gas emissions per head are the highest in the developed world for any country other than Luxembourg. There are a number of reasons for this, including the fact that - as the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development noted in its annual health check on the US last year - consumption of fossil fuels is encouraged by gasoline prices being too low. So, with driving cheap and the economy growing rapidly, Americans have bought more cars and bigger cars over the past decade, and vast quantities of other consumer goods. The consequences of all this over-consumption are highlighted by the second chart, which shows what has been happening to the US current account in recent years. The burgeoning deficit is clear evidence that the US is living beyond its means. But the current account - broadly trade in goods and services - only makes up one half of a nation's balance of payments. The other half is the capital account, which shows whether a country is a net importer or a net exporter of capital, either in the form of direct investment in new plant or through the buying and selling of financial assets. Since the balance of payments should, by definition, balance, a deficit on the current account has to be matched by an equivalent surplus on the capital account. In reality measurement problems mean that this does not always happen, but as the US current account has risen, so it has increased its dependency on capital flows from the rest of the world. The amount it sucked in to finance its spending habit more than tripled from $113.3bn in 1995 to $399.1bn last year as the current account headed towards the record deficit of $435.4bn in 2000. Savers in Germany and Japan are indirectly allowing American consumers to carry on polluting at the current rate. This burden will increase if Bush uses up the US budget surplus to finance tax cuts, since at least under Clinton the failure of consumers to save was partly offset by the government saving for them. But without savers in the rest of the world, US consumers would have to consume less and save more, and the result of that would be a considerable slowdown in US growth. The policy implications of this should be quite clear: Bush is free to say that the US will break its Kyoto commitments, but the rest of the world is equally free to respond by cutting off the flow of funds to finance the US current account deficit. For Bush the consequences would be far more severe than abiding by Kyoto, with an almighty crash on Wall Street and - as Robert McTeer, the president of the Dallas Federal Reserve, admitted last week - a collapse in the value of the dollar. "Capital inflows are holding the dollar up despite the negative tone of the current account deficit," he said, adding that for the moment the US remained an attractive place for the world's savers. "If something should happen to cause them to lose faith, then there would be a problem and a dramatic downward pressure on the dollar." Of course, a deliberate attempt by Europe and Japan to stem the flow of capital to the US could be seen as a classic example of cutting off your nose to spite your face, because a sustained US downturn would have knock-on effects on the rest of the world. But there are several points that need to be made. The first is that a day of reckoning is coming for the US. At some point the days of live-now-pay-later will have to stop. A rebalancing of the global economy, with a smaller US current account deficit and a smaller Japanese current account surplus is much to be desired. The second point is that the Europeans and the Japanese would never need to make their threat explicit. A quiet word at a meeting of G7 finance ministers, backed up with a juicy non-attributable quote to the press would have the alarm bells ringing in the White House within five minutes. Third, while Tokyo might not want to see an appreciation of the yen against the dollar at a time when the Japanese economy is so weak, the Europeans would certainly like a stronger euro, which would facilitate lower interest rates and restore some pride in the single currency. Finally, the idea that the big financial institutions are a law unto themselves and would refuse to cooperate is a myth. French banks, for example, rarely say anything negative about the euro because it has been made clear that the ministry of finance finds such behaviour "unhelpful". Will this be contemplated? It depends on how serious the world is about global warming and how willing it is to stand up to the US. But let nobody say that there is nothing that can be done. All that's needed is a strike by European and Japanese capital. Get militant, comrades.

webTitle: The Good Friday Agreement, three years on

fields.headline: The Good Friday Agreement, three years on
fields.standfirst: The 1998 peace deal raised hopes of a new era of peace in Northern Ireland. However, little has changed. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: The 1998 peace deal raised hopes of a new era of peace in Northern Ireland. However, little has changed. Derek Brown explains.
fields.body:
Is the deal in good shape?
Hardly. There are fears that David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader and first minister in the power-sharing executive, will be severely undermined by hardliners in the upcoming general election. Sinn Fein, the republican party, is so alarmed by the prospect that it is calling for an immediate renegotiation to shore up the peace process.

What do they want exactly?
New measures to ensure that anti-agreement loyalists cannot block legislation in the Northern Ireland assembly. Also, acceleration of "demilitarisation" (ie the withdrawal of British troops) and criminal justice reforms.

Are they likely to get it?
With the government immersed in the foot and mouth crisis, and of course in an elongated election campaign, there is no appetite for a reappraisal of Northern Ireland policy, let alone a root-and-branch re-writing of the Good Friday Agreement.

Will the election really go badly for Trimble?
The signs and signals are alarming. The unionist community is disillusioned with the failure of the IRA to disarm, and with continuing paramilitary violence. Support for the Rev Ian Paisley's anti-agreement Democratic Unionist Party, and other hardline groups, has grown considerably.

What about Sinn Fein's election prospects?
The republicans are locked in a bitter struggle with the moderate nationalists of the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP), for the hearts and minds of the Catholic minority. Sinn Fein could even emerge from the election as the bigger party, for the first time. At the same time, the unionists could lose seats to either Sinn Fein or the SDLP.

How rapidly is the demographic balance changing?
This month's census is expected to show a sharp rise in the proportion of Catholics in the roughly 1.65m population. Indeed, that proportion may already exceed 46%. Some demographers suggest that there will be a Catholic majority within ten years.

So that would finally solve the problem?
Not a bit of it. The issue of a discontented minority within Northern Ireland, would be replaced by the much bigger issue of a discontented minority within Ireland as a whole. And while the Catholics of Northern Ireland account for less than 2% of the UK population, the Protestants of Ireland amount to nearly a third of the island's people.

fields.headline: Lights, camera, election
fields.standfirst: It's the election that could see a historic second term for Labour or the biggest upset in 30 years if William Hague wins. Sky political editor, Adam Boulton, veteran of four general elections, tells Matthew Tempest how he sees the run up to June 7
fields.trailText: It's the election that could see a historic second term for Labour or the biggest upset in 30 years if William Hague wins. Sky political editor, Adam Boulton, veteran of four general elections, tells Matthew Tempest how he sees the run up to June 7.
fields.body:
Q: We know who will win the election, so how are the broadcasters going to make it interesting?

Firstly, we don't know who's going to win. That's what makes it interesting right through election night and into the next day. And one thing we can be sure of - one of the parties is going to have a pretty horrible campaign. So as soap opera, we can all enjoy that. If Labour do win, and Blair is as quick as he was last time, we'll also have a reshuffle to look forward to, although I think he'll want to reorganise Whitehall departments too, so that may be further down the line.

Q: What advantages, and disadvantages, does television have in covering the election?

I think television and websites like your own are the new civic spaces, where people can challenge politicians. A news resource like the web, where huge information resources are constantly online, is a great boon for democracy.

I personally think we should have A levels in current affairs, as one way of keeping debate alive and countering apathy, but until then the internet is an incredible tool for an informed public.

Similarly with live, rolling news, we have the space to keep a civic consciousness going - whatever's going on, you can be there through the TV. What we can't do, which the papers can, is run on the "lobby terms", ie unattributed comments and remarks. I can, of course, put these to politicians myself.

There is the "CNN factor", whereby more saturation news coverage, as during an election campaign, does make figures sag, but the interested, regular viewers tune in more. No one watches Sky by accident, in the way that you see the BBC or ITV news come on after watching a soap or serial, so we're very pleased with the figures we get. But in some ways there will be less political coverage than ever before in Britain this time around; with the two main channels clashing at 10pm, there will be less audience share than ever before for news.

There'll be plenty of coverage on Sky - I'll be hosting "The Boulton Report" twice a day, six days a week, where we will interview the leaders and wrap up all the day's events.

We are also developing "the worm" - our polling tool we used during the budget to gauge public reaction to what's going on. It's something we've been planning for five years. There will also be animated party leader graphics reflecting how they've fared during the past 24 hours - should be fun.

What's great for broadcasters during an election campaign is that for once we set the agenda rather than the newspapers. We'll be covering the three main parties election news conferences live every morning, which will set the ball rolling for the whole day.

In fact, if I could claim anything for Sky, I think broadcasting press conferences live, which the BBC was loath to do until we came along and did it, has made one of the biggest differences to broadcast journalism in the past decade.

Q: As a journalist, obviously you have no view as to who will win the general election, but what's your prediction for turnout?

I'm optimistic it will keep above 70%, for three reasons:
 There's a big, live controversy - foot and mouth - which is a major national news event
 Recently Blair and the Labour party have come under some pretty heavy fire: that should get out both angry Tories and disaffected Labour loyalists
 You get longer daylight hours for a June election, which should help keep people voting.

Q: Are there still politicians who get nervous about appearing on TV, or refuse to appear, or are they a dying breed now?

Gordon Brown is famously reluctant to appear on telly, and Alan Milburn and Stephen Byers both dislike shows where the public can ask questions, although I noticed Byers was on Question Time last week.

MPs can be their own worst enemy sometimes - running in late to show how important they are, then getting sweaty under the lights because they're in a rush and haven't had the make-up.

With the party leaders there's always a little game-playing. They'll come on, but you have to go to them, they won't come to the studio. Or, they will, but then the night before there's a call, and all plans are changed. It's part and parcel of the whole thing.

Q: What about televising the lobby briefing given to political journalists by Alastair Campbell - presumably you're in favour?

Actually, I'm quite cautious about that. It would change the nature of political reporting forever. There's a danger that ministers, and in particular the prime minister, would appear less and less before the cameras if we had footage of their press spokesman or an unelected civil servant answering questions every day, and that would be a bad thing.

Secondly, like prime minister's questions in the Commons, it would probably be reduced to once a day, which doesn't help accountability.

And thirdly, it would make political journalism more hierarchical. At the moment, the reporter from the Wolverhampton Star is in there with everyone else. If it were televised, there'd be less access for the smaller players.

Mind you, my sources say if Blair does win a second term, there is likely to be another look at the whole issue of press relations.

fields.headline: Why Myler is out and Weaver is in
fields.standfirst: Statement from Mark Haysom, the managing director, national newspapers of MGN
fields.trailText: The Mirror Group statement in full.
fields.body:
"Mirror Group Newspapers has now completed its review of the editorial and legal processes that preceded the publication of an interview in the Sunday Mirror of 8th April.

This review has established that the well-defined procedures in operation in the company were followed and that legal opinion was sought prior to publication. This legal opinion contributed to the decision to go ahead with publication on the basis that the interview was deemed not to be prejudicial to the court case in Hull.

Whether publication of this article is subject to contempt proceedings is a matter for the Attorney General. We will, of course, be co-operating fully with his office on this matter. It would, however, be wholly inappropriate for us to comment further on this aspect at this time.

Irrespective of the issues of contempt, it is clear from events that have unfolded this week that the decision to publish was a serious error of judgement. We would wish to take this opportunity to express again our regret at the consequences of that decision.

Colin Myler has resigned as editor of the Sunday Mirror and has left the company. Colin is a very experienced editor who has held senior roles in this company over a number of years. It is a considerable sadness that he has departed under these circumstances.

Tina Weaver, currently deputy editor of The Mirror, has been appointed editor of the Sunday Mirror. Tina has made a significant contribution to the rejuvenation of The Mirror in recent years. Particularly notable was her role in the launch of the award-winning M magazine.

We are going to take the opportunity presented by Tina's appointment to ensure that The Mirror and the Sunday Mirror work together more effectively.

Tina has, of course, worked closely with Piers Morgan, editor of The Mirror, for a number of years. In her new trole she will continue to do so.

It will be the responsibility of Piers and Tina to ensure that the titles are more closely aligned and that we take advantage of our strengths across the week."

fields.headline: Article was 'serious error'
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: The Sunday Mirror has admitted the decision to publish an article that led to the collapse of the Leeds footballers trial was a 'serious error of judgement', writes Claire Cozens.

12.04.2001: Sunday Mirror editor quits
fields.body:
The Sunday Mirror has admitted the decision to publish an article that led to the collapse of the Leeds footballers trial was a "serious error of judgement".

In a statement issued today, Mirror Group Newspapers said: "Irrespective of the issues of contempt, it is clear from events that have unfolded this week that the decision to publish was a serious error of judgement. We would wish to take this opportunity to express again our regret at the consequences of that decision."

The company added that the appointment of Ms Weaver as new editor would ensure the Sunday Mirror was more closely aligned with the daily title.

"Tina has made a significant contribution to the rejuvenation of the Mirror in recent years. Particularly notable was her role in the launch of the award-winning M magazine," the company said.

MGN said it had received legal advice before publishing the article and had concluded it would not be prejudicial to the court case.

The attorney general is expected to decide next week whether the paper will be charged with contempt of court.

Sources have expressed surprise that Mr Myler, an experienced journalist with a track record of being meticulous, has quit. Many in the industry expected him to "brazen out" the storm following the publication.

This is not the first time Mr Myler, who succeeded Bridget Rowe as Sunday Mirror editor in 1992, has been in trouble.

The Sunday Mirror faced the fury of politicians, press watchdogs and Buckingham Palace when the paper published snatched photographs of Diana, Princess of Wales, exercising in a private gym.

webTitle: Foreign journalists in the dark over foot and mouth

fields.headline: Foreign journalists in the dark over foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: The government claims to be doing everything in its power to persuade tourists to visit Britain - despite the foot and mouth crisis. So why is it ignoring the foreign media? Nik Hole explains
fields.trailText: The government claims to be doing everything in its power to persuade tourists to visit Britain - despite the foot and mouth crisis. So why is it ignoring the foreign media? Nik Hole explains.
fields.body:
The Downing Street website has recently added a personal appeal from Tony Blair to tourists thinking of visiting Britain. "We are doing everything we can to get over the message - at home and abroad - that the whole of the UK is open for business, as indeed it is," the prime minister says.

In his internet appeal, Tony Blair criticised the foreign press for its coverage of foot and mouth, saying: "I've seen some of the foreign news broadcasts about the impact of foot and mouth disease on Britain. I can promise you that they paint a picture of our country which bears little relation to reality."

But foreign correspondents based in the UK argue that - despite the government's formidable reputation for spin - No 10 is barely trying to communicate its message abroad.

American and EU journalists expected to have been wooed by No 10 since the outbreak of foot and mouth, as vital conduits for getting the message across. Instead they have been cold-shouldered.

Catherine Mayer is a London correspondent for Focus, a German news magazine: "A week ago I had an irritating set of phone conversations with Maff when they showed no inclination to put up one of their scientific advisors to brief us. We're trying to report responsibly and tackle some of the wilder scare stories circulating abroad, but they're not providing the backup to enable us to do so."

She is not alone. Philippe Le Corre, London bureau chief of La Tribune, has been trying to arrange for a minister to hold a briefing for foreign journalists at the FPA for weeks. He is surprised at how hard it has been: "On the one hand, the government has never been so pro-active at promoting Britain as a tourist destination for foreigners, on the other, Maff seems unwilling to give UK-based correspondents access."

Jef McAllister was a reporter at the White House during the Clinton presidency and is now London bureau chief of Time magazine. He feels that the attitude of the Blair government to foreign reporters has a striking similarity to the Clinton administration.

"The Democrats turned their time in office into a continuous campaign for re-election and support," he says. "This inevitably meant that foreign journalists got second-rate treatment."

This approach might work in normal times - but it is not the way to lessen the economic impact of foot and mouth disease. Teresa Wickham, chairwoman of the London tourist board, says: "Americans are very confused and are connecting the issues of BSE and foot and mouth. London is a key gateway for foreign tourists and the US is the No 1 market for tourists coming to the UK - 2.7m US visitors came to London alone last year."

But, while many of the scare stories that are damaging the tourist trade are being written by foreign correspondents, government departments have not woken up to the risk.

Ms Mayer feels that lessons from the BSE crisis have not been learnt. She says: "The government press offices are impenetrable and unaccountable, and it's a matter of luck whether you get someone helpful on the phone. She says: "It is very important that everything possible is done to help them get access to the facts and to challenge the myths."

fields.headline: Government rethinks £35m PR spend
fields.trailText: 10am: The government is poised to overhaul its £35m spend on public relations, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
As Alastair Campbell prepares to quit as Tony Blair's press secretary, the government is set to overhaul its £35m spend on public relations.

The Central Office of Information has announced a review of its 26-strong roster of PR agencies, which accounts for £35m of its £200m communications budget.

It is the first shake-up of the government's PR roster since the list was compiled in July 1998.

Agencies including Cohn & Wolfe, Hill & Knowlton, GCI and Consolidated Communications will have to reapply to remain on the roster.

Other PR firms will now be able to tender for a place. The deadline for applications is May 14 and a decision is due to be made by the autumn.

The role of the COI itself is under review by the cabinet office.

A number of options is being considered, including scrapping the agency in favour of each governmental department procuring its own PR, advertising and media agencies.

webTitle: Campbell to quit as PM's voice

fields.headline: Campbell to quit as PM's voice
fields.standfirst:
Blair's press secretary to take less visible strategic role after election amid Labour fears of spin overload

Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Alastair Campbell is to abandon his role as Tony Blair's press secretary after the general election, writes Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell is to abandon his role as Tony Blair's press secretary after the general election, amid fears in Downing Street that he has come to symbolise harmful images of Labour spin.

The former Daily Mirror journalist, who has become one of the government's most visible figures, will take on a less visible role as director of communications in Downing Street. In his new post, he will be in charge of co-ordinating the government's overall message rather than the daily briefing of journalists.

He is said by friends to be "ready for a change" after constant battles with the media. There was speculation last night that he was prepared to leave No 10 altogether after the election.

One minister said last night: "Tony does not want to lose Alastair, but he does not want him to be his official spokesman. He is too high profile. He has become the story. The government looks as if it is run by spin instead of just using spin."

There are fears in No 10 that spin could undermine the government in the way that sleaze destroyed the Tories. Mr Blair is said to hope that Labour's second term in office will be "less media focused", and that the government will spend less time "chasing tomorrow's leading headlines".

Mr Campbell's new role, which is to be modelled on the head of press at the White House, will formalise his position in Downing Street, which changed last year. In the face of Tory claims that Labour was "all spin and no delivery", Mr Campbell stood back in the autumn from the daily press briefings to concentrate on devising a wider strategy for putting across the government's message. In recent months he has returned to the Downing Street briefings a few times a week.

He will resign from Downing Street when the election is called to allow him to play a key role in Labour's election campaign. If Labour wins, he will return to No 10 to plan media handling of big events. These will include the Budget, although this is likely to create tensions with the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who will be wary of such a loyal Blairite.

Mr Campbell is also expected to take a key role in handling major crises. There is a feeling in No 10 that the Ministry of Agriculture has been out of its depth during the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Campbell's move is likely to mean that the prime minister will return to the practice of having a career civil servant as his main spokesman. Mr Campbell's deputy, Godric Smith, will be seen as the frontrunner. He is highly regarded in Downing Street and by the press.

Mr Campbell is said to be ready to "move on" and to end his day-to-day "combat" with the press. But the former political editor is likely to miss the cut and thrust of arguing with parliamentary lobby journalists. As a former Westminster journalist, he was said to have been put out when Mr Blair initially suggested last year that he should withdraw from day-to-day briefings.

His position became difficult, however, when he starred in a BBC television programme about the Downing Street press operation. The Michael Cockerell programme was regarded as favourable but it turned Mr Campbell into a media celebrity and was used relentlessly by the Tories to criticise the prime minister for using spin to cover up the government's failings.

No 10 this morning refused to comment on Mr Campbell's future. A spokesman said: "We are not going to comment on speculation about events which may or may not happen after an election, whenever that may be."

webTitle: Chiefs to play at tragedy stadium within days

fields.headline: Chiefs to play at tragedy stadium within days
fields.trailText: South African club Kaizer Chiefs are set to play another match at Ellis Park - just days after 43 people died in a stampede at the stadium.
fields.body:
South African club Kaizer Chiefs are set to play another match at Ellis Park - just days after 43 people died in a stampede at the stadium.

The Chiefs' African Cup Winners Cup match against Stade Tamponnaise of Reunion was due to be played at Ellis Park this Sunday, but following a request by South African officials it has been put back until next Wednesday - exactly a week after the tragedy.

CAF secretary-general Mustapha Fahmy said because the visiting team had already arrived in South Africa the match could not be put off any longer.

"In accordance with our statutes we have postponed the game by 72 hours and it must take place on Wednesday," he told Reuters.

South African officials are set to cancel all weekend league matches as a mark of respect, Danny Jordaan, the South African Football Association's chief executive officer, said today .

fields.headline: Reuters bids for US rival
fields.trailText:
2pm: Reuters has moved to fill a gap in its business by bidding for parts of Bridge Information Systems, writes Dan Milmo.
10.04.2001: Reuters eyes up US rival
04.04.2001: Reuters online float under fire
23.03.2001: Reuters gains from Bridge collapse
fields.body:
Reuters has moved to fill the US gap in its business by bidding for parts of rival financial news service Bridge Information Systems.

The news group has made an offer for several Bridge assets, including the company's brokerage business, its bond data and analysis operation and its eBridge internet arm.

The move is an abrupt change in stance for Reuters, after Tom Glocer, chief executive of Reuters, recently scorned the attractiveness of the Bridge businesses.

However, Bridge is in dire financial difficulties following a three-year acquisition spree.

Reuters has been unable to resist the temptation of snapping up its assets on the cheap.

Analysts said the dual factors of a low bid price and the group's weakness in the US market made today's offer inevitable.

"There is no great surprise in this. If a company is making a distress sale, you should expect an opportunistic move," said Simon Baker, an analyst at SG Securities.

"It makes sense to pick up something if it is priced to go," he added.

The US market has long been the achilles heel in Reuters's international strategy. A Bridge bid should reassure investors who have been looking for movement on that front.

Bridge has filed for bankruptcy in the US and would-be buyers have until April 16 to file bids for the company.

webTitle: Charity turns its focus to 'less photogenic' causes

fields.headline: Charity turns its focus to 'less photogenic' causes
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCurry explains why a charity which raised £20m in a high profile appeal to help the victims of the Gujarat earthquake is shifting its emphasis from natural disasters to working in areas with poor human rights records
fields.trailText: Patrick McCurry explains why a leading charity which raised £20m to help the victims of the Gujarat earthquake is shifting its emphasis from natural disasters to working in areas with poor human rights records.
fields.body:
The Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) raised an impressive £20m in just two months through its Gujarat earthquake appeal but it has decided to concentrate its efforts on increasing awareness of less visible humanitarian catastrophes.

The DEC, which represents a group of international aid agencies in Britain, found that the Gujarat appeal was one of its most successful. It compares with £10m raised for the Sudan and £5m for the Bangladesh floods in 1998 and £7m following the Orissa cyclone in 1999. Even the Hurricane Mitch appeal in 1998 raised less at £18m, despite lasting longer than the Gujarat fundraising appeal.

Only the Kosovo crisis and the Mozambique floods raised more money in recent years. Although one of the contributing factors to the high sums raised in the Guajarat appeal was the response by the UK's Asian communities, DEC spokesman Antony Robbins says another reason was the striking TV footage beamed from India soon afterwards. "The fact that the disaster's results were easily accessible from the state capital meant TV crews could report on it quickly and that helped us reach people in the UK," he explained.

By contrast, the Orissa cyclone appeal, while raising a respectable £7m in 1999, was nowhere near the amount raised for the Mozambique floods appeal despite the fact that the humanitarian cost of the Orissa disaster was far worse, says Mr Robbins. "In Orissa it was much less accessible and so we didn't have the same media footage, while for Mozambique you had pictures of people being rescued from trees and that captured public imagination."

Despite these challenges, the DEC chief executive Brendan Gormley, formerly at Oxfam, is determined not to let the committee be turned into supporting purely televisual causes. He is keen for the DEC to push for appeals on less visible disasters, such as widescale human rights abuses in Afghanistan and Indonesia.

"It's important for the DEC to promote appeals not just for natural disasters but also the more uncomfortable or non-photogenic disasters," said Mr Gormley. But achieving that will require close coordination with the main broadcasters, on which the DEC relies to provide peak time spots for appeals. One of the main conditions for a DEC appeal is that there is sufficient public awareness of a particular disaster and that could be a stumbling block when it comes to human rights abuses.

"To do an appeal on human rights causes we would need a high level of coverage for a particular cause in the media," said Mr Robbins. He points to the recent coverage of the destruction of ancient Buddha monuments in Afghanistan by the Taliban regime. "That's been the big story from Afghanistan but very few people are aware of the wider human rights abuses, particularly of women," he said.

The British government has raised the profile of international human rights and this could contribute to changes in public awareness in the long term. Mr Robbins believes: "This government has had human rights higher up the agenda than previous administrations and we've seen the enactment of a Human Rights Act, but there's still a lot to be done to make the public aware of these issues."

Mr Gormley says he hopes that the growing trend towards follow-up reporting by TV presenters like Nick Ross, who is expected to return to Gujarat to see how the appeal money has helped to rebuild lives, will benefit future fundraising. Mr Gormley said: "The public want their donations to be used not just for saving lives but also to help rebuild communities after disasters and follow-up programmes can show the wider picture of what appeals can achieve."

fields.headline: Myler quits as editor of Sunday Mirror
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Colin Myler, the editor of the Sunday Mirror, has resigned abruptly, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Colin Myler, the editor of the Sunday Mirror, has resigned abruptly. He walked out of the paper's Canary Wharf headquarters just before 1pm today.

He will be replaced by Tina Weaver, deputy editor of the Mirror.

"Everyone here is utterly shellshocked," said one journalist on the paper.

"Everything was business as usual here this morning. He held conference and was making executive decisions.

"People are really, really gutted. He was an extremely fair guy and one of the best editors the paper has had in years."

Mr Myler's resignation comes after a turbulent week, which started with an article related to the Leeds footballers trial.

On Monday, the trial, which has cost taxpayers £10m, was halted and the jury discharged as a result of the article.

On Tuesday, the paper expressed its "deep regret" over the subsequent chain of events.

Although the paper faced the opprobium of its rivals - in particular the Sun - it was believed Mr Myler would ride the storm.

The paper still faces contempt of court charges.

"What happened on Sunday was chronically out of character for him. Nobody knows how that article was published," said one loyal member of staff.

Mr Myler is believed to have taken his decision following a meeting at Trinity Mirror this morning.

He called in senior staff on the paper to thank them for their hard work over the last few years.

As he departed, Mr Myler said: "The truth will out."

webTitle: Baggage pick-up service to take off at Gatwick, says BA

fields.headline: Baggage pick-up service to take off at Gatwick, says BA
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Airways is starting trials of a free baggage collection service from home for passengers to take some of the strain out of travelling, the company confirmed last night.
fields.body:
British Airways is starting trials of a free baggage collection service from home for passengers to take some of the strain out of travelling, the company confirmed last night.

The service will be for Gatwick passengers at first, but if it is successful it will be extended to other airports throughout the UK.

BA has been negotiating a deal with the transport department for several months and is expected to introduce the service, covering all passenger classes, in the summer.

The government is required to give its approval because the airline must deal with terrorist threats and passengers carrying illegal goods.

The Department for the Environment, Transport and the Regions confirmed that it had given its approval for the baggage trials, adding that the scheme would be required to comply with the "standards of the national aviation security programme".

A spokesman said that BA would take the "necessary counter measures" to ensure maximum safety.

This suggests that BA will need to be aware of the contents of passengers' luggage before taking bags from their premises. And passengers will need to be present while their luggage is inspected. BA has declined to talk about the scheme but said: "We are always looking at ways of improving our customer service."

Although BA will initially make it a free scheme, it is expected to make a charge if the service becomes established.

A similar scheme is planned by a start-up business airline, Blue Fox, which, from next year, intends to operate a twice daily business class only service between Stansted and New York for a flat rate of £1,200 return. The company said that for £25 it would collect three items of luggage within a 30-mile radius of the airport and deliver them to the passenger's destination.

A similar scheme is planned by a start-up business airline, Blue Fox, which, from next year, intends to operate a twice daily business class only service between Stansted and New York for a flat rate of £1,200 return. The company said that for £25 it would collect three items of luggage within a 30-mile radius of the airport and deliver them to the passenger's destination.

fields.standfirst:
George Bush won a positive response from the US media to his handling of the diplomatic row with China over the spy plane

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush won a positive response from the US media to his handling of the diplomatic row with China over the spy plane
fields.body:
The details of Bush's involvement are consistent with his past management style: He set broad parameters and then dispatched his underlings to do the job, checking in regularly on points that particularly interested him. He also placed strong emphasis on public perceptions and demanded discipline from the small group of advisers he trusted to handle the matter.
The Washington Post

Despite its tough talk on China in the weeks the standoff, the Bush administration handled the crisis with consummate cool, and the President will come through his first major international crisis with his stature considerably enhanced.
Time magazine

Bush steered a firm, patient course, despite fervour to escalate the crisis from one wing of his party. The portrait of China's leadership, though, is far less flattering.
USA Today

China's political support in the United States has been weakened, with many of those who have urged sympathy for China in the past failing to rush to Beijing's side this time. At the same time, the incident will probably harden the view among some US military and security officials that China is a potential long term adversary.
Los Angeles Times

The Chinese may not feel superior to Americans in terms of economic power or fancy weapons. But when it comes to dynasties, the Middle Kingdom brooks no rivals. That is why the Celestial Empire decided to administer a lesson to the Kennebunk Empire. When you are ruled by dynasties for 4,000 years, a family that produces two American presidents ruling for a mere four years and a couple of months is about as significant as a single stone in the Great Wall. To the Chinese, the Bushes are a puny dynasty.
Maureen Dowd - International Herald Tribune

fields.headline: Shippam's recalls 'substandard' meat paste
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: A food firm has been forced to recall thousands of pots of sandwich spread over fears that they may contain meat intended for dog food.
fields.body:
A food firm has been forced to recall thousands of pots of sandwich spread over fears that they may contain meat intended for dog food.

Sussex-based Shippam's has been alerted that chicken condemned as unfit for human consumption could have been used in its products by mistake. Bosses have now recalled its meat pastes and some other products as "a precautionary measure".

The scare comes after an investigation centred on a pet food-processing plant near Ripley, Derbyshire. Derbyshire police last month arrested 19 people in connection with the scare. No one has yet been charged.

A spokesman for Shippam's said that it had been alerted by the Food Standards Agency (FSA) that "substandard" chicken could have been used in some of its products. He said: "There is no food safety risk but the product recall is the responsible action to take."

A spokesman for the FSA said: "Shippam's are taking this action as they may unwittingly have received and used in their products meat condemned as unfit for human consumption.

"This is a precautionary measure. It is highly unlikely that there would be any health risks from these highly processed products."

Customers who have already bought the products should take them to shops for a full refund.

The products affected are:
 Shippam's Chicken Spread 35g, best before Sept 6 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken Spread 75g, best before Oct 3 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken & Ham Spread 35g, best before Nov 28 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken & Ham Spread 75g, best before Sept 12 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken & Ham Spread 100g, best before Dec 1 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken & Stuffing Spread 75g, best before Sept 1 2003.
 Shippam's Chicken Tikka Spread 75g, best before Dec 6 2003.
 Sutherland's Potted Chicken 78g, best before Nov 29 2003.
 Sainsbury's Chicken & Ham Paste 35g, best before Nov 2002.
 Sainsbury's Chicken & Ham Paste 75g, best before Oct 2002.
 Sainsbury's Chicken Paste 75g, best before Dec 2002.

webTitle: Aircrew fly back to 'very sorry' US

fields.headline: Aircrew fly back to 'very sorry' US
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: All 24 crew members of the US spy plane at the centre of the standoff with China headed home early this morning after Washington said it was "very sorry" for the incident - twice - but refused to give the outright apology that Beijing had earlier demanded.
fields.byline: Duncan Hewitt in Hainan Island, John Gittings in Hong Kong and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
All 24 crew members of the US spy plane at the centre of the standoff with China headed home early this morning after Washington said it was "very sorry" for the incident - twice - but refused to give the outright apology that Beijing had earlier demanded.

The Americans left Hainan Island early today aboard a chartered passenger jet bound for Hawaii. It was expected to stop over at the Pacific island of Guam on the way.

But the EP-3 spy plane, whose immediate return was demanded by the Bush administration early last week, remained firmly on the ground in Chinese hands.

Preparations were under way for the 24 crew to be reunited with their families by the end of the week at Whidbey Island, Washington state, where they are based.

"That's great," President George Bush said, when officials phoned him at the White House yesterday to confirm that the deal had been struck.

The end of the 11-day crisis came after China accepted the terms set out in the fourth draft of a letter from the US ambassador to Beijing, Joseph Prueher, which expressed American sorrow for the death of a Chinese airman and for entering Chinese airspace to land the plane on April 1.

The letter's painstakingly constructed diplomatic language continued to cause translation problems yesterday, even after both sides had agreed it.

Mr Prueher's letter said the US was "very sorry" for the loss of the Chinese pilot Wang Wei, and for entering Chinese air space without verbal clearance. However the Chinese version put out by the US embassy, and a separate Chinese summary given to reporters by the Chinese foreign ministry contained different terms.

In addition to agreeing on the release of the crew, the US and China will hold talks starting next Wednesday in which they will offer their differing versions of what happened in the April 1 clash, and discuss ways to avoid further clashes.

The passage in Mr Prueher's letter which appears to have unlocked the crisis was the one relating to the landing of the US spy plane on Hainan.

The American letter said: "Although the full picture of what transpired is still unclear, according to our information, our severely crippled aircraft made an emergency landing after following international emergency procedures. We are very sorry the entering of China's airspace and the landing did not have verbal clearance."

The letter asked China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, to "convey to the Chinese people and to the family of [the Chinese pilot who died] that we are very sorry for their loss." He also said that "we appreciate China's efforts to see to the well-being of our crew".

President Jiang Zemin, speaking during a visit to Uruguay, said that China had ordered the release "out of humanitarian consideration", but the incident "was not fully settled".

However he also said that good relations between the two countries were "vital for peace and prosperity in the region and the world".

webTitle: No crowing when Bush breaks news

fields.headline: No crowing when Bush breaks news
fields.standfirst:
China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: While many Americans were still asleep yesterday morning, President George Bush stepped before reporters in Washington at 8.25am local time to announce the resolution of the first major international test of his presidency.
fields.body:
While many Americans were still asleep yesterday morning, President George Bush stepped before reporters in Washington at 8.25am local time to announce the resolution of the first major international test of his presidency.

"I'm pleased to be able to tell the American people that plans are under way to bring home our 24 American servicemen and women from Hainan island," he said.

There was no crowing in his short statement, the words chosen to underscore and repeat the expression of regret which China had demanded before it would free the crew of the EP-3 spy plane held on Hainan since it made an emergency landing on April 1 after a mid-air collision with one of two Chinese fighter jets sent to challenge it.

"This has been a difficult situation for both our countries," Mr Bush said.

"I know the American people join me in expressing sorrow for the loss of life of a Chinese pilot. Our prayers are with his wife and child."

Mr Bush was woken just after 5am yesterday to take a telephone call from his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, reporting that the two sides had reached agreement. He woke his wife Laura to tell her that the American crew was coming home.

Just over an hour later Chinese television went on the air to confirm publicly that the deal was done. As far as Ms Rice and her national security team was concerned, that confirmation was the green light for the administration to begin to relax.

The initial reaction in Washington was that Mr Bush had handled the confrontation with China well.

Although many conservatives on the Republican side have grumbled privately that he was too deferential, the criticism that surfaced publicly came on radio talk shows, the internet and in the conservative Weekly Standard magazine, which this week described the incident as "a national humiliation" for the US.

But in political circles support for the president held, though conservatives will be hoping that Mr Bush finds a way of "punishing" China for the incident once the crew of the US reconnaissance plane are safely home.

The diplomatic solution to the crisis has also been a significant success for the secretary of state, Colin Powell, who has been depicted as an isolated and even marginal figure in an administration weighted towards more hawkish views about China.

Mr Powell was in Europe yesterday, but will return to Washington a stronger figure than he was before the confrontation began on April 1.

"The president has done a fabulous job," said Porter Goss, the Republican chairman of the House of Representatives intelligence committee.

"I think the president was very wise and his foreign policy team was very wise to give them [China] time. It caused us to be impatient, but we'll get over it."

When Mr Bush was campaigning for the presidency last year he frequently said that he would conduct American foreign policy in a mood of humility. In spite of pressure from some in the Republican camp to take a more bullish line, the adopted a sufficiently soft tone to appease the Chinese and end the 11-day stand-off.

The cards they held

China

The crew China had the ultimate bargaining chip: the 24 US aircrew guarded by elite forces. A rescue mission was out of the question

The plane Though the crew destroyed sensitive equipment before it landed, the plane was still packed with technological secrets

Threat of prosecutions Captain could prosecuted for the Chinese pilot's death; electronic specialists could be accused of spying

International pressure Enjoyed a a good deal of sympathy and could have embarrassed the US with its demand for an end to the spy flights

Future fears Could have encouraged fear of hardliners taking over in Beijing

US

Trade US could have stepped back from allowing China permanent normal trading relations and obstructed bid to join World Trade Organisation.

Olympics Could have pressed International Olympic Committee members not to back Beijing's bid for 2008

Taiwan US is to decide soon whether to sell sophisticated weapons to Taiwan

Diplomatic freeze Mr Bush could have cancelled visit to Asia-Pacific economic summit in Shanghai in October and visit to Beijing afterwards

Human rights Could have stepped up attack on China's human rights record, including treatment of Tibet, the Falun Gong and arrest of dissidents

fields.trailText: SocietyGuardian.co.uk is brimming with news and features today. Just click below to see the latest and log on later for more.
fields.body:
SocietyGuardian.co.uk is brimming with news and features today. Just click below to see the latest and log on later for more.

Housing news: Reports expose poor performance

Some of the biggest and best known housing associations have been exposed for poor performance in the first ever publication of regulation reports in the sector.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/

Social care: 'Abuse' at school for deaf

A school for deaf children has been severely criticised by the NSPCC for a catalogue of abuse and neglect.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/0,7886,374545,00.html

Policy: Lib Dems 'regeneration' pledge

Liberal Democrat environment spokesman Don Foster has unveiled his party's urban manifesto.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/policy/story/0,8108,471979,00.html

Local government: Scottish councils failing to collect £68m, says watchdog

Scottish local government could be losing out on nearly £70m every year because it is failing to effectively collect council tax and rents, a report from the country's public spending watchdog has warned.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/scottishlg/0,8145,452390,00.html

Modernisation: Distress over delay of mayoral legislation

Local government leaders have attacked ministers for failing to produce crucial legislation that must come into effect before city mayors and council cabinets can be introduced.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/modlocalgov/0,7989,392390,00.html

Voluntary sector: Refugee Council faces financial crisis

The Refugee Council is facing a financial deficit of £700,000 and has had to freeze 44 posts since the government cut funding to services in London as part of its dispersal programme.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/voluntary/

Charities must wait for Comic Relief's £40m

Nearly £40m has been raised through Red Nose Day this year but charities will not see any money until the end of June.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/fundraising/0,8145,390106,00.html

Policy: Help, minister

Special advisers, thinktanks and plans for more local government control have left the civil service with an identity crisis. What is it for, asks David Walker.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/policy/

Social care: Coroner to report failings of Feltham after prison suicide

Failures in communication and the identification of at risk prisoners at Feltham young offenders institution are to be reported to the Home Office by a coroner following an inquest into the death of a teenager at Britain's largest youth jail.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/crimeandpunishment/0,8145,430910,00.html

Health: Medical research threatened by patient consent

Crucial medical research is under threat, warns Ben Traynor, because of moves to force medics to seek patients' permission for every study.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/healthandsocialcarebill/0,7995,420325,00.html

More health: Hospitals step up security as attacks on staff rise

They are supposed to be places of safety, but Britain's hospitals are having to be turned into fortresses.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health/

Practice: Refugee doctors left in limbo

The NHS is short of doctors but the many qualified refugee health workers who could alleviate the shortage find it difficult to practise their skills. David Batty reports on initiatives to get refugee doctors into work.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/NHSstaff/0,7995,391986,00.html

Just for fun: test your wits with our weekly quiz

http://www.societytheguardian.com/dailyquiz/0,7927,374103,00.html

The SocietyGuardian.co.uk daily email briefing will be back on April 17.

fields.headline: Maff halts release of foot and mouth figures
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Government officials today said that it will not release any more figures about the numbers of animals condemned by foot and mouth until they are satisfied that the latest statistics are both "robust" and "accurate".
fields.body:
Government officials today said that it will not release any more figures about the numbers of animals condemned by foot and mouth until they are satisfied that the latest statistics are both "robust" and "accurate".

Maff also claimed that the numbers of animals now being slaughtered was "immaterial" in the light of new evidence produced yesterday, which showed that the disease may already have peaked.

Shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, who has already voiced concerns over the lack of information being provided by the government, described Maff's claim that there was no immediate need for fresh statistics as "ludicrous".

The government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, announced yesterday that the numbers of outbreaks appeared to be "flattening out".

Professor King said that the latest figures showed that there was now a steady decrease in the average number of new cases being recorded each day. The average number for the week ending April 8 stood at 32 a day, compared with 43 for the previous week.

Maff today denied suggestions that updated figures were being deliberately withheld to mask the true scale of the situation.

A spokeswoman said the delay was being caused by problems collecting accurate data on the ground, as vets continued the battle to contain the disease.

She said: "We are not releasing any more figures until we are confident they are accurate. Until such a time we feel they are robust we will not publish them.

"We know how many cases there are so how many animals are being slaughtered is immaterial.

"David King said we are very near to meeting the 24 hour culling target. That is the important thing."

Mr Yeo said: "Yesterday, Professor King said that the situation was getting better. Today, Maff are still refusing to publish their figures. This is the first time New Labour have suppressed good news."

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, presented the last accurate figures on the total number of animals culled to the House of Commons on Monday.

He said that, as of 7pm on Sunday, 1,366,000 animals had been earmarked for slaughter. Of those, 888,000 had already been culled, while 478,000 had yet to be dealt with. The bodies of 329,000 dead animals also remained to be disposed of.

fields.headline: Mirror awards are a winner for ITV
fields.trailText: 1.30pm TV overnights: The Pride of Britain awards, hosted by Carol Vorderman, held more than 8m viewers over two hours on ITV, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Mirror's Pride of Britain awards helped ITV to another comfortable peaktime ratings victory last night, holding more than 8m viewers over two hours.

ITV's coverage of the event, which was hosted by Carol Vorderman and featured a galaxy of stars including Robbie Williams and Geri Halliwell, ran from 9pm to 11pm.

The Pride of Britain awards attracted 8.1m viewers and a 38% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

It beat a BBC1 repeated wildlife special between 9.05pm and 10pm.

Polar Bear, narrated by David Attenborough, pulled in 4.5m viewers.

Medical drama A&E, which stars Martin Shaw and Niamh Cusack, made a successful return to ITV for a third run between 8pm and 9pm.

A&E had 7.4m viewers and a 33% audience share.

BBC1 opposition This is Your Life and Animal Hospital had 5.8m and 4.4m viewers respectively.

Elsewhere last night, the last instalment of acclaimed BBC2 drama the Cops went out between 9pm and 9.50pm.

The series signed off with a muted 1.4m viewers and a 6% audience share.

It was up against ER on Channel 4, which had 2.6m and 11% of the available audience.

ER was followed at 10pm by home-grown Channel 4 drama Teachers.

The Bristol-set drama, which gives Andrew Lincoln his meatiest role since he played Egg in This Life, attracted 2.1m viewers and had a 10% share.

webTitle: Keane: I could join Celtic in 2003

fields.headline: Keane: I could join Celtic in 2003
fields.trailText: Roy Keane has admitted he could join Celtic when his current contract at Old Trafford runs out in 2003.
fields.body:
Roy Keane has admitted he could join Celtic when his current contract at Old Trafford runs out in 2003.

Speaking on MUTV last night, the Manchester United captain said is he is seriously considering moving on in two years time.

"At the end of this contract I will be 31 and maybe that will be time to say thank you for the memories because hopefully by then there will be new players coming through," he said.

"I've said I would like to play at Celtic at some stage in my career," he added. "In two years' time, when my contract is up, if United say I can go, then Celtic is the club I would like to play for. I've been up there a few times and I think it's an outstanding club with an outstanding manager.

"Hopefully they can do well in Europe next year and obviously with me being Irish I support Celtic."

But Keane was quick to reassure supporters that he is happy at Old Trafford - and says he could sign a contract extension to stay at the club.

"We will be buying big players and maybe my time might be then," he said. "But I feel great and I feel I can do a job for United for the next few years. I'm pretty confident I can remain at United for the next couple of years and hopefully in the next year or two I might sign an extension."

However Keane has once again warned United they must be prepared to spend to keep up with the top European clubs.

"A club like United should be looking to buy the best," he said. "I'd love to see two or three players come here. I think Rivaldo is an outstanding player and Figo is an outstanding player. But all that is down to the manager.

"We need to keep up with the Madrids of this world, as they seem to be improving all the time," he added. "We know what it's like when you buy players, especially world-class players. It lifts everybody. It puts us all under pressure and that's the way it should be at a big club."

"You've got to do well in Europe if you want to be regarded as one of the so-called great teams - and we are nowhere near being called a great team yet," he continued. "And the only way we can prove that is by winning the European Cup again - or at least by getting to the final.

"We didn't do that last year and we are struggling this year."

fields.headline: No 13. Sunderland
fields.standfirst: Chris Liddle of Sunderland fanzine Ready To Go talks Black Cats
fields.trailText: Chris Liddle of Sunderland fanzine Ready To Go talks Black Cats.
fields.body:
What makes us so special?

Sunderland can truly claim to be a real club run by fans for the fans. I can't think of another club where the chairman and the board have such a good relationship with the supporters. There's a real sense of everyone pulling in the same direction to try and make us one of the biggest clubs in Europe. We certainly have the fans to do it-it's up to the manager and chairman to provide us with the team.

The high points

Undoubtedly beating Leeds in the 1973 FA Cup final. Leeds had a phenomenal side at the time, and we were in the Second Division, as it was then. Bob Stokoe did wonders with that side. I think he could have walked on water that year. More recently, our 2-1 victories at St. James' Park were special moments, especially after all the stick their fans have given us over the last ten years. Winning the First Division with 105 points was a very pleasing experience, especially after losing to Charlton in the play-off final the year before.

The low points

There have been several relegations over the years, and the hardest to take until recently was the demotion to the old Division Three on away goals, after extra-time. However, that pales into insignificance compared to losing that play-off final. To lose out on the Premiership on penalties after a 46-game season was a uniquely soul-destroying experience. There were over 40,000 Mackems at Wembley that day-and even the most hard-bitten of us had a lump in our throats after that one. Someone at work congratulated me on being part of such a memorable game, but I couldn't quite see it that way.

What's going on at the moment?

We've had a bit of a dodgy run, which is starting to threaten our dreams of European football for next season. Unlike last season, we've not played badly during this poor run, and have not been helped by a series of poor and questionable refereeing decisions. It's not just us moaning - the video evidence has been clearly in our favour on the majority of these occasions. It's very frustrating, because if those decisions have gone our way, we'd be well in the running for a Champions League spot. Off the field, the chairman has just announced reduced season ticket prices for next season (at least £20 off each ticket). This was a goodwill gesture to the fans for their magnificent support, home and away.

Last fixture

At the time of writing, it was against Leeds at the SOL, and we lost 2-0. We didn't play great, we didn't play that bad. There was the customary iffy refereeing decision at 0-0, and Leeds went straight up the other end and scored. It was disappointing to lose, especially after our fine win at Chelsea the week before.

Next fixture

At the time of writing, the next game is at Middlesborough. They need the points as much as we do, and it is a must win game for us if we are serious about Europe for next season. Incidentally, we don't consider Boro to be our rivals; they're just a small town in Yorkshire. [The game ended goal-less.]

Will we qualify for Europe?

In a word, yes. Our destiny is in our own hands. We have seven games left, all against sides below us in the league. We have a very determined and skilful bunch of players who will give their all to achieve this aim. I'm confident we will do it.

Should Kevin Phillips play for England?

Kevin has never been given the chances that Andy Cole has. He has not been in the sensational form of last year, but he's still scored 15 goals, despite having no pre-season due to injury. He is a quality finisher, and has a much-improved all-round game this year. He offers far more for the future than, say, Teddy Sheringham. If Eriksson picks Ted, he has to play him, especially at 34. Phillips will score goals at international level, but only if he gets a chance to! With Cole out for the next qualifier, Eriksson must have a look.

Sore point

One thing that irks a lot of fans is our treatment in the press. We are often made out to be some sort of northern Wimbledon, and rarely get the credit we deserve in the press. It's frankly a disgrace to insinuate that we are a hump-and-hoof-it-forward team. Yes, we do have Niall Quinn up front, and him being six foot four, it makes a degree of sense to use his aerial power! Sunderland have a side packed full of internationals, an average gate of over 47,000 at home, and always sell out their full away allocations. There's not a lot in common with Wimbledon in that lot, is there?

Manager

Peter Reid has done a fantastic job, turning the club round from relegation candidates in the First Division to European challengers in six years. He is a real players' manager, and his strong points are man-management and getting players to play for him. He has created a superb team spirit, and brought in some real quality players in his time at the club. He is a real stubborn bugger though, and woe betide anyone player who crosses him. He is supposedly on the verge of signing a new £6m, four-year contract, which is well deserved. He now has to take the club forward into Europe, and make us serious challengers for the Premiership.

The chairman

Bob Murray has a dream of making Sunderland one of the biggest clubs in Europe, and is making a very good attempt at doing so. Murray was the driving force behind the Stadium of Light, and like all good chairmen, keeps out of the limelight much of the time. Whilst he is nominally in charge, it's Reid who basically runs the club. Although a native Yorkshireman, he has been a lifelong Sunderland fan, and has not forgotten his modest family roots despite being a successful multi-millionaire businessman. You can see that he has a feel for the ordinary man in the street, and he puts the priorities of these supporters well above that of the corporate "fan". This is a refreshing change in this day and age.

Rivals

Our rivals are Ne*c*stle United, and no-one else. There is a great deal of "feeling" between the two sets of supporters, a bit like Celtic-Rangers without the sectarianism. We have had to put up with their taunts of how superior they are, how they are a massive club (second only to Barcelona in Europe, apparently) and other such rubbish over the last ten years. The truth is that they've spent a fortune on mediocre players, owe a fortune to the banks, and have won precisely NOWT. And their ground is a lop-sided carbuncle.

Kit

We are in the first year of a deal with Nike, and the current kit is fairly traditional, save the all black socks. My favourite kit was the one we wore when we won the Cup in 1973, despite those floppy collars. The worst kit ever was the nasty pinstripe effort with red shorts in the days of Ally McCoist, in the early eighties. There is talk of a third strip in Internazionale colours, to compliment our all-white away kit.

Most ridiculous piece of merchandise

For some reason, I find the idea of "club" chocolates and wine a bit daft. Why should a football club want to be associated with such items? You can just imagine the reaction of your beloved lady if you presented her with a box of SAFC chocolates. You might need to pay a visit to casualty to get them removed.

Mascots

We originally had a black cat called Samson, and now he's got a mate called Delilah. Samson is definitely a bit of a lad. He was allegedly spotted drinking in a pub near Prenton Park a few years ago. He is very popular with the kids, and is known for taking the mickey of opposing mascots/fans.

Players rated

Don Hutchison is currently flavour of the month, which is no mean feat given his Geordie roots. He is surely the bargain of the season at £2.5m. Phillips and Quinn have been superb over the last four years, and McCann is starting to fulfil his enormous promise. As for other teams, I really rate Steven Gerrard, and Roy Keane was absolutely outstanding against us earlier this year. Marcus Stewart has been superb this year, and has done a Phillips. It will be interesting to see what happens to him in his second season.

Players hated

Kevin Kilbane seems to be the target of the boo boys at the minute, which is a shame as he had a pretty good start to the season. As for other clubs, well it has to be Alan Shearer. Not only did Shearer allegedly say that he didn't like playing with Phillips for England, but he also took the rise out of the Fulwell End at the end of the last derby at Roker. Needless to say, his penalty miss in last November's derby was greeted with universal acclaim on Wearside. I think most people saw it as poetic justice.

The Stadium of Light

The new ground is a vast improvement on the dilapidated Roker Park. With excellent views from every seat, and much better catering facilities, supporters are well looked after. However, trying to go for a half-time 'comfort break' is never easy, or quick. There are plenty of toilets, but the planners failed to account for the thirst of the average Sunderland supporter.

Atmosphere on match days

The bowl of the stadium seems to help the noise generated, so the atmosphere is usually good. The big games are something special, as you can sense that the fans are really up for these games. When Phillips scored the equaliser in last year's derby, the roof nearly came off. I've never heard a noise so loud at any football match I've ever been to.

What to do before the match

There are numerous watering holes in Sunderland City Centre, which is only ten minutes walk from the ground. A more extensive guide can be found on the website. Sunderland is quite a good place to come to for the away fan, as most of our lot like having a bit of crack with the opposition over a pint. You can have a drink in the ground, and maybe try one of our delicious chicken balti pies. Programmes are top quality, and can be bought at the food outlets, or outside the ground.

Links

There are many Sunderland related fanzines published regularly, though Ready To Go is probably the only "busy" and active site written by the fans for the fans with a total independent view. Sites such as A Love Supreme and The FTM Executive Club, www.ftmx.co.uk offer great alternatives. The club does have an official website, www.sunderland-afc.com which has up to the date news on the team, interviews with the players, merchandise, club stats and ticket availability - even if slow to update at times.

Phillips will score goals at international level, but only if he gets a chance to! With Cole out for the next qualifier, Eriksson must have a look. Sore point One thing that irks a lot of fans is our treatment in the press. We are often made out to be some sort of northern Wimbledon, and rarely get the credit we deserve in the press. It's frankly a disgrace to insinuate that we are a hump-and-hoof-it-forward team. Yes, we do have Niall Quinn up front, and him being six foot four, it makes a degree of sense to use his aerial power! Sunderland have a side packed full of internationals, an average gate of over 47,000 at home, and always sell out their full away allocations. There's not a lot in common with Wimbledon in that lot, is there? Manager Peter Reid has done a fantastic job, turning the club round from relegation candidates in the First Division to European challengers in six years. He is a real players' manager, and his strong points are man-management and getting players to play for him. He has created a superb team spirit, and brought in some real quality players in his time at the club. He is a real stubborn bugger though, and woe betide anyone player who crosses him. He is supposedly on the verge of signing a new £6m, four-year contract, which is well deserved. He now has to take the club forward into Europe, and make us serious challengers for the Premiership. The chairman Bob Murray has a dream of making Sunderland one of the biggest clubs in Europe, and is making a very good attempt at doing so. Murray was the driving force behind the Stadium of Light, and like all good chairmen, keeps out of the limelight much of the time. Whilst he is nominally in charge, it's Reid who basically runs the club. Although a native Yorkshireman, he has been a lifelong Sunderland fan, and has not forgotten his modest family roots despite being a successful multi-millionaire businessman. You can see that he has a feel for the ordinary man in the street, and he puts the priorities of these supporters well above that of the corporate "fan". This is a refreshing change in this day and age. Rivals Our rivals are Ne*c*stle United, and no-one else. There is a great deal of "feeling" between the two sets of supporters, a bit like Celtic-Rangers without the sectarianism. We have had to put up with their taunts of how superior they are, how they are a massive club (second only to Barcelona in Europe, apparently) and other such rubbish over the last ten years. The truth is that they've spent a fortune on mediocre players, owe a fortune to the banks, and have won precisely NOWT. And their ground is a lop-sided carbuncle. Kit We are in the first year of a deal with Nike, and the current kit is fairly traditional, save the all black socks. My favourite kit was the one we wore when we won the Cup in 1973, despite those floppy collars. The worst kit ever was the nasty pinstripe effort with red shorts in the days of Ally McCoist, in the early eighties. There is talk of a third strip in Internazionale colours, to compliment our all-white away kit. Most ridiculous piece of merchandise For some reason, I find the idea of "club" chocolates and wine a bit daft. Why should a football club want to be associated with such items? You can just imagine the reaction of your beloved lady if you presented her with a box of SAFC chocolates. You might need to pay a visit to casualty to get them removed. Mascots We originally had a black cat called Samson, and now he's got a mate called Delilah. Samson is definitely a bit of a lad. He was allegedly spotted drinking in a pub near Prenton Park a few years ago. He is very popular with the kids, and is known for taking the mickey of opposing mascots/fans. Players rated Don Hutchison is currently flavour of the month, which is no mean feat given his Geordie roots. He is surely the bargain of the season at £2.5m. Phillips and Quinn have been superb over the last four years, and McCann is starting to fulfil his enormous promise. As for other teams, I really rate Steven Gerrard, and Roy Keane was absolutely outstanding against us earlier this year. Marcus Stewart has been superb this year, and has done a Phillips. It will be interesting to see what happens to him in his second season. Players hated Kevin Kilbane seems to be the target of the boo boys at the minute, which is a shame as he had a pretty good start to the season. As for other clubs, well it has to be Alan Shearer. Not only did Shearer allegedly say that he didn't like playing with Phillips for England, but he also took the rise out of the Fulwell End at the end of the last derby at Roker. Needless to say, his penalty miss in last November's derby was greeted with universal acclaim on Wearside. I think most people saw it as poetic justice. The Stadium of Light The new ground is a vast improvement on the dilapidated Roker Park. With excellent views from every seat, and much better catering facilities, supporters are well looked after. However, trying to go for a half-time 'comfort break' is never easy, or quick. There are plenty of toilets, but the planners failed to account for the thirst of the average Sunderland supporter. Atmosphere on match days The bowl of the stadium seems to help the noise generated, so the atmosphere is usually good. The big games are something special, as you can sense that the fans are really up for these games. When Phillips scored the equaliser in last year's derby, the roof nearly came off. I've never heard a noise so loud at any football match I've ever been to. What to do before the match There are numerous watering holes in Sunderland City Centre, which is only ten minutes walk from the ground. A more extensive guide can be found on the website. Sunderland is quite a good place to come to for the away fan, as most of our lot like having a bit of crack with the opposition over a pint. You can have a drink in the ground, and maybe try one of our delicious chicken balti pies. Programmes are top quality, and can be bought at the food outlets, or outside the ground. Links There are many Sunderland related fanzines published regularly, though Ready To Go is probably the only "busy" and active site written by the fans for the fans with a total independent view. Sites such as A Love Supreme and The FTM Executive Club, www.ftmx.co.uk offer great alternatives. The club does have an official website, www.sunderland-afc.com which has up to the date news on the team, interviews with the players, merchandise, club stats and ticket availability - even if slow to update at times.
