fields.headline: US basketball needs bounce
fields.standfirst: The vaguest possibility of Michael Jordan's return is the only light on the horizon for the languishing sport of basketball, writes Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: The vaguest possibility of Michael Jordan's return is the only light on the horizon for the languishing sport of basketball, writes Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
There are those who think that there's only one thing wrong with basketball, the sport of urban America: Michael Jordan isn't playing any more.

You can see their point. Since the most talented player in the game's history last played nearly three years ago, a lot of the lustre has gone. That and many of the fans. Attendances are down outside the main centres such as New York and so too is the television audience.

One in every five who used to watch on NBC has found something else to do other than watch the three games available back-to-back on the small screen on a Sunday.

So when Jordan says that there is a 99.9% chance that he will not return, all anyone sees is the 0.1% chance that he will do so. For one thing, Abe Pollin, owner of the hapless Washington Wizards, where Jordan is director of basketball operations says: "The odds are that he's going to come back."

Then there is "Super" Mario Lemieux, the all-time ice hockey great, who knows something about comebacks himself, having returned for the Pittsburgh Penguins at the end of last year, as good as new after being out for three and a half years.

Lemieux, who has had cancer and problems with his back, is a golf partner of Jordan and says he expects to see the 38-year-old, who won six National Basketball Association titles with the Chicago Bulls, back on the court next year. "I think it's very exciting for basketball and obviously I'm very excited about it," said Lemieux. "He's going to give it a shot and he's working very hard. I'm sure when he gets back he'll be the best player again."

If Jordan does come back, it will not be for the money. He still rakes in about $40m a year in endorsements but it is said that he has kept a close watch on how Tiger Woods has advanced on his redoubt as probably still the world's most famous sportsman.

But quite a lot has changed since Jordan's last act as a professional, claiming the basket that won the Bulls their last championship. This is not simply a reference to the damage Jordan did to the tip of his right index finger a couple of years ago - the victim of a cigar cutter - which makes it hard for him to hold the ball as he would wish.

Rather, the views of one of the leading coaches of the day must be taken into account. Jeff Van Gundy, the single-minded designer of plays for the New York Knicks, has identified debilitating factors that go far beyond the NBA's lack of a transcendent Jordan-like beacon for the game: golf and God.

Van Gundy, a diminutive, self-critical guru of glumness, is the first to say that he is not the most positive of men. His team, he says, are "sleepy and lethargic."

Nor is he the most culturally aware. He is baffled by the observation that at the age of 39 he is not that much older than some of his players, yet each listens to music that the other cannot fathom (80% of the players in the NBA are black).

And what does he listen to? "One of my college room-mates was into the Police and I got to like them. But I hear one of the guys left the band." The coach is talking about Sting. "Yeah, that's it, I understand he's got a solo career, right?"

But golf and God? He says that they are the nemesis of the modern game: "And I don't mean that in a derogatory way to God." So what does he mean? "We let a preacher into our locker room. Spends as much time as he wants with our players before games.

"Now, do people in offices have preachers coming into their place of business, interrupting their work? No. They have to do it before or after work. They don't get to do it during work. That's the problem I have.

"As a team and an organisation, you've got to try to minimise those distractions. It used to be alcohol and women more. I think we've given this guy, this pastor, too much freedom.

"And I think the interaction between people before games, opposing sides, the fraternisation, is wrong for the league, it's wrong for competition. Everybody's hugging before games, praying together."

This guy, this pastor, an assistant minister at a church in Baltimore, says he's only trying to help with his ten-minute Bible studies and several of the players were upset by the coach's performance.

Van Gundy says that he stands by his opinions though he wishes he had not expressed them. He had better make an accommodation with the G-force: Michael Jordan plays golf and he is the nearest thing to a god that basketball has seen.

fields.headline: Tina weaves her way to the top
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: Tina Weaver, the new editor of the Sunday Mirror, has tabloid instincts Richard Desmond would kill for, writes Richard Desmond.
12.04.2001: Article was 'serious error'
12.04.2001: Mirror Group statement in full
12.04.2001: Myler quits as Sunday Mirror editor
fields.body:
Tina Weaver, the new editor of the Sunday Mirror, has tabloid instincts that Richard Desmond would kill for.

Deputy to Piers Morgan since 1998, Ms Weaver has combined a passion for "feminine" human interest stories with a hard news instinct.

It was she who broke what the Mirror believed was its best scoop of 1999 - that Tony and Cherie Blair were expecting their fourth child.

Headlined "Scoop of the year: Blairs' Babe: They are utterly and completely Gobsmacked", the story was written by the deputy editor herself.

Although many argued Matthew Wright's expose of hoaxers on the Vanessa Feltz show was a better story, Cherie's baby got the attention of the establishment and the Mirror's rivals.

Ms Weaver's came to the public eye with her scoop revelation on Today that Michael Jackson's marriage to Lisa Marie Presley was a sham, a story that won her the reporter of the year award in the British Press Awards in 1994.

Ms Weaver, who joined the Mirror in 1995, has gravitated towards the feminine, with heart-rending interviews with the family of Sarah Payne and Helen Rollason a staple of her work.

Eyebrows were raised recently by her decision to splash on an exclusive interview with Coronation Street star Helen Worth.

She made the media gossip pages when, while editing a reader Q&A with Tony Blair, she substituted questions about the state of the health service for "Do you mind losing your hair?" and "Who does the cooking at Number 10?".

And mischievous gossips recall the time she went with editor Piers Morgan to visit Tony Blair clad in a tiny mini-skirt.

But she has won plaudits for her launch and editorship of the Mirror's Saturday magazine M, which is widely thought to be a slick, aspirational magazine with more of an edge than some of the glossies it copied.

Sources say her combination of good people skills and toughness make her ideal for the Sunday Mirror.

Now, with the editors of the two highest-selling Sunday tabloids both female, pundits are immediately focusing on the battle of the bimbos.

Ms Weaver is likely to be searching even now for a campaign to grab headlines like Ms Wade's paedophile "name and shame" campaign on the News of the World.

And staff at M will be lamenting the loss of their leader.

webTitle: Cuba loves Costner, less sure about movie

fields.headline: Cuba loves Costner, less sure about movie
fields.trailText: Kevin Costner jets out of Havana today following an eventful visit to promote his recent film Thirteen Days, which re-enacts the Cuban missile crisis of 1962
fields.body:
Kevin Costner jets out of Havana today following an eventful visit to promote his recent film Thirteen Days, which re-enacts the Cuban missile crisis of 1962. For Costner the message from the Cubans seems to have been a case of: "Love you, not sure about your movie."

Certainly the star of JFK and Dances With Wolves was cheered to the rafters when he entered Havana's Charles Chaplin cinema for Wednesday night's special screening. "I feel like I should start singing a song," quipped Costner above the bedlam. Fortunately he contented himself with gracious words: "You do us a great honour by filling this room. My heart feels really big right now."

But while the assembled Cubans loved seeing Costner in the flesh, they appeared less sure about the film itself. Applause as the end credits rolled was lukewarm at best, and various members of the audience felt that it had glamourised America's role in the crisis.

"Kevin Costner is a great actor and a good and thoughtful man," one cinema-goer told Reuters. "But I'm tired of this vision of the world where they are always the good guys fighting to save world harmony. History has shown us that is not true."

Two evenings earlier, Costner had watched Thirteen Days alongside Fidel Castro, during an extended seven-hour meeting. By all accounts, Cuba's president took a more tolerant view. "He said that he enjoyed the film and that he understood it was just that - a film and not a documentary," said Costner.

According to Costner's entourage, the Marxist leader was disappointed that he himself did not appear in the picture. When asked who he'd like to see play him on screen, Castro apparently responded: "Me."

fields.headline: Caught in the safety net
fields.standfirst: The internet can be a dangerous place for kids to roam freely. But protecting them is hazardous too, writes  Mike Anderiesz
fields.trailText: The internet can be a dangerous place for kids to roam freely. But protecting them is hazardous too, writes Mike Anderiesz.
fields.body:
While it is tempting to argue that the internet and kids go together like sharks and custard, in truth there's no keeping them away from it.

With Easter upon us, parents are entitled to feel more than the usual concern at the average three hours per week a child spends online. However, recent press coverage has probably exaggerated the extent of an admittedly serious problem. The internet can be as safe as you want, it's just a question of how draconian you want to be and how much you trust your kids.

According to the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF) the organisation that investigates and monitors offensive websites, there are three areas of potential danger to children: Content, Contact and Commerce. Only the first two are perceived as serious problems, but all can be overcome by a combination of using the technology available and following the basic rules of childcare.

"It's a good parenting issue," says David Kerr of the IWF, "and it can be approached in any number of ways. At the younger ages it's no more than looking over their shoulder or keeping them out of certain areas. As they get older they face the same dangers they face on the streets. It's a matter of training and trusting them."

And trust is fundamental. Yes, it is perfectly possible to filter internet content heavily and snoop on what your kids are up to, but both are blunt instruments and can backfire in spectacular ways. Kids are not only protective of their privacy but there are good reasons why this should be respected. The NSPCC website includes instructions on how to delete temporary folders and History files to prevent genuine pleas for help becoming known to abusers. Just as any child would resent you recording their personal phone calls, so unnecessary snooping on email or browsing habits could have very counterproductive effects.

As a rule, then, protecting your children from online dangers falls into four stages, briefly outlined on these pages. Finding the right combination depends on how much you are prepared to entrust to technology, and what you prefer to deal with yourself.

Keeping tabs on your children's activities just through Internet Explorer is easier than you might think. Be warned, however, that older kids have a habit of rising to the challenge of such obstacles.

Controls
1) Setting up home: The homepage, above, is where most online journeys begin, and choosing a safe one will eliminate most problems in a stroke. In Explorer select Tools|Internet Options and type in your preferred address. Some suggestions for safe homepages are listed.

2) Monitoring activity: The History folder keeps a record of the most recently visited sites. You can inspect this log by opening Explorer and clicking the arrows to the right of the address window.

3) Double checking: You can also take a quick look at the Temp and Temporary Internet Files folders, which keep a record of applets and cookies that often betray Spam advertisers and unwelcome transactions.

4) Content controls: Internet Explorer can block access to any website that has not signed up for an RSACi rating. There are four levels of control, the first only blocking the most offensive (and honest) culprits, the last excluding almost everything. These settings can be tweaked and are password protected.

5) Spotting the birdie: While little can be done to track or filter adult chatrooms, follow-up material is easier to spot. Offensive images, for instance, are usually stored as .jpg or .gif files, and videos tend to be in an .mpg or .avi format. You can search for them by clicking Start|Search for Files or Folders and then typing in the file extension. You can view them all at once by right clicking in the search window and selecting View|Thumbnails.

webTitle: Medical research threatened by patient consent

fields.headline: Medical research threatened by patient consent
fields.standfirst: If you have ever seen a doctor, you are being tracked. Information about you is being stored and analysed as part of a vast pool of medical data. But now this crucial area of research is under threat, warns  Ben Traynor, because of  moves to force medics to seek patients' permission for every study
fields.trailText: If you have ever seen a doctor, you are being tracked. Information about you is being stored and analysed as part of a vast pool of medical data. But now this crucial area of research is under threat, warns Ben Traynor, because of moves to force medics to seek patients' permission for every study.
fields.body:
Every time you step inside a hospital, the chances are that someone, somewhere is watching you - though that someone is more benevolent than your average stalker, and it is your disease and your data that he or she is interested in, not you.

Epidemiologists, or medical statisticians, watch the figures for health across the country, spotting trends. They work by trawling through information from the records of millions of people. It is epidemiologists who assess the dangers of the contraceptive pill, whether ethnic minorities have equal access to health care and whether electricity pylons cause leukaemia. It is they who work out which treatment is best for breast cancer - and whether your GP might be quietly murdering old ladies in their homes.

Because they work with whole populations, epidemiologists can see what is dangerous and what isn't, whether particular illnesses are becoming more or less common, what treatment works and what doesn't, and - in the case of surgeons - who is dangerous and who isn't. Epidemiology has helped save more lives than any of the other more glamorous branches of medicine.

Every time a doctor advises you about your health or decides how best to treat you, he or she is using the evidence provided by epidemiologists. Universal clean water and sewage facilities, and advising people not to smoke, were among their most famous ideas.

But all of this may have to come to an end. The General Medical Council (GMC) has decided that this kind of purely observational work is an infringement of patients' rights - even though it reveals nobody's identity and does nothing to alter or withold anyone's treatment.

The GMC has declared that each study should go ahead only with every patients' expressed and informed consent, and that doctors should not provide data about their patients to any other doctors without that consent. It's a nice idea: patient autonomy and patient confidentiality are crucial, and it would be wrong to dismiss them out of hand. But because such consent is often unworkable - for a host of practical and scientific reasons - the change might stop epidemiology and clinical audit in their tracks and severely impede further advances in medicine.

Ironically, epidemiologists and other doctors who use records purely for research and statistical purposes are the people in medicine who have taken confidentiality and data encryption most seriously. Anyone worried about the confidentiality of material relating to their health should be more concerned about the underpaid temporary staff working on the front desk of their local GP surgery than about a group of medical statisticians cooing over a meta-analysis of 50,000 cases of cancer. There are no scandals in epidemiology.

The problem is that the data being shared must, at some stage, include the identity of the patient. Looking at how our world-renowned national net work of cancer registries works, you can see why. For decades, 11 cancer research centres around the country have collected morsels of data on patients afflicted with cancer in their region. From the type of cancer to how they were treated, from the details of their laboratory investigations to their death certificate, all the information is collated, stored and analysed in order to improve the care of the next generation of patients.

There is a good reason that it is not possible for this information to be filed entirely anonymously, without identification of the patients attached. The cancer registry system collates data from innumerable diverse and unrelated bodies: the registrar of deaths in the town hall, the GP, the hospital pathologist. And the patient's identity is the only thing that unifies these disparate pieces of information, allowing the registry to match up tissue diagnosis with symptoms with death certificate and trace the life of one person's cancer.

But it is not as if the information is being broadcast on the nine o'clock news. This is the confidential transfer of information between doctors, which is then held with obsessive security, with the doctors being accountable to the GMC if they treat the information irresponsibly.

It is the most comprehensive national cancer database ever constructed and is the envy of the world. Every doctor in the country is expected to file data to the cancer registries on their patients. But the GMC has given a deadline of October 2001 for the cancer registries to put mechanisms in place for seeking and recording the consent of everyone on their books. Without this consent, doctors will have to stop the flow of information to them. Because this is impractical, cancer registries may have to close.

But if the GMC wants us to, why can't we just ask people for consent? Can it really be so difficult? In some circumstances it may be, and not just for practical reasons. Insisting on consent can systematically skew the data, and give answers that are weaker, or simply wrong.

If you ask people to agree to having their data used in an observational study, some will refuse. That, of course, is the reason you are asking them in the first place. And when they refuse, particularly if certain types of people are consistently more likely to refuse, such as the demented, the psychotic, the homeless, or those embarrassed by their health problems, that skews your data.

This is what medical statisticians call "consent bias". It is important because it can turn your data on its head, render it useless and give the wrong conclusions. In medicine, that costs lives.

There are unscalable practical barriers to seeking consent from the whole population. It remains a Herculean task even if, instead of considering specific cases with patients, we assume that we only want to ask everyone in the country the rather uninformative and vacuous question: "Do you consent to your data being shared, on a confidential basis, for anything we can think of?" There are 60 milion of us, after all.

How quickly can you get informed consent, and explain why you want it? Will three minutes tacked on to the first consultation with a GP be enough? A tick-box? Who will keep a central record? What about the patient with Alzheimer's who can't give consent? What if you change your mind? What if you switch GPs? What if you never go to a GP, but just pitch up in A&E one day? It is a far bigger undertaking than the census, and it is hard to imagine it ever happening.

It would be far easier to legislate to protect the work of cancer registries and other organisations concerned with epidemiology and health services research, to ensure that the confidential data they need could never be used for non-medical purposes. That would protect the public and promote new medical knowledge.

As a doctor, I don't expect patients just to tolerate the kind of work that the cancer registries and epidemiologists do: I believe they would be astonished if it weren't done. Epidemiology is the foundation on which all preventative medicine is based. Without it, much would be just anecdote and small drug trials. This move to tie its legs together can only be motivated by some unthinking adherence to an abstract philosophical doctrine about privacy. The point of the principle of confidentiality was to protect the patient from untoward disclosure of information which could be used to his or her detriment. It should not be a moral absolute, at so great a cost.

Is our adherence to principles about privacy so important that we would sagely shave months or years off our life expectancies? I'd rather have another birthday, thanks.

The GMC has declared that each study should go ahead only with every patients' expressed and informed consent, and that doctors should not provide data about their patients to any other doctors without that consent. It's a nice idea: patient autonomy and patient confidentiality are crucial, and it would be wrong to dismiss them out of hand. But because such consent is often unworkable - for a host of practical and scientific reasons - the change might stop epidemiology and clinical audit in their tracks and severely impede further advances in medicine. Ironically, epidemiologists and other doctors who use records purely for research and statistical purposes are the people in medicine who have taken confidentiality and data encryption most seriously. Anyone worried about the confidentiality of material relating to their health should be more concerned about the underpaid temporary staff working on the front desk of their local GP surgery than about a group of medical statisticians cooing over a meta-analysis of 50,000 cases of cancer. There are no scandals in epidemiology. The problem is that the data being shared must, at some stage, include the identity of the patient. Looking at how our world-renowned national net work of cancer registries works, you can see why. For decades, 11 cancer research centres around the country have collected morsels of data on patients afflicted with cancer in their region. From the type of cancer to how they were treated, from the details of their laboratory investigations to their death certificate, all the information is collated, stored and analysed in order to improve the care of the next generation of patients. There is a good reason that it is not possible for this information to be filed entirely anonymously, without identification of the patients attached. The cancer registry system collates data from innumerable diverse and unrelated bodies: the registrar of deaths in the town hall, the GP, the hospital pathologist. And the patient's identity is the only thing that unifies these disparate pieces of information, allowing the registry to match up tissue diagnosis with symptoms with death certificate and trace the life of one person's cancer. But it is not as if the information is being broadcast on the nine o'clock news. This is the confidential transfer of information between doctors, which is then held with obsessive security, with the doctors being accountable to the GMC if they treat the information irresponsibly. It is the most comprehensive national cancer database ever constructed and is the envy of the world. Every doctor in the country is expected to file data to the cancer registries on their patients. But the GMC has given a deadline of October 2001 for the cancer registries to put mechanisms in place for seeking and recording the consent of everyone on their books. Without this consent, doctors will have to stop the flow of information to them. Because this is impractical, cancer registries may have to close. But if the GMC wants us to, why can't we just ask people for consent? Can it really be so difficult? In some circumstances it may be, and not just for practical reasons. Insisting on consent can systematically skew the data, and give answers that are weaker, or simply wrong. If you ask people to agree to having their data used in an observational study, some will refuse. That, of course, is the reason you are asking them in the first place. And when they refuse, particularly if certain types of people are consistently more likely to refuse, such as the demented, the psychotic, the homeless, or those embarrassed by their health problems, that skews your data. This is what medical statisticians call "consent bias". It is important because it can turn your data on its head, render it useless and give the wrong conclusions. In medicine, that costs lives. There are unscalable practical barriers to seeking consent from the whole population. It remains a Herculean task even if, instead of considering specific cases with patients, we assume that we only want to ask everyone in the country the rather uninformative and vacuous question: "Do you consent to your data being shared, on a confidential basis, for anything we can think of?" There are 60 milion of us, after all. How quickly can you get informed consent, and explain why you want it? Will three minutes tacked on to the first consultation with a GP be enough? A tick-box? Who will keep a central record? What about the patient with Alzheimer's who can't give consent? What if you change your mind? What if you switch GPs? What if you never go to a GP, but just pitch up in A&E one day? It is a far bigger undertaking than the census, and it is hard to imagine it ever happening. It would be far easier to legislate to protect the work of cancer registries and other organisations concerned with epidemiology and health services research, to ensure that the confidential data they need could never be used for non-medical purposes. That would protect the public and promote new medical knowledge. As a doctor, I don't expect patients just to tolerate the kind of work that the cancer registries and epidemiologists do: I believe they would be astonished if it weren't done. Epidemiology is the foundation on which all preventative medicine is based. Without it, much would be just anecdote and small drug trials. This move to tie its legs together can only be motivated by some unthinking adherence to an abstract philosophical doctrine about privacy. The point of the principle of confidentiality was to protect the patient from untoward disclosure of information which could be used to his or her detriment. It should not be a moral absolute, at so great a cost. Is our adherence to principles about privacy so important that we would sagely shave months or years off our life expectancies? I'd rather have another birthday, thanks.

fields.headline: Switching off gran
fields.standfirst: Doctors think it is their right to decide when to stop treatment. So do patients and their families
fields.trailText: Doctors think it is their right to decide when to stop treatment. So do patients and their families. Michael Rennie weighs up the debate.
fields.body:
Last year, a 67-year-old patient from Southampton discovered after leaving hospital that a junior doctor had written a do not resuscitate (DNR) order for her without consulting her or her husband.

Age Concern claimed to know of more than 100 similar cases that it promised to bring to the attention of Alan Milburn, the health secretary. At its annual conference, the British Medical Association resolved that junior doctors should not be coerced into signing DNR orders. It called upon its own ethics committee to consider whether doctors should be obliged to get prior written consent from patients and families before writing such orders.

The Department of Health has since written to chief executives of all NHS trusts, instructing them to make sure that agreed resuscitation policies not only have patients' rights at their heart but are readily available to patients and their families.

The sadly often well-founded perception by patients that doctors are paternalist and authoritarian has been fanned by the media, and was worsened by Mr Milburn's willingness to lay blame for the recent Alder Hey affair indiscriminatingly at the feet of the medical profession.

In these circumstances, the instructions concerning treatment for the terminally ill would, if instituted, be astonishingly good examples of best practice in the open, patient-oriented NHS New Labour tell us they are determined to deliver.

Oddly, no explicit deadline for implementation was given. For a policy with such important consequences for clinical care, and of such avid interest to patients, their relatives and the media, this is surprising.

Most of the obligations the Mr Milburn placed upon chief executives are sensible. They should allow difficult decisions to be made more easily and more acceptably to those they affect.

However, making the policies on resuscitation and other critical treatments readily available to patients and their families is likely to have a major impact upon decisions to withhold and withdraw treatment from terminally ill patients, which may not necessarily be in their best interests.

In Britain, as elsewhere in Europe, medical paternalism is being beaten back by health care professionals with much more open, flexible and humane attitudes than their predecessors.

Nevertheless, unlike in the US where most doctors accept the primacy of patient autonomy and the overriding will of the family in life or death decisions, doctors in Britain have traditionally regarded decisions concerning whether to resuscitate as their primary responsibility, even their right.

In this they are probably very similar to Swedish doctors, two-thirds of whom wished to make decisions concerning, for example, continuation of ventilation, without reference to the families of patients who were incapable of deciding on their own behalf.

Such attitudes and practices are unlikely to survive pressure from patients and their families once the text of any policy is made accessible to them.

Some patients and their relatives will simply not accept the professional right of doctors to make important medical decisions, as has been amply illustrated by the substantial number of parents who refuse to accept conventional medical opinion on the safety and efficacy of the MMR vaccine for their children.

Once policies become transparent, the wishes of the families will inevitably assume much more impor tance. If patients are not competent, major difficulties will arise when families disagree with the decisions of doctors.

Advance directives (so-called living wills) will not necessarily solve the problem. Very often, as is shown by experience in the US, there are conflicts between what the patient says should happen and what the decision turns out to be. Also, even when patients participate in decisions concerning themselves and are sanguine at the time of the discussion, within a week up to a third may have become substantially distressed and wish to change their minds.

Under the new Human Rights Act, the right to life is fundamental. It may not be sufficient for doctors to argue that resuscitation should be denied where there was, say, only a 20% chance of intervention resulting in a patient's recovery to a satisfactory state of existence.

It may be possible to argue that the only justification for withdrawing a treatment would be absolute certainty of its futility. The European court has been silent on this matter, presumably because it will be so difficult to resolve.

In the current circumstances of near paranoia about hospitals and doctors, and as the expectations of patients increase inexorably, the formulation and implementation of rational, humane, practical and acceptable resuscitation policies will be extraordinarily difficult.

 Michael Rennie is professor of physiology at Dundee University

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 52: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 52: The government's chief scientific adviser now says foot and mouth has peaked.
fields.body:
The Times
Reports on its front page that the government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, now says foot and mouth has peaked nearly two months before the government's original forecast.

Daily Mail
On page nine the paper visits Devon farmer Adam Stanbury, who has lost 150 newborn lambs, not through foot and mouth, but because restrictions on movement mean they are dying stuck in rain-sodden muddy fields.

Daily Star
Tony Blair yesterday admitted the foot and mouth crisis has been the toughest he has faced as prime minister, the Star reports on page five.

Daily Mirror
Tony Blair's gamble to delay the May election paid off last night as experts declared the worst of the plague was over, according to a page two report.

Financial Times
Page five quotes new research suggesting Scotland will be worst hit by the loss of tourism revenue in the wake of the crisis, but London could actually gain overall.

fields.headline: Strange history
fields.standfirst: The RSC's omnibus package of the two tetralogies reveals as much about Shakespeare's artistic progress as his royal subjects, says  John Sutherland
fields.trailText: The RSC's omnibus package of the two tetralogies reveals as much about Shakespeare's artistic progress as his royal subjects, says John Sutherland.
fields.body:
The big question with the bard (Happy 437th birthday, William) is whether to swallow him whole, like a boa-constrictor with a goat, or break off gem-like bits to treasure. Holism has its attractions. Trying to explain Shakespeare's greatness by quotations (or even by citing single plays), Dr Johnson said, is like trying to describe a cathedral by carrying a brick in your pocket.

On Monday, the Royal Shakespeare Company began This England - The Histories, an omnibus package of Shakespeare's two tetralogies: first Richard II, Henry IV Parts I and II and Henry V; then Henry VI Parts I, II and III and Richard III. These eight long plays span a turbulent century, from the 1380s to the 1480s.

The period is dominated by two cataclysmic conflicts: the Hundred Years War, and the Wars of the Roses. It begins in the aftermath of the Black Death, and ends with the emergence of modern England. The final act, the Battle of Bosworth, was about as far away from Shakespeare when he began to write his histories as the Boer war is from us. He might even, as a boy, have known sons of veterans who fought against (or for) Crookback, and heard "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse".

For those who sign up for the whole week, This England means 22 hours of bladder-straining theatre time and a wallet-straining £220 in price. The RSC should award long-service medal for those who stay (and pay) the course. But this whole-enchilada approach to Shakespeare's history plays is not new. In 1964 (when Shakespeare was a mere 400 years old), John Barton and Peter Hall did them all in two days at the Aldwych as The Wars of the Roses. A version was adapted for TV. It was mind-blowingly original. The directors (then rising stars, now patriarchs) took outrageous liberties with the texts to fuse the grand design together. They rewrote and reshaped Shakespeare. Creative vandalism; great theatre.

This latest fusion is more reverential. This is not, you understand, the 1960s. The RSC production will, however, like the Barton-Hall experiment, allow the same actor to move across plays. Young Bolingbroke will, before the audience's eyes, become decrepit Henry IV. Coltish Prince Hal, habitue of the Eastcheap taverns, will grow up (as played by the same actor) into the sagacious warrior king.

Long transtextual perspectives can work with Shakespeare, as Orson Welles proved in his magnificent (but incomplete) Chimes at Midnight. Like Welles's film, This England will weld together Falstaff elements from three plays into unity, and a single actor's persona.

The idea that the two tetralogies compose distinct epic designs, or Henriads, is a critical commonplace. Shakespeare clearly saw the outline of two large structures as he penned the eight plays. It's also self-evident that the plays are chronologically and thematically coherent. There is, then, sound historical justification for the RSC omnibus. The company's artistic director, Adrian Noble, is right to claim that "this will be an amazing opportunity for audiences to see English history unfolding before their eyes".

But the artistic logic behind the This England venture is dubious. For this reason: Shakespeare wrote the tetralogies in reverse historical sequence. The first (the three Henry VI plays and Richard III), was composed between 1588 and the early 1590s. It is early, rough-edged Shakespeare. The second (Richard II, the two parts of Henry IV and Henry V), dates from between 1595 and 1599. It represents the dramatist at the height of his artistic power.

The 1590s was a decade in which Shakespeare became Shakespeare. Had he died after writing Richard III, he would rank little higher than Fletcher or Dekker. Great but not the greatest. He'd get about 500 words in Maggie Drabble's Oxford Companion to English Literature (as opposed to 5,000). Henry VI, Part I opens with the Duke of Bedford's lament on the recent death of Henry V:

Hung be the Heavens with black, yield day to night!

Comets, importing change of times and states,

Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky!

Compare this fustian with the self-mocking chorus that opens Henry V ("Oh, for a muse of fire"), written 10 years later, and one can see the yawning gulf between Shakespeare's apprentice work and the dramatic mastery of his maturity.

If, as This England does, you put the eight plays in the right historical order (Richard II to Richard III), you put them in the wrong artistic order. The audience will, inevitably, have the eerie feeling that Shakespeare is going off. Losing his touch, as he moves forward in historical time.

This England is none the less a worthwhile enterprise. If nothing else, it will get those seldom- performed Henry VI plays on the stage, to full houses. But audiences investing so much time and money should do a little homework. They should check out where the different plays come in Shakespeare's writing career, so as to make the necessary aesthetic adjustments.

The best preparation is to buy John Julius Norwich's 1999 book Shakespeare's Kings. Norwich recalls being taken by his parents, as a 15-year-old in the mid-1940s, to see the two parts of Henry IV in consecutive matinee performance, starring Ralph Richardson as Falstaff and Olivier as Hotspur. His interest in the long expanses of Shakespeare's history was sharpened by the Barton-Hall compilation, The Wars of the Roses, which he sat through from beginning to end, 20 years later.

As a historian, Norwich cannot but point out the woeful inaccuracies. But, as he reminds us: "Shakespeare was not a historian; he was a dramatist. The play was the thing." Make that plays - all eight of them.

 Shakespeare's Kings, by John Julius Norwich, is published by Penguin, price £9.99. To book tickets for the RSC's history plays, call the box office on (020-7638 8891).

fields.headline: Gladiator to make UK TV debut on pay-per-view
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: UK cable and satellite viewers will get the first glimpse of Gladiator on TV later this month, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
UK cable and satellite TV viewers will get a first glimpse of the multi-Oscar-winning film Gladiator later this month, when it launches on pay-per-view services u>direct tv and Front Row.

The deal is a coup for the fledgling companies, which normally play second fiddle to their bigger rival BSkyB.

The toga epic, which was directed by British film-maker Ridley Scott, will be available on PPV from Monday April 23.

Gladiator is being offered by u>direct via the Sky Digital satellite platform, and by Front Row to NTL's and Telewest's 3.6m analogue and digital cable subscribers.

BSkyB's own in-house PPV operation, Sky Box Office, is thought to have missed out on the UK TV premiere of Gladiator.

u>direct came in for criticism after football fans experienced difficulties trying to subscribe to the England v Finland World Cup qualifier last autumn.

Gladiator last month picked up five Oscars - more than any other movie - at the 2001 awards ceremony, including best picture and best actor for Russell Crowe.

Both u>direct and Front Row have picked up the film through a deal with Hollywood studio Universal.

Channel 5 is expected to pick up the UK terrestrial premiere of Gladiator in a ground-breaking joint deal with Channel 4.

webTitle: Distress over delay of mayoral legislation

fields.headline: Distress over delay of mayoral legislation
fields.trailText: Local government leaders have attacked ministers for failing to produce crucial legislation that must come into effect before city mayors and council cabinets can be introduced.
fields.body:
Local government leaders have attacked ministers for failing to produce crucial legislation that must come into effect before city mayors and council cabinets can be introduced.

Many local authorities had hoped to have the new cabinets in place for their annual general meetings (AGMs) next month, when local politicians elect their authority's leader and committee chairmen.

But the government has not yet produced laws that will tidy up the statute book to remove clashes between the new structures and old legislation. Civil servants say these changes will be brought into effect over May and June, but it is unclear what effect a general election might have on that timetable.

The announcement, made in a letter sent to local authority chief executives, means councils will only be able to start operating the structures from June and, if they adopt a cabinet after their AGM, councillors may have to re-elect their entire leadership.

Local Government Association chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham said: "It's all a bit unsatisfactory, really. It does mess things up."

This is not the first time government legislation has left councils in the lurch over their new political structures - crucial regulations for mayoral referendums were held up last year by the Home Office, which was said to see them as low priority.

The move ruled out referendums in May, and the first round of ballots is now expected in June and July.

Most councils are still facing a June deadline for sending proposals for their new structures to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

However, ministers this week announced that those authorities with delayed elections, or that have had their work disrupted by the foot and mouth crisis, will have until September to file their plans.

The announcement, made in a letter sent to local authority chief executives, means councils will only be able to start operating the structures from June and, if they adopt a cabinet after their AGM, councillors may have to re-elect their entire leadership. Local Government Association chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham said: "It's all a bit unsatisfactory, really. It does mess things up." This is not the first time government legislation has left councils in the lurch over their new political structures - crucial regulations for mayoral referendums were held up last year by the Home Office, which was said to see them as low priority. The move ruled out referendums in May, and the first round of ballots is now expected in June and July. Most councils are still facing a June deadline for sending proposals for their new structures to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. However, ministers this week announced that those authorities with delayed elections, or that have had their work disrupted by the foot and mouth crisis, will have until September to file their plans.

fields.headline: Octagon eyes entertainment arena
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Sports marketing company Octagon is expanding into the music and entertainment arena, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Sports marketing company Octagon is expanding into the music and entertainment arena with the appointment of a team of specialists from its sister PR company, Weber Shandwick.

Octagon and Weber Shandwick are both owned by the world's largest advertising and marketing communications group, the Interpublic Group.

Interpublic agreed the team would be better situated within Octagon, which is keen to take advantage of the increasing interest among brands to promote themselves through film, music, theatre and international entertainment events.

Niki Turner heads up the team as one of Octagon's four senior vice-presidents. Two other members of her team join from Weber Shandwick and a fourth has been hired from outside.

The team have managed campaigns including Miss World 2000, the Three Tenors World Cup concerts, Sunset Boulevard, Tony Bennett and opera singer Bryn Terfel.

"A significant number of major clients are interested in music and entertainment as a way to connect with their target group - be that for corporate hospitality or consumers to whom sport doesn't appeal," said Alasdair Ritchie, president of Octagon Marketing.

Octagon recently bought the overseas broadcast rights to Premiership football for £178m as part of a consortium with News International.

webTitle: Lib Dems pledge poll on regional government

fields.headline: Lib Dems pledge poll on regional government
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats today launched a range of election proposals designed to rejuvenate the country's towns and cities, and promised to hold referendums on English regional government.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats today launched a range of election proposals designed to rejuvenate the country's towns and cities, and promised to hold referendums on English regional government.

Setting out its "manifesto on urban and suburban England", the party says it would protect greenfield sites and encourage urban redevelopment by allowing local councils to replace the uniform business rate with a system based on site value.

The proposals follow reports that Labour is to offer voters the prospect of elected regional government in England. A green paper on the issue is widely expected after the next general election, but ministers maintain that this is simply speculation.

Don Foster, the Liberal Democrat spokesman for the environment, transport and the regions, said: "We want communities to be able to make decisions for themselves. Power must be put back in their hands. Labour's patchwork quilt of regeneration budgets has created confusion. Every one of their regeneration schemes has been massively underspent.

"Liberal Democrats would create a unified regeneration fund to cut red tape and make it easier for communities to kick-start projects in their areas. We would guarantee local democratic input into decision making."

The party said it would also create 2,000 part-time community police officers and introduce a "safe front doors for all" initiative on crime.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes said that, by funding the community officers, police forces would be given more flexibility.

Mr Hughes said: "People in our towns and cities want to be free from the fear of crime."

The proposals were being launched at the New River Green estate in Islington, north London.

webTitle: Moody's puts paid to BT's fragile rally

fields.headline: Moody's puts paid to BT's fragile rally
fields.trailText: Moody's, the influential credit agency, yesterday said it was sceptical about the economics of next-generation mobile phones, ending the fragile rally in BT's share price. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Moody's, the influential credit agency, yesterday said it was increasingly sceptical about the economics of next-generation mobile phones, ending the fragile rally in the share price of British Telecom.

The sector review from Moody's was enough to over ride reports that BT had found another £1bn from the hoped-for sale of its fleet of vans to a vehicle-leasing operator. BT aims to agree the sale and lease-back of its fleet of 58,000 vehicles.

The company, which has seen its wider strategy for reduction of its £30bn of debt knocked off course by the volatile state of the stock market is raising another £2bn from the sale of its property portfolio. Analysts are largely unimpressed by the piecemeal approach. The shares, which reached a low of 479p little more than a week ago, slipped 4.5p to 569.5p.

Moody's reiterated its negative outlook on the European telecoms sector due to the doubts about the ability of next generation UMTS networks to bring significant returns, the pressures of competition and the hurdles to the repayment of debt.

At the same time, the report noted, the likes of BT, Deutsche Telekom and France Télécom face increased risk and calls on cash because of their diversification into other businesses and countries.

Carlos Winzer, senior vice-president at Moody's said: "We believe the European telecoms companies remain vulnerable because of their need to reduce debt at a time when increasing shareholder pressure and a non-receptive market for new equity issuance and asset sales are going to make that very difficult."

The report said breakeven on third generation mobile was unlikely to be achieved before the fourth or fifth year of operation at least. "Cash flow generation from investment in UMTS is very uncertain, both in terms of amounts and timing," Mr Winzer said.

About £10bn of BT's debt was built from the bidding for licences in Britain and Germany alone. The companies holding licences now face the cost of building the new networks. France Telecom and KPN , the Dutch operator have fallen to Aa3 and Baa2 rankings - BT is not alone in facing huge problems.

BT has promised to reduce its debt by a third by the end of the year but plans to raise cash from the partial flotations of its mobile phone division and directories business Yell are now looking unlikely. BT has a period of exclusive negotiations with a venture capital consortium including Apax Partners.

There were some comforting noises from Moody's. BT, Deutsche Telekom and Sonera of Finland have all fallen from Aa1 to A2 and are already under review for further downgrade. But the report said it saw the fall in ratings hitting a floor. "There is a limit as to how far ratings can fall given the leading positions these incumbent providers enjoy in their core markets."

By the time the incumbents fixed line businesses were dented by competition, they would be replaced by other revenues, it said.

fields.headline: Bank sees trouble brewing for Lycos
fields.trailText: 8.30am: There is trouble ahead for Lycos Europe, according to a report from a top investment bank, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
There is trouble ahead for Lycos Europe and T-Online is best positioned to brave negative market conditions, according to a report from a top investment bank.

In a comparative analysis of the leading quoted European portals and internet service providers, ABN Amro concluded all players would steer clear of funding problems except Lycos Europe, which will need to raise additional funding.

The conclusions are based on the assumption the online ad market may fail to pick up in the next few years.

ABN estimates the total Western European online advertising market in 2001 will reach no more than £680m - up from £495m last year.

Of this figure, the UK will reap just £142m.

Tiscali comes out best in ABN's forecast, due to its limited exposure to portal revenues.

The companies to be hardest hit include Terra Lycos and Freenet.

ABN expects Lycos Europe to cut its marketing budgets drastically and experience narrow short-term losses in the face of mounting funding problems.

"The future of the online advertising market has never been as uncertain as it is at present," said Andrew Moffat, author of the Into Empty Space report.

"In addition, the fallout in the dot.com sector and the reluctance of offline companies will put the viability of even the portal business model in doubt," he added.

Despite a largely negative outlook on the growth of advertising revenue growth in Europe, ABN concluded European ISPs and portals were generally undervalued.

fields.headline: Ex-minister stripped of Tory whip
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Politics
fields.trailText: Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister, was last night stripped of the Tory whip amid allegations that he is to support an independent Conservative candidate at the next election.
fields.body:
Charles Wardle, the former Home Office minister, was last night stripped of the Tory whip amid allegations that he is to support an independent Conservative candidate at the next election.

James Arbuthnot, the Conservative chief whip, moved against Mr Wardle after supporters of the retiring MP announced plans to field an independent Tory candidate in his Bexhill and Battle constituency at the election.

Mr Wardle fell out with his local association last year after he accepted a £120,000 job with Harrods.

Mr Arbuthnot last night wrote to Mr Wardle to inform him that the whip had been withdrawn after he "openly declared" his intention to support an independent Tory against the party's official candidate Greg Barker.

Mr Arbuthnot said: "This is in total conflict with Mr Wardle's continued receipt of the Conservative whip. I have therefore withdrawn the whip from him until such time as he can satisfy me that the allegation is without foundation."

The Tory leader William Hague is likely to face criticism for his action against Mr Wardle which contrasts with the mild reprimand delivered to the Yorkshire East MP John Townend after he recently lavished praise on Enoch Powell.

Mr Wardle becomes the second Conservative MP to lose the party's whip at Westminster since the last general election.

Peter Temple-Morris, the MP for Leominster, had the whip removed in October 1997 before he eventually defected to Labour.

Mr Wardle won Bexhill and Battle at the last election with a majority of 11,100. His seat is regarded as safe although an independent Tory candidate could split the Conservative vote.

fields.headline: No agreement
fields.standfirst:
But the future in Ulster need not be bleak

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Whatever other criticism can be levelled against Sinn Fein, few would accuse the party of failing to see the big picture.
fields.body:
Whatever other criticism can be levelled against Sinn Fein, few would accuse the party of failing to see the big picture. On the contrary, as our front-page account today suggests, they are congenital gazers into the future, forever shaping a long-term strategy - and a strategy for the period after that.

Some of it may sound like fantasy politics, wishful thinking and dreamy scenarios, but it is useful both as a window into the republican mindset and as an analysis of a situation which could be about to change dramatically.

Sinn Fein believes, with a breathtaking confidence, that it is now in a "countdown scenario" toward its historic goal of a united Ireland. The starting point for its optimism comes on April 29 with the first population census since 1991 - and only the second for which republicans have urged cooperation rather than boycott. They believe the new data will show Catholics at about 46% of the total Northern Irish population, a five point upward leap from the last survey. If that pattern holds, says Sinn Fein, Catholics will no longer be a beleaguered minority in the province: they will form its majority.

This puts a spring in the republican step, feeling what Sinn Fein chairman Mitchel McLaughlin calls "a sense of destiny". They need only sit it out; time and the Catholic birth rate will eventually deliver them to the promised land. Unionists may be "in denial" about the coming reality but, says Sinn Fein, republicans and nationalists know history is on their side.

Accordingly, the party envisages a "border poll" - a referendum asking Northern Ireland's people whether they wish to live in the United Kingdom or a united Ireland - the first since 1973, which yielded no meaningful result because of a nationalist boycott. Mr McLaughlin wants such a poll within the next couple of years. He knows his side will lose, but it will show their strength. Then, in the next 10 years, he wants another one. Eventually, his side will have the numbers and it will win.

To add to his breezy confidence, there is the changing face of nationalist politics. Sinn Fein might well emerge as Northern Ireland's biggest party, in terms of votes cast, at the next election. They are breathing down the neck of the Social Democratic and Labour party, casting themselves now as the energetic, authentic voice of nationalism/republicanism. The SDLP's leadership is ageing, with no large figure to compete with John Hume or Seamus Mallon.

Sinn Fein remains equally dominated by Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, but those men are younger - and their ranks are being reinforced by politicians who, unlike them, have no background in paramilitary activity. If they do not overtake the SDLP this time, they reckon they will at the next.

What blots this sunny horizon? You might think the change within unionism would alarm republicans a bit. The Ulster Unionist party could take a pasting at the election, surpassed by Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party; even within the UUP, those who support the Good Friday agreement could lose out to those who say no. David Trimble may well be ousted, leaving Sinn Fein to deal with a naysayer like Jeffrey Donaldson. Surely that would trouble Sinn Fein?

Not a bit of it. If unionism walks away from the agreement, republicans have a plan B and C. They would either demand the renegotiation of the accord - allowing pro-agreement forces, unionist and nationalist, to run the executive together in their own coalition, leaving Messrs Paisley and Donaldson in opposition - or they would push for London and Dublin to impose joint rule. That would suit Sinn Fein just fine. The British and Irish governments could well proceed with the reforms, on policing and demilitarisation, which republicans want - and, as an added bonus, unionists would be scared back to the negotiating table by the prospect of rule from Dublin.

They have it all mapped out. Unfortunately some facts get in the way. The census will indeed show an uptick for the Catholic population, but it may well reveal a peak which has passed. Demographers say that, while the Catholic presence in secondary schools is above 50%, it falls below that figure at primary level. In other words, the future will still see a narrow Protestant majority.

Add to that a dose of political reality. No British government is about to allow anything as divisive as a border poll: it is not going to happen. Calling for the renegotiation of the Good Friday agreement is all very well, too: but who are republicans going to renegotiate with? They have found it hard enough with Mr Trimble: surely they do not think they will have an easier time with Mr Donaldson. Lastly, the Sinn Fein analysis misses out the problems of their own backyard. The rejectionists of the Real IRA are winning recruits by branding Sinn Fein as sellouts. If the republicans' partners in the peace process - the UUP - walk away, that will make the rejectionist case, that the peace effort was always doomed, all the more credible.

For all that, there is a larger truth that Sinn Fein do appear to have glimpsed. While unionism shifts from its lukewarm yes to a more robust no, it ignores the emerging reality of Northern Ireland. The country is changing, heading to a point where, even if Catholics are not in the majority, the land can only be governed by both traditions working together. The old days of unionist domination are over. The choice for unionists now is not to ignore that trend or wish it were otherwise - but adapt to it, before it sweeps them away.

fields.headline: Mother of Parliaments is reduced to just a sideshow
fields.standfirst:
Devolution, the EU and globalism leave MPs tinkering at the margins

Special report: House of Commons
fields.trailText: Devolution, the EU and globalism leave MPs tinkering at the margins.
fields.body:
The first Blair parliament is over. It will meet again after Easter, but only to close itself down prior to the election of another one. There will be time enough to assess the government's record, but I'm already visited by deeper-throated thoughts that suit the confessional season. On the brink of our age-old ceremony of democratic transition, I find it hard to engage at a fitting level with the awesome political climax the election is supposed to produce. This has nothing to do with the fallacy that the result makes no difference. The result will matter greatly. My confession concerns parliament itself.

Why do I, for the first time in my life, experience tremors of heretical disbelief when I pass that great building in Westminster? Gazing up at Big Ben these past few years, I've begun to see it more as the icon of a theme park than the tower of democracy. It's a huge, magnificent sight, none more elemental in the entire democratic world, especially at night. But what goes on inside? Is that where power in Britain actually resides? How much are the sacred processes - the winding-up and then the rebirth - now symbol, and how much reality?

We know the bottom line. The very presence of these 659 MPs is a massive, immovable guarantee against dictatorship. Because they're there, certain horrors will never happen. Their existence, like the election that will produce the next batch, distinguishes countries such as Britain from great tracts of Africa and Asia, on to which the Mother of Parliaments somehow failed in the last century to graft a permanent culture of functioning democracy. We need elections to be open and uncorrupt, and must hope they engage the maximum number of citizens in voting. This is a system worth defending.

But what was once the parliament of an empire is now not the parliament of even a single nation. Perhaps 80% of the government decisions that affect Scotland are no longer made under these ancient rafters. The setting-up of the Scottish parliament means that 72 MPs at Westminster are not responsible for much of public life as it touches their constituents. Welsh devolution, though less drastic, also drains power away. Thus, two tranches of MPs, 112 in all, will return as impostors - only partially connected to the mandate of legitimacy, they need to justify the influence they hope to command. The perception of enfeeblement begins.

It homes in from other directions. Against Motorola, or Tesco, or Goldman Sachs, the tribunes of the people can do no more than flap their hands. The power of corporations, and the speed at which trillions of dollars are moved round global markets, sharply confine any big-picture agenda MPs may expect to control.

So does the encroaching writ of the European Union. A decade ago, Jacques Delors famously declared that before long 80% of the social and economic laws affecting Europe would be decided in Brussels. It never came to that, and now the tendency is to try to move the other way. But Europe is a mighty force for the rearrangement of sovereignty. European verities add to the feeling that the sound and fury we're about to witness is, in part, a charade. Still doing one's best to be impressed by the neo-Gothic palace beside the Thames, all one remembers, unfortunately, is the idleness and lack of tenacity with which Westminster handles its existing right to invigilate what Brussels commands.

Parliament remains, of course, sovereign. It has the power to overturn devolution, cancel the Treaty of Rome, and pass statutes containing solemn words that purport to undo the laws of global economics. It could re-declare itself the potent centre of what it means to be British: a private member, eaten by Euro-scepticism, is doubtless at work on a text. The more telling point is that most of the disablement has been at the hands of parliament itself. MPs willingly passed the laws - on Scotland, on Europe - that decimated their own importance. They responded, for very good reason, to imperatives that sent some power down to regions and some up to Europe. They now have to live with the consequences, beside which Big Ben and the Palace of Westminster look more like a protective facade than a fortress of democracy.

Many MPs make the best of this. Invited by the Guardian to name what they were proudest of doing in the past four years, a lot of them had answers you could admire. An amendment here, a campaign there, a cause taken up, a constituent rescued from NHS injustice. The accumulation of selfless labour in the Commons rebuts the pervasive and quite false impression of a chamber with its collective hand in other people's pockets, sometimes corrupt, always on the make.

But the sources of pride were mostly small beer. Politician as welfare officer, road mender, modest public servant. The members of this place watch the wider world from sidelines more distant than their Victorian forbears could ever have imagined. The theatre to which we will shortly return them is unobserved, to a degree unthinkable 30 years ago.

If there is another Labour landslide, it's hard to imagine backbenchers will be listened to any more by the second Blair government than the first. For the bigger the victory, the less important the MPs. It's one of the paradoxes that corrode our parliament, with its voting system and its deadening discipline: the more emphatic the democratic verdict, the less relevant the individual democrat.

Some of this will change if the next result is narrower. Part of the reason parliament seems otiose is because it is utterly dominated by the government controller. A prime minister who had to worry every week about the 10pm votes might find unwelcome political life breathed back into the theme park.

But not much. The truth is that higher powers have thrust national parliamentarians to the margins. Minor politicians can tinker with small things but not many big ones. A year when the issue that most burned MPs was fox-hunting tells the story. The big stuff is decided by a tiny cabal across the road, in the light of agreements and forces and networks and markets over which this multinational state now has startlingly little control, and never will have again, even if parliament were to exercise its sovereign power to take Britain out of the European Union.

This is no reason not to vote. Pieces of the local agenda are still important. Which side has its hands on executive power will affect the way public money is spent, and determine the British tone of voice. The way in which we fight, or reconcile with, the forces greater than we are could be much affected. But the public, in their apparent distancing from Westminster, may be more realistic than their politicians. Inside the imperial structures of the body politic beats the weakest parliament since universal suffrage.

webTitle: Crucial poll for Ulster peace process

fields.headline: Crucial poll for Ulster peace process
fields.standfirst:
Unionists Shift in mood may wreck Trimble's party

Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Northern Ireland assembly HREF="http://politics.guardian.co.uk/northernirelandassembly/0,9054,441059,00.html">Special report: Northern Ireland assembly
fields.trailText: David Trimble has read his political obituary so often, perhaps he will calmly wave aside the latest gloomy forecasts of his downfall. But it will take courage. For the warning signs are unprecedentedly stark: a growing consensus in Northern Ireland suggests the general election could spell ruin for his party - and for his leadership.
fields.body:
David Trimble has read his political obituary so often, perhaps he will calmly wave aside the latest gloomy forecasts of his downfall. But it will take courage. For the warning signs are unprecedentedly stark: a growing consensus in Northern Ireland suggests the general election could spell ruin for his party - and for his leadership.

On current trends, Mr Trimble's Ulster Unionist party could be heading for electoral meltdown, reduced to just three or four parliamentary seats, with Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, staunch opponents of the Good Friday agreement, emerging as the province's strongest force in Westminster.

The UUP leader even has a battle on his hands in his own constituency of Upper Bann, which includes the flashpoint of Drumcree. Orangemen there are said to be planning to "send a message" to Mr Trimble by slashing his majority.

As the graphic, right, illustrates, the DUP are threatening their UUP rivals across the province - with particularly strong challenges in North Belfast, East Derry and Strangford. Polling experts say that if the trend holds for Mr Paisley, his party or its allies could even pick up Fermanagh and South Tyrone, doubling their representation in the Commons. The UUP would be reduced to an all-time low.

"Clearly there's a possibility of a very bad result," conceded one senior Trimble aide last night, adding that high-ranking Unionists are even debating whether the leader could continue to serve as Northern Ireland's first minister if he was ousted from the UUP command. Mr Trimble's advisers say he would regard staying on as "tacky" and that "he would resign very quickly".

The roots of the alarm are in last September's South Antrim byelection. That once-safe Ulster Unionist seat was won by the DUP's William McCrea following a militantly anti-agreement campaign. But what polling experts expect the gen eral election to prove is that, even within Ulster Unionism, the momentum has moved away from pro-agreement forces who back Mr Trimble - towards the No camp, led by the Lagan Valley MP Jeffrey Donaldson.

On the most pessimistic prognosis for Mr Trimble, he could return to Westminster as the sole pro-agreement member of his parliamentary party. With moderates like Ken Maginnis - dubbed Dublin Ken for his willingness to engage with the Irish republic - and the perennial waverer, John Taylor, stepping down, the Trimbleite voice within "the Unionist family" is set to be drowned out either by the DUP or by No men within the UUP's own ranks.

Polling suggests the safest UUP seats are held by opponents of the agreement. Two more local UUP parties have defied Mr Trimble by naming anti-agreement candidates to fight winnable Unionist seats: Peter Weir in North Down and PR consultant David Burnside, picked to fight South Antrim once more. These are the men who could form the faction Mr Trimble is meant to lead - a situation that all sides agree would be unsustainable. The logical result would be a split, with Yes and No camps forming separate parties. Trimbleites estimate two thirds of UUP members are Yes voters, but they doubt many would have the stomach for a civil war. The Donaldson faction, they say, is more committed.

The clearest evidence of the trend within Unionism from Yes to No has surfaced at the Stormont assembly. Two members of Mr Trimble's UUP group there - Mr Weir and Pauline Armitage - have effectively switched sides, voting with Mr Paisley's No bloc.

Many Unionists argue that their side has given up much, ceding the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, emptying the jails and seeing republicans in government. They accuse Mr Trimble of naivety, giving up much in return for mere promises.

For its part, Sinn Fein attributes the shift from Yes to No to a Unionist refusal to accept the changed reality of Northern Ireland, including the fact that the two traditions could soon be equal in numerical strength. As one high-ranking republican puts it, "Unionists are in denial."

webTitle: Sliding SDLP in bitter fight to stay ahead of Sinn Fein

fields.headline: Sliding SDLP in bitter fight to stay ahead of Sinn Fein
fields.standfirst:
Nationalists Hume overhauls party in bid to keep Adams at bay

Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Northern Ireland assembly
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein and the Social Democratic and Labour Party are squaring up for a bitter election fight after talks over a nationalist pact recently collapsed.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein and the Social Democratic and Labour Party are squaring up for a bitter election fight after talks over a nationalist pact recently collapsed.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, is hoping that his party will finally overtake John Hume's SDLP as the largest nationalist party in the election. This is a highly ambitious target and most psephologists believe that Sinn Fein will probably see its share of vote increase, putting the party in a strong position to overtake the SDLP at the election after this.

Mr Adams has overseen a dramatic increase in his party's share of the vote from a low of 9.1% in the 1989 European parliament elections. At the last general election Sinn Fein secured 16.1% of the vote - up by six points on the 1992 election. This rose to 17.6% in the elections to the new Northern Ireland assembly in 1998.

By contrast, the SDLP vote has been slipping. In the 1997 general election, it secured 24.1% of the vote, which dropped to 22% in the assembly election, although the party topped the poll after a poor performance by the Ul ster Unionists. Alarmed by the fall in its vote, the SDLP has radically overhauled the party in the past year. Former BBC journalist Barry Turley has been brought in to to head a large press operation, while the indefatigable West Belfast assembly member Alex Attwood has been elected party chairman. They will face an equally impressive Sinn Fein election operation directed by Mitchel McLaughlin, the party's chairman.

The battle between the two parties will focus on two key issues - whether nationalists should sign up to the new Northern Ireland police service and how best to represent nationalist interests in the peace process.

Mr McLaughlin highlighted speculation that the SDLP will accept the new police force after the election. "It could be their terminal mistake," he said.

The SDLP is equally withering about Sinn Fein and has devised a slogan which will infuriate republicans. "We work for more than ourselves alone," the party's candidates will say, in a pointed reference to the English translation of Sinn Fein - Ourselves Alone.

One SDLP source said: "We will be making clear that there is a lot of work to be done in the peace process. The Provos have prevaricated and there is a general feeling that we should get a move on."

Behind the increasingly bitter war of words, strategists in both parties believe they will hold on to the seats they won at the last general election. Mr Adams will sweep home in West Belfast, while Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, will have little difficulty in Mid Ulster.
