fields.headline: Collapse of Ulster deal feared
fields.standfirst:
Sinn Fein seeks to combat anti-agreement unionists

Special report: Northern Ireland assembly
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein yesterday called for the renegotiation of the Good Friday agreement to save the Northern Ireland peace process from a post-election challenge by hardline unionists.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt, Owen Bowcott and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Sinn Fein yesterday called for the renegotiation of the Good Friday agreement to save the Northern Ireland peace process from a post-election challenge by hardline unionists.

Amid growing fears that the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble will be severely weakened by hardliners in the election, the Sinn Fein chairman Mitchel McLaughlin said the Good Friday agreement must be "reconfigured" to ensure its survival.

Speaking on the eve of the third anniversary of the signing of the agreement, Mr McLaughlin outlined a two-point plan to ensure anti-agreement unionists cannot wreck the peace process if they outnumber Mr Trimble's supporters after polling day. He called for:

 "Re-evaluation of the basic architecture of the Good Friday agreement" to ensure that anti-agreement unionists could not block votes in the Northern Ireland assembly;

 Acceleration of the process of demilitarisation and reform of Northern Ireland's criminal justice system "to ensure that the clock cannot be turned back".

Mr McLaughlin told the Guardian: "The balance within unionism could shift to the anti-agreement side after the election which means a re-evaluation of the basic architecture of the agreement... The basic arrangements [of the agreement] may not be enough to complete the journey."

His remarks came amid increasing anxiety that the beleaguered pro-agreement unionists could suffer a devastating election result at the hands of anti-agreement forces in Mr Trimble's party and from hardliners in Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party.

Nationalists, on the other hand, are expected to gain at least one seat off the unionists, while a further two seats are up for grabs. Mr McLaughlin said the optimism among nationalists would place Northern Ireland's constitutional future at the centre of the political debate, not least because the forthcoming census is likely to show a rise in the Catholic population.

"There is inescapable evidence that there has been a change," Mr McLaughlin yesterday said, reflecting nationalist hopes that they will form a majority of the population in 10 years.

"This will concretise the view that for nationalists and republicans this is the end phase. There is a majority emerging."

Mr McLaughlin added that, in the light of the population shift, the government should hold a referendum on whether Northern Ireland should join forces with the Irish republic to form a united Ireland. "The countdown scenario is emerging," Mr McLaughlin said.

Sinn Fein knows that it could not win a referendum in the medium term because the party believes the census will show, at best, that the Catholic population has risen to 46% from 41% in 1991. However, the party hopes that holding a referendum would, in the long term, create a momentum towards Irish unity while, in the short term, putting pressure on unionists to cut a deal with nationalists.

Sinn Fein hopes that it will be in a stronger position to argue for a border poll after the election if it overtakes the Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) as the largest nationalist party in the province.

In a sign of the bitter election contest between the two nationalist parties, the SDLP last night dismissed Sinn Fein's call for a border poll and the renegotiation of the Good Friday agreement.

A spokesman said: "Sinn Fein's call for a border poll shows that they do not accept the existence of the other side. It is ridiculous to talk about renegotiating the Good Friday agreement - we have come leaps and bounds in recent years because we have worked on the basis of consensus."

The SDLP view will be shared by the British government which would regard a border poll as divisive.

Ministers are concentrating on reviving the peace process after the election through a three-point plan which would see republicans making a gesture on arms in exchange for the army removing watchtowers in border areas. Nationalists would also sign up to the new police service.

webTitle: Protestant majority predicted to fall sharply

fields.headline: Protestant majority predicted to fall sharply
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Northern Ireland assembly
fields.trailText: The Protestant majority in Northern Ireland is expected to show a sharp decline when results from this month's census are published. Catholics may already account for more than 46% of the population.
fields.body:
The Protestant majority in Northern Ireland is expected to show a sharp decline when results from this month's census are published. Catholics may already account for more than 46% of the population.

But two factors have left in the balance the crucial question of whether nationalists will overtake unionists: rapid decline in the Catholic birth-rate and the unprecedented impact of immigration.

The arrival of the census once every 10 years always raises sectarian temperatures. In 1971, republicans burnt forms in protest at unionist gerrymandering of the Stormont government. Ten years later the IRA shot dead a census taker in Derry; she was deemed to be an official of the occupying British state. By 1991, Sinn Fein's position had been reversed. Chasing an electoral mandate, republicans became eager to register the rapid growth in numbers of predominantly nationalist-voting Catholics.

Final calculations of the relative size of the Catholic and Protestant populations, however, are complicated by the fact that many respondents decline to state any religious affiliation. By common assumption, the 1991 census suggested Northern Ireland was around 42% Catholic and 58% Protestant. Nearly 300,000 people - 18% of the population - that year declined to state their religion.

Following the last census, some statisticians suggested Catholics could constitute a majority in Northern Ireland by 2025. Sinn Fein has implied the changeover might arrive as early as the census after next, in 2011.

Ian Shuttleworth, a geography lecturer at Queen's University, Belfast, yesterday accepted that projecting forward past trends indicates this year's census on April 29 would result in a narrowing Catholic minority of between 46 to 48%. But immigration into Northern Ireland - the province's population has grown since 1991 by 100,000 to 1.67m - has cast doubt on the reliability of previous trends.

No one knows if the influx is made up predominantly of returning Catholics or Protestants. "The traditionally high Catholic birthrate is also falling faster than the Protestant one," Dr Shuttleworth said.

fields.headline: Prospects for the parties
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Northern Ireland assembly
fields.trailText: Seats that could change hands
fields.body:
Seats that could change hands

West Tyrone (N)

Willie Thompson, the anti-agreement Ulster Unionist MP, is likely to lose to nationalists. Brid Rodgers, SDLP candidate and Northern Ireland agriculture minister, is thought to be ahead of Pat Doherty, Sinn Fein vice-president

North Belfast (U)

Cecil Walker, the pro-agreement UUP MP, is vulnerable to a challenge from Nigel Dodds of the Democratic Unionists and Alban Maginness of the SDLP.

East Derry (U)

Willie Ross, the anti agreement UUP MP, could be vulnerable to a challenge from Gregory Campbell, a DUP minister in the Northern Ireland executive. The DUP, which came second in 1997, topped the poll in the seat's assembly election.

Fermanagh and South Tyrone (U)

This seat, won by hunger striker Bobby Sands in a 1981 byelection, is a four way contest. James Cooper, the pro-agreement UUP candidate, who is replacing retiring MP Ken Maginnis, will be vulnerable to a challenge from the DUP or independent anti-agreement unionist Jim Dixon. Split unionist vote could help Sinn Fein, whose two candidates won the highest number of votes in the assembly elections, or the SDLP, whose sole candidate came top.

Strangford (U)

Iris Robinson, wife of DUP deputy leader Peter Robinson, is a frontrunner for this seat, currently held by retiring UUP deputy leader John Taylor. But David McNarry, the pro agreement UUP candidate, could benefit from a split anti-agreement unionist vote, because Cedric Wilson, an anti-agreement fringe unionist, is standing.

Other battlegrounds

Upper Bann (U)

David Trimble, the UUP leader, faces challenges on a series of fronts. Anti-agreement members of his local party are hoping to deselect him, although this is likely to fail. The DUP hopes that Orangemen angry at restrictions imposed on the local Drumcree parade will flock to their candidate. But the DUP was a long way behind Mr Trimble in the 1997 election and the assembly election.

South Antrim (U)

A battle between the two anti-agreement unionists who contested the seat in last year's byelection.The DUP's William McCrea, who captured the seat from the UUP, is hoping to see off another challenge from the UUP's David Burnside.

Other seats

South Belfast (U)

Martin Smyth, anti-agreement UUP MP, should hold seat.

East Belfast (U)

Peter Robinson, DUP deputy leader, certain to hold staunchly unionist seat.

West Belfast (N)

Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, will retain seat.

Newry and Armagh (N)

Seamus Mallon, SDLP deputy leader, should hold seat.

Mid Ulster (N)

Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein education minister, will have little difficulty in holding seat.

Lagan Valley (U)

Jeffrey Donaldson, leader of anti-agreement UUP faction, likely to retain seat.

Foyle (N)

John Hume, SDLP leader, will hold seat. But it may be his last election contest.

South Down (N)

SDLP's Eddie McGrady will hold seat.

North Down (U)

Independent anti-agreement unionist Bob McCartney should hold seat, helped by divisions within UUP camp.

East Antrim (U)

Anti-agreement UUP Roy Beggs will hold seat.

North Antrim (U)

DUP leader Ian Paisley will hold seat. It may be last poll outing for Mr Paisley, 75 this month.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • And so to inaugural Manuscript of the Month, Maverick: A Mind of My Own by Teresa Gorman. How and why some 40 A4 pages of this literary feast reached the Diary is obscure, but since you wouldn't bet heavily on them ever appearing in anything that might technically be described as "a book", our job is not to speculate but to publicise.
fields.body:
 And so to inaugural Manuscript of the Month, Maverick: A Mind of My Own by Teresa Gorman. How and why some 40 A4 pages of this literary feast reached the Diary is obscure, but since you wouldn't bet heavily on them ever appearing in anything that might technically be described as "a book", our job is not to speculate but to publicise.

Teresa begins by revealing that her political crusade was not, after all, a pitiful stab at some version of fame; but a holy crusade against "the rules and regulations which the government was dumping on small businesses" in the late 1960s. Teresa had just set up one of her own when "Harold Wilson devalued the pound and had the temerity to tell us the pound in our pockets would not change in value."

Thus far, 14 lines in to her book, she still hasn't mentioned it, but the honeymoon is soon to end. "The government talked about deregulation but followed the path now dictated by Europe with all the bureaucracy that went with it ...." Yes, she's off. Next time, Teresa charms an Irish family's votes with her uncanny gift for accents.

 The fight against farmers illegally moving livestock is joined by an important new voice. "When there is a financial incentive, there's always a risk of somebody being unscrupulous," says the trading standards person in charge of Foot & Mouth at Maff sagely. I don't know if we will ever find out who appointed Nick Cull, but hats aloft to you whoever you are.

 Black armbands out for my mockney friend Janet Street-Porter, ferociously hands-on Independent on Sunday editor no longer. It is not our way to kick someone when they are down, so Janet will be getting the usual call offering her Diary shifts shortly. As for her replacement, one name mentioned is Chris Blackhurst who performed the role of Rizla Rosie Boycott's poodle with such distinction at the Express.

After we ran the item about the fish fingers buried beneath Rosie's bath, Chris would often ring on her behalf, yappingly demanding that we betray our source, and as a cheap and obedient substitute for a proper IoS editor he would do splendidly. We wish him well.

 An email arrives from Geoff Baker. Yesterday we learnt how Paul McCartney's press man reacted to remarks about his boss's comparison between killing cattle and "what Hitler did to the f****** Jews", sending a letter which climaxed: "I think you should apologise. You f****** twat." The former Daily Star man remembered for the exclusive revelation that Princess Margaret was to join the cast of Crossroads also appeared to lecture on accurate journalism. But that's all water under the bridge after Geoff's latest missive. "Touche," he writes. "Not lecturing, only caring. Apologies for being rude." Thank you, Geoff. All we need now is Paul's apology for Wings, Ebony and Ivory and all the other post- Beatles nonsense and we can draw a line under this whole sorry business.

 An insolent press release arrives from Gavin Lewis at Frank PR. "Slendertone Flex gets behind this year's London Marathon by launching a Rear of the Race Award," it chirps. How droll. "Instead of marvelling at the running skills of the 45,000 runners, Slendertone is encouraging spectators to focus their attentions on the runners' bums!" Tremendous.

And yet this is not the altruistic endeavour it seems, but a canny attempt to launch "the new Slendertone Flex Bottom and Thigh Toning Product". How cruel. I can't believe that Gavin is unaware of my own capacious arse. The question is whether Lord Michael Henderson of the Telegraph put him up to it.  In Canterbury, New Zealand, Stuart McPherson has been arrested at his home. The burglar's one error, say police, was ringing victims on his traceable phone to complain that the items he'd nicked from them were "rubbish".

webTitle: Surprise  ' There is plenty of work here'

fields.headline: Surprise  ' There is plenty of work here'
fields.trailText: Bemused workers poured out of the gates of Cammell Laird to the sound of the lunchtime hooter yesterday as rumours swirled that the company's financial problems had finally sunk the business.
fields.body:
Bemused workers poured out of the gates of Cammell Laird to the sound of the lunchtime hooter yesterday as rumours swirled that the company's financial problems had finally sunk the business.

Birkenhead's Steve "Snowy" Suckley has been a crane driver at the 177-year-old yard,which built the Ark Royal, for 24 years. "My father worked here. Our sons, our grandsons work here," he said. "We're all puzzled because there's plenty of work. I'm doing loads of overtime."

Cammell Laird has six ships in the yard at present, including the Argos, a navy auxiliary vessel being repaired and updated.

In recent months Mr Suckley has been working a 66-hour week and he will be in the yard over Easter. "Our main concern is to get the Argos completed on time," he said.

"Since concentrating on ship repairs six months ago, the yard has gone from strength to strength. It has provided men with jobs."

Like many workers, he invested his savings in the business because of the new confidence created by the stream of repair orders coming in. But they were unaware of the company's true financial position. "The majority of us have shares," he said. "I bought 4,000 at £1 each. Employees learnt of the possibility of liquidation when they listened to a news bulletin yesterday morning.

"It's taken everyone by surprise because we've been working flat out," he said. "It would be a tragedy if it goes now after the turnaround in the past five years."

Mr Suckley said that things had changed significantly since the 1980s when workers would stand around waiting for someone to tell them what to do.

"Now we can get on with it," he said. "There's a lot more flexibility, more demarcation."

But the debacle over the Costa Crociere contract took a lot out of the workforce. "It took a while for the lads to get back to work after the Italian order fell through," he said.

Employees at the yard would prefer to do more MoD orders because the work is guaranteed by the government.

Mr Suckley said he felt betrayed by the government. "Someone high up wants to see this yard closed."

webTitle: 45 die in stampede at football match

fields.headline: 45 die in stampede at football match
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Football
fields.trailText: About 45 football fans were killed - some of them children - in a stampede for seats at a packed game between the Orlando Pirates and Kaizer Chiefs in Johannesburg last night. Police are believed to have provoked the disaster by firing teargas into the crowd.
fields.body:
About 45 people were killed - some of them children - in a stampede for seats at a packed South African football match last night. Some fans alleged that police provoked what is believed to be the worst stadium disaster in South African history by firing teargas to disperse an angry crowd with tickets who were being refused entry.

Live television coverage of the match showed the pitch littered with the dead and injured. Some people were crushed against barbed wire. Others were trampled underfoot in what one fan described as an "animal stampede".

The victims were crushed trying to gain entry to a league match between two of South Africa's most popular teams, Orlando Pirates and Kaizer Chiefs.

Nearly 200 other people were being treated for injuries, including dozens who were seriously hurt. Johannesburg emergency services spokesperson, Paddy Mallett, said ambulances were called from across the city to deal with the disaster and paramedics were working to save the lives of at least 10 people.

The chaos began outside the Ellis Park stadium as fans tried to force their way through gates to the stands about 20 minutes into the game. Officials from both clubs went outside to appeal for calm.

Some fans allege that the police then fired teargas. Others say the fans had already dispersed after police intervention but regrouped and charged the turnstiles.

Louis Shipalana, 42, a security guard at the stadium: "The stadium was full. There was no place to stand. The people were pushing toward the fence and the fence collapsed and the people in the back stepped on those in front."

"I was in my seat and the next thing we knew, people were on top of us and we were flung out of our seats," Harrieth Dlamini told the South African press association. "I have no feeling in my legs."

Television commentators had said before the disaster that too many tickets had been sold for the match.

President Thabo Mbeki, who was watching the game on television, said an inquiry would be launched into the disaster.

The game was only called off as fans began to spill on to the pitch after 35 minutes. The large television screen in the stadium displayed the telephone numbers for the mortuary and the hospital.

The sports minister, Ng conde Balfour, said: "We're stunned, we're shocked and we're sending our condolences to those families. Whatever will need to be done, we will do."

The managing director of Kaizer Chiefs, Kaizer Mo taung, told the spectators to understand why it could not continue.

"We have a moral obligation not to continue with the game and to show respect to the bereaved and reschedule the game for another day."

webTitle: Yahoo! to cut 12% of its workforce

fields.headline: Yahoo! to cut 12% of its workforce
fields.trailText: First-quarter earnings for Yahoo! beat Wall Street's dramatically reduced expectations, but the struggling internet portal is still cutting 12% of its workforce.
fields.body:
First-quarter earnings for Yahoo! beat Wall Street's dramatically reduced expectations, but the struggling internet portal is still cutting 12% of its workforce.

Yahoo! is streamlining its business to focus on "essential services," centralising operations and cutting back on marketing, chief executive and chairman Tim Koogle said yesterday - that means cutting its workforce of 3,510 employees by about 420 people.

With advertising revenue drying up, Yahoo! posted its second straight net loss - $11.5m (£7.8m) in the first quarter, or 2 cents a share, compared with a profit of $67.6m, or 11 cents per share, in the comparable period of 2000.

Excluding one-time charges, Yahoo! earned $7.6m in the three-month period ending March 31, or 1 cent per share, beating the break-even results analysts had expected, according to a survey by Thomson Financial/First Call. That figure was lowered last month from 5 cents per share.

Revenue was $180m, a 22% drop from $230.8m in the first quarter of last year.

Shares in Yahoo! fell 16 cents, or 1%, to $5.86 yesterday on the Nasdaq stock market before the earnings announcement. In after-hours trading, Yahoo! shares were up to $16.65.

The company also warned that it would "approximately break-even" in the second quarter. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had been expecting 1 cent per share. - Reuter

webTitle: Napster told to speed up its efforts

fields.headline: Napster told to speed up its efforts
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: A warning shot was fired across Napster's bows yesterday by the federal judge in charge of the online song-swapping service's fate. By David Teather.
fields.body:
A warning shot was fired across Napster's bows yesterday by the federal judge in charge of the online song-swapping service's fate.

US district judge Marilyn Hall Patel warned Napster it could still face closure if the website does not speed up its efforts to remove copyrighted songs from the service. She said it was "disgraceful" that copyrighted material could still be downloaded and told Napster: "You created this monster, you fix it."

Napster lawyers, Jonathan Schiller, pictured left with Robert Silver, argued that the firm has spent millions in the past five weeks filtering such copyrighted songs off the network.

A court-appointed expert will review claims from the music industry that songs can still be accessed.

Berteslmann, the German media group which owns the BMG music business, said talks with others in the industry aimed at hatching a peace deal with Napster were "progressing well".

webTitle: Amazon snaps up US rival's internet business

fields.headline: Amazon snaps up US rival's internet business
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Amazon.com agreed yesterday to take over the internet operations of Borders, the second-largest bookseller in the US.
fields.body:
Amazon.com has managed to take out one of its leading American competitors, agreeing yesterday to take over the internet operations of Borders, the second-largest bookseller in the US.

Some 70 jobs will be lost at Borders.com, which is being revamped and relaunched in August as a co-branded site. Amazon will run the site, which will feature Amazon merchandise, while Borders will promote both Amazon and the new internet offering through in its own bookshops.

No financial details on the agreement were released, but the news was enough to spark a fresh rally in Amazon's badly damaged share price. Neither was there any information on how the firms might deal with the problem of customers overlapping on the internet.

In March, as Borders announced that fourth-quarter profits had almost halved, the company said it would be cutting costs and seeking out new partnerships for its online operations. The agreement with Borders is similar to deal struck by Amazon with Toys R Us, the toy retailer, in the autumn covering Toysrus.com. Under that venture Toys R Us provides the products and Amazon handles fulfilment and customer service.

Amazon said the agreement with Borders demonstrated the attractions of its e-commerce platform.

fields.headline: Tiger joins the Disney world
fields.trailText: Tiger Woods is to join the payroll at Disney in a deal that will make him the highest-paid sportsman in terms of endorsements alone. by Mark Tallentire.
fields.body:
The fantasy world of Tiger Woods took another turn yesterday when it emerged that the 25-year-old Californian is to join the payroll at Walt Disney in a deal that will make him the highest-paid sportsman in terms of endorsements alone.

The value and length of the deal has yet to be disclosed but Woods earned in excess of £40m ($54m) last year from a dozen or so commercial tie-ups, $20m of it from his club manufacturer Nike.

Woods, who on Sunday won the US Masters to make it four major titles in a row and six in his four years as a professional, is expected to appear in advertisements for Disney's theme parks - two in the US, one in Paris and one in Tokyo - endorse its merchandise and work with the company's television unit.

Woods already has contracts with General Motors, Rolex and American Express among others. His earnings will now surpass the estimated $45m that the basketball star Michael Jordan made in his best year with Chicago Bulls.

Disney's choice of Woods is not altogether surprising as the clean-cut American fits with the company template of hiring people who excel at what they do, are at ease in front of the TV cameras and who live life on the straight and narrow.

Nancy Kerrigan, the ice skater famously whacked on the knee before the 1994 Winter Olympics by associates of her arch-rival Tonya Harding, signed a $2m deal with Disney soon after winning the silver medal at Lillehammer.

An appearance at a Disney parade in Florida did not go well, however, when the press picked up her aside that a pose with Mickey Mouse was "the corniest thing I've ever done".

fields.headline: Profits at a premium
fields.standfirst:
SMS is the next big thing, but the early birds will benefit most says Amy Vickers
More net news
fields.trailText: SMS is the next big thing, but the early birds will benefit most says Amy Vickers
fields.body:
There is so much going on in the burgeoning text message industry. Almost every day, you can open a newspaper and find reams of copy about the phenomenon that has caught the mood of the nation. The Guardian is adding to the mood by staging a poetry text message competition, and Bridget Jones's diary will, from tomorrow, be available by text message.

Once you've started texting, it's difficult to stop. It becomes addictive. I was contacted by a BBC producer last week to ask if I would appear in a documentary about text message addiction, which I graciously bowed out of, but not before I had put her in touch with a couple of real text message addicts I knew.

These addicts, who incidentally are in no way afraid to admit to this affliction, liked text messaging so much that they set up their own text message companies. One is running a pioneering business called Scan (scan.com), an SMS shopping service, and the other is launching SMS chatroom services in Britain for Bolt (bolt.co.uk), the US mobile portal.

Scan has already won an award for best mobile service in the UK and is selling thousands of CDs, videos and books to customers on the move. To buy, the consumer simply sends in a message with the product details and the rest is as simple as making toast. I'm a fan, but I worry about the longevity of the service given that it has been incubated by the troubled Idealab.

As SMS, as a medium, comes into its own this year, one thing the marketing people should bear in mind is that it is not just confined to Generation Text (teens to early twenties). Those of us that don't quite fit the demographic are also doing it, and doing it a lot. During my text message education, one of my most revealing teachers was someone not far off 40.

Those of you yet to get excited about text messaging should take a look at the new premium rate SMS models about to hit the market.

To say that it's an opportunity ripe for exploitation is an understatement. Premium SMS will make a fortune for mobile operators, and even a tidy penny for the new wave of text messaging businesses coming out of the internet deadwood. Just like premium rate phone calls, new pricing models are being developed to pull in the types of revenue an internet start-up would die for.

Those already part of the fledgling industry can pat themselves on the back for having first-mover advantage. But no doubt the bandwagon will roll and soon everyone and his grandmother will be trying to sell their wares through SMS. That will be the turning point. Like the internet it will get scary: the Direct Marketing Association will start slapping wrists and tabloids will start running scare-mongering stories about paedophiles lurking in every text message.

With SMS prices varying from 5-12p apiece, it is premium SMS - timely and value-added messages that people will pay anything up to £2 for - that will sustain the market. Vodafone has already introduced these services, and other operators are expected to follow suit within months, although the jury is still out on whether this will take off until broadband mobile kicks in.

Nevertheless, the potential for the premium SMS market is huge. Danish research firm Strand Consult reckons the UK alone will reap benefits of £265m in just the first proper year of premium SMS. Marketers savvy enough to negotiate revenue-sharing deals will be left with smug grins.

Further down the line is enhanced text messaging (EMS), enabling attachments such as pictures, video and audio to come into play. Already the phone manufacturers are developing models and software to do EMS, and the content people are getting excited about ways in which they can distribute clips virally, while getting end users to pay 50p a pop to receive them. Not even the limited inbox space will make a difference to this, as the next set of phones to hit the market will all have extended inbox capacity.

Forgive me if this piece in some way contributes towards the hype, but at least you can say you are slightly prepared for the onslaught that's going to hit your phone in the next year.

Text poem competiton

There is still time to enter our pioneering interactive text message poetry competition - which ends tomorrow. Simply text us a poem - up to 160 characters long - from your mobile to 07753 828610.

What next Our specialist team will start sifting the poems immediately to winnow the thousands we have received down to 100 to present to our expert panel.

April 19: The judges - poets U A Fanthorpe and Peter Sansom accompanied by Guardian Unlimited's books editor, Justine Jordan - will meet to winnow them down to the best seven entries.

April 22: Every entrant will be sent a text message to remind them that the interactive stage of the competition is about to begin.

April 23 to April 29: Every entrant will be sent one of the final seven entries every day. Give a mark out of 10 (numerals, please) and send it back as soon as possible. Only entrants who have replied to the first entry will be sent subsequent poems.

May 3: Results and samples from the 100 shortlisted entries will be published in Online.

Details:

www.theguardian.com/mobilepoems

webTitle: Street-Porter to step down as IoS editor

fields.headline: Street-Porter to step down as IoS editor
fields.trailText: Janet Street-Porter is to step down as editor of the Independent on Sunday after two years in the post. The paper said her departure had been planned since Christmas, but no successor was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Janet Street-Porter is to step down as editor of the Independent on Sunday after two years in the post. The paper said her departure had been planned since Christmas, but no successor was announced yesterday.

Simon Kelner, the editor in chief, praised Ms Street-Porter's "hard work" at the paper, and said she would continue as "editor at large". He denied that she had been asked to leave.

Ms Street-Porter failed to make any significant impact on the paper's sales figures, which languish at around 250,000. She was seen as an unusual choice when she took over: she had very little newspaper experience and Kelvin MacKenzie, her former boss at the ill-fated youth channel Live TV, said she "couldn't edit a bus ticket".

Yesterday, Mr MacKenzie said: "It's a great day for bus tickets."

The frontrunner to take over from Ms Street-Porter is Chris Blackhurst, who was deputy editor at the Express under Rosie Boycott until the pair left last year. Previously, he was Ms Boycott's deputy editor at The Independent where he has returned as a political investigative journalist.

During her reign at the IoS, Ms Street-Porter earned a reputation among staff for being difficult to work with. Her celebrity lifestyle also raised eyebrows.

Ms Street-Porter will contribute a weekly column and regular feature articles from home and abroad for the IoS, as well as writing for the daily paper.

Ms Street-Porter, 54, said: "I have thoroughly enjoyed my two years as editor of the Independent on Sunday and would like to thank all the staff for their support. I am looking forward to my new role with great enthusiasm."

Mr Kelner said: "I am very grateful to Janet for all her hard work as editor of the Sunday paper over the past two years. I am delighted we have been able to persuade her to continue to work with us in her new role as editor at large."

He denied Ms Street-Porter had been asked to resign. "Janet intimated to me when she took this job on that she didn't want to do it until she took her pension," he said. "Shortly after Christmas, she intimated that, come the spring, the time would be right for her to look around for something else."

He said of her critics: "She's proved them all wrong."

Ms Street-Porter set up Channel 4's influential teenage magazine Network 7 in 1986 and was the BBC's head of youth from 1988.

In 1995, she worked with Mr MacKenzie, a former editor of the Sun, to launch the cable channel Live TV.

Yesterday, Mr MacKenzie said: "It's a great day for bus tickets." The frontrunner to take over from Ms Street-Porter is Chris Blackhurst, who was deputy editor at the Express under Rosie Boycott until the pair left last year. Previously, he was Ms Boycott's deputy editor at The Independent where he has returned as a political investigative journalist. During her reign at the IoS, Ms Street-Porter earned a reputation among staff for being difficult to work with. Her celebrity lifestyle also raised eyebrows. Ms Street-Porter will contribute a weekly column and regular feature articles from home and abroad for the IoS, as well as writing for the daily paper. Ms Street-Porter, 54, said: "I have thoroughly enjoyed my two years as editor of the Independent on Sunday and would like to thank all the staff for their support. I am looking forward to my new role with great enthusiasm." Mr Kelner said: "I am very grateful to Janet for all her hard work as editor of the Sunday paper over the past two years. I am delighted we have been able to persuade her to continue to work with us in her new role as editor at large." He denied Ms Street-Porter had been asked to resign. "Janet intimated to me when she took this job on that she didn't want to do it until she took her pension," he said. "Shortly after Christmas, she intimated that, come the spring, the time would be right for her to look around for something else." He said of her critics: "She's proved them all wrong." Ms Street-Porter set up Channel 4's influential teenage magazine Network 7 in 1986 and was the BBC's head of youth from 1988. In 1995, she worked with Mr MacKenzie, a former editor of the Sun, to launch the cable channel Live TV.

fields.headline: Hasbro unleashes Shelby in time for Easter
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Parents the world over will be bracing themselves for the launch of Shelby, the toy cousin to Furby, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Parents the world over will be bracing themselves for the launch of Shelby, the toy cousin to Furby.

Furby, the furry, talking critter, kicked off the kiddie craze for electronic pets when it first appeared a couple of years ago.

Hasbro is launching Shelby, an animatronic clam with a 1,000-phrase memory, in the US this week - just in time for Easter.

In addition to Furby, Tiger Electronics, Hasbro's technology division, has been responsible for giving the world Poo-Chi the electronic dog.

Shelby has a 70% bigger vocabulary and 50% more memory than Furby.

It knows 275 words, more than 1,000 phrases and can tell knock-knock jokes.

The toy responds to light, sound and touch and the more it is played with, the more it develops.

Shelby has moving eyes, antennae and shell and speaks English, "Furbish" and its own language.

More than 40m Furbys have been sold worldwide and more than 10m Poo-Chis were bought last year.

The toy will retail for around £18 in the US but, in the UK, most electronic pets cost between £25.99 and £39.99.

webTitle: China spy plane drama: The hostile panda

fields.headline: The hostile panda
fields.standfirst:
The spy plane drama shows China wants to be a superpower. It should be stopped

Special report: China
fields.trailText: No one used the words "hostage crisis" about China's 11-day detention of the US spy plane crew, but in blunt terms the deal they wanted was the crew's return in exchange for an apology.
fields.body:
No one used the words "hostage crisis" about China's 11-day detention of the US spy plane crew, but in blunt terms the deal they wanted was the crew's return in exchange for an apology.

China's insistence on an apology is revealing both of its attitude to the outside world and its inner tensions and aims. In particular, its extreme touchiness to perceived slights from the west is evidence of a disturbing fact: that although China desperately needs western trade, technology, and capital, the dominant section of its leadership is profoundly hostile to the west, and resents being dependent on it.

Under government influence, China's media described the spy plane's flight as an "invasion," and linked it directly to the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999. The two incidents are cited as evidence of western, and specifically American, hostility. Chinese public xenophobia is thereby roused, serving the regime's propaganda aims of reducing western attractiveness to young Chinese, and propping itself up by directing attention towards a supposed outside enemy. An apology from America over the spy plane incident was seen as a essential for propaganda purposes; which is why Chinese news media began selectively translating American regrets over the loss of China's fighter aircraft as if they were the apology demanded, thus preparing the Chinese public for announcement of the crew's release.

The use of anti-western propaganda has been standard practice by the communist leadership in China since its victory in 1949. During the years I lived in Beijing and subsequently worked as a China human rights activist, I saw many instances of the regime's divided attitude to things western, but could not fail to recognise its underlying tenor as hostile. In analysing China's attitude to the spy plane incident, one premise has to be that China does not see the west in terms of present or potential partners and friends, but as a rival and a threat.

One obvious reason for China's insistence on an apology was to gain time for its intelligence services to examine the spy plane's equipment, and to eavesdrop on the crew. But the foreign relations game masked a perennial battle within China's ruling Communist party between modernisers and the old guard. The latter are the last phalanx of leaders directly connected to the party's early revolutionary struggles, most notably the Long March of 1934-5 which saved them from defeat. They remain dominant, and have their followers among the younger generation of leaders. These latter accept the necessity of western trade and technological tutelage, but regard it as supping with the devil; their prickliness over the spy plane incident is a measure of the length of chopsticks they accordingly use.

These attitudes are not products of Communist party ideology but a longstanding feature of Chinese relations with the outside world. In this respect China's contemporary leaders are no different from Empress Ci Xi a century ago, who supported the Boxer Rebellion aimed at expelling all foreigners from Chinese soil. Modernisers in her time were regarded as traitors and that attitude persists, which is the fatal weakness in the position of such leaders as Jiang Zemin, who recognise that without engagement with the west, China will fall behind in world terms.

This fear is the key to a further aspect of Chinese attitudes. The Chinese nourish enormous historical resentment towards the west as a result of foreign domination in the 19th century. China had then long been weak because its institutions and army were antiquated and its economy too reliant on subsistence agriculture. It fell easy prey to the commercial exploitation, missionary arrogance and territorial depredations inflicted on it by foreign powers. Feeble attempts at resistance were heavily punished, as when British and French troops famously destroyed the emperor's summer palace outside Beijing in reprisal for infringement of foreign rights on Chinese soil.

These historical insults are galling because China always had, and has still, a "master-race" syndrome. It has always regarded itself as superior to the rest of the world, an attitude fostered by its justly held pride in once being, in Tang times (6th to 10th century AD), the world's most advanced country. Chinese attitudes remain racist and supremacist, to a degree startling to foreigners when they first encounter Chinese hostility to black people, and learn of their belief that the "minority peoples" who live as colonised populations within China's current borders are less evolutionarily advanced than the Han Chinese.

A persistent theme in China since 1949 has been the impulse to growth in military power and territorial expansion, under the guise of "reclaiming" past possessions, and the realisation of its superpower aspirations. China's huge but once useless army suffered humiliating defeats in Vietnam; now that its military technology and capacity has been and continues to be upgraded dramatically, it has grown in confidence - witness its newly aggressive stance towards US monitoring. The collision between one of its fighters and the US spy plane shows how aggressive its posture has become.

It is a mistake to think that, under its present regime, China can be treated as a reliably peaceful partner in trade and international relations. Western treatment of China should instead be premised on the fact that China is a potentially rogue state, which will not flinch from any means to get its way if it thinks it can succeed - especially as regards Taiwan, where the prospect of an invasion by China is a real one.

One need only look at the persistently high level of human rights violations in China, and its brutal behaviour in Tibet, to see how it is capable of acting.

The west needs to operate a policy of severe containment until China has democratic institutions. Chief among them should be trade sanctions and restrictions, withholding full membership of the international community, denying China cosmetic triumphs such as the Olympic Games, and maintaining pressure on China's widespread human-rights violations.

The US should continue to arm Taiwan and support its autonomy; and the west collectively should keep watch over China's other territorial ambitions, especially towards Mongolia and the islands of the South China sea. All China's claims about "reclaiming" its territories are a nonsense - it is a regional imperialist power, as witness its occupation of Tibet, Xinjiang, and other minority areas (the so-called "autonomous regions") which China has colonised over the centuries. These colonies will fight back one day, as is already happening in Tibet and Xinjiang, and China will not be able to contain them indefinitely. Perhaps their efforts ought to be supported by the west, since that is a good way of preoccupying China, reducing its threat to peace in the Pacific region and hastening the demise of the current regime.

That, at any rate, is the moral to be drawn from the agenda concealed behind China's anger over the spy plane incident. China longs to be a superpower, and if it becomes one it could be a menace; it is never too soon to limit such pretensions, but it can too soon become too late.

 AC Grayling is the author of two books about China, where he has lived. He teaches at Birkbeck College.

fields.headline: A life inside
fields.standfirst:
Felix almost ended it with a noose made from torn-up sheets - but he chose philosophy instead

Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: Felix almost ended it with a noose made from torn-up sheets - but he chose philosophy instead.
fields.body:
Felix the gambler lives in the cell next door to mine. As a kitchen worker (responsible for preparing the vegetarian diets - his Gypsy pie has been known to lift the morale of the whole prison) he regularly has to start work at 6am. But he is a good neighbour. We have lived alongside one another for over a year, yet I have never been disturbed by his dawn rise.

You could say he is one of the old school who knows how to conduct himself in jail. He has done a lot of time over the past three decades. But he never complains and bothers nobody. "It's my own fault I'm here," he says whenever his recategorisation or parole knock-backs crop up in conversation. "Let's face it," he is fond of saying as we sit together in Big Rinty's cell, trying to deconstruct the system over a jug of coffee, "would you take a chance on a man with a history like mine?"

But Felix is asking the wrong people. Unlike the authorities, when a prisoner looks at a fellow prisoner he does not see the history, only the man.

Felix presents a cool character, calm and steady. But it wasn't always that way. Once, during an earlier sentence, a prison psychiatrist told him that he had "the mind of the mad monkey - you want to be somewhere else, you want to be something else and you want to be somebody else". "So what's the cure?" Felix asked the psychiatrist. "There is no cure," came the reply.

It was soon after that interview, some 18 years ago, that Felix formulated his own cure. After plaiting strips torn from a sheet into a sturdy rope, he climbed on to the metal bed end and tied one end to a cross-bar on the cell window. Moments later he slipped a crudely fashioned noose over his head, drew up the slack so it was tight against his throat, and prepared to step out into space.

Twelve times that night Felix climbed on to the bed end and pulled the noose tight, until finally the crisis was over. "On the 12th time, I actually took one foot off the bed end and it was in that instant that I realised I had a choice," he told me a few months ago, when we were talking about the different ways people cope with the prospect of long years in prison. "So I made the choice to do the time. After that I felt in control, no longer helpless."

Following the experience of the 12 noose tightenings, Felix never looked back. Buddhism beckoned, along with the Open University. And so he developed his still conspicuous philosophical outlook on life, death and the universe.

Clearly the new approach did not result in the resolution of all his troubles, otherwise he would not have returned to prison. But the human psyche is complex and mysterious. Felix is not without contrition for his past actions.

Now some people think that prison is a life of leisure: no responsibilities, plenty of "mates" with whom to play pool and darts, and watch TV. Some prisoners think that way too - but not prisoners like Felix. At least not until recently.

Countless years in prison are bound to take their toll on the well-being of even the most resilient character. When Big Rinty snapped at me last month for no good reason I didn't really take it to heart. There was a bit of an atmosphere between us for a while, but when the big man tried a couple of weeks later to apologise I stopped him in his tracks. "Shhht," I said. "It doesn't matter. You're stressed. You're entitled to the odd psychotic moment." And we laughed and shook hands.

It's different for Felix. He has reached a stage where all avenues forward appear to be blocked. According to the experts there is no more room on the scale for his risk factors. Probation, psychology and the Home Office are presenting formidable barricades between him and eventual liberty. The only hope lies in yet more "offending behaviour" courses. But it's a long shot. "My file must be that deep," Felix said the other day, holding his hands out in front of him a couple of vertical feet apart. "It's all been said. I've been analysed until I'm paralysed. And anyway, what do I want to get out for? Everything I need is in here."

Me and Rinty glanced at each other. These words weren't spoken in jest. We couldn't say anything at the time - he would not have listened. But dig deep, Felix: "doing the time" was the right choice when things last got so critical. Spend longer considering your options. There has to be more to this existence than a life inside.

 Erwin James is serving a life sentence. The fee for this article will be paid to charity.

fields.headline: Long-term goals sway Chinese
fields.standfirst:
Spy plane showdown Beijing is relieved to avoid a new cold war, and America's leader has passed a test

China
George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As news of the deal to release the 24 crew of the US spy plane from their prison on Hainan island swirled around Beijing last night, a few angry voices could be heard objecting to the scaling down of China's demand for a full apology.
fields.body:
As news of the deal to release the 24 crew of the US spy plane from their prison on Hainan island swirled around Beijing last night, a few angry voices could be heard objecting to the scaling down of China's demand for a full apology.

"If 'being sorry' means the same thing as 'apologising'," one message on a popular website said, "then we had better rewrite the New China Dictionary."

But most Chinese will be relieved that a settlement has been reached. They share the conviction of their senior political leaders that China's long-term interest in developing a good relationship with the US must come first.

"I don't want a new cold war," another contributor to the People's Daily chatroom wrote. "Do we really want to provoke the US into giving new weapons to Taiwan?" asked another.

President Jiang Zemin was forced to intervene early in the crisis by making an explicit demand for an apology after President George Bush started the tit-for-tat exchange by calling for the immediate release of the crew.

But the foreign minister, Tang Jiaquan, quickly said that Beijing still "values relations with the US".

Beijing imposed a familiar pattern on the crisis by first raising the temperature and then subtly cooling it. It threatened to submit the air crew to Chinese law, hinting at a spy trial. It gave US diplomats only limited access to the crew.

The family of the crashed Chinese pilot shed tears on television, and the military brass hinted that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) was pressing for a tougher line.

By the weekend Mr Jiang - on a state tour to Latin America but still evidently in control - had secured an important gain. Mr Bush's advisers showed that they too valued relations with Beijing by saying it was not in US "longer-term interests" to retaliate.

And there was enough give in the language of American "sorrow" (especially when translated into Chinese) to gloss over the fact that it fell short of an apology.

With Mr Jiang and other senior leaders due to step down in 2002 and 2003, China experts have seen signs of political manoeuvring in Beijing. Mr Jiang's ability to dictate the succession would have suffered if he could not have delivered on the crisis.

Some experts believe that the military already posed a serious challenge to his authority and pressed for a tougher line in the past week.

Mr Jiang can now tell his critics in the Communist party and the PLA that he has forced the Bush administration to take China seriously. It will be much harder now, he can argue, for Mr Bush to play down relations with Beijing, as he had seemed to be doing.

Mr Jiang and his team have never wavered from the objective they set in the Clinton years of seeking "partnership" with the US. They say this is crucial for peace and development in the coming century, for Asia and the world.

To the Chinese political and business establishment - though less so to poor peasants and jobless workers - this includes as a high priority China's forthcoming admission to the World Trade Organisation.

In economic terms China, while still a long way behind the US, is regarded as a fast-rising competitor who within one or two decades could present a formidable challenge.

In terms of Beijing's foreign policy, this was and remains the only strategic game in town. It survived the severe jolt given by the US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade two years ago, when angry demonstrators took to the streets and hardline nationalists predicted a future war.

Public opinion this time has been more vocal, and more diverse.

"Even an apology should not have been enough," a nationalist voice protested. "We should have put the crew on trial."

But another sounded a sceptical note. "Why make them apologise? Our pilot probably made a mistake."

The spy flights are as offensive to China as they would be to the US if China ran similar missions off the Atlantic coast. But many Chinese are quite capable of being angry and realistic at the same time.

"In the end," said one calm voice, "we could not get an apology because China is weak and the US is strong."

The strength of China's hardliners has been exaggerated in recent days by western China watchers. Some suggested that the PLA had manufactured the incident and embarrassed Mr Jiang by its claim that the US plane was to blame. This mirrors isome unofficial Chinese claims that Mr Bush sent the plane "to test our resolve on home ground".

Most Chinese, including apparently the PLA, accept that what happened was an accident. Yesterday showed once again the PLA's fundamental loyalty to the revolutionary tradition that "politics remains in command of the gun".

The team Mr Jiang left in Beijing to handle the crisis was headed by another civilian, Hu Jintao, whom he is grooming to succeed him. But Mr Jiang and any successor must still reckon with public opinion, which has become sceptical of diplomatic spin and can be easily roused to anger.

China knew that in the end it would not get a full US apology. Indeed no one can remember the last time that Beijing apologised to anyone for anything. In Chinese political culture an apology indicates a total confession of guilt.

Beijing imposed a familiar pattern on the crisis by first raising the temperature and then subtly cooling it. It threatened to submit the air crew to Chinese law, hinting at a spy trial. It gave US diplomats only limited access to the crew. The family of the crashed Chinese pilot shed tears on television, and the military brass hinted that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) was pressing for a tougher line. By the weekend Mr Jiang - on a state tour to Latin America but still evidently in control - had secured an important gain. Mr Bush's advisers showed that they too valued relations with Beijing by saying it was not in US "longer-term interests" to retaliate. And there was enough give in the language of American "sorrow" (especially when translated into Chinese) to gloss over the fact that it fell short of an apology. With Mr Jiang and other senior leaders due to step down in 2002 and 2003, China experts have seen signs of political manoeuvring in Beijing. Mr Jiang's ability to dictate the succession would have suffered if he could not have delivered on the crisis. Some experts believe that the military already posed a serious challenge to his authority and pressed for a tougher line in the past week. Mr Jiang can now tell his critics in the Communist party and the PLA that he has forced the Bush administration to take China seriously. It will be much harder now, he can argue, for Mr Bush to play down relations with Beijing, as he had seemed to be doing. Mr Jiang and his team have never wavered from the objective they set in the Clinton years of seeking "partnership" with the US. They say this is crucial for peace and development in the coming century, for Asia and the world. To the Chinese political and business establishment - though less so to poor peasants and jobless workers - this includes as a high priority China's forthcoming admission to the World Trade Organisation. In economic terms China, while still a long way behind the US, is regarded as a fast-rising competitor who within one or two decades could present a formidable challenge. In terms of Beijing's foreign policy, this was and remains the only strategic game in town. It survived the severe jolt given by the US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade two years ago, when angry demonstrators took to the streets and hardline nationalists predicted a future war. Public opinion this time has been more vocal, and more diverse. "Even an apology should not have been enough," a nationalist voice protested. "We should have put the crew on trial." But another sounded a sceptical note. "Why make them apologise? Our pilot probably made a mistake." The spy flights are as offensive to China as they would be to the US if China ran similar missions off the Atlantic coast. But many Chinese are quite capable of being angry and realistic at the same time. "In the end," said one calm voice, "we could not get an apology because China is weak and the US is strong." The strength of China's hardliners has been exaggerated in recent days by western China watchers. Some suggested that the PLA had manufactured the incident and embarrassed Mr Jiang by its claim that the US plane was to blame. This mirrors isome unofficial Chinese claims that Mr Bush sent the plane "to test our resolve on home ground". Most Chinese, including apparently the PLA, accept that what happened was an accident. Yesterday showed once again the PLA's fundamental loyalty to the revolutionary tradition that "politics remains in command of the gun". The team Mr Jiang left in Beijing to handle the crisis was headed by another civilian, Hu Jintao, whom he is grooming to succeed him. But Mr Jiang and any successor must still reckon with public opinion, which has become sceptical of diplomatic spin and can be easily roused to anger. China knew that in the end it would not get a full US apology. Indeed no one can remember the last time that Beijing apologised to anyone for anything. In Chinese political culture an apology indicates a total confession of guilt. webTitle: US hardware to help Macedonia monitor guerrilla movements

fields.headline: US hardware to help Macedonia monitor guerrilla movements
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The US is to supply Macedonia with hi-tech communications equipment to help it to monitor the movements of ethnic Albanian insurgents.
fields.body:
The US is to supply Macedonia with hi-tech communications equipment to help it to monitor the movements of ethnic Albanian insurgents.

The American embassy in Macedonia's capital, Skopje, said yesterday that the equipment was "the latest technology", and that it "fully meets Nato standards".

The move follows the EU's stabilisation and association agreement earlier this week, which gave Macedonia generous trade terms.

Macedonia responded yesterday by setting up a commission to guarantee equal treatment of its ethnic Albanian minority, which makes up about 30% of the population. The majority group is of Slav origin.

After meeting leading politicians from both communities to discuss the new commission, President Boris Trajkovski said: "This is a very special situation in Macedonia, and we want to reach a general consensus." The commission will also investigate ways to fight organised crime.

The US has urged Mr Trajkovski's government, which includes two ethnic Albanian parties, to face up to the "legitimate grievances and long-standing concerns" of the country's minority.

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, will address that issue in Macedonia today before flying to Kosovo and Bosnia. He will also caution the Macedonian government to use "proportionate" force against the rebels, a US official in Paris with Mr Powell said yesterday.

While describing the rebels as "terrorists", the EU is concerned about provoking further militancy among Macedonia's minority ethnic group. The United States is worried about this too.

The Macedonian government had accused Nato-led peacekeepers of being soft on the rebels on the Kosovo side of the border.

Meanwhile, Nato-led peace keepers detained 12 suspected ethnic Albanian guerrillas crossing into Kosovo from Albania, a United Nations police spokesman said yesterday.

They were suspected of belonging to a guerrilla group operating in Macedonia, the UN spokesman told Reuters news agency.

Rebels of the self-styled Na tional Liberation Army emerged in Macedonia last month claiming they were fighting for equal rights for the country's large Albanian minority.

Two weeks ago German peacekeepers detained 44 suspected guerrillas crossing the border into Kosovo with refugees fleeing the fighting in Macedonia.

webTitle: Coroner to report failings of Feltham after prison suicide

fields.headline: Coroner to report failings of Feltham after prison suicide
fields.standfirst: Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: Failures in communication and the identification of at risk prisoners at Feltham young offenders institution are to be reported to the Home Office by a coroner following an inquest into the death of a teenager at Britain's largest youth jail.
fields.body:
Failures in communication and the identification of at risk prisoners at Feltham young offenders institution are to be reported to the Home Office by a coroner following an inquest into the death of a teenager at Britain's largest youth jail.

The west London coroner, Allison Thompson, said she would be reporting her concerns about Feltham after a jury returned a verdict of suicide in the case of Kevin Henson, 17. Henson, who had suffered alcohol problems since the death of his mother, was found hanging from exposed pipes in his cell on September 6 last year. He had been refused bail on a charge of wounding the previous day.

The three day inquest at Hammersmith and Chelsea coroners court heard of a succession of failures at Feltham, which houses around 700 inmates aged between 15 and 21.

Power cables for televisions were housed in pipes that were left exposed in some cells. Henson hanged himself from one of these.

Medical records, including an assessment by a police doctor who diagnosed Henson as suffering from alcoholism and severe anxiety were not passed to reception staff at the jail. Senior staff at Feltham were unable to provide an explanation as to how that happened.

Despite being seen by three health care workers no concerns were raised about the risk of self-harm in Henson's case.

Henson's father, also named Kevin, called for an independent investigation into procedures at Feltham which was described as "rotten to the core" by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.

"Short of pulling the place down, it will be nice for an outside agency to go in. If it's left to the Home Office to investigate there will be no criticism." he said. "I've just spent three days listening to people justifying their failure to take action. The prison service ... didn't do their job."

A representative of the family said they would be taking the case to the parliamentary ombudsman, reporting a GP who saw Kevin in Feltham to the General Medical Council, and requesting a meeting with the prisons minister, Paul Boateng.

Deborah Coles of the campaign group Inquest accused the prison service of attempting to restrict the remit of the inquiry in order to stifle criticism of staff.

"This inquest has painted a disturbing picture of the complete failures in the screening and identification of at risk prisoners," she said.

Martin Narey, director of the prison service, said in a statement: "Kevin Henson's death was a tragic waste of young life which has affected many people who knew Kevin, including the staff at Feltham. On behalf of the prison service and the staff at Feltham I can only reiterate our heart felt regrets and condolences."

Mr Narey pointed out that £8m would be invested this year to drive down prison suicides and that the numbers of suicides fell last year for the first time in five years.

Nick Pascoe, the governor of Feltham, said the remaining exposed pipes in cells would be boxed in by the end of next week.

Kevin Henson was deeply traumatised following the death of his mother of cancer on his 14th birthday in August 1997. He turned to alcohol and within 18 months was an alcoholic.

In 1998 his father, struggling to cope, turned to social services for help and Kevin moved to a foster home in Milton Keynes. He was settled for a while but after 14 months he was moved to a home in Luton after an argument with another teenager.

After breaking hostel rules in Luton he moved back to his father's house in Uxbridge, Middlesex, where his behaviour deteriorated.

In November 1999 he was arrested for a street robbery and being drunk and disorderly, and on August 15 2000 he was made the subject of a probation order. A GP diagnosed him as alcoholic.

Less than two weeks later on the bank holiday weekend Kevin got drunk and got into a fight during which he slashed another teenager across the face. He was arrested, charged with wounding with intent and held at Uxbridge police station.

A doctor at the station examined him and noted, "asthmatic, anxiety plus, alcohol plus plus". This record was not passed to medical staff at Feltham.

On September 5 Henson was refused bail and warned he could face two years in jail. He cried on hearing he would be returning to Feltham and told his father he was worried he would not be able to visit his mother's grave on her birthday the following month. Later that night he tore a strip off a bed sheet, tied it to the exposed pipe, and hanged himself. In a letter to his father he said: "I've been thinking about doing this since mum died. I just want to be with mum."

webTitle: Japan takes first steps towards protecting battered wives

fields.headline: Japan takes first steps towards protecting battered wives
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The growing political influence of Japanese women was acknowledged last week by the passage of the country's first law on domestic violence.
fields.body:
The growing political influence of Japanese women was acknowledged last week by the passage of the country's first law on domestic violence.

The law is the latest step away from the Confucian family values and shame-orientated culture that have long discouraged the authorities from entering the sanctuary of the Japanese home.

It is only in recent years, as the number of women in government and parliament and at work has grown, that Japan has begun to consider domestic violence a social malaise.

But it has quickly become apparent that the problem exists on an alarming scale.

A recent survey by the municipal authorities in Osaka found that two-thirds of women reported physical abuse by their partners. A central government study last year found that 5% of wives feared for their lives, and one in seven had received medical treatment after being beaten by their husbands.

A growing number of victims are beginning to speak out.

Hiromi Sakurai (not her real name), 36, the mother of two, spent seven years trapped in a violent marriage which nobody wanted to know about.

"Sometimes he would beat and kick me all night," she said. "He'd punch me so hard and for so long that his hand would start to hurt. To ease his pain, he'd wrap a flannel around his fist and then carry on."

Neighbours ignored her screams and his cursing and doctors accepted excuses about her injuries, which included a broken leg and an eye wound that needed surgery. Even her father told her that she should quietly endure the pain for the sake of the family name.

"At first I was almost relieved that people ignored my pain because, in Japan, it is a terrible thing to bring shame on the home," she said.

"But when I heard that from my own father, I felt like I might as well die."

Instead, she decided to start life again. Two years ago she took refuge in a women's shelter and divorced her husband. She has been in hiding ever since.

The new law, passed on April 6, came too late for her but it should help others like her.

It establishes a system of restraining orders, increases the number of shelters (currently there are only 20 for a population of 126m) and encourages health and social workers to report suspected cases of abuse to the police.

"The Japanese home has been like a black box," said Mizuho Fukushima, an MP who played a leading role in the campaign for the bill.

"Until now the law couldn't enter. With families ultra- conscious of their reputations, violence was all too easily hidden or downplayed."

Ms Sakurai welcomes the new law as a sign of progress, but only in so far as it can help to change attitudes.

"The bill is deficient in many ways, but it is a first step. If nothing else, it should offer some encouragement for victims and witnesses to break their silence."

webTitle: Comment: Farmers' grief leaves us all bereft

fields.headline: Farmers' grief leaves us all bereft
fields.standfirst:
Emotional and spiritual loss must be properly addressed

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Emotional and spiritual loss must be properly addressed.
fields.body:
As many as 25% of small farms will have closed by 2005, according to government projections the Guardian revealed yesterday. But the present crisis in the countryside is a psycho-spiritual, as well as a political and financial, one.

With the increasing industrialisation of agriculture (along with every other part of daily life), the countryside had become the repository of our most romantic, and some would say sentimental, spiritual longings - the raw to the city's cooked.

Of course, on some level we all knew that it was made by humans, yet still its place as the guardian of the natural - a place somehow beyond capital and labour - seemed secure. Now that looks to change. The disappearance of small farms will make the romantic rural fiction hard to sustain.

The past six weeks have certainly been a steep learning curve for townies. Which of us back in February knew about the homing instincts of hefted sheep (which seems like some conceit out of Little Bo Beep)? Or how unwild the Lake District really is, and how threatening real wildness would be to its cherished landscape?

For farmers, the psycho-spiritual issues have become immediate. Bound up with their animals, rhythms, theirs is the original 24/7 life, without holidays. Early retirement or the slaughter of their animals leaves a hole much larger than job-sized. It's as if part of the farmer himself has been culled.

Andrew Samuels, professor of psychology at Essex, believes the crisis "is a terrific blow in the spiritual area. People who work with animals have a lot of meaning in their work - a craft-based spirituality which most of us no longer have, and this strikes at that meaning".

Though vegetarians might scoff, there's usually something paternally protective about farmers' relationship with their animals - at least until market-time. But the peremptory requisitioning of herds for culling has induced a sense of impotence and helplessness. One phoned the Rural Stress Information Network and said to the volunteer manning the helpline, "Will you talk to me while they shoot my animals?" The volunteer could hear the gunfire as he spoke.

Vets are similarly affected. It wouldn't be surprising, when the foot and mouth crisis is over, to see an epidemic of post-traumatic stress disorder among vets who've been forced into the role of executioner and had to sign the animals over for slaughter.

Farmers are also experiencing a sense of historical failure and guilt. They become attached to a pedigree herd or flock, perhaps started by a great-grandfather, and in the family for generations. Though he can't directly blame himself for what's happened, nevertheless he is now the generation which lost a herd. The whole heritage of the family that was under his custodianship has gone.

With farming now going the way of mining and fishing, it's another stage in the occupational shift away from brawn, leaving farmers with few alternatives. Yet the majority of phone calls to the volunteer Farm Crisis Network asking for help for male farmers come from women (a wife, sister, or friend). Most farmers still aspire to be masterful and lack a language through which to articulate loss. In common with most men in our culture, they find it easier to express rage than grief: the anger directed at Tony Blair can be understood, at least partly, in this plight.

Many of the calls to the helplines are deeply distressing, and the volunteers themselves need supporting. In the case of the FCN, some of those people manning the phones are going through the same experience themselves, with their own animals being slaughtered.

The British countryside is awash with grief. No psychobabble needed here, but this is an opportunity, beyond the Princess Diana mass hysteria, to speak openly about the painful process of grieving and loss, both personal and collective.

For we're all of us psychologically affected. Images of giant cranes tipping carcasses into vast graves stir memories of newsreel footage of mass burials in newly liberated Bergen-Belsen. Coming after BSE, floods, railway failure, and with its likely permanent impact on the landscape and ecology, the agricultural crisis seems an irrefutable declaration that the infrastructure is buckling beneath natural forces which our social system is utterly inequipped to tackle. While some people find this politically and ideologically cheering in an "I told you so", kind of way, they also find such a major tectonic shift in the country scary.

The erosion of agriculture-as-we-know-it, without the prospect of an organic utopia to take its place, leaves us all with profound questions about our relationship to the commercial and the natural - issues much more commanding and pressing than we could ever have suspected at the innocent start of the year.

 George Monbiot is away.

In the case of the FCN, some of those people manning the phones are going through the same experience themselves, with their own animals being slaughtered. The British countryside is awash with grief. No psychobabble needed here, but this is an opportunity, beyond the Princess Diana mass hysteria, to speak openly about the painful process of grieving and loss, both personal and collective. For we're all of us psychologically affected. Images of giant cranes tipping carcasses into vast graves stir memories of newsreel footage of mass burials in newly liberated Bergen-Belsen. Coming after BSE, floods, railway failure, and with its likely permanent impact on the landscape and ecology, the agricultural crisis seems an irrefutable declaration that the infrastructure is buckling beneath natural forces which our social system is utterly inequipped to tackle. While some people find this politically and ideologically cheering in an "I told you so", kind of way, they also find such a major tectonic shift in the country scary. The erosion of agriculture-as-we-know-it, without the prospect of an organic utopia to take its place, leaves us all with profound questions about our relationship to the commercial and the natural - issues much more commanding and pressing than we could ever have suspected at the innocent start of the year.  George Monbiot is away. fields.headline: Green allies demand vaccination option
fields.standfirst:
Anger grows on slaughter policy

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Environment and conservation groups with a combined membership of more than 3m have formed a coalition to protest against the Ministry of Agriculture's mass slaughter policy and to ask for selective vaccination of stock.
fields.body:
Environment and conservation groups with a combined membership of more than 3m have formed a coalition to protest against the Ministry of Agriculture's mass slaughter policy and to ask for selective vaccination of stock.

The National Trust, RSPB, Soil Association, Wildlife Trusts and many smaller organisations, including university departments, companies, research institutions and preservation groups, have set up Farmers for Voluntary Vaccination.

"Giving farmers an alternative to slaughter in the firebreak zones is the only way to regain their confidence. They must have an option," said the Soil Association, which is co-ordinating the move. "They have been told that vaccinated animals have to be slaughtered but this is not true."

Meanwhile, opposition to the slaughter was growing with many farmers in Gloucestershire and Cumbria protesting at what they called Maff's "arrogance and incompetence" and at the slipshod methods of disposal.

"People are getting vocal and angry now," said Gail Bennet, of Bollow, near Westbury-on-Severn, Gloucestershire, who is disputing Maff's order to kill her farm animals.

"There have been misdiagnoses. I am refusing to let Maff on my farm. They are incompetent and arrogant. They confirmed my sheep were not infected weeks ago, but they cannot admit they have made mistakes."

Clive Davies, a Gloucestershire farmer who lost his herd of 255 cattle to a cull later proved to have been carried out through clerical error, said he was furious with the ministry. "You become a statistic... it becomes a rollercoaster and there is no stopping it."

As demonstrators marched through Carlisle yesterday to protest against bureaucratic delay in getting government cash to help Cumbria's tourist-based businesses, farmers in the county and in Gloucestershire were blockading their farms, preparing legal injunctions and protesting at the methods of carcass disposal.

Up to 20 farmers used tractors to block off a landfill site at Ufton, Warwickshire, where carcasses were being dumped. "Blood was running across the road," said a member of Friends of the Earth. "It's clear the assurances given by Maff are worthless."
