fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Tebbit to head new airline
fields.body:
Tebbit to head new airline

Lord Tebbit, former chairman of the Conservative party who was once a pilot, is to become head of a new business airline, which is offering a flat-rate return fare of £1,200 between Stansted airport and New York. It will operate two flights a day. The airline is looking for £65m to back the venture which it hopes to start from next March.

Derek Jewson, its chief executive, said yesterday that it plans to expand its operations to Boston, Los Angeles and San Fransisco.

FSA seeks Barum wind-up

The financial services authority has taken the unusual step of applying for an Aberdeen-based stockbroking firm to be wound up on the grounds of alleged "misappropriation" of client money.

The regulator said yesterday it had issued a petition in the Edinburgh court of session seeking the winding up of Barum House Securities Limited, which is now no longer trading and had around 200 customers, mostly from the local area.

The FSA's petition states that there has been alleged misappropriation of the funds of at least one customer, and alleged unauthorised trading on customer accounts.

PPL clones transgenic pigs

Cloning specialist PPL Therapeutics has announced the birth of the world's first transgenic piglets, in a further step towards its goal of growing human organs in animals.

The five piglets have a foreign "marker gene" inserted in their DNA. The next step will be to produce "knockout" pigs, switching off the genes incompatible with the human immune system. PPL believes the market for transplantable organs could be worth $5bn (£3.4bn).

Plug pulled on online fraud

Investigators have foiled an attempted international online banking fraud involving fake documents worth $3.9bn (£2.7bn), it was announced yesterday.

The International Chamber of Commerce's London-based commercial crime bureau said fraudsters had published fake European banking guarantees on at least 29 websites.

The bureau approached the fraudsters' internet service provider in the US, which agreed to shut down the sites. A spokesman said it feared some private investors may have lost money as a result of the scam, but did not have any more information.

Transco starts £666m spend

Transco, the gas pipelines company, is to spend £666m more over the next five years replacing metallic pipes following serious concerns over safety and a series of accidents.

The increased outlay, part of a planned £12bn spending programme between 2002 and 2006, could be even greater if the health and safety executive and Ofgem, the energy regulator, impose a speedier replacement programme.

fields.headline: Bonus protesters target RBS pair
fields.trailText: On the day Royal Bank of Scotland pulled the plug on shipbuilder Cammell Laird with the potential loss of 1,800 British jobs, its top executives were fending off criticism of a £2.5m bonus scheme.
fields.body:
On the day Royal Bank of Scotland pulled the plug on shipbuilder Cammell Laird with the potential loss of 1,800 British jobs, its top executives were fending off criticism of a £2.5m bonus scheme.

At the bank's annual meeting in Edinburgh, shareholders showed their disapproval by casting an unusually large vote against the reappointment of two directors.

Viscount Younger, the outgoing chairman, said the bank was "sorry" if shareholders felt they had been inadequately consulted about the bonuses paid to four of the bank's senior directors, including his successor, Sir George Mathewson.

Sir George stoked up the row by saying last month that the bonuses - awarded after Royal Bank won control of NatWest in last year's arduous battle - "wouldn't give you bragging power in a Soho wine bar".

One small shareholder won applause by saying that Sir George's comments suggested "arrogance".

To protest against the special bonuses, the National Association of Pension Funds, whose members control some 25% of the stock market, had advised pension funds to vote against the reappointment of two senior non-executives, British Telecom boss Sir Iain Vallance and banker Sir Angus Grossart.

Both sit on the remuneration committee which approved the bonuses and, while both were re-elected, leading institutional in vestors, who did not speak, insisted that the votes of 10% and 15% respectively against the reappointments were larger than usual.

"The whole point is to send a message," one said. "These votes are more normally like being elected to the politburo. You don't expect to see people voting against."

The Napf insisted it was not disappointed the rebellion had not been larger. "Our intention was to raise the issue, not to just make Royal Bank of Scotland aware [that we do not approve of such transaction bonuses] but to the corporate sector in general," said Chris Baldry, manager of the Napf's voting issues service.

Viscount Younger and fellow board members had an easier time than many expected.

Small investor Mary Mackenzie was one of the few to pick fault.

"One cannot admire people who need so many bonuses and financial inducements to do a day's work," she said.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Denise Kingsmill, deputy head of the competition commission, is in tough-talking mood briefing journalists before the recent Lloyds/Abbey National public hearing.
fields.body:
 Denise Kingsmill, deputy head of the competition commission, is in tough-talking mood briefing journalists before the recent Lloyds/Abbey National public hearing. She tells hacks the commission has only 200 tickets for the public, and has got from the banks a list of the "nutters" who often turn up at these things, to try to ensure the Lloyds-Abbey event does not turn into a free-for-all for individual complaints. Ms Kingsmill's "nutters" quote duly appears in, well, this newspaper. Yesterday we receive a call from a veteran bank protester, Keith Whincup, to say he has written to Ms Kingsmill demanding an apology and that he is taking legal advice. The commission declines to comment except to say it is "delighted to confirm that we have received a wide range of views since the beginning of the inquiry". Mr Whincup is best known for attending bank annual meetings with a large crucifix on his back, in a graphic illustration of the effects of excessive bank charges.

 Times are tough (part one): The big investment banks are cutting back on all sorts of things - coffee, taxis, fruit baskets and so on. It may be getting worse than that: yesterday the Guardian received mail from both JP Morgan and Commerzbank with unpaid postage for which we had to stump up. That's £2.47 in total - we'll have to sell another five papers to cover it, thanks very much.

 Times are tough (part two): With media business drying up, new lows are being stooped to, to drum up trade. Take minnow The Bank, which tried to run a topless female model in an ad booked for page three of the FT. Not surprisingly, the FT said no (as would every other national broadsheet). So I rang to ask if this was just a pathetic stunt to drum up publicity using a soft porn photo that it knew the FT would turn down? "Erm, no" said Stuart Bradbury, torn between having to admit it was a stunt or admitting his agency was stupid. "It's not really a soft porn shot ... it's a topless lady." Mmm. He passes me to his boss, Ian Cassie, whose brilliant idea it was. "It's not a pathetic stunt to get publicity," says Ian. "It's a nice little joke to cheer people up, with everything around like foot and mouth." So let me get this clear: you wanted to run an ad with a topless model because of foot and mouth? "No, I didn't say that," says Ian.

 Ian would doubtlessly applaud the latest stunt by Playboy.com, which is running a contest seeking votes for the "hottest bear market babe" among Wall Street's female financial television presenters. First prize is the chance to pose nude for Playboy magazine. "It's tough enough to get ahead as a female without having that kind of asinine behaviour," one of the women targeted told Reuters.

 Time again for Dog of the Day - today's effort is a treat from our friends at Merrill Lynch. Its analysts have taken to heart their special classes on how to downgrade stock recommendations: yesterday the bank lowered advertising group Aegis from "accumulate" to "intermediate neutral" (whatever that means). Needless to say, the share price promptly shot up more than 6%. Oh dear. I was tempted not to award this to Merrill's media team, because its leader, Neil Blackley, is highly regarded in the City for his quiet modesty. But that's life in the big city. Woof.

 One of the funniest web spots is eBusiness magazine's 100 Dumbest Moments in E-business. My especial favourite is number 12: "After raising $10m in funding in May 1998, James Cramer, founder of TheStreet.com, issues a press release in which he exults: 'The dead-tree boys must be shaking in their boots. We now have the money we need to complete our vision of crushing the old line media behemoths'." Most of you will be reading this on a dead tree.

webTitle: Regulator vows to view price-rise application with 'critical' eye

fields.headline: Regulator vows to view price-rise application with 'critical' eye
fields.trailText: The Post Office faced an uphill struggle yesterday to convince the new industry regulator and consumer watchdog of its case for raising the cost of both first and second class letters by 1p, writes David Gow .
fields.body:
The Post Office faced an uphill struggle yesterday to convince the new industry regulator and consumer watchdog of its case for raising the cost of both first and second class letters by 1p, writes David Gow .

They would rise to 28p and 20p respectively from October 1. First-class mail rose to 27p last April when the PO cut the cost of second-class letters, after a five-year freeze, from 20p to 19p.

PostComm, the regulator, said it would consider the PO's application to increase prices from October 1 "carefully and critically", pointing out that it would be allowed only if "there is a significant risk to the company's ability to finance its licensed activities".

It added that the PO, now known as Consignia, must also prove that no other course -such as improving efficiency - is appropriate.

The industry regulator, which issued the PO's firstlicence in its 350-year history late last month, and the new consumer watchdog, PostWatch, made plain that the proposed increases would be subjectto stringent consultation.

Peter Carr, PostWatch chairman, claimed that Consignia had been arguing for a price freeze just 10 days before its licence was granted and the increases in stamps and other products would cost customers £280m over 18 months - on top of £240m increases over three years in other parts of the PO business already conceded.

"Service levels to customers are at their lowest for years. Customers cannot be expected to continue to pay more and more for a deteriorating service.

"First-class prices were increased last summer and then service standards collapsed," he said. "Customers must not bail out inefficiency and mismanage ment." But Richard Dykes, Consignia's managing director of mail services, said postage prices over the past decade were below the average rate of increases for the country as a whole.

In the past five years first-class had gone down 8% in real terms and second-class by 16%.

Mr Carr said the case for raising prices to fund new investment was "pretty thin", adding: "What are they doing with all the money they've had before?" Mr Dykes insisted, however, that some increases were now crucial for investment to drive up mail reliability.

Price rises would provide about a third of the finance needed to upgrade mail centres, with the rest coming from increased efficiency.

He said that the British postal service was one of the best in value and the least expensive in Europe with letter charges only a third of those in Germany.

fields.headline: JJB plans superstore move on to continent
fields.trailText: Sports retailer JJB is planning to open superstores throughout Europe. The first could be in business by the end of this year.
fields.body:
Sports retailer JJB is planning to open superstores throughout Europe. The first could be in business by the end of this year.

Chairman Dave Whelan said he was convinced JJB's superstores would be a success on the continent. "We will definitely be there next year and maybe by the end of this year."

The retailer, which already has 224 superstores in Britain out of a total 433 outlets, is targeting the Netherlands and France but Mr Whelan believes the group might also move into Spain, Germany and Italy.

JJB staff were already look ing for suitable sites and considering how the business should be structured in mainland Europe. "We have to decide whether we need warehousing. If we only have three stores in Holland, we could send the stock from here. We have to look at all the options and we want to be prepared."

Ultimately, he said, the scale of the expansion would depend on whether Britain joined the euro. "My instinct tells me we shouldn't join, but I think we will, and if we do we have to be ready to take the Europeans on."

JJB was reporting annual profits up 18% to £84m, with like-for-like sales up 5% in the past 10 weeks and an improvement in margins. The result was better than City expectations and the shares rose 56.5p to a record 725p.

The Wigan-based company plans a one-for-one bonus issue to make the shares more attractive to small investors.

Turnover was up 8% at £663.3m and JJB raised its final dividend to 8p per share, making a total of 11.5p, up 15% on the previous year.

The company is pursuing a strategy of replacing high street stores with larger out-of-town outlets. It plans 34 such projects this year and 35 next.

Chairman Dave Whelan said he was convinced JJB's superstores would be a success on the continent. "We will definitely be there next year and maybe by the end of this year." The retailer, which already has 224 superstores in Britain out of a total 433 outlets, is targeting the Netherlands and France but Mr Whelan believes the group might also move into Spain, Germany and Italy. JJB staff were already look ing for suitable sites and considering how the business should be structured in mainland Europe. "We have to decide whether we need warehousing. If we only have three stores in Holland, we could send the stock from here. We have to look at all the options and we want to be prepared." Ultimately, he said, the scale of the expansion would depend on whether Britain joined the euro. "My instinct tells me we shouldn't join, but I think we will, and if we do we have to be ready to take the Europeans on." JJB was reporting annual profits up 18% to £84m, with like-for-like sales up 5% in the past 10 weeks and an improvement in margins. The result was better than City expectations and the shares rose 56.5p to a record 725p. The Wigan-based company plans a one-for-one bonus issue to make the shares more attractive to small investors. Turnover was up 8% at £663.3m and JJB raised its final dividend to 8p per share, making a total of 11.5p, up 15% on the previous year. The company is pursuing a strategy of replacing high street stores with larger out-of-town outlets. It plans 34 such projects this year and 35 next.

fields.headline: Pact fails to tame wildcats
fields.trailText: "The management are bullying the workforce all the time," the east London postman said.
fields.body:
"The management are bullying the workforce all the time," the east London postman said.

The postie (he refused to give his name, claiming a fear of managerial reprisals) was speaking in advance of a threatened 24-hour strike at the Whitechapel district sorting office that would have crippled mail deliveries to City banks and national media organisations 10 days ago.

That strike was called off at the last minute but the Post Office lost 60,000 working days in the financial year just ended, almost three times as many as in 1999-2000 and 10% of all days lost through strikes in Britain.

Most disputes are unofficial, wildcat stoppages, such as the recent walk-out by 5,000 staff in Glasgow protesting at what they regarded as lenient disciplining by managers in a sexual harassment case. This has prompted widespread accusations that the Communication Workers Union has lost control of its members.

Mr Keggie claims 65% of disputes are down to an outmoded code of conduct and managers misusing outdated procedures. The CWU wants an independent inquiry into PO industrial relations.

A national agreement, The Way Forward, signed by PO and CWU 18 months ago and approved by union members, is designed to offset a shorter working week and higher basic pay with greater efficiency and productivity.

The deal, seen by Mr Roberts as able to deliver 3% annual productivity growth, raises basic pensionable pay from £10,000 to £13,000 then in three years to £15,000 - peanuts in London.

fields.headline: Chief lands £44m for Wainhomes stake
fields.trailText: Cheshire millionaire Bill Ainscough, who took regional housebuilder Wainhomes into private ownership in 1999, is about to receive £44m through the sale of the business.
fields.body:
Cheshire millionaire Bill Ainscough, who took regional housebuilder Wainhomes into private ownership in 1999, is about to receive £44m through the sale of the business to construction firm Wilson Connolly.

Mr Ainscough, founder and chairman of Wainhomes, will have almost trebled the £15m stake he held in the company prior to the management buyout.

The controversial move to private ownership prompted some institutional investors to suggest the company - then valued at £88m - had been sold too cheaply.

Yesterday, Wilson Connolly made an offer of £132.5m for Wainhomes' business and debt of £70.7m. It said that Mr Ainscough's business would bring the enlarged group greater presence in important housebuilding markets around Chester, Cheltenham, York and Wigan.

John Tutte, chief executive of Wilson Connolly, said the deal would force an unspecified number of job cuts.

No jobs will go among Wainhomes management. Mr Ainscough will become a non-executive director of Wilson Connolly, which is chaired by former Asda boss, Allan Leighton.

Mr Ainscough will receive £2.4m in cash and the balance in shares and loan notes. Shares in Wilson Connolly rose 3.5p to close at 177.5p.

fields.headline: Chip designer ARM defies slowdown
fields.trailText: Microchip designer ARM Holdings yesterday bucked the slowdown trend in the global semiconductor industry by delivering results in line with expectations and saying it remained confident about future trading prospects.
fields.body:
Microchip designer ARM Holdings yesterday bucked the slowdown trend in the global semiconductor industry by delivering results in line with expectations and saying it remained confident about future trading prospects.

Shares in the Cambridge-based firm have fallen sharply in the past week amid fears that it would be forced to issue a profits warning but bounced 28p to 308p yesterday on the lack of bad news.

Analysts believe that ARM will eventually be hit by the slowdown in the microchip industry because royalty revenues, which take three months to filter through to its accounts and make up around 25% of its income, do not yet illustrate the true state of the market.

But chief executive Robin Saxby argued that ARM was relatively immune because it only designs and does not manufacture chips. He said: "We're like the architects in the building trade. The builders may be experiencing a bit of a slump right now but they are still looking for designs for new projects."

While royalty revenues may weaken over coming months, the increase in revenues from new licences should offset that, Mr Saxby said.

ARM's chips are used in electronic gadgets from mobile phones and digital cameras to games consoles and set-top boxes.

Results for the three months ending March 31 showed quarterly revenues up a record 52% at £32.5m and profit before tax 39% higher at £11.4m.

webTitle: GUS picks up profit as America falters

fields.headline: GUS picks up profit as America falters
fields.trailText: The US slowdown has produced an unexpected upturn for Great Universal Stores.
fields.body:
The US slowdown has produced an unexpected upturn for Great Universal Stores.

Although GUS is mainly associated with catalogue shopping, its Argos store chain and Burberry luxury brand, its biggest business is the Experian credit checking operation.

Experian, which also provides lists for direct mail advertising, gets 60% of its business from the US and the division as a whole generates 40% of GUS profits.

GUS suffered as signs emerged that the US slowdown would prompt Experian's American clients to cut costs, but yesterday finance director David Tyler said it had performed better than expected.

Clients are checking credit ratings more often to avoid bad debts and direct mail advertisers are continuing to spend to attract new customers. Lower US interest rates have created new business. "As rates have come down, many Americans are remortgaging," Mr Tyler said. "They do it quickly and every time they approach a lender there's at least one credit check."

Experian's underlying US sales grew 4% in the six months to the end of March and 9% in the past three months . The entire division saw a 7% improvement.

Elsewhere, home shopping sales were down 5% but Argos like-for-like sales climbed 6%,and Burberry sales were up 41%.

fields.headline: At this price?  Pittards
fields.trailText: Somerset-based leather goods manufacturer Pittards issued its second profit warning yesterday in as many months, blaming the foot and mouth crisis for a 30% escalation in the price of UK hides. Profits, the company said, would be "substantially" down as a result.
fields.body:
Somerset-based leather goods manufacturer Pittards issued its second profit warning yesterday in as many months, blaming the foot and mouth crisis for a 30% escalation in the price of UK hides. Profits, the company said, would be "substantially" down as a result.

The maker of leather goods - from Louis Vuitton handbags to Puma football boots - said the company's main Leeds factory relied on abattoirs across Britain for most of its products. Only its glove-making division, which uses hides from specialised overseas breeds but accounts for only a third of revenues, was unaffected by the crisis.

In a statement to the stock exchange yesterday, the company said that since it first voiced concern, the outbreak had worsened. "The prospects of an early return of raw material supplies to normality seem low," it said.

However, after dipping 8p on the back of this news, shares in Pittards recovered yesterday to close down 3.5p at 56.5p. Against a backdrop of mixed fortunes for household goods, this is one of the most promising signs to date that the City is beginning to feel confident that the crisis has peaked.

John Buckley, Pittards group managing director, said he was glad investors were focusing on the company's long-term fundamentals. "In March, we reported a 71% increase in pretax profits to £3m on sales of £80.2m - and demand is still strong," he said. "We are still making money, but rather less than we had hoped."

The company said turnover was running ahead of forecasts.

With high-profile designer customers, such as Hermes and Louis Vuitton, keen to avoid any interruption in supply from Pittards, the company has been forced to look abroad for hides and is confident it can weather the effects of the outbreak.

Meanwhile, the cautiously optimistic signals from the Ministry of Agriculture appear to have found the ear of some long-term investors.

fields.headline: Bad news plagues WPP
fields.trailText: Traders are advising clients to steer clear of advertising group WPP for the moment.
fields.body:
Traders are advising clients to steer clear of advertising group WPP for the moment.

Not only have rumours of a profits warning been heard in the Square Mile this week, but also joint broker Merrill Lynch has cut its rating and profits forecast for the company.

Yesterday, Merrill media analyst Neil Blackley lowered his near-term rating on WPP to "neutral" from "accumulate" and cut his 2001 pretax profits forecast to £547m from £587m. Mr Blackley's new forecasts reflect the lack of visibility on advertising and marketing services revenues.

Downgrades from house brokers are taken seriously in the City because their profit forecasts tend to reflect guidance supplied by the company.

With 50% of its business done on the other side of the Atlantic, WPP is seen as vulnerable to the slowdown in the US.

WPP shares ended 3.5p lower at 725p.

webTitle: Home is where the firm is

fields.headline: Home is where the firm is
fields.trailText: It has long been considered essential for directors of publicly quoted companies to align their interests with those of shareholders by having an equity stake.
fields.body:
It has long been considered essential for directors of publicly quoted companies to align their interests with those of shareholders by having an equity stake.

It was therefore no surprise to see the market react with anger to yesterday's news that Michael Kirkham, the chief executive designate of market research firm Taylor Nelson Sofres, had sold 600,000 shares at 225p each.

Taylor Nelson shares ended 13.5p lower at 213.5p - the worst performer in the FTSE 250. But could the market have misread Mr Kirkham's intentions?

A spokeswoman for Taylor Nelson said Mr Kirkham had sold the shares - worth £1.35m - to pay for a new house. But not just any house. Apparently he needs a home close to Taylor Nelson's head office in west London, so he can give the business his full and undivided attention. Mr Kirkham's current address is not known, but should he have any difficulty finding a suitable property, he might want to make an appointment at Rolfe East estate agents at 51 the Mall, Ealing.

They have a pair of "highly individual" five- bedroom, detached houses, situated just off the common, on the market for a mere £1m.

Mr Kirkham was not the only director selling stock yesterday, Michael Spencer, chief executive of moneybroker Garban, down 2.5p to 488.5p, sold 111,930 shares. Mr Spencer has sold over 577,000 shares since December 21.

In the meantime, the FTSE 100's recent strong run came to end, ironically because of renewed enthusiasm for tech stocks. The catalyst for the buying was strong figures from chip designer ARM Holdings, up 28p to 308p, and a Salomon Smith Barney upgrade of US semiconductor makers.

With institutions selling their holdings of heavily weighted drug issues to buy tech stocks, the blue chip index came to rest 14.9 points lower at 5,788.1. GlaxoSmithKline, off 45p to £18.07, and AstraZeneca, down 103p to £33.22, inflicted most of the damage.

The sector rotation was, however, good news for the FTSE Techmark 100, which finished 53.10 points higher at 1,889.50, with Misys rising 31.5p to 472p after a strong push from Deustche Bank.

Deutsche reckons Misys has performed so badly in the past week because of its exposure to the banking industry and fears that Microsoft and Pfizer are about to muscle in on its core medical market.

But, while Deutsche accepts that Misys cannot avoid the repercussions of a serious recession in the banking industry, it notes that its exposure is broadly spread and not focused on investment banking.

Furthermore, it takes the interest of Microsoft in the healthcare software market as an endorsement of its poten tial. Given these factors, Deutsche sees a price of 550p as appropriate for Misys.

Other strong tech performers included Spirent, up 29.25p to 364.25p, Logica, 43p higher at 919p and Dimension Data, 9.5p better at 305p.

Back among the blue chips, Deutsche Bank was exacting influence over another stock - BG. The shares of the gas exploration group fell 10p to 270p after Deutsche told its clients that its rating was unsustainable without a bid.

In the smaller companies' world, dealers noted with interest heavy trading in Mentmore Abbey. A couple of weeks ago the self-storage specialist warned on profits and saw more than £100m of its market value disappear. Dealers hear rumours that the fall has attracted the interest of a predator. Mentmore shares closed 1p higher at 118.5p

Computer games designer Eidos pushed up 10.75p to 194.75p.

On AIM, transport group Tolmount rose 12p to 34.5p on talk of a contract win, while computer systems group Baron Corp added 2p to 31.5p as rival Euro Systems Projects appeared on its share register with a 5.25% stake.

fields.headline: Lost in music
fields.standfirst: Miles Davis created some of the best-loved jazz of the past half-century. So why do we know so little about the man himself?  John Fordham  reports
fields.trailText: Miles Davis created some of the best-loved jazz of the past half-century. So why do we know so little about the man himself? John Fordham reports.
fields.body:
I never met the trumpeter who used to live near me a decade ago. But that sound of methodical practice, drifting across the gardens in the summer, was enhanced by the mystery of its source. It wasn't usually jazz; often it would be classical exercises: rounded, glossy chromatic scales, airy, teasing pirouettes in the upper register, stuttery tonguing routines like morse code.

Then Miles Davis went into a coma. It was the summer of 1991. The invisible player's music suddenly changed, to Davis's famous ballad sound of the 1950s, a vivid, personal approximation of his bruised poignancy, his tenderness with timbre, even a little of his graceful swing. And that summer, for months after Davis's final departure in September, trumpeters all over the world were undoubtedly doing the same thing.

But if the point about Davis had only been that trumpeters, or other jazz musicians, loved and appreciated his unique sound, he wouldn't have been the colossus of contemporary music he remains - nor the romantic hero he was for so many listeners.

Miles Davis is the best-known jazz musician of the past half-century, one of the few to become a household name. His most famous recording, Kind of Blue, has sold steadily for 40 years and still does, in numbers that go way beyond the cognoscenti. Trumpeter, author and educator Ian Carr, Davis's British biographer, recalls a 1980s Davis concert in which fans were reverently touching the superstar's garments, as if celestial bliss would be the next move for him and them alike. Davis inspired awe, respect, sometimes fury and frequently fear.

Carr and producer/director Mike Dibb are behind an unprecedented British television jazz profile - a two-and-a-half-hour account of Davis's life and times showing over two nights this weekend that catches his power and inspirational charisma without mystifying the process by which his music was made.

Davis, in extensive interviews from the later years, and in those early black-and-white photographs through which he developed an image as the epitome of hip, is examined with a candour unusual for jazz documentaries. Handsome as a bust carved from hardwood and driven for much of his life by an appetite for the edge that gave him ideas, glamour, damaged health and chaotic relationships, Davis was easily bored and so impatient with the familiar that (as Keith Jarrett observes in the film), he would rather have a bad band playing bad music than repeat himself.

One of the most fascinating conundrums of his life - that he appeared to be a domineering and egotistical man who was nonetheless one of the most open, experimental and collaborative of artists - is spotlit with rare clarity. Carr and Dibb have managed to expand the complex, contradictory picture of Davis in a manner never attempted before. They have done this by augmenting an A-list of famous former Davis musicians and riveting concert footage with long interviews with several of the women who were influential in the trumpeter's life (including his first girlfriend, Irene Cawthorn, who adds an affectionate, razor-sharp and distinctly un-bedazzled authenticity to the early St Louis years).

Carr and Dibb first had the idea 23 years ago, but a combination of mainstream TV indifference to jazz, Davis's long layoff with health problems in the late 1970s and a 10-year moratorium on Davis biopics to prolong the life of an American documentary delayed it until 1996.

Carr says the BBC still didn't want it then, but Channel 4 quickly committed itself to a budget appropriate for two and a half hours' duration, unprecedented for a British TV jazz documentary on an individual. The Miles Davis Estate, usually an expensive obstacle course for Davis's chroniclers, presented no difficulties. The late Davis's management, sold on Carr's plan from the start, smoothed the way at every turn.

"Apart from my love of his music as a listener and a player," says Carr, "I've always thought Miles's career was the obvious one to enlist in any attempt to get rid of the patronising, ignorant attitudes still surrounding jazz. He's the only one who ever dared to always do what he wanted to, and everything he did had quality. It wasn't just that he was an innovator: when you listen to Kind of Blue you're not noticing its structural radicalism, you just notice that it's beautiful."

Carr says that it is Davis's volatile, difficult, and sometimes downright forbidding personality that fascinates many of those interviewing him about the film, and the way it seems to represent the dark side of the extraordinary luminescence of his music. "I talked to Gil Evans about this," Carr says, "and he would say, 'Don't believe anything you read about Miles Davis, he's a sweet guy.' All right, that doesn't mean he couldn't be very nasty, too, but it was a protection thing. The more sensitive a person is, the more difficult it can be to get rid of things that aren't right, and sometimes you have to be blatantly rude.

"People are always asking me, 'Wasn't he a very selfish man?' I say it's irrelevant. If you want to do something 100%, you have to be focused, maybe selfish, otherwise it just goes off at half-cock. Within his vision, he was often kind. The guitarist John Scofield says that whenever he bawled the band out, he'd always come along later and say something encouraging."

Among many others, the guitarist John McLaughlin emphasises in the film how important relationships were to Davis's way of making music - Davis's daughter Cheryl goes as far as to say the relationship with music took priority over any other in his life. When Davis drew new constellations of musicians together, eventually young experimenters with little reputation, through whom he was putting his career on the line, he was looking for qualities he knew they had, even if he and they had no clear idea what those were until they flowered in the hothouse of the ensemble.

"McLaughlin pointed out that Miles had such impeccable intuition that when that thing happened he could recognise it at once," Carr explains. "Jazz is a collective activity. It doesn't matter that there isn't a single composer. But to me the real test of a great jazz musician is somebody who learns all the time. Miles Davis did. So did Duke Ellington. In the early 1950s, Miles took his drummer Philly Joe Jones to hear Ahmad Jamal. Jamal had no drummer that day, but his guitarist would hit the wood of the guitar with his thumb every fourth beat. Miles said to Philly Joe, 'You put a rimshot on every fourth beat, it'll swing like a motherfucker.' It became part of that band's special sound. That was typical of him - the antennae were always out."

Carr's most vivid personal memory of Davis dates back to the first edition of his book, and the 1984 interview he did then formed part of the second edition's considerable expansion. It was a point in Davis's life when his emotional and physical energies were on an upswing, and much of his unnerving inaccessibility was gone. "I asked him to sign my copy of the book," Carr recalls. "He did a drawing of a head with a trumpet, and wrote, 'To Ian the Great' underneath. Then he said, 'I haven't read it, but my wife has.'" Carr laughs uproariously.

"I was in Italy last week, giving a lecture about the film, and I played the track Generique from Miles's improvised score for the Louis Malle film Ascenseur Pour L'Echafaud. At the end, the audience applauded, as if he'd been there. Because it's just so beautiful, there's so much love and warmth coming out. What a contribution to humanity."

 The Miles Davis Story is on Channel 4 at 8.05pm on Saturday and 7.10pm on Sunday.

But that sound of methodical practice, drifting across the gardens in the summer, was enhanced by the mystery of its source. It wasn't usually jazz; often it would be classical exercises: rounded, glossy chromatic scales, airy, teasing pirouettes in the upper register, stuttery tonguing routines like morse code. Then Miles Davis went into a coma. It was the summer of 1991. The invisible player's music suddenly changed, to Davis's famous ballad sound of the 1950s, a vivid, personal approximation of his bruised poignancy, his tenderness with timbre, even a little of his graceful swing. And that summer, for months after Davis's final departure in September, trumpeters all over the world were undoubtedly doing the same thing. But if the point about Davis had only been that trumpeters, or other jazz musicians, loved and appreciated his unique sound, he wouldn't have been the colossus of contemporary music he remains - nor the romantic hero he was for so many listeners. Miles Davis is the best-known jazz musician of the past half-century, one of the few to become a household name. His most famous recording, Kind of Blue, has sold steadily for 40 years and still does, in numbers that go way beyond the cognoscenti. Trumpeter, author and educator Ian Carr, Davis's British biographer, recalls a 1980s Davis concert in which fans were reverently touching the superstar's garments, as if celestial bliss would be the next move for him and them alike. Davis inspired awe, respect, sometimes fury and frequently fear. Carr and producer/director Mike Dibb are behind an unprecedented British television jazz profile - a two-and-a-half-hour account of Davis's life and times showing over two nights this weekend that catches his power and inspirational charisma without mystifying the process by which his music was made. Davis, in extensive interviews from the later years, and in those early black-and-white photographs through which he developed an image as the epitome of hip, is examined with a candour unusual for jazz documentaries. Handsome as a bust carved from hardwood and driven for much of his life by an appetite for the edge that gave him ideas, glamour, damaged health and chaotic relationships, Davis was easily bored and so impatient with the familiar that (as Keith Jarrett observes in the film), he would rather have a bad band playing bad music than repeat himself. One of the most fascinating conundrums of his life - that he appeared to be a domineering and egotistical man who was nonetheless one of the most open, experimental and collaborative of artists - is spotlit with rare clarity. Carr and Dibb have managed to expand the complex, contradictory picture of Davis in a manner never attempted before. They have done this by augmenting an A-list of famous former Davis musicians and riveting concert footage with long interviews with several of the women who were influential in the trumpeter's life (including his first girlfriend, Irene Cawthorn, who adds an affectionate, razor-sharp and distinctly un-bedazzled authenticity to the early St Louis years). Carr and Dibb first had the idea 23 years ago, but a combination of mainstream TV indifference to jazz, Davis's long layoff with health problems in the late 1970s and a 10-year moratorium on Davis biopics to prolong the life of an American documentary delayed it until 1996. Carr says the BBC still didn't want it then, but Channel 4 quickly committed itself to a budget appropriate for two and a half hours' duration, unprecedented for a British TV jazz documentary on an individual. The Miles Davis Estate, usually an expensive obstacle course for Davis's chroniclers, presented no difficulties. The late Davis's management, sold on Carr's plan from the start, smoothed the way at every turn. "Apart from my love of his music as a listener and a player," says Carr, "I've always thought Miles's career was the obvious one to enlist in any attempt to get rid of the patronising, ignorant attitudes still surrounding jazz. He's the only one who ever dared to always do what he wanted to, and everything he did had quality. It wasn't just that he was an innovator: when you listen to Kind of Blue you're not noticing its structural radicalism, you just notice that it's beautiful." Carr says that it is Davis's volatile, difficult, and sometimes downright forbidding personality that fascinates many of those interviewing him about the film, and the way it seems to represent the dark side of the extraordinary luminescence of his music. "I talked to Gil Evans about this," Carr says, "and he would say, 'Don't believe anything you read about Miles Davis, he's a sweet guy.' All right, that doesn't mean he couldn't be very nasty, too, but it was a protection thing. The more sensitive a person is, the more difficult it can be to get rid of things that aren't right, and sometimes you have to be blatantly rude. "People are always asking me, 'Wasn't he a very selfish man?' I say it's irrelevant. If you want to do something 100%, you have to be focused, maybe selfish, otherwise it just goes off at half-cock. Within his vision, he was often kind. The guitarist John Scofield says that whenever he bawled the band out, he'd always come along later and say something encouraging." Among many others, the guitarist John McLaughlin emphasises in the film how important relationships were to Davis's way of making music - Davis's daughter Cheryl goes as far as to say the relationship with music took priority over any other in his life. When Davis drew new constellations of musicians together, eventually young experimenters with little reputation, through whom he was putting his career on the line, he was looking for qualities he knew they had, even if he and they had no clear idea what those were until they flowered in the hothouse of the ensemble. "McLaughlin pointed out that Miles had such impeccable intuition that when that thing happened he could recognise it at once," Carr explains. "Jazz is a collective activity. It doesn't matter that there isn't a single composer. But to me the real test of a great jazz musician is somebody who learns all the time. Miles Davis did. So did Duke Ellington. In the early 1950s, Miles took his drummer Philly Joe Jones to hear Ahmad Jamal. Jamal had no drummer that day, but his guitarist would hit the wood of the guitar with his thumb every fourth beat. Miles said to Philly Joe, 'You put a rimshot on every fourth beat, it'll swing like a motherfucker.' It became part of that band's special sound. That was typical of him - the antennae were always out." Carr's most vivid personal memory of Davis dates back to the first edition of his book, and the 1984 interview he did then formed part of the second edition's considerable expansion. It was a point in Davis's life when his emotional and physical energies were on an upswing, and much of his unnerving inaccessibility was gone. "I asked him to sign my copy of the book," Carr recalls. "He did a drawing of a head with a trumpet, and wrote, 'To Ian the Great' underneath. Then he said, 'I haven't read it, but my wife has.'" Carr laughs uproariously. "I was in Italy last week, giving a lecture about the film, and I played the track Generique from Miles's improvised score for the Louis Malle film Ascenseur Pour L'Echafaud. At the end, the audience applauded, as if he'd been there. Because it's just so beautiful, there's so much love and warmth coming out. What a contribution to humanity."  The Miles Davis Story is on Channel 4 at 8.05pm on Saturday and 7.10pm on Sunday.

webTitle: Arthur Smith on Spike Lee's Bamboozled

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Having already done Andy Williams and Leonard Cohen, I am wondering how to complete the "Arthur Smith Sings ..." trilogy.
fields.body:
Having already done Andy Williams and Leonard Cohen, I am wondering how to complete the "Arthur Smith Sings ..." trilogy. The Supremes seems an obvious choice and I have worked out a dynamic opening. A glitzy set, thumping music and disco lights presage the arrival at the microphone of two gorgeous black women in shimmering dresses. I join them in the middle as Diana Ross and we launch into a sensational version of Baby Love.

It has been pointed out that an ugly, white middle-aged man singing badly while dragged- and blacked-up may be offensive. I say it would be an ironic comment on the nature of racism, sexism and panto in the world of entertainment."Oh yeah, ironic," they agree.

The idea came to me when I read about Spike Lee's new film, Bamboozled, about a TV show with black entertainers singing, dancing and made up like the "coon" performers of yesteryear. Black people in showbiz has been a topical subject in Britain since it was shown how under-represented they are in TV, and since Greg Dyke described the BBC as being "hideously white".

The opening of Lee's film is entertaining and thought-provoking. The first audience to witness Man Tan: The Millennium Minstrel Show are appalled, bemused and uncertain how to react; then the "applause" and "howl" lights come on in the studio, and the show becomes a surprise hit, with audiences blacking up to watch recordings.

It has been said that the film loses focus as it goes on, and there are too many themes and distractions. But this is a complex issue and I applaud Spike Lee for not creating a fable with obvious Lessons to be Learnt. I left the cinema feeling uncomfortable, which is as it should be. What is Spike Lee saying? What am I supposed to think? Then I remembered the title of the film and became comfortable again in my bamboozlement. But I've decided to abandon the Supremes notion and am again considering the great Serge Gainsbourg.

fields.headline: Do I look like a one-hit wonder?
fields.standfirst: Shaggy tells  John Aizlewood how he managed to top Oh Carolina (even if it did take him seven years)
fields.trailText: Shaggy tells John Aizlewood how he managed to top Oh Carolina (even if it did take him seven years).
fields.body:
Back in March 1993 Shaggy's souped-up version of Oh Carolina spent a fortnight at number one and the smart money had it that he would turn out just as much of a one-hit wonder as fellow reggae artists Sugar Minott, Smiley Culture or Althia and Donna.

Eight years later Shaggy's latest single, It Wasn't Me, recently hit number one. In America, his fourth album, Hot Shot, has sold 6m copies. Not bad for a "singles" artist.

"Heh, heh," he chuckles in an accent that owes more to New York than his native Jamaica. "Not bad at all. I am the only international reggae artist right now. I'm the second biggest Jamaican artist, and I've sold more records than Bob Marley did in the same space of time."

Orville Burrell was raised in Ray Town, Kingston. His father was absent, though he has recently resurfaced ("We're not very close"). Puberty left the boy tall and skinny, with a haircut that was part hedge, part Afro. To his peers, this combination recalled Scooby Doo's cowardly chum Shaggy. "I hated that name until I came to England and discovered what 'shagger' means. Suddenly I liked it. These days, when chicks ask how I got my name, I say, 'It's because I'm a shagger - want me to shag you?' Heh, heh."

In 1986, aged 18, Shaggy moved to Brooklyn with his mother ("A very, very stern woman; I wish I had a closer relationship with her") and carved out a name for himself in dancehall, the hoarse-voiced reggae offshoot that spawned Buju Banton and Shabba Ranks. If, like Mampie, his singles sold 10,000 copies, they topped New York's reggae chart.

At 19, brimming with adolescent anger ("If I was going through an alley and saw two rough tough guys, I'd have my knife on me and walk straight in there - I was that stupid") he joined the Marines. "I swear to God I didn't know the Marines was the hardest service," he says. "I just wanted to get off the streets. I saw a Marines uniform and thought it looked really mean. The recruiting officer sold me a bunch of bullshit and I was in."

He got a sergeant's stripes, then lost them after taking a weekend off to record. Soon Private Burrell was helping save the western world during the Gulf war.

"I was a skater. In military terms that means you don't do shit - you skate out of everything. If a commanding officer came by I'd act like I was working, but I just sat in my Jeep and put my feet up. Jesus, they expected me to guard my post at 3am. Who the hell was gonna come for us in the middle of the goddamn night? Man, I was the worst Marine." Having defeated Saddam Hussein, Shaggy found himself working as a live DJ for Maxi Priest, whose Close To You was the first American number one by a British reggae act. In 1992 they went to Brazil.

"That was the turning point. I saw 30,000 people who didn't speak English singing along with his version of Wild World and I knew that's what I wanted. Maxi was criticised because he had this pop element, had seen the bigger picture and wanted it. Bob Marley was criticised for the same thing, and so am I right now."

Oh Carolina was a snapshot rather than the bigger picture. The follow-up, Soon Be Done, reached number 46 ("It was not given any love; I was blacklisted") and that seemed to be that. "But even today the fuel to my fire is negativity. The more negative you talk about Shaggy, the more I'm driven to prove you wrong. I had to make a record that was not only bigger than Oh Carolina but one I wrote myself. It was never a problem because I knew I was making musical history."

Two and a half years after Oh Carolina, Boombastic, helped by a jeans advertisement, reached number one in Britain. In America the album of the same name won a Grammy for the best reggae album and sold a million copies. Even so, in late 1997 Shaggy found himself without a label. "I received a letter saying I was not on Virgin any more. I never saw that curve ball coming; it shattered my ego and self-esteem."

He eventually got another record deal, with MCA - and then his album Hot Shot failed to reach the US Top 100. "Everyone thought I was dead," he sighs.

Then, last autumn, a Honolulu radio DJ began playing It Wasn't Me, a cheeky duet from Hot Shot with Ricardo "RikRok" Ducent. The word spread and soon it was an American number one, receiving a record 8,000 radio plays in one week. In Britain, six years after Boombastic, It Wasn't Me became Shaggy's third chart topper. Hot Shot has been relaunched and another American number one, Angel is yet to come. This time, surely, there will be no calamity. "I'll stay around. I've got a label that believes in me - I'm the biggest seller MCA have right now. I was viewed as a singles artist and needed to prove I was an albums artist. I've done just that."

With the new success have come the brickbats. There have been rumours of over-zealous management ("My manager is a product of the streets, as I am, but he's not Mafia- or don-connected. He's just a stern person and a very good businessman") and suggestions of a casual attitude towards women. "Shaggy makes making-baby music," he claims, "but I set a good sexual example. I don't sing about safe sex because that should be second nature. It's like going on the telephone. You can't communicate without a cellphone nowadays; you can't have sex without a condom. I've always written very positive songs about women. Angel is a great song for the ladies. There could be no bigger compliment than saying you're my angel."

He looks to the future with confidence. "Everything is in my favour now. Shaggy has weathered all storms and is in a category with no one else. Whenever I go back to Jamaica, it's huge respect because I've survived. I feel life is unfair, because I've gotten so much."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Leakey sued in Kenya court
fields.body:
Leakey sued in Kenya court

The distinguished palaeontologist Richard Leakey is being sued in a Kenyan court for allegedly intervening, when head of the Kenyan civil service, to halt a criminal case.

John Nottingham, the British-born owner of a failed flower-growing business, claims that Mr Leakey abused his office by halting the prosecution of four men accused of defrauding the company. Mr Leakey, former head of the Kenyan wildlife service, was a cabinet minister and head of the civil service from July 1999 until his resignation last month.
AP, Nairobi

Bus plunge kills 29 in S Africa

An overloaded bus plunged 70 metres (230ft) down an embankment in South Africa yesterday, killing 29 people, including seven children.

The accident happened between Franklin and Kokstad, 300 miles south of Johannesburg. Sixty-one people were hurt, 20 seriously.
AP, Franklin

£5bn to banish chemical arms

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, sought help yesterday with the £5bn cost of destroying the country's chemical weapons.

The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons in the Hague said Mr Ivanov's visit showed that Russia wanted to cut the stockpile, but it had hoped for more details.
AP, the Hague

LA favours Latino mayor

Los Angeles moved closer to electing its first Latino mayor since 1872 when Antonio Villaraigosa took 30% of the first round votes. He will compete on June 5 against his fellow Democrat James Hahn.
Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

webTitle: Art show in Siberian corpse inquiry

fields.headline: Art show in Siberian corpse inquiry
fields.trailText: The Russian police are investigating how 54 corpses and 440 brains were removed from a medical school in Siberia and illegally transported to a controversial embalming institute in Germany.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
The Russian police are investigating how 54 corpses and 440 brains were removed from a medical school in Siberia and illegally transported to a controversial embalming institute in Germany.

There is concern that some of the bodies from the Novosibirsk medical academy may have ended up as human sculptures in a German anatomist's exhibition of preserved corpses in Berlin.

Gunther von Hagens' Bodyworld exhibition comprises dead bodies that have been skinned, dissected and positioned in lifelike poses. They are preserved using his "plastination" technique, in which body fluids are replaced by synthetic resins.

The removed Russian corpses and limbs are believed to belong to prisoners and homeless and mentally ill Russians whose remains were unclaimed after they died.

The Siberian serious crimes division was alerted to the case when customs officials noticed a load of human remains being exported in suspicious circumstances late last year.

The police discovered that there had been regular shipments of apparently unwanted human remains from the city's medical academy to Professor Hagens' Institute for Plastination in Heidelberg since 1999.

The directors of 14 medical organisations in the city, including psychiatric hospitals and retirement homes, are under investigation. No charges have been brought so far.

Anatoly Efremov, director of the medical school, said that his institute was taking part in research into the embalming techniques used in the Heidelberg institute. Under Russian law, unclaimed corpses can be used for medical research.

Professor von Hagens says all the corpses are awaiting plastination in his Heidelberg centre, and he denies breaking the law.

"They were fixed with formaldehyde and had already been classed as anatomical specimens," he said.

"Adhering to my policy that I should never receive money for specimens, no money changed hands, and I only paid for the shipment costs."

Novosibirsk residents were dismayed by a television report about the Bodyworld exhibition broadcast earlier this week.

Tattoos in cyrillic script were clearly visible on one of the exhibits.

Professor von Hagens said there were no Russian bodies in his exhibition, and that the tattooed body belonged to a German citizen, whom he had known personally.

He conceded that the scandal aroused by the Russian bodies was damaging.

"If this continues, I'm seri ously considering sending the bodies back," he said.

A bit of controversy is good for my exhibition, but not anything that damages the reputation of anatomy."

The Novosibirsk police are trying to uncover the nature of the agreement signed by the city's medical school and the Plastination Institute.

Representatives of all the medical institutes under investigation have denied breaking the law, but have refused to make any further comment.

"We are investigating the role played by the director of the medical school, which violated federal law on burial," a spokeswoman for the Novosibirsk prosecutors' office, Natalya Markassova, said yesterday.

Professor von Hagens invented plastination 20 years ago, replacing bodily fluids with silicone after death to preserve the corpses in a lifelike way.

Since the late 1990s he has displayed his plastinated specimens, including foetuses, pregnant women, and a horse, in the Bodyworld exhibition.

The exhibition is due to move to London early next year. It has already toured Germany, Japan and Austria.

The professor says that all the bodies in the exhibition were donated, and that 3,600 people have signed away their bodies to be plastinated after death.

The illegal trade in human organs is a growing problem in Russia.

Last year investigators in Siberia opened a criminal case against a forensic expert accused of stealing more than 1,000 pituitary glands from corpses and selling them abroad; the gland produces growth hormone and can be used in the treatment of people with growth defects.

A grandmother was arrested in southern Russia in October as she tried to sell her five-year-old grandson to a man who planned to take him to the west to have key organs removed and sold.

Since the late 1990s he has displayed his plastinated specimens, including foetuses, pregnant women, and a horse, in the Bodyworld exhibition. The exhibition is due to move to London early next year. It has already toured Germany, Japan and Austria. The professor says that all the bodies in the exhibition were donated, and that 3,600 people have signed away their bodies to be plastinated after death. The illegal trade in human organs is a growing problem in Russia. Last year investigators in Siberia opened a criminal case against a forensic expert accused of stealing more than 1,000 pituitary glands from corpses and selling them abroad; the gland produces growth hormone and can be used in the treatment of people with growth defects. A grandmother was arrested in southern Russia in October as she tried to sell her five-year-old grandson to a man who planned to take him to the west to have key organs removed and sold.

fields.headline: Activists burn off-roaders
fields.trailText: Radical environmentalists have set fire to four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicles (SUVs), worth about £1m at a dealership in Eugene, Oregon.
fields.body:
Radical environmentalists have set fire to four-wheel-drive sport utility vehicles (SUVs), worth about £1m at a dealership in Eugene, Oregon.

It is the latest arson attack by environmentalists, who have now destroyed property worth about $50m (£35m) in the US.

An anonymous communique issued yesterday through the North American press office of the Earth Liberation Front (ELF) claimed responsibility for the night-time attack, in which 30 vehicles were destroyed.

It said: "Gas-guzzling SUVs are at the forefront of this vile, imperialistic culture's caravan towards self-destruction.

"We can no longer allow the rich to parade around in their armoured existence, leaving a wasteland behind in their tyre tracks. The time is right to fight back."

The same company, Romania Chevrolet, was attacked in June last year, for which two people have been arrested.

The communique also referred to those arrests.

"The techno-industrial state thinks it can stop the growing resistance by jailing some of us but they cannot jail the spirit of those who know that an other world is possible," it said.

A company spokesman said yesterday that it had received no warning before the attack.

SUVs are particularly disliked by environmentalists because they use a lot of petrol and can cause damage when driven off-road.

The sporting goods company Nike, which is based in Oregon, has attacked the ELF, which claimed responsibility for an attempt to burn down one of its shops in a mall in Albertville, Minnesota, last week. It called on other anti-globalisation groups to condemn the attack.

fields.headline: Mass protest at economic mismanagement
fields.trailText: Protest rallies have been banned in the Turkish capital after the biggest demonstration since the currency plunged in February.
fields.body:
Protest rallies have been banned in the Turkish capital after the biggest demonstration since the currency plunged in February.

Thousands of protesters clashed with the police and more than 200 were injured yesterday at a rally in the main square to demand the resignation of the government, blamed by many for Turkey's financial crisis.

The police fired in the air and used water cannon and teargas to break up the crowd of more than 70,000 after some demonstrators threw stones, bricks and pieces of wood at them, and tore up large paving stones for barricades.

One group, most of them shop owners, used a truck to ram a police armoured personnel carrier.

Many officers hid behind armoured vehicles. Paramilitary police were called in as reinforcements, but then withdrawn. Officials accused Islamic groups of infiltrating the protests to stir up trouble.

The lira has fallen by more than 40%, interest rates have soared, and about 500,000 people have been laid off work. One shopowner at the rally, Salih Erdogu, said these things had forced him to declare bankruptcy.

"I had five workers with me. They are all jobless now and so am I. I am ashamed of this," Mr Erdogu said, tears rolling down his face.

In the Aegean city of Izmir at least 40,000 people marched and shopkeepers supported the protest by staying closed. About 20,000 people marched in the central Anatolian city of Konya.

Critics have pointed to the government's reluctance to make structural reforms in the banking sector and key state companies as the main cause of the crisis.

But the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said yester day that his government had no plans to leave office.

"If they are shouting, resign, they also have to provide an alternative. I am not glued to my chair," he said.

In the current parliament there are few alternatives to his three-party coalition.

On Tuesday the biggest business group, the Turkish Union of Chambers, representing about 1m companies, said the government should go, having lost the people's trust. AP

webTitle: New eco-tax awaits tourist legions in Majorca and Ibiza

fields.headline: New eco-tax awaits tourist legions in Majorca and Ibiza
fields.trailText: Holidaymakers visiting Majorca, Ibiza and Menorca are to be forced to pay a "green tax" to help repair the damage done to the Spanish islands by 30 years of mass tourism.
fields.body:
Holidaymakers visiting Majorca, Ibiza and Menorca are to be forced to pay a "green tax" to help repair the damage done to the Spanish islands by 30 years of mass tourism.

The tax was approved by the Balearic islands' regional government on Tuesday, ignoring opposition from the national government in Madrid and warnings from British tour operators that the extra cost would deter visitors.

Island hoteliers too are afraid that some of the 4m British tourists who visit each year will head for Turkey or Tunisia instead - though for visitors staying at campsites the tax will be just over £1 a week for each person: 0.25 euros or 15p a night.

The money will go into an ecological fighting fund being set up by the regional government. The islanders want to raise £40m a year for their green war chest, though they have not said exactly what it will be spent on.

The tax will be added to bills at hotels, villas, apartments and camp sites. At the other end of the scale, wealthier visitors staying at five-star hotels will each have to pay two euros a night: £8.68 a week at current exchange rates.

The Balearic islands helped to invent package tourism and the grim beachside concrete jungles its legions inhabit.

In recent years, however, the island authorities have started demolishing some of the worst eyesores.

Tourism accounts for 85% of the regional income. It has raised the standard of living of islanders above the European average.

But there is growing impatience with this huge invasion. German and British people buy almost half the property for sale on the islands, forcing up prices. Then they form their own national ghettos.

In recent years there have even been protest marches in the islands' capital, Palma, against the annual influx and its effects.

Spain as a whole is the third-ranking tourist destination in the world, after France and the US. Each year 48m visitors pour into the country.

Celesti Alomar, the regional government's tourism minister, said the Balearic islands were tiring of cheap, destruc tive tourism. "We have to compete now with quality and that means protecting and restoring the environment and countryside," he said.

Hotel owners are furious about the tax.

"This is an insult," said Pere Canellas, head of the Majorca Hotel Owners Federation.

The industry also argues that the tax is unfair in excluding visitors staying in private homes.

The Spanish government, led by the centre-right Popular party, is also an opponent to the tax.

The tax minister, Cristobal Montoro, said Madrid planned to challenge the measure in the constitutional court.

Other holiday regions in Spain have said they will not follow the example of the Balearics in taxing visitors. The Canary islands, however, say they are looking for ways to raise money to restore and protect the environment.

fields.headline: Schoolboy shot in head in dawn attack on family
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Police in Buckinghamshire are hunting two armed men after a 15-year-old boy was shot and critically injured in a dawn attack that also left his older twin brothers with serious gunshot wounds.
fields.body:
Police in Buckinghamshire are hunting two armed men after a 15-year-old boy was shot and critically injured in a dawn attack that also left his older twin brothers with serious gunshot wounds.

Jahangir Khan was shot in the head and neck outside his home in High Wycombe, just before 6am yesterday, after a dispute with other youths.

His brothers, Shokat and Azad, both 21, received arm, chest and neck injuries after chasing the boy's attackers down an alley. The gunmen made their escape by car.

Police said the attack took place after a row, a few hours earlier, between the family and another group of youths.

Mushtaq Khan, a father of eight, bundled his sons into a car immediately after the shooting and took them to Wycombe general hospital. The schoolboy was later transferred to a specialist unit at the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford, where his condition yesterday was described as "very serious", and deteriorating.

"His condition does not look good and we are very concerned for his welfare," said Detective Superintendent Trevor Davies, who is leading the investigation for Thames Valley police.

His brothers' injuries were described as "serious but not life threatening". Last night their condition was stable.

A long curved sword was also found at the scene, which yesterday was sealed off and being examined by dozens of forensic officers.

Det Supt Davies said an altercation had taken place outside the house between 2am and 3am. A number of men returned to the house at around 6am, he said, when the schoolboy was attacked. Two Asian men are being sought .

"We have not been able to establish a motive as yet and we need that to give the investigation some direction," he said, adding: "We don't want people running around the streets of High Wycombe discharging firearms."

Police sealed off the area and neighbours wanting to leave the street were escorted by armed officers wearing flak jackets. One neighbour, who did not want to be named, said: "We were awoken with a jolt by this loud bang, and then we heard terrible screams. I looked out the window and saw this little boy lying in the middle of the road."

Mohammed Saleem, another neighbour, said he had heard three shots, one on its own followed by two others in quick succession.

fields.headline: A face in the crowd
fields.standfirst: The Burren, Ireland
fields.trailText: The Burren, Ireland.
fields.body:
Kilometres of arcades with mosaic or tiled floors, some with ceilings of paintings: we were in Bologna, Italy. Such a gracious city, younger people giving us their bus seats, and faces in the crowd from the Italian Masters: Caravaggio, da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael. And again, in Ravenna, to notice a face similar to one in the beautiful mosaics of San Appolinaris in Classe is to be transported back not only to the sixth century but also to the 1960s when I first visited this magnificent church, having walked from Ravenna - I had little money.

On my return, a farmer and his wife gave me a lift. I sat among straw in their Cinquecento exclaiming, "Bellissima Italia", in an atmosphere of infinite goodwill. The church then rose out of seemingly limitless green fields. There were but four other people gazing at... paradise. To visit Italy always makes me aware and proud of our European heritage. To return to England is to see faces from The National Portrait Gallery in London's streets. To come back to the Burren is to see faces from the Book Of Kells, Jack Yeats, O'Conor, Lavery. What a fullness of ages in faces!

This morning, furze, daffodils and primroses tumble in the gale. The mist rises, disappears and the sun strikes beauty from limestone, sea and fields. Forbidden fields now that we are trying to limit foot and mouth disease to the one case in the north-east of the Republic. We are still able to walk the Flaggy Shore, the lanes and public roads, while blackthorn blooms in hedge and field. Brent geese are plentiful - I counted 20 in Ballyvaughan Harbour. We are lucky that they spread "gray wings" on "every tide" (Yeats).

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Jamie Oliver

fields.headline: No 1857
fields.standfirst: Jamie Oliver
fields.trailText: Jamie Oliver.
fields.body:
Oh, him. He works down my local supermarket. Cheese counter. Are you sure?

Oh yes, I'd swear blind I've seen him slicing the crumbly Lancs. Actually, that's the decidedly tasty Jamie Oliver of television cookery fame and mopedic repute.

Blimey! Is it? I saw his show the other day. Him and some mates went off in this camper van and ate some mozzarella. Turns out, when he gets back home - would you Adam-and-Eve-it? - he can only get the bleedin' stuff down at his local Safeway! Sainsbury's.

Whatever. I think you'll find that the buffalo adventure was an advert for Sainsbury's supermarkets. His cookery show is on BBC2.

But I tuned in specially! Yes, it was an easy mistake to make. Sainsbury's has been screening its ads at the same time as Jamie's Naked Chef-ing over on the Beeb, contravening the rules of his £1m deal.

The cheeky beggars. It was an accident ...

That's what they all say. That's what Professor Plum said when they caught him red-handed with the lead-piping in the conservatory. No, it seems it was a genuine error. Sainsbury's claims that BBC2 didn't send it its schedules 10 weeks in advance.

Ah-ha! The plot thickens. Yes, using Sainsbury's own-brand cornflour, 69p, I'll wager.

Are you suggesting there has been a spot of product placement going on? Sort of - the Beeb has complained that the kitchen in the supermarket ads is eerily similar to the one in Jamie's show ...

He seems a likeable lad to me. To everyone. In a Radio 5 Live phone-in, Jamie came out top to be president, if the monarchy was abolished.

Really? What was his manifesto? Free wok-cooked fragrant mussels for all. Followed by seafood risotto and then steamed chocolate pudding.

Take me to the polling station!

fields.headline: It's a sick world
fields.trailText: A & E | ER | Animal Hospital
fields.body:
Right! Everyone sit up and pay attention. You're not in Teachers now.

What we have here are two hospital dramas, A & E (ITV) and ER (Channel 4). Try not to confuse the two. And try to get out of the way fast as the trolleys thunder through.

A & E - formerly known as Always And Everyone but that made things too easy - has an entertaining double act in Michael Kitchen and Martin Shaw, playing surgeons. Two serious actors though, of course, not at their most serious here. Shaw gazes benevolently over his spectacles and Kitchen twinkles wickedly over his mask. As Lord Olivier used to say, "It's all in the eyes, dear boy." Admire their acting as they both pretend to smoke. It takes years to perfect that sort of aplomb.

Actresses in flight from soaps seem to drift into nursing so, for our younger viewers, there is the arrival of Leanne Battersby from Coronation Street (Jane Danson) as the sort of nurse who makes you feel nervous.

ER is a superior product. It is American and it helps if you can appreciate Dr Greene's Dr Seuss joke as he makes breakfast ("Greene's eggs and ham") or understand the crucial difference, in terms of falling down in the street, between Thanksgiving turkey and Wild Turkey. The writers don't seem quite as clued up about Britain as they might be. Dr Corday, played by British actress Alex Kingston, was having an uncomfortable meeting with the hospital manager. She confided that a paralysed patient was suing her for malpractice. He confided right back, "When his lawyers get through with you, you'll be lucky if you're slinging fish and chips back in England." Saying which, he crunched a handful of pills like peanuts and pushed off. But then he had a blonde waiting.

This gave me such pause for thought that I lost several yards of the plot. I know it is traditionally American to sling hash, whatever hash may be. Perhaps you can also sling a hamburger, skimming it like a frisbee from pan to plate. But fish and chips are, I would suggest, virtually impossible to sling. Admittedly, in Coronation Street this week Eileen Grimshaw threw three bags of chips at Dennis, her lodger-cum-lover, and hit the target every time, but personally I would describe her action more as a slow leg break.

This ER was a Thanksgiving episode and we can only be grateful over here that we have nothing to be thankful for. Dr Greene discovered he has a brain tumour, Dr Corday found out she was pregnant, you couldn't move for mothers, and the weather was just terrible. Oh, and the hospital exploded, like an acetylene torch, in tongues of fire. It is symptomatic of the pace and noise of ER that you'd forget a little thing like that.

On balance, I would rather go into Animal Hospital (BBC 1) than either A & E or ER. There is, admittedly, the risk of being neutered, but there is also Rolf Harris, ever on hand, who will call me a good girl and stroke my bottom.

One man brought in a sick puppy. "I said I'll never have another bitch. I had my last bitch for 14 years. That were the hardest day of my life wi' no doubt because we'd done everything together that bitch and me. But this one comes along and you can't resist 'em." You will be pleased to hear his puppy pulled through. There is more love going begging here than in most TV dramas.

Except The Cops (BBC 2). The exceptional Cops is the exception to everything. In this episode three people are half mad with love and loss, two of them policemen. Roy (John Henshaw), whose wife has died, is stunned but still standing like a poleaxed ox. When Shona, a deranged girl, stabs her rival screaming, "She's dead!", the words bounce off his big, bemused, bereaved face. Colin's wife has, rather understandably, left him. I was, I fear, very tickled by Colin's complaint, "I joined this job for the camaraderie but no fucker likes me."

A & E - formerly known as Always And Everyone but that made things too easy - has an entertaining double act in Michael Kitchen and Martin Shaw, playing surgeons. Two serious actors though, of course, not at their most serious here. Shaw gazes benevolently over his spectacles and Kitchen twinkles wickedly over his mask. As Lord Olivier used to say, "It's all in the eyes, dear boy." Admire their acting as they both pretend to smoke. It takes years to perfect that sort of aplomb. Actresses in flight from soaps seem to drift into nursing so, for our younger viewers, there is the arrival of Leanne Battersby from Coronation Street (Jane Danson) as the sort of nurse who makes you feel nervous. It is American and it helps if you can appreciate Dr Greene's Dr Seuss joke as he makes breakfast ("Greene's eggs and ham") or understand the crucial difference, in terms of falling down in the street, between Thanksgiving turkey and Wild Turkey. She confided that a paralysed patient was suing her for malpractice. He confided right back, "When his lawyers get through with you, you'll be lucky if you're slinging fish and chips back in England." Saying which, he crunched a handful of pills like peanuts and pushed off. But then he had a blonde waiting. This gave me such pause for thought that I lost several yards of the plot. fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | The Material World | Costing The Earth
fields.body:
Olenka Frenkiel reports for Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) on an unfortunate row which has erupted around some child survivors of Rwanda's 1994 massacres. In an effort to find them a safe haven, the were taken from their African orphanage to foster homes in Italy. Many have been adopted by local families and are formally regarded as Italian citizens. The Rwandan government, however, is preparing court proceedings to have them returned to relatives in a country of which they have little or no memory.

Quentin Cooper follows biblical advice in The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) and considers the ant. Some 8,000 species have been around since the dawn of time. They are industrious enough on their own behalf but they also sustain around 100,000 other species. One unexpected client is the Large Blue butterfly, a variety which breathed its last in Britain 20 years ago. Entomologists trying to reintroduce it have discovered they can't succeed without the help of one species of red ant.

In the new series of Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4) Alex Kirby plunges into the foot-and-mouth crisis. Whoever started it, there is no doubt that someone broke the rules. Officials responsible for food safety and environmental regulation say they have insufficient power to put bad farmers out of business. Many think it is time to ban farmers lacking an official licence.
