What's more, you haven't fallen apart. Of course, some women do. Some women don't age well. They haven't grown and it's more to do with intelligence than about the way they look. But I love post-40. It's the time when so many women seem to hatch like new-born chicks. (So Goldie Hawn at fiftysomething does look like a fluffy chick.) They break open the shell. They crawl out. They get stronger, brighter, bolder. Men, conversely, get drabber, more predictable, less interesting. The married women I know started reappraising their lives. Took jobs, degrees, retrained. They also started confessing about sex. Especially after the divorces. "You go through the baby years when you don't sleep, the early school years when you're a chauffeur, the awful teenage years when you're worried sick about your kids' futures. You're busy and tired all the time, you get into bed and you go to sleep. If you're married to a professional man, you know he's rarely home before 8 o'clock," says my 52-year-old friend Barbara. "I was far less confident before I got divorced," she adds. "Post-divorce sex is terrifying to contemplate. Just so frightening. But if you find the right man - and I did - it's magical, simply magical. He made me feel so calm and confident. Told me I had the best body he'd ever seen. I think the pleasure is more intense as you get older." But sometimes when the kids have finally flown the nest and there are no more boys bringing home friends and washing on weekends, then couples rediscover each other. I know of two couples having great sex after 32 years, the woman in one case feeling and looking "better than ever". There are flowers, romantic restaurants for dinner, weekends away. It's no good asking if sex gets better. It obviously depends who you are and who you're with, and if you liked sex in the first place. And what if you're 45, 50-plus, with a husband who jabs you with his elbow in the small of your back and demands sex just when you're trying to get to doze off? "Look," said another friend, Suzie, "you either do it in your sleep, which takes a bit of experience, or you say, get off. It's not life-threateningly serious. He's just a man." Of course, if he does it too often and there's no foreplay and no postcoital conversation, then you should pack up and leave. But I've known women who don't. Some women can't. Celibate marriages? Britain is bristling with them. But it's rarely talked about. So what is one supposed to make of that? If you don't mind, it doesn't matter. As long as you both don't mind. Of course I have 50-plus friends in celibate marriages who have very good sex lives. With Other People. They wink and grin quite often and do amazing teenage things in the backs of cars parked in dimly lit Notting Hill streets. It all gets so much easier when you disentangle sex from love. When you don't act as if the man owes you something. You attach yourself from a position of detachment. You have a man because you desire him. Not because you need him. God knows that takes years. And years. But so many of my friends have married in their 40s and 50s. It was all easy as Sunday morning stuff. No pain, no strain involved in getting the men to commit. No shyness now. "So you have a bit of flab and he doesn't always get an erection. So what? You just laugh about it. I just love my sex life these days," says my friend Joanne, who's 54. What can I confess, as one who has stayed single and talks detachment? I look across the gardens now as the sunlight streams into my perfect living room and I think the last thing I need is a man "to take me away from all this". That would be dreadful. It's taken me blood, sweat and tears to get here, and I'm happy. Listen, for a woman, life and sex as you get older is a bit like the Grand National. If you didn't fall at the first few hurdles and you're still hanging on in there and giving good race when you're two-thirds of the way round - well, I tell you, it's just great. It's the ride of a life, even though it goes by so fast. More people than you dreamed of seem to be rooting for you. Whatever happens at this point, you feel like a winner. Who'd have thought it? Not me when I was young.

fields.headline: Drugs not genes cause birth defects in babies of epileptic women
fields.trailText: Birth defects in the babies of women who take medicine for epilepsy while they are pregnant are caused by the drugs and not by the epilepsy, according to new research reported in the US.
fields.body:
Birth defects in the babies of women who take medicine for epilepsy while they are pregnant are caused by the drugs and not by the epilepsy, according to new research reported in the US.

The study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine today, claims that the idea that the genetic abnormalities which cause the epilepsy are then passed on to the foetus, is wrong.

Lewis B Holmes and his colleagues from the paediatric service of Massachusetts general hospital, in Boston, say it is the medication which is to blame for the children's defects.

Since the 1970s it has been recognised that women taking the drugs most frequently given to prevent epileptic fits, have a higher risk than usual of giving birth to babies with certain malformations, such as abnormalities of the face and fingers, and retarded growth.

The Massachusetts team examined 316 babies born to women who had taken anticonvulsant drugs during pregnancy and 98 babies of women with a history of epilepsy who had not had the medication.

They compared the babies with 508 other babies whose mothers did not have epilepsy and had not taken medication while pregnant.

They found that the babies of women who had taken drugs for epilepsy had a much higher rate of birth defects - 20.6% of infants exposed to one drug, and 28% of infants exposed to two or more drugs in the womb. This figure compared with 8.5% of those having birth defects and mothers who had taken nothing.

Women with epilepsy who had not taken drugs in pregnancy were no more likely to have a baby with birth defects than women who had no history of the disease.

The research poses a big dilemma for women with epilepsy, as stopping the medication would put some women and their unborn babies at risk of damage from seizures.

A spokeswoman for the British Epilepsy Association said it might not always occur to GPs to raise the issue with their female patients. "But it is really important for all women with epilepsy who are planning a family to go and seek specialist advice beforehand so that the medication can be looked at and then possibly changed," she said.

webTitle: Hoax trip 'led to man killing his daughter'

fields.headline: Hoax trip 'led to man killing his daughter'
fields.trailText: A computer firm's employees are being investigated over an alleged "dirty tricks" campaign which may have prompted a businessman to kill his 12-year-old daughter.
fields.body:
A computer firm's employees are being investigated over an alleged "dirty tricks" campaign which may have prompted a businessman to kill his 12-year-old daughter.

Marketing manager Phillip Hall, who had a history of mental problems, stabbed his daughter Emma with a carving knife after returning from a business trip to India last June.

He was allegedly duped by a series of hoax emails emanating from a rival computer company, Cardiff-based AB Biomonitoring, into flying to New Delhi to meet a non-existent customer.

The stress of the wasted trip caused Hall's illness to worsen, and he became convinced that he had to kill his own family and commit suicide to save 15 other families from death.

Hall, of Whitelye, Gwent, was found not guilty of Emma's murder due to insanity at Swansea crown court last December. He was ordered to be detained indefinitely at a secure psychiatric hospital.

Gwent police confirmed yesterday that detectives are investigating the dirty tricks allegations aired at Hall's trial and have interviewed employees of AB Biomonitoring.

Employees of the firm could now face an allegation of forgery and the rare charge of causing actual bodily harm to Hall via the internet - the harm being mental rather than physical trauma.

If a prosecution is brought, it could be a landmark case. A spokesman said the Home Office was not aware of such a charge having been brought previously. "Our view is that the law of the land applies equally online as it does offline. It would apply whether the internet was used, or phone calls or letters."

Hall was working for Molecular Light Technology, a firm which makes computer equipment for testing the health and meat quality of livestock.

The purpose of his trip to India was to market a device that tested cattle for benzene contamination.

Psychiatrists testified at his trial that Hall had been diagnosed as a chronic paranoid schizophrenic who suffered from profound delusions.

His first signs of delusional behaviour, the court was told, began when he went to the US briefly to work in 1992. He later claimed he had made a profound discovery - that he was Jesus Christ. However, he made progress with his career despite spending time in psychiatric hospitals.

Prosecution counsel Neil Bidder QC told the court: "The trip was an elaborate hoax perpetrated on Mr Hall and his company by employees of another company.

"They sent phoney emails and the result was a wholly unnecessary and expensive trip to meet a potential customer in Delhi."

A Gwent police spokeswoman said the inquiry was continuing and a file had not yet been sent to the crown prosecution service, which will make a decision on whether to bring anyone to court.

A spokesman for AB Biomonitoring confirmed that the firm had cooperated with police.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Seven bailed in mob killing case
fields.body:
Seven bailed in mob killing case

Seven people who were arrested in connection with the murder of Robert Hamill, a Catholic who was kicked to death by a loyalist mob in Portadown, Co Armagh, in 1997, have been released on police bail. The seven, including a Royal Ulster Constabulary reserve constable, were detained on Tuesday on the orders of the Northern Ireland police ombudsman.

'Rape victim' 86, dies

An 86-year-old woman who was allegedly raped at her home in Trefnant, Denbighshire, has died in hospital. A 23-year-old man has been charged with rape, causing grievous bodily harm and arson.

School death teacher appeals

A teacher convicted of the manslaughter of a 13-year-old-girl on a school trip to France is to appeal against his sentence. Mark Duckworth, who teaches in Leeds, was supervising pupils on a visit to Le Touquet in 1999 when Gemma Carter drowned while bathing in the sea. He was given a six-month suspended prison sentence by a judge in Boulogne who found him guilty of involuntary homicide, the French equivalent of manslaughter.

'Belly flop' assault

Andrew Baldry, 32, a 23-stone meat factory worker in Beccles, Suffolk, was warned yesterday that he faced jail for doing a belly flop on a colleague as three other workers held the victim down. Baldry denied assault causing actual bodily harm but was found guilty at Ipswich crown court and will be sentenced at a later date.

McCutcheon set for return

Former EastEnders star Martine McCutcheon will go back into rehearsals for her starring role in the West End hit My Fair Lady today. She has been out of action for three weeks because of throat and blood clotting problems.

fields.headline: Forsyte Saga star dies at 61
fields.trailText: Nyree Dawn Porter, the actor best remembered for her role in the 1960s TV drama, The Forsyte Saga, has died at her London home, aged 61.
fields.body:
Nyree Dawn Porter, the actor best remembered for her role in the 1960s TV drama, The Forsyte Saga, has died at her London home, aged 61.

The cause of the New Zealand born actor's death on Tuesday was not immeditaely known, and a spokesman for her agent said it had come as a great shock to colleagues, friends and family.

She was awarded an OBE in 1971 and starred in programmes such as Madame Bovary and the 1980 drama For Maddie With Love. But she is best remembered playing Irene in the 1967 television phenomenon The Forsyte Saga, which followed the lives of a well-connected Victorian family, and had a worldwide audience of 160m.

Porter, who turned down the lead role in the hit TV series The Avengers, married actor Bryon O'Leary, who died of a drugs overdose in 1970. Three years later she married actor Robin Halstead. They divorced in 1987. She leaves a daughter, Talya.

Yesterday Alan Yentob, BBC director of drama, entertainment and children's television, said: "Nyree Dawn Porter was one of the earliest stars of television drama. Her performances, most famously in the Forsyte Saga and Madame Bovary, gripped a generation of viewers."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Prison siege ended
fields.body:
Prison siege ended

A siege at Wakefield prison ended yesterday morning when staff overpowered a male inmate who had held a woman prison officer hostage for 13 hours.

Met's 89% clear-up rate

The Metropolitan police brought charges in 89% of murder inquiries in the year to March, new figures show. There were 189 homicides and people were charged in 170 cases.

Tube chief quits

Derek Smith, 52, yesterday quit as London Underground's chairman and managing director. He is to become chief executive of the Hammersmith Hospitals NHS Trust in October.

Woman crushed to death by bull

A woman, 50, died after being crushed by a bull in Lostwithiel, Cornwall. Police said: "She was showing it to a prospective buyer when she fell and was stepped on."

Shipman inquiry date

A public inquiry into the activities of the serial killer Harold Shipman will begin in Manchester in June.

Cantona puppet nets £4,000

The Spitting Image puppet of ex-Manchester United player Eric Cantona was yesterday sold for £4,000 at an auction of footballing memorabilia.

webTitle: QC list sparks 'jobs for boys' row

fields.headline: QC list sparks 'jobs for boys' row
fields.trailText: Two barristers from the lord chancellor's former chambers have become QCs in this year's batch of 77 lawyers granted the right to put the coveted letters after their name.
fields.body:
Two barristers from the lord chancellor's former chambers have become QCs in this year's batch of 77 lawyers granted the right to put the coveted letters after their name.

James Goudie QC, joint head of 11 Kings Bench Walk, the chambers headed by Lord Irvine before he became lord chancellor, dismissed accusations of cronyism, although the appointments are made by the lord chancellor personally.

The title Queen's counsel is reserved for the top 10% of barristers and a handful of solicitors. The honour entitles the holder to charge higher fees and is a stepping-stone to the high court bench.

Mr Goudie said suggestions of cronyism were "a load of rubbish". He said the two barristers from his chambers, Tim Kerr and John Cavanagh, "got it entirely on their merits".

He said two members of the chambers had been included in the last QCs list from the former Conservative lord chancellor, Lord Mackay.

The QC selection system has been widely criticised for favouring the elite chambers from which most high court judges have sprung, and for overlooking women, ethnic minorities and solicitors. The Law Society, which represents solicitors, has pulled out of the consultation process.

There are calls for the system to be abolished, and even the Bar has hardly attempted to defend it. David Pannick QC said this week: "If the legal system were being created today, the rank of Queen's counsel would have no place."

A report from the office of fair trading last month attacked the system, concluding "it is hard to see what benefits it brings to consumers".

The report asked why the government should be involved in a system which makes it possible for the top 10% of barristers to charge enhanced fees.

Andrew Dismore, Labour MP for Hendon, who is pushing for the abolition of QCs, said: "It's a price-fixing cartel to ensure the public pays more for legal services. I hope the government will take on board the OFT's recommendations."

The new QCs earned an average of £228,836 last year without the extra letters, and the highest paid pocketed £648,000. Unsuccessful applicants averaged £183,105 .

Of the 77 successful candidates - chosen from 456 applicants - 10 are women, three are from ethnic minorities, and one is a solicitor.

fields.headline: Goon who turned buffoonery into art
fields.standfirst: Falsetto giggles and fine tenor voice made him one of the great entertainers of his generation
fields.trailText: Comedian and television presenter Sir Harry Secombe died yesterday at the age of 79.
fields.body:
Comedian and television presenter Sir Harry Secombe died yesterday at the age of 79.

The comedy genius of radio's The Goon Show and more recently the presenter of Songs of Praise and Highway, who had been battling prostate cancer since 1998, died at 3pm in a Guildford hospital with his wife, Myra, at his side.

Sir Harry's daughter, Jenny, said the family was shattered.

The Prince of Wales, one of the millions of fans who subscribed to the Goon Show brand of humour for which Sir Harry became famous, led the tributes last night, expressing great sadness at the loss of an old friend and one of Britain's comedy greats.

"I was deeply saddened to learn of the death of Sir Harry Secombe, to whom I spoke only recently in hospital. He was one of the great life-enhancers of our age and gave pleasure and constant happy laughter to so many of us throughout his life, most particularly when he was part of the never-to-be-forgotten Goon Show.

"He will be profoundly missed by all those people who appreciate wit and unmalicious humour," he said.

The chat show host Michael Parkinson, who was a close friend of Sir Harry for many years, said he was deeply saddened by the news of his death.

"He was one of my boyhood heroes. I used to see him on the theatre during his variety act and I was fortunate enough to get to know him personally later.

"Of all the people in showbusiness there are very few who escape gossip or who you do not hear something nasty about, but with Harry there was simply nothing nasty to say about him."

Tributes for the Swansea-born Sir Harry flooded in last night. Welsh radio and TV presenter and comedian Owen Money spoke of his sadness on hearing of the death. "People all over Wales will be absolutely devastated," he said.

Sir Harry, one of the founders of The Goon Show, made slapstick and buffoonery into an art form using the surreal and bizarre characters he conjured up with fellow Goons Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Michael Bentine.

The comedy show, which became one of the most revered in radio history, ran for 200 episodes from 1951 until 1960.

Whether he was Neddy Seagoon, Sir Cumference or just plain Harry Secombe, Sir Harry's falsetto giggles spilling through to an inevitable raspberry were unmistakable.

The show won a cult following with lines like "Ying tong iddle I po" becoming catch phrases in houses throughout Britain.

Spike Milligan, sole survivor of the comedy quartet, offered a succinct tribute to his colleague: "I grieve for an unbelievable friend," he said.

Sir Harry was also a singer with a classical tenor voice that sometimes moved people to tears, an actor, a writer and a tireless charity worker.

In later years he became best known for his Sunday night programme Highway, a "God-slot" show he began for Tyne-Tees television in 1983.

Throughout his career he was involved in charity work for organisations such as the Army Benevolent Fund and the Stars Organisation for Spastics, as well helping appeals for spina bifida and hydrocephalus (water on the brain).

Knighted in 1981 for his services to entertainment and charity, Sir Harry was held in great affection by his peers as well as fans, who included royalty and prime ministers such as Lord (Harold) Wilson and John Major, who said yesterday: "He was one of the loveliest of men and a comic genius who gave pleasure to millions."

Greg Dyke, director general of the BBC, also paid tribute to the star, describing him as one of the country's greatest enter tainers. "It's hard to believe that it's 50 years since the Goons were first broadcast on BBC Radio. Since then Harry Secombe has been loved as one of the greatest entertainers this country has ever known.

"The Goons transformed comedy and their humour has transcended the generations."

The veteran comic retired from showbusiness in 1999 after a career which spanned six decades.

He had suffered a run of ill health in the later years of his life, coping with diabetes and suffering from a stroke early in 1999 which affected the left side of his body and badly impaired his speech.

Knighted in 1981 for his services to entertainment and charity, Sir Harry was held in great affection by his peers as well as fans, who included royalty and prime ministers such as Lord (Harold) Wilson and John Major, who said yesterday: "He was one of the loveliest of men and a comic genius who gave pleasure to millions." Greg Dyke, director general of the BBC, also paid tribute to the star, describing him as one of the country's greatest enter tainers. "It's hard to believe that it's 50 years since the Goons were first broadcast on BBC Radio. Since then Harry Secombe has been loved as one of the greatest entertainers this country has ever known. "The Goons transformed comedy and their humour has transcended the generations." The veteran comic retired from showbusiness in 1999 after a career which spanned six decades. He had suffered a run of ill health in the later years of his life, coping with diabetes and suffering from a stroke early in 1999 which affected the left side of his body and badly impaired his speech.

fields.headline: Ofsted chief woos teachers
fields.standfirst:
New head of schools watchdog vows that future inspection regime will work with, not against, unions

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The head of the government's schools watchdog delighted teachers last night by promising a less aggressive inspection regime after the general election.
fields.body:
The head of the government's schools watchdog delighted teachers last night by promising a less aggressive inspection regime after the general election.

Mike Tomlinson, the chief inspector of schools, told the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference in Torquay that he wanted inspections to be "done with you, rather than to you". The move confirms a decisive break with the era of Chris Woodhead, who resigned as Ofsted's head in November after six years of conflict with teachers.

The pledge to delegates came as Tony Blair prepared to woo teachers with an appeal to the unions to join in a new "partnership" with the government to raise standards.

Mr Tomlinson told reporters that after the election he would unveil a new consultation paper on the future of school inspections, in advance of the next round beginning in 2003. This is likely to involve a prominent role for self-evaluation by teachers.

"I think there is a need to look again at the inspection system, not to take any of the rigour or proper challenge out of that process but to ensure that it's done with schools, not to schools," he said. The new system would involve taking more account of data collected by schools on staff performance and management.

"Inspection has to ask itself how it fits into that different environment," he said. But he added: "I don't support Ofsted pulling back entirely. There is a need for an external objective look at the performance of schools. This needs to be done by those not involved deeply in any shape or form in the running of the school."

Peter Smith, general secretary of the ATL, said: "It is extremely good news. Ofsted is going to become a resource and support to schools."

Eddie Ferguson, president of the ATL, said: "Times they are a-changing. Who would have believed 12 months ago that we would have given such a warm reception to the chief inspector of schools."

Earlier delegates had unanimously passed a resolution calling for a revamp of the inspectorate to "aid the positive development of each and every school in England".

But Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said last night: "There is scope for Ofsted to change the way it inspects schools, but for the sake of maintaining standards we need Ofsted to remain rigorous and independent."

Mr Blair will today urge delegates to join "a partnership founded on trust and honesty on both sides", as he hails teachers' "skill, dedication and sheer hard work".

"I am here because teaching is the most critical profession in Britain today," he will tell the delegates in Torquay.

"You stand for the values which bind Britain together: equal worth, community, responsibility and the right of everyone to get on and develop their talents to the full."

He will insist education remains his priority, and pledge to increase again the share of national income spent on education in the next parliament.

On Monday, the ATL, the most moderate of the main associations, voted to join three other teacher unions in pursuit of a 35-hour working week. Mr Smith, threatened "civil disobedience" in the classroom if their demands were not met.

He will present new figures showing that 10,000 more teachers have been employed since 1997, with half of them coming in the last year. Labour has boosted spending per pupil by £190 in the last year and £540 since 1997, he will claim. He is expected to pledge to speed up the rise in the number of specialist schools from 600 to 1,500 by 2006.

webTitle: Seagoon, Bloodnok, and a whole host of immortal figures of fun

fields.headline: Seagoon, Bloodnok, and a whole host of immortal figures of fun
fields.trailText: When Harry Secombe, Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Michael Bentine created the Goon Show, the BBC was baffled. Legend has it that one executive, at a meeting of programme planners, said: "Tell me about this Go On Show."
fields.body:
When Harry Secombe, Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Michael Bentine created the Goon Show, the BBC was baffled. Legend has it that one executive, at a meeting of programme planners, said: "Tell me about this Go On Show."

The Goons first emerged on May 28 1951 under the title The Crazy People. Radio listeners were confronted by surreal clowning and punning wordplay the like of which had never been heard on the air.

The show swiftly became a hit and is now seen as the father of alternative comedy - inspiring Monty Python and, more recently, the comedians Paul Merton and Harry Hill.

Fans - who besieged Broadcasting House when it was announced that the ninth series would be the last - were delighted by falsetto giggles and raspberries, while lines such as "niddle-naddle-noo" became catchphrases across Britain.

Goon characters such as Bluebottle, Major Denis Bloodnok and Sir Cumference became household names. Sir Harry played the hero/idiot of the shows, Neddy Seagoon, who was prone to signing his life away without realising the consequences.

The show's recordings were fuelled by generous helpings of brandy, and the Goons did their own warm-up act - which often involved Sir Harry whipping away Peter Sellers's braces.

With Sir Harry's death following that of Michael Bentine in 1996 and Sellers in 1980, Spike Milligan is now the only survivor of the show's original line-up.

Sir Harry said recently: "People read shades of Dylan Thomas into it but it was just us having a ball."

webTitle: Letters: How juries do their duty

fields.headline: How juries do their duty
fields.trailText: I served on a jury earlier this year, on a relatively complicated case which involved violence (Leeds footballers face assault case retrial, April 11). The judge treated us with respect and made it clear that we should disregard anything we might have heard about the case outside the court.
fields.body:
I served on a jury earlier this year, on a relatively complicated case which involved violence (Leeds footballers face assault case retrial, April 11). The judge treated us with respect and made it clear that we should disregard anything we might have heard about the case outside the court.

There was also erratic behaviour by the defendant in the court - ducking down behind the dock whenever anything unpleasant was said about him and squirming in the witness box. But there was no great difficulty: we were repeatedly reminded that we should consider the evidence and only the evidence. And the evidence against him was a tissue of lies.

So, personal feelings generated by the odd mannerisms were not relevant. And in the end, although the man did not deny committing a strangely violent act, we found him not guilty on the grounds of self-defence. He was not being charged with being a bad man, but with assault.

I think there are two problems with the Leeds case. First, the judge could have saved a lot of public money (and much wasted time) simply by making it clear to the jury that newspaper articles, however persuasive, are not evidence. If two jurymen are influenced by a newspaper article, there are 10 more to argue against it. Second, there is a danger that juries are treated as a uniform block and consequently underestimated. A jury is unlikely to be made up of 12 fools.

My experience is that we all approached the task with absolute seriousness and concentration. The atmosphere was almost that of a church, a mosque or a synagogue. Inside the court building, we were scrupulously respectful of our duty. The outside world felt far away and we were absolutely focused on a serious civic task.
Name and address supplied

 The events in Hull are a prime example of the fundamental arrogance of judges and lawyers. The assumption that jurors will, as a matter of course, even after weeks of hearing evidence and argument, necessarily be influenced by an article in a tabloid newspaper is insulting to the intelligence and integrity of ordinary men and women. Would those who so casually make that assumption admit that they might be so influenced?

It is to be hoped that the judge will be admonished for instigating a waste of public funds. After all, if the jury in the abandoned case is held to have been likely to be prejudiced, why should the same argument not apply to any subsequent jury? At the least there should be a thorough overhaul of procedure in cases where it is alleged press coverage inhibits a fair trial.
L Phillips
Drayton, Somerset
Ixionmag@btinternet.com

 Your correspondent Sam Logan (Letters, April 11) should know that erring newspaper editors haven't always got away with it lightly. In the late 50s another Mirror editor, Sylvester Bolam, went to jail because he ran a feature about vampire bats alongside a report of the on-going trial of acid-bath murderer Haigh (there were rumours that he had drunk the blood of his victims). Bolam - who once gently turned me down for a job on the Mirror - never recovered from the ordeal and died not long after his release.
Peter Hewitt
London

 How unfair can you be to a trial judge (Leader, April 10)? Once it was clear that jurors in the Leeds United trial had read the article, a strong appeal must have existed on any conviction. Why lambast a judge whose actions may have prevented an unsafe conviction and thereafter a powerful ground of appeal?
Nigel Pascoe QC
Winchester, Hants
Nigelpascoe@cs.com

fields.headline: Floral personation
fields.trailText: I have never possessed green fingers and my beautiful peace lilies are withering. Perhaps I should send them to Stormont (Looks like a bunch of lilies. But in Ulster nothing is that simple, April 11).
fields.body:
I have never possessed green fingers and my beautiful peace lilies are withering. Perhaps I should send them to Stormont (Looks like a bunch of lilies. But in Ulster nothing is that simple, April 11), where I trust they will flourish in a conducive atmosphere of reconciliation, understanding and progress.
Dr Shirley Dent
New Humanist magazine

 Didn't John Otway get it right when he sang "Beware of the flowers ('cause I'm sure they're gonna get you, yeah)"?
Alasdair Liddell
Wotton-under-Edge, Glos

 You missed a great tie-in opportunity with your reader offer for arum lilies. Why not "as used by the Northern Ireland assembly"?
Richard Towers
Lymm, Cheshire

 Indeed, "in Ulster nothing is that simple". They need to recall the assembly, as there is a clear case of personation here. The zantedeschia in your photograph is a type of arum lily, not the Easter lily, which is lilium longiflorum. The assembly should consider whether our native arum maculatum, or cuckoo-pint, would be appropriate for Stormont.
Brian Flannigan
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Have child can travel
fields.trailText: I take the points raised by Richard Colbey (Rail commuter's ticket ordeal, Jobs & Money, April 7) very seriously and an investigation is under way. We are sorry that a customer was refused a ticket for a child.
fields.body:
I take the points raised by Richard Colbey (Rail commuter's ticket ordeal, Jobs & Money, April 7) very seriously and an investigation is under way. We are sorry that a customer was refused a ticket for a child, and I confirm that it is possible for an adult to buy child-rate tickets for use by children. We will ensure that staff are reminded of this. It is proper, however, for them to verify the age of the person for whom the ticket is intended.

We try to strike a balance between fare-paying customers and those who attempt to travel free. The recent high profile "Everybody Pays the Price" week was a great success in getting across the message that we will not accept fare evasion. In just one week that campaign saw over 1,500 penalty fares issued; led to 150 people pending prosecution for fare evasion and fraud; and generated more than £250,000 in extra revenue.

Some 95% of our security and disorder problems come from ticketless travel. By clamping down on this, we not only reduce the security problem and the train delays it often causes, we also generate revenue to pay for extra security measures.

We estimate that ticket fraud costs Connex £30m a year. That money could buy 30 new train coaches or employ another 1,000 people.

It is not true that we give priority to this issue at the expense of others. We are working hard to improve in each of our five business objectives: customer satisfaction, safety, performance, employee development and profitability.

I am confident that we have made significant progress in the past few months and that our current plans will bring tangible improvements soon.
Olivier Brousse
Managing director, Connex

fields.headline: Helping politics rise like a phoenix
fields.trailText: Your feature on MPs' work rightly emphasised the importance attached by most MPs to their constituency duties (Called to Account, G2 April 10). But it's wrong to say that the link between MP and constituent would be threatened by the introduction of a more proportional voting system.
fields.body:
Your feature on MPs' work rightly emphasised the importance attached by most MPs to their constituency duties (Called to Account, G2 April 10). But it's wrong to say that the link between MP and constituent would be threatened by the introduction of a more proportional voting system. Many proportional voting systems - such as that recommended by Jenkins - retain that link.

MPs do not have a monopoly on representing our local areas. In my entry to the G2 feature I mentioned the saving of the Longbridge car plant last year. As the local MP, I think the role I played was important. But it would be crazy for me to claim I was the only one involved. Others from the area, from councillors to MEPs, were also active.

Ministers such as Stephen Byers played key roles. And nobody should underestimate the contribution of the Phoenix consortium that took over the company, of the unions, of parts of the media or of the thousands of people who organised and took part in the public campaign.

It was the combination of different people's efforts that made the difference as elsewhere. Creating a more pluralistic political culture would help recognise that. Changing the voting system would be a step along that road.
Richard Burden MP
burdenr@parliament.uk

 Our members of parliament are "a mystery to us". But can't this public ignorance be traced back to the MPs and the British system itself? Is it not incredible in the age of the internet that the basic function of MPs - to represent their constituents by voting in parliament - is almost nowhere recorded in a format which would be helpful to the public?

At fifthmoon.com we are committed to addressing the democratic deficit where constituents are unable to discover how their MP has voted on the issues which matter to them. "You and Your MP" was set up to allow members to check how all 659 MPs voted on issues of particular concern to the over-50s.

We applaud the Guardian's Ask Aristotle database and look forward to parliament trusting the people with the information they require to judge the usefulness, or otherwise, of their representatives.
Jeremy Dummett
fifthmoon.com

fields.headline: Khan do
fields.trailText: I note Vicki Wood's cynicism about Jemima Khan's visit to a refugee camp for Afghan refugees in Pakistan (Is this the new Diana? G2, April 11).
fields.body:
I note Vicki Wood's cynicism about Jemima Khan's visit to a refugee camp for Afghan refugees in Pakistan (Is this the new Diana? G2, April 11). At Unicef we welcome the support of our celebrity partners in helping to bring attention to the people in situations so frequently marginalised by the media. In an environment of rapidly dwindling foreign news outlets, we continue to struggle to communicate such devastating situations. If there is a media outlet out there that is not influenced by the power of celebrity, please step forward.
Anita Tiessen
Deputy director, Unicef UK
info@unicef.org.uk

webTitle: Leader: right result for the US

fields.headline: Right result for the US
fields.standfirst:
Future rows with China will not be as easy

Special report: China
fields.trailText: China was right to agree to release the 24 Americans whom it had detained on Hainan island since their spy plane landed there on April 1. The stand-off with the United States had gone on long enough.
fields.body:
China was right to agree to release the 24 Americans whom it had detained on Hainan island since their spy plane landed there on April 1. The stand-off with the United States had gone on long enough. China had made a powerful point, challenging America's presumption that it has a right to spy whenever and wherever it chooses around the world.

But China's self-righteousness, never wholly convincing from a nation which is no slouch on the espionage front either, was wearing very thin. Demands for an outright apology from Washington were both unreasonable and unrealistic. Yesterday's apparent resolution of the 11-day crisis was a welcome sign that someone in Beijing knows when it is time to move on.

The United States deserves its share of credit, too. In its early weeks, the Bush administration has alarmed the world. It has seemed to be donning an off-the-peg foreign policy woven by the overwrought minds of one of Washington's conservative think-tanks. To the delight of arms manufacturers around the United States, China was in the process of being recast as the enemy that America has been searching for ever since the end of the cold war.

President Bush's brusque early reaction to the Hainan incident, demanding that the Chinese return the plane and the crew immediately (something the US would never dream of doing if the boot was on the other foot) was all of a piece.

For the past week, however, a cooler approach has prevailed and seemingly without serious internal challenge. With out giving way on the apology issue, Mr Bush and his foreign policy team have opted for patience, diplomacy and the recognition that other nations see things differently.

The State Department, not the Pentagon, has set the terms of America's response. The Republican attack dogs have mostly stayed muzzled. That has produced the result that America wanted and the rest of the world needed. It may also have taught the Bush administration a practical lesson that it could not have learned in any other way.

The lesson for both Washington and Beijing is one and the same. For all its military power, the United States does not have the ability to conduct its international activities unconstrained by other nations and other considerations. When it came to the crunch over the spy plane, Washington had relatively few cards in its hand. Any threats that it made - like rearming Taiwan, or going cold on free trade with China, or even cancelling President Bush's October visit to Beijing - would have been double-edged swords, and would not have brought the US boys and girls home.

But any satisfaction which some may feel at this proof of the limits of American power needs to be set against the dangers. Chinese power is a very threatening force too, both internally and internationally. The confrontation in east Asia is not over. There are likely to be further confrontations between the US and China - above all over Taiwan - which will not and cannot be so easily resolved as the Hainan stand-off now thankfully seems to have been.

fields.bodyText: China was right to agree to release the 24 Americans whom it had detained on Hainan island since their spy plane landed there on April 1. The stand-off with the United States had gone on long enough. China had made a powerful point, challenging America's presumption that it has a right to spy whenever and wherever it chooses around the world. But China's self-righteousness, never wholly convincing from a nation which is no slouch on the espionage front either, was wearing very thin. Demands for an outright apology from Washington were both unreasonable and unrealistic. Yesterday's apparent resolution of the 11-day crisis was a welcome sign that someone in Beijing knows when it is time to move on. The United States deserves its share of credit, too. In its early weeks, the Bush administration has alarmed the world. It has seemed to be donning an off-the-peg foreign policy woven by the overwrought minds of one of Washington's conservative think-tanks. To the delight of arms manufacturers around the United States, China was in the process of being recast as the enemy that America has been searching for ever since the end of the cold war. President Bush's brusque early reaction to the Hainan incident, demanding that the Chinese return the plane and the crew immediately (something the US would never dream of doing if the boot was on the other foot) was all of a piece. For the past week, however, a cooler approach has prevailed and seemingly without serious internal challenge. With out giving way on the apology issue, Mr Bush and his foreign policy team have opted for patience, diplomacy and the recognition that other nations see things differently. The State Department, not the Pentagon, has set the terms of America's response. The Republican attack dogs have mostly stayed muzzled. That has produced the result that America wanted and the rest of the world needed. It may also have taught the Bush administration a practical lesson that it could not have learned in any other way. The lesson for both Washington and Beijing is one and the same. For all its military power, the United States does not have the ability to conduct its international activities unconstrained by other nations and other considerations. When it came to the crunch over the spy plane, Washington had relatively few cards in its hand. Any threats that it made - like rearming Taiwan, or going cold on free trade with China, or even cancelling President Bush's October visit to Beijing - would have been double-edged swords, and would not have brought the US boys and girls home. But any satisfaction which some may feel at this proof of the limits of American power needs to be set against the dangers. Chinese power is a very threatening force too, both internally and internationally. The confrontation in east Asia is not over. There are likely to be further confrontations between the US and China - above all over Taiwan - which will not and cannot be so easily resolved as the Hainan stand-off now thankfully seems to have been. fields.headline: Harry Secombe
fields.standfirst: Though he might easily have become a leading operatic tenor, he could never resist the delight of making people laugh
fields.trailText: Though he might easily have become a leading operatic tenor, he could never resist the delight of making people laugh.
fields.body:
If Spike Milligan was the most anarchic member of that cult 1950s BBC Radio show The Goons, Peter Sellers ultimately the richest and Michael Bentine the most sophisticated, Harry Secombe, who has died of prostate cancer aged 79, was the sanest and, in his own way, the most versatile.

Apart from being a member of the most wildly manic comedy team since the Crazy Gang, he was a high-powered medium tenor equally at home in opera or musical comedy and, late in life, a knight and a much-loved presenter of religious television programmes for both ITV and the BBC .

Whereas the other Goons tended to extremes of temperament and behaviour, the short and tubby Harry Secombe specialised in nothing more dangerous and subversive than endearingly gormless voices and scatological gags like blowing raspberries, at which he professed himself an expert, the only difficulty being their appropriate volume and duration during Royal Variety Performances in the presence of the Queen.

His association with Prince Charles, who was charmed by the Goons into frequent imitation, remained equable throughout his life. His marriage to a girl he met long before his fame was similarly stable. Both had had happy, loving childhoods: with that, he always claimed, you could cope with anything.

There was hard sense amidst his professional nonsense: he was one of the few performers who declined to be represented by the agent Lew Grade, figuring that Lew's cigar-waving promises of early appearances at the Palladium would be bad for his career and that a slower climb would last longer. He remained on excellent terms with Lord Lew, as with everyone else.

Harry Secombe was the third child of a none too successful commercial traveller living on a council estate near Swansea, whose hobby was drawing cartoons. Harry became a church choirboy at seven, was a cat in a Sunday school concert soon after, but blotted his copybook by reading the lesson in church in the North Country tones of the popular comic Sandy Powell. He was so shy that his mouth went dry before every performance, until he realised that if he took off his glasses he couldn't see the audience - or fear them.

Both his affinities with church and his benevolence were established early: until he went to school his best friend was a boy with a cleft palate, for whom he acted as "interpreter". Guilelessly, he left his autograph book at the Swansea Empire, only to find that the bandleader Roy Fox used a rubber stamp. Unselfishly, he played straight man to his sister Carol in a sketch called The Welsh Courtship at the Central Hall, Swansea; and when at 16 he became a junior pay clerk for a steel firm at 10 shillings (50p) a week, he obligingly took off his superiors for the benefit of his fellow juniors.

With war looming in 1939, he joined the Territorial Army and "went off to war" with a flourish, standing on the front seat of a friend's open car and imitating Hitler with a comb as the moustache. The recruiting office couldn't deal with him at once, so he went back home later that day. With the Royal Artillery in North Africa and Italy, he gravitated to concert parties and broadcast from Bali in Services Cocktail, a talent show run by Carroll Levis, who specialised in discovering unknown talent.

Still not demobbed, the young comic and singer toured US airforce bases in Italy, played the Fairy Queen in a panto and devised a comic routine in which, trying to shave, he immersed the whole area in lather - a sketch he was to use for years after the war. As a member of the Central Pool of Artists touring Italy he met another member, Spike Milligan, whose offbeat sketches were considered rather too advanced, but with whom he felt a professional affinity.

Back home in 1946, he met Myra Atherton, the woman destined to become his wife: she and their four children - Andrew, Katy, Jennifer and David - survive him. He then took his shaving routine to that unofficial academy for aspiring comics, the nude-show Windmill Theatre, and appeared increasingly on radio shows, including Welsh Rarebit, sometimes using material written by Michael Bentine.

Jimmy Grafton, who wrote scripts for the comedian Derek Roy, kept the Grafton Arms near Victoria station, which became the venue for jazz and comedy sessions involving Secombe, Milligan and Bentine. Later Sellers joined the gang for experimental shows intended for the BBC Light Programme but, as too "way out", shunted off to the more experimental and intellectual Third Programme.

The quartet met socially as well as for these sessions, in a wildly creative splurge incon ceivable with today's market-led programme planners, who would not have given the time of day to what at the start in 1949 was The Junior Crazy Gang and in 1951 became The Goons - complete with the sententious Major Bloodknock, the dithering Ned, Bluebottle, the villain ous Count Moriarty, Eccles, and other fantastical persons who were to grip Britain for decades.

Secombe, the most semi-detached member of the gang, usually joined them only for the recordings of the broadcasts, motoring down in a battered car from his singing and comedy engagements at music halls throughout the country. He and his wife usually stayed only in digs selected from the Actors' Church Union recommended list.

Secombe's film career never really took off. His Song of Norway (1970), with Edward G Robinson, fell flat. Davy (1957), for Sir Michael Balcon at the British end of MGM, was the story of a young comic given the chance of a singing career at Covent Garden but turning it down to keep his comedy team together. It caused the Daily Mirror critic Donald Zec to write: "He sings like Caruso - Sugar Ray Robinson Caruso."

It was an unjustly flip jibe: Manlio di Veroli, his early singing teacher, said that with "a little concentration" he could be the finest medium tenor not only in England, but in the world. Gigli's impresario pressed him often but unsuccessfully to appear with a symphony orchestra at the Royal Albert Hall. "Concentration" was difficult when he could make 10 times more money singing and acting in popular shows.

His Mr Bumble in the film of Lionel Bart's Oliver! (1968) was acclaimed. But it was Leslie Bricusse's Pickwick (1963) that made him. His song, If I Ruled the World, was an instant recording success, and the stage show itself had a triumph in Britain and on Broadway. In 1993, he revived it at Chichester, rejoicing that he no longer needed a bald wig: it became an annual event.

Harry Secombe appeared extensively in popular musicals, including The Four Musketeers (1967), which lost £50,000 during a 14-month run widely thought to have been sustained only by his reputation. He was especially popular in Australia, where during one tour he fell ill and was told he had only two years to live unless he stopped drinking and took his diabetes seriously. He managed to take off five of his 20 stone as well, and became president of the British Diabetic Association.

His health never prevented him from singing with several "serious" singers, including the duet from Bizet's The Pearl Fishers with Sir Geraint Evans. He also wrote two successful comic novels, Twice Brightly (1974) and Welsh Fargo (1981), as well as two volumes of autobiography and a number of fantastical stories for children.

In 1983, Bill Ward of Associated TV suggested a new "Godslot" programme with music and interviews from a different place each week. The idea was to talk to survivors of life's hardships, from concentration camp victims to cancer sufferers - anyone who had an uplifting story to tell. It proved a winning formula. The first contract was for six programmes. Highway - the first was from Durham Cathedral with Wendy Craig - ran for 10 years, covering 25,000 miles a year and attracting an audience of seven million. It became, Secombe remembered, a new way of life for him.

When it was killed - because it didn't fit the sort of people the commercials were aimed at - he did Sunday With Secombe for Scottish TV, then in the 1990s started presenting Songs of Praise for the BBC. He was undoubtedly one of the few people who could have translated an attractive twinkle into religious programming without detracting either from himself or the programme. He said in his own cod obituary: "He suffered fools gladly because he was one of them." In truth, he only played the fool, steering well clear of most of the disasters to which showbiz personalities can be prone.

Captain of the Lord's Taverners Golfing Society for over 25 years, he once introduced Mrs Margaret Thatcher, one of the first woman guests, as "the thin edge of a delectable wedge". Mrs Thatcher, apparently thinking it was a reference to her figure, huffily replied that she had never thought of herself as a wedge. It was perhaps fortunate that she had already given him his knighthood.

 Sir Harry Secombe, comic, singer and writer, born September 8 1921; died April 12 2001

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Keep off! | Desktop abuse
fields.body:
Keep off!
How can I keep other people out of my computer? The Windows password can easily be got round by hitting Esc. Are there any other ways of ensuring that only I can get in? I'm using Windows 98. Rob Walsh
robis@discemail.fsnet.co.uk

Jack Schofield replies:
The Windows log-on provides useful personalisation but, as you say, nothing in the way of security. For that, you could try a combination of a boot (start up) password and a password-protected screen saver.

To set a boot password you need to access your PC's BIOS set-up screen, possibly by pressing the Del key during the start up process. (Instruc tions are shown on screen when your PC is turned on.) The computer will not run unless the password is typed in.

However, if you forget a BIOS password, it could be difficult to regain access to your PC. Also, a BIOS password provides no protection once your PC is running. For that, you need to use a password-protected screen-saver as well.

If you just want to protect certain files or folders, there are dozens of programs that will do that: www.davecentral.com/encrypt.html lists shareware or free examples. You could look at Encrypted Magic Folders, Folder Guard, Kremlin and Ixis Software's Security Administrator www.softheap.com/secagent.html )

Desktop abuse
Just why is it "best not to save files on the desktop" (Ask Jack, March 29)? Robin Usher
robin.usher@btinternet.com.

JS: Why is it best not to keep groceries on the kitchen table? It is better to store things where they belong, rather than cluttering up your workspace with them. It is just as easy to save files in a directory called My Downloads as it is in Desktop. It is also quicker than saving them to the desktop then moving them later.

Here's how to make things magically appear on and dis appear from the Windows desktop. Open Windows Explorer and go to the C:\Windows\Desktop directory.

Try using the mouse to move one or two files into this directory, and out again.

Frustration
I have been reading the Irish Times online. The front page and leading articles download correctly, but recently, readers' letters have appeared from previous issues. Despite clearing the history file, maverick items keep coming back. Can you explain? Albert Moore
armoore@welwyn28.freeserve.co.uk

JS: When asked for a page, web browsers look to see if they already have it in their cache memory (from the French cacher, to hide). In Internet Explorer's case, this is the Temporary Internet Files folder in the Windows directory. It is cleared in IE5 by selecting Tools|Options and clicking the button, Delete Files.

If this folder is empty, you might assume fresh data would be fetched from the server. However, your ISP (internet service provider) is almost certainly caching pages as well. This saves fetching the same page repeatedly, for different users. Unfortunately not all these "proxy caches" are refreshed often enough, and some continue to ship pages long after they should have expired. In theory, the browser can check whether a page has been updated. In IE5, go to Tools|Internet Options and click the Settings button. This is where you can tell IE to check for new pages. You should also be able to force a fresh page by holding down the Control key and clicking Refresh, or by pressing Ctrl-F5. But often, this does not work either.

One trick to force the server to revisit the site you want is to add ?123 or something similar (the numbers don't matter) to the end of the address (eg www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/?123). If there is a more recent version of a page, this will usually get it.

Alternatively, try reading the page via Safeweb ( www.safeweb.com ). This is slower but normally gets the very latest content. It also means your ISP can no longer see what you are reading.

Address saver
How can I transfer my Outlook Express address book on my PC to OE on a new laptop? Amanda Parkyn
parkyn@clara.co.uk

JS: Outlook Express normally uses the Windows Address Book (Wab.exe) program. Click the Addresses icon in OE and it should appear. Select File|Export| Address Book (WAB) and save your addresses with memorable name, such as Amanda01 (the .wab will be added automatically).

Copy this file from My Documents (or wherever you saved it) to My Documents on your laptop and do the reverse. That is, open the Address Book, select File|Import| Address Book (WAB), and import the file called Amanda01.wab (which will probably be the only file visible).

You might also get away with copying your current .wab addressbook file from the desktop to the same directory on the laptop. You can find where it is stored by looking under Help|About Address Book. It will probably be in the C:\Windows\ Application Data\ Microsoft\Address Book directory.

You can also run Windows Address Book separately from OE. Go to Start|Run, type wab in the Open box, and click OK.

Crosswords
In my more youthful days with an Atari, I picked up a piece of freeware which constructed a crossword given a collection of words for insertion.Where does one find something shareware or free? Geoff Saul
geoff@gmsaul.freeserve.co.uk

JS: Try the About guide to puzzles hosted by Dave Fisher. He reviews several crossword compilers starting at http://puzzles.about. com/ games/puzzles/cs/ puzzlesoftware/ There are also useful selections at http://thinks.com/software/crosswords.htm and the Open Directory.

Quick key
I'm using IE 5.5 and I'm pretty sure that in some earlier versions you could just type something basic in the Address Bar and it would add the requisite www and com. Please help my typing fingers. Mark Paterson
m.paterson@bristol.ac.uk

JS: The trick is easily forgotten. Type in the name of the site, such as Google, then hold down the Control key while pressing Enter. Result: www.google.com

Mail delivery
In the last Start Here column, I described how to set up Outlook Express to collect email from a POP3 mailbox. However, Iain Noble points out that one leading online service, CompuServe, uses the IMAP mail protocol instead. "This has caused considerable problems for CompuServe 2000 users," writes Iain, "and has led to my writing a set of instructions." They can be found at www.forumscentral.com/email/imap.htm

webTitle: Coroner to report failings of Feltham after prison suicide

fields.headline: Coroner to report failings of Feltham after prison suicide
fields.trailText: Failures in communication and the identification of at risk prisoners at Feltham young offenders institution are to be reported to the Home Office by a coroner following an inquest into the death of a teenager at Britain's largest youth jail.
fields.body:
Failures in communication and the identification of at risk prisoners at Feltham young offenders institution are to be reported to the Home Office by a coroner following an inquest into the death of a teenager at Britain's largest youth jail.

The west London coroner, Allison Thompson, said she would be reporting her concerns about Feltham after a jury returned a verdict of suicide in the case of Kevin Henson, 17. Henson, who had suffered alcohol problems since the death of his mother, was found hanging from exposed pipes in his cell on September 6 last year. He had been refused bail on a charge of wounding the previous day.

The three day inquest at Hammersmith and Chelsea coroners court heard of a succession of failures at Feltham, which houses around 700 inmates aged between 15 and 21.

Power cables for televisions were housed in pipes that were left exposed in some cells. Henson hanged himself from one of these.

Medical records, including an assessment by a police doctor who diagnosed Henson as suffering from alcoholism and severe anxiety were not passed to reception staff at the jail. Senior staff at Feltham were unable to provide an explanation as to how that happened.

Despite being seen by three health care workers no concerns were raised about the risk of self-harm in Henson's case.

Henson's father, also named Kevin, called for an independent investigation into procedures at Feltham which was described as "rotten to the core" by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.

"Short of pulling the place down, it will be nice for an outside agency to go in. If it's left to the Home Office to investigate there will be no criticism." he said. "I've just spent three days listening to people justifying their failure to take action. The prison service ... didn't do their job."

A representative of the family said they would be taking the case to the parliamentary ombudsman, reporting a GP who saw Kevin in Feltham to the General Medical Council, and requesting a meeting with the prisons minister, Paul Boateng.

Deborah Coles of the campaign group Inquest accused the prison service of attempting to restrict the remit of the inquiry in order to stifle criticism of staff.

"This inquest has painted a disturbing picture of the complete failures in the screening and identification of at risk prisoners," she said.

Martin Narey, director of the prison service, said in a statement: "Kevin Henson's death was a tragic waste of young life which has affected many people who knew Kevin, including the staff at Feltham. On behalf of the prison service and the staff at Feltham I can only reiterate our heart felt regrets and condolences."

Mr Narey pointed out that £8m would be invested this year to drive down prison suicides and that the numbers of suicides fell last year for the first time in five years.

Nick Pascoe, the governor of Feltham, said the remaining exposed pipes in cells would be boxed in by the end of next week.

Kevin Henson was deeply traumatised following the death of his mother of cancer on his 14th birthday in August 1997. He turned to alcohol and within 18 months was an alcoholic.

In 1998 his father, struggling to cope, turned to social services for help and Kevin moved to a foster home in Milton Keynes. He was settled for a while but after 14 months he was moved to a home in Luton after an argument with another teenager.

After breaking hostel rules in Luton he moved back to his father's house in Uxbridge, Middlesex, where his behaviour deteriorated.

In November 1999 he was arrested for a street robbery and being drunk and disorderly, and on August 15 2000 he was made the subject of a probation order. A GP diagnosed him as alcoholic.

Less than two weeks later on the bank holiday weekend Kevin got drunk and got into a fight during which he slashed another teenager across the face. He was arrested, charged with wounding with intent and held at Uxbridge police station.

A doctor at the station examined him and noted, "asthmatic, anxiety plus, alcohol plus plus". This record was not passed to medical staff at Feltham.

On September 5 Henson was refused bail and warned he could face two years in jail. He cried on hearing he would be returning to Feltham and told his father he was worried he would not be able to visit his mother's grave on her birthday the following month. Later that night he tore a strip off a bed sheet, tied it to the exposed pipe, and hanged himself. In a letter to his father he said: "I've been thinking about doing this since mum died. I just want to be with mum."

fields.headline: Gulf veterans more likely to report illness, but death rates no higher
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Gulf war veterans are twice as likely as other servicemen and women to report ill health, a government funded study reveals today.
fields.body:
Gulf war veterans are twice as likely as other servicemen and women to report ill health, a government funded study reveals today.

The results of research, seven years after the 1991 conflict, suggest veterans are far more likely to complain of symptoms suggestive of nerve damage or widespread pain. But every one of 95 symptoms covered by questionnaires, from tiredness to convulsions, was more frequently mentioned by those who had served in the Gulf.

The researchers from Manchester University said more investigation was needed into whether vaccinations or pesticides played a part.

But they also concluded that death rates among veterans are no different than other service personnel, and the Ministry of Defence last night insisted: "There is no evidence of a Gulf war syndrome".

It said the latest work reinforced other findings that although the veterans reported more illness, "the overall severity of the symptoms is not high".

Lewis Moonie, a junior defence minister, welcomed the findings and said further research was already under way. "We are determined to continue to address the concerns of Gulf veterans."

The Manchester study, reported in the medical journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine, compared the responses of more than 8,000 UK veterans to those of around 4,000 servicemen and women who had not served in the war.

Detailed comparison of exposure to possible risk among the personnel also indicated that severity of symptoms was linked to numbers of inoculations and time spent handling pesticides.

The research team concluded: "There is clear evidence ... that among those who went to the Gulf there are substantial subgroups who feel unwell. Such ill health has been reported after previous conflicts and it may be that this reflects changes in perception resulting from the disruptions of war rather than specific chemical, physical, infective, or psychological exposures."

Khalida Ismail, of the department of psychological medicine at Guy's, King's and St Thomas's school of medicine, London, said in an editorial accompanying the research reports: "Health problems should be anticipated after future conflicts. Research into ill health in Gulf veterans was delayed, which may have fuelled various conspiracy theories."

Sean Rusling, chairman of the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association, said the research pointed more definitively to vaccines and organophosphate pesticides as possible causes than previous studies.

He added: "We brought these to the attention of the ministry and the Commons defence committee in the early days."

But he disputed the suggestion that Gulf veterans were no more likely to die as a result of their service. The study was conducted three years ago, and only last month the Royal British Legion had put the death toll of Gulf veterans at 527.

webTitle: Comment: the McVeigh execution media circus

fields.headline: The star execution
fields.standfirst:
The intense focus on the impending execution of Timothy McVeigh brings into relief once again the emotive issue of capital punishment, says Mark Tran

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The intense focus on the impending execution of Timothy McVeigh brings into relief once again the emotive issue of capital punishment, says Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Executions are routine in the US, but interest abounds in the one about to take place on May 16, when Timothy McVeigh goes down. McVeigh is no mere footsoldier on death row, but the man convicted of the worst act of terror on American soil, when his homemade fertiliser bomb killed 168 people, including 19 children, in 1995.

Reporters from all over the world will be covering his death, although only 10 of the 1,400 will actually see the execution at Terre Haute prison in Indiana. Fascinating details of the arrangements have emerged courtesy of the Washington Post.

For the reporters willing to fork out $1,146.50, there will be "chilled bottled water", "a padded chair", writing tables festooned with freshly laundered "table skirts", phones and transport by golf carts. Otherwise they presumably have to bring their own sandwiches.

Easy as it is to mock the media circus aspects of America's first federal execution since 1963 - state executions being fairly regular - the event will once again bring into sharp focus debate on the death penalty. Some relatives of McVeigh's victims have requested a closed-circuit TV feed of the execution to Oklahoma City so all of the victims' relatives can watch him die.

As the US justice department ponders the request, a Florida company, Entertainment Network, has sued for the right to put a webcam inside the death chamber so it can broadcast the event to its subscription only sites.

Entertainment Network is following a well-worn path. Throughout history, executions have served as a form of family entertainment. In America, people turned up with picnic baskets for black lynchings.

Even if Entertainment Network does win its case, there will be little to see as every effort has been made to make the ordeal as bland as possible. In fact it will be guaranteed to be anticlimactic - there will be no B-movie scenes of people dragged to the electric chair.

America has gone to inordinate lengths to make executions "humane", a fact that sank home when I visited the death chamber in the Angola prison, Mississippi. A strenuous attempt is made to distance the executioner from the person to be executed. It is all done sneakily, guiltily, as if the authorities are doing something shameful so everything must be done to avoid being tainted by a dirty process.

On the day of what he describes as his "state-assisted suicide", McVeigh will be injected with sodium pentothal to make him unconscious. Then come the other chemicals that will kill him. Despite the effort to "automate" the process as much as possible, somebody has to insert the intravenous line and start the whole thing.

More than 700 people have been executed in the US since it brought back the death penalty in 1977 amid widespread international criticism. Amnesty International points out that among those put to death were those who committed their crimes when they were still children, the mentally impaired, those denied adequate legal representation, foreign nationals denied their consular rights, and defendants whose guilt was still in doubt. And race continues to play a role in who gets a death sentence: in over 80% of the 700 cases, the crimes involved white victims.

Amnesty argues that the US has diverted millions of dollars away from more constructive efforts to fight crime and that there is no evidence that the death penalty has prevented a single felony. It can be argued that the relatives of the victims deserve retribution, but most people who have worked with death row prisoners and relatives of victims put the lie to this.

Sister Helen Prejean, a prison minister who inspired the film Dead Man Walking, once said of an execution: "[the relatives] could have watched his death I think a thousand times but that vacuum and the loss that they have sustained could never be filled by the death of another person."

fields.headline: Davis delight for ten-man Fulham
fields.trailText:
Ten-man Fulham grabbed the points courtesy of a Sean Davis injury-time winner in what was an impressive dress-rehearsal for top-flight competition for both teams
Second Division

Millwall 1 - 0 Port Vale
fields.body:
The Fulham armoury was already substantial. Add to it a slice of luck and a passion fuelled by an intense sense of indignation here last night, and Premiership teams can justifiably start looking nervously over their shoulders at the club so close to joining them.

After Sean Davis stole a winner in injury-time for a team reduced to 10 men for more than half the game, Fulham will be back in the top flight for the first time in 33 years even before their next game, at Huddersfield on Saturday, should Bolton lose at home to Birmingham tomorrow. Favourable results elsewhere could also see Fulham clinch the title this weekend.

It will be deserved. For, as their midfield pivot Lee Clark emphasised, there has been more to Fulham's season than pretty patterns.

"We have shown the side of out character that many people think we didn't have. They asked whether we had the heart to go to places and get results on the muddy pitches of winter.

"It's fair to say we showed Blackburn a bit more respect than they showed us. We won when we were down to 10 men against the best side in the league," he said with more than a hint of irony, referring to comments this week from Graeme Souness, implying that his Blackburn side carried that mantle.

Souness's response after defeat in this summit meeting was indignant: "We have been punched on the nose in the cruellest possible way," he said. "Only the most extremely biased observer could say that Fulham deserved all the points."

Blackburn have closed the quality gap with Fulham over the latter stages of the season and comfortably dominated the early exchanges.

Matt Jansen, a striker who will grace the Premiership should Blackburn clinch the second automatic promotion place, struck after only six minutes. Keith Gillespie's floated free-kick found the striker unmarked at the back post and a headed goal was a formality.

For all their possession, though, Blackburn failed to press home the advantage and, after the dismissal of Rufus Brevett shortly before half- time for retaliating against a Garry Flitcroft challenge, it was clear the home side would no longer be afforded the luxury of exploiting Fulham's tendency to spread the play. Blackburn also needed to guard against the sucker punch, but it arrived sooner than expected, in first-half injury-time.

When Brad Friedel attempted to catch Steve Finnan's cross, he found the back of his own defender Henning Berg in his way. The ball slipped from the goalkeeper's grasp and Louis Saha was on hand to stroke home.

Now Fulham defended in numbers. Blackburn constantly pressed and Jansen and Flitcroft should both have scored. The threat of a Fulham counter-attack remained though, and in the dying seconds it materialised.

Clark's initial shot rebounded off the heels of a retreating Berg and looped into the path of Sean Davis, who ignored suggestions of an offside position to devour the chance.

fields.headline: Guardiola reunion on Robson's mind
fields.trailText: Bobby Robson is hoping to entice the unsettled Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola to Tyneside
fields.body:
Bobby Robson is hoping to entice the Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola to Tyneside after the Spanish international midfielder yesterday said that he would leave the Catalan club when his contract expires in the summer.

Guardiola, who was a ball-boy at Barcelona before joining them at the age of 13 from the nearby Gimnastic Manresa club, played under Robson during his spell as coach at the Nou Camp in the late 1990s. In his 17 years as a Barcelona player Guardiola won the European Cup, the European Cup-Winners' Cup, two European Super Cups and six league titles as well as 43 caps.

"On June 30 I will leave the club to play abroad," said the 30-year-old, who has not been offered a new contract by Barcelona. "It's not an easy decision but after weighing things up I think it's for the best. I met with club president Joan Gaspart last night to inform him of my decision.

"I came to Barcelona without five pesetas and I leave a family man. I had to think of two things: to continue here or to experience new societies, cultures, team-mates, rivals and putting everything into perspective I realised I want to experience new things.

"I don't know where I'll end up as I haven't listened to any offers. I'll be looking at England, France, Germany and Italy. I want to leave to teach all I have learned here, but I'd like to play in another big club and continue to win titles."

Robson, who has sold almost £22m of talent since the end of last season, expects to meet his chairman Freddie Shepherd later this week to discuss what funds will be available to rebuild in the close season, is convinced he can lure Guardiola to the north-east.

"There isn't anybody that we would be afraid to go and buy," he said. "If we could afford Guardiola's wages, I know he would be prepared to come to Newcastle."

Meanwhile, Sunderland's manager Peter Reid is closing in on QPR's Peter Crouch as the replacement for Niall Quinn after sending his coach Adrian Heath and scout Tony Book to watch the 6ft 6in striker at Crewe on Tuesday.

QPR are desperate to keep the former England youth international but are in financial crisis and would be unable to resist a £3m offer for the 20-year-old player at the end of the season.
