fields.headline: City tumble towards trap door
fields.standfirst: Rampant Arsenal hand out a football lesson to Joe Royle's men
fields.trailText: Freddie Ljungberg got a brace to help Arsenal heap humiliation on City and leave Joe Royle's men teetering on the brink of relegation.
fields.body:
Manchester City's increasingly forlorn survival bid took another hammer blow last night as an under-strength Arsenal plundered Moss Side, filled their boots and left the home side defiantly singing the blues.

A quartet of breathtaking first-half goals had City on their knees, but this might have been an Oceania World Cup mismatch such was the visitors' superiority. Teetering precariously on the brink, Joe Royle's side face the nightmare prospect of being relegated on Saturday week at Old Trafford - the day their bitter rivals could claim the title.

"We're not giving up but they were awesome and too bloody good for us," Royle conceded. "They gave us a spanking. On that form they could win the Champions League. They were on a different planet to us."

Amid the carnage, the home support stood by their favourites until the end. "Even if that was gallows humour it was terrific," added Royle. "I've never heard anything like that before."

The visit of Arsenal was hardly the best opportunity to blood a new goalkeeper, yet Nicky Weaver's recent howlers paved the way for Carlo Nash, the former catwalk model who arrived at Maine Road via Clitheroe, Crystal Palace and Stockport, tomake his Premiership bow. The unhappy Weaver was demoted despite his manager insisting that he would go on to play for England. Poor Nash didn't know what had hit him.

"He had no chance with any of the goals," Royle added. "They were all through him, over him and round him. It was a harsh lesson for us all."

It took only eight minutes for Arsenal to find cruise-control. Ashley Cole, trotting unchallenged down the left, crossed for Sylvain Wiltord on the edge of the six-yard box. The Frenchman miscontrolled the pass but the ball obligingly ran for Freddie Ljungberg, charging unmarked into the area, to tap home.

City had barely recovered when Ray Parlour skipped down the right and centred for Wiltord. This time the striker's touch was true as he spun, bamboozling his marker Richard Dunne, and fired low across Nash and inside the far post. The new goalkeeper, understandingly shell-shocked, had yet to touch the ball other than to pick it twice out of the back of the net.

What there was of the home defence - cluttered and utterly panic-stricken as it was - duly yielded a third after 16 minutes. Kanu, spinning beyond Jeff Whitley with the ball glued to his instep, split the gaping rearguard with a sumptuous flick. Ljungberg sprinted into the space and lifted his shot over the on-rushing Nash.

"We knew that their confidence was not at its highest and we were very mobile, passing the ball well," said the visiting manager Arsène Wenger. "I suppose we were lucky to score two quick goals. That was maybe too much for them. But they never gave up; the crowd stuck behind them and were magnificent."

Their fight-back - gung-ho and toothless - was limited to bustling forays with little shape and less style. All the while Arsenal were show- boating. Their defence soaked up the sporadic long balls that did not catch Paulo Wanchope off-side while their midfield, oozing class, serenely caressed balls into the acres of vacant space.

Nine minutes before the interval Wiltord back-heeled through a static back line, Cole ran into the space and, having drawn Nash, squared for Kanu. The Nigerian might have slotted home with his first touch; instead he had time to turn, cushion the ball and shoot past Steve Howey on the goalline.

Only with the visitors content - "It's difficult to keep going when you are 4-0 up at half-time," said Wenger - did Mark Kennedy find fleeting joy down the left, although his crosses were magnetically drawn to Arsenal heads.

Yet the chasm between the two sides was only ever one clever pass away from gaping wider. The substitute Thierry Henry missed an open goal and Kanu, spreading mayhem whenever in possession, saw his low shot deflected past a post, but by then the philosophical home fans had taken to clapping his every move.
